[Page 219]

This part of my conclusion has to be taken on trust. It rests upon natural philosophy which explains that nothing can return to its natural condition after it has suffered a complete, total deprivation \[of life\]. Therefore, if such a thing happens it is a miracle and comes from God alone. The evil spirit cannot inform that body, because he himself is a perfect, complete substance, and putting together another substance as a part \[of something else\] is incompatible with his \[capabilities\]. I prove that an evil spirit cannot reintroduce to the body a soul which has been separated from it so that \[the body\] can inform the soul, because there is only one natural way of joining a soul and a body, and that is by begetting and creating the body and pouring a soul into it. In the case we are discussing, however, the body is not begotten and therefore in this case the natural way of joining \[soul and body\] does not exist; and the supernatural way of the kind which takes place in a resurrection belongs to God alone. If God were to give His permission, an evil spirit could force a damned soul to enter a body in order to give it movement and let people see it performing some actions, because he himself can enter it and could, by means of torture, compel an unwilling soul to do this.

Magicians, too, with the help of evil spirits of a higher rank, (because of their mutual pact), can compel evil spirits of lower rank to enter a corpse, wear it, move it, and do everything else for the time being which make it seem to be alive. Cornelius Agrippa did this in Leuven. He used to have an inquisitive member of his household and on one occasion, when Agrippa went on a journey and left the keys of his library with his wife, (whom he later divorced), with the instruction that she was not to let anyone enter it, this ill-considered young man kept badgering the poor woman in and out of season until he succeeded in getting from her the means of entering \[the library\]. He went in, came across a small book of invocations, and read it.

Well now, lo and behold he was disturbed by a knocking at the door! He continued reading. Someone knocked again. The young man, who was inexperienced in these things, did not answer at all and an evil spirit came in. \'Why have you summoned me?\' it asked. \'What are your instructions?\' Fear stopped the young man from speaking. The evil spirit blocked his throat, and thus the wretched \[youth\] paid the price of his wicked curiosity. Meanwhile the arch-magician returned to the house and saw evil spirits jumping about all over it. He made use of his customary magic, and they answered his summons and told him what had happened. He ordered them to enter the corpse of a murderer and go for a walk every so often in the market-place, (where the rest of his students were accustomed to meet quite frequently), and leave the corpse there. The body walked there three or four times and then fell down as the \[spirit\] which was directing it left it. For a long time, people believed the corpse fell down because \[the man\] had died all of a sudden, but the signs of suffocation started to give rise to suspicion, and later on time revealed everything and Agrippa fled to Lotharingia and began to spew out the heresies had had been concealing.

Book 2, Question 29, Section 2

We are presented with many stories about those resuscitated by the power of Aesculapius-Tyndareus Glaucus, Admetus, and so forth-not only by pagan poets, but also by weightier writers. Plato tells a story about Er, Pliny about Gabienus and others, Apuleius about Zaclas the Egyptian, Philostratus (Book 4) about those resuscitated by Apollonius \[of Tyana\], Clemens and Hegesippus about those resuscitated by Simon Magus, and Prochorus, in his apocryphal \[Acts of John\] about others \[resuscitated\] by the magician Numadius. There is an extraordinary story in Plutarch who tells us that Enarchus was left for dead by his doctors and was seen not long afterwards to come back to life. He said he really had risen again from the dead and that the evil spirits which had taken him away from life had been severely reprimanded by their prince because they had carried him off instead of Nicandas, a tanner, who had been seized by fever the same day and hour while lying in bed and had died of his illness.

[Page 220]

Not content with this, in order to prove he had come back from the dead, he predicted to Plutarch, who was not well at the time, that he would soon be fully recovered-and that is how things turned out. Ranulf \[Higden\], the author of Polychronicon, tells us that one night Earl Richard went into a church all by himself to offer a prayer, and there found a bier on which a corpse had been laid out. \'All of a sudden, while the Earl was praying, the dead man jumped off the bier with a loud cry and came towards the Earl with his arms outstretched, as though to knock him down in his embrace. The Earl made the sign of the cross on his own forehead and somewhat forcefully adjured \[the dead man\] to go away. This he did not do, so \[the Earl\] drew his sword and cut him down, and thereafter gave instructions that watch was to be kept over corpses throughout the whole region\'.

More extraordinary than either of these \[stories\] is one told by \[Robert\] Gaguin in his description of Muscovy, and I shall now add it \[to my account\]. \'Certain people living in Lucomorye, a province of Russia\', he writes, \'die every year on 27th November, as swallows and frogs are in the habit of doing, before the cold of winter sets in. Then, when spring returns, on 24th April, they come back to life again\'. He adds, \'When these people sense that death is near, they put goods they want to sell in certain places and their neighbours, the Grustintzi and Serponovtzi, take them away, leaving behind in the same spot payment of equivalent value. When the people of Lucomorye come back to life, they take this payment if they think it fair. If they do not, they ask for their goods back. It is said that this is why quarrels and wars very frequently arise between them\'. Sigismund \[von Herberstein\] tells the same story, but \[Cesare\] Baronio thinks it is a fairytale, (see his book on Muscovy, folio 86).

Consequently, I must briefly reply to all these and similar examples by saying that evil spirits usually \[create\] many illusions in connection with this kind of \[phenomenon\]. Sometimes \[a spirit\] steals the bodies of the dead and substitutes others made from air which move as though they belonged to living people. We know from Livy that \[a spirit\] removed Romulus\'s body this way, and we know \[about\] Cleomedes\'s \[body\], and that of Alcmene which \[spirits\] fashioned and gave to Rhadamanthus as his wife. We also know from Plutarch and Herodotus about Aristeas of Proconnesus, and from Antoninus Liberalis about the virgins Aspalis and Cresylla. Likewise, \[a spirit\] substituted other people for Glaucus, Tyndareus, Er, and others, or her himself secretly entered their skins.

Sometimes, in order to make things which are actually corpses come to life, he secretly goes into them and, like a sailor making a ship move, he makes them move and forces them to act as though they were alive and imitate the gestures \[of living people\]. Now, because people raise objections, at this point I must refer you to what was done by Simon Magus, to what happened in the case of Earl Richard, and to what happened in the case of Er of Pamphylia or Armenia, (unless that instance was actually made up by Plato in order to frighten people away from wrong-doing by making them afraid of the underworld, which is what \[pseudo-\]Justin Martyr thought in his Exhortation).

There are also the cases of Gabinius, Polycritus, and Publius whose heads predicted the future, and the example from Apuleius about Socrates whose head was cut off by a female inn-keeper who was also an aged sorceress \[veratrix\]. Having cut it off, she joined it to the body again by sticking a sponge \[under the cut\]; but next day, when the unfortunate man, contrary to her instruction, drank from a river, the sponge fell out and he lost his head because it really had been cut off and its restoration was counterfeit, \[Metamorphoses 1.16-18\]. Relevant here is the story I told about Agrippa\'s boarder, three others which \[Nicolas\] Rémy tells in Book 2, chapter 1 of The Worship of Evil Spirits, and one told by Philostratus in Heroic Deeds dialogue 1. \[18\] about Phrygian shepherds.

content:

When their cattle were being killed by murrain, they gathered at the tomb of Ajax, son of Telamon, in Sigeum, and heaped various curses on the dead man. One \[shepherd\], more forward than the rest, began to recite verses from Homer in which Ajax is described as running away-\'Aïas δ\' oùxéti µíuvev\' \[Ajax stayed no longer, Iliad 14.727\]-and a voice burst fiercely from the tomb, \"AMou \"piliov\' \[But I did stay\], and the shepherds, thoroughly frightened, took to their heels. The origin of the voice, you see, was an evil spirit. Finally, also relevant here is the story about a German youth which I shall tell in the next question, which would be remarkable but for the fact that he pretended to be killed, even though he had not been killed, but had simply fainted away and then thought he was decapitated. Everyone else thought the same, since their eyes had been blinded, but his head had not been cut off, nor had it been restored. It was all a conjuring-trick.

At this point, let me add one example of a fictitious resurrection. Antiquity had produced no story more convincing or more wonderful than this one. It took place in Dalheim in Lotharingia in 1581, and involved Petronius, a herdsman, and Abrahel, a succuba. In his summary of Book 2, that remarkable man, Nicolas Rémy, had shown most picturesquely and in very elegant verse, how Abrahel seduced Petronius into criminal embraces, then into the murder of his own small son, and finally, because of his grief and despair and a false resurrection of his child, into idolatry: and how the evil spirit presented him with a likeness of the living \[child\] for a whole year and then abandoned it as a corpse. I shall transcribe this with greater pleasure than equanimity because, as the result of the insupportably bad practice of its recent printer, the verses in \[Rémy\'s\] Worship of Evil Spirits have been removed and the work published in mutilated form. \[Thus\] they will be preserved unharmed, and in consequence will be read in more places.

\'There is a country in the middle of the bounds of an enormous kingdom Between the winding streams of the sandy Moselle And the straight courses of the Saar with its undisturbed river-bank. There is a village here called Delheim-not a well-known nameAnd while a herdsman was grazing his flock in a distant valley there And pondering the various cares which were rolling around in his heart, Perhaps sick of the unfairness attendant on his straitened circumstances, Or contemplating, with a degree of passion, revenge and anger Because of a loss he had suffered, or high words exchanged in a quarrel, A succuba presented herself quite unexpectedly.

She was most seductive. Her face had a maidenly expression, her gestures were charming, Her head was decked with false sapphires, And \[her hair\] was twisted into glistening curls on each side \[of her face\]. She comforted the unhappy man and gave him hope of becoming master of his situation, And promised him the wealth which the needy have so often prayed for in vain, Or which the long-eared king \[Midas\] was willing to demand of Iacchus \[Dionysus\] As long as he did not object to what he was saying. Just as when a fire which is quickened by a pair of bellows Licks the iron while the puffing renders \[the metal\] ductile, So that the hard \[substance\] is persuaded to be compliant And is prepared \[to receive\] all its instructions, And does not disregard the arts of persuasion: \[The herdsman\] is happy to submit to \[the succuba\'s\] alluring command, And on both sides trust is strengthened by a \[mutual\] pact. He made his way into her dreadful embraces. Their unequal love was cemented by senseless coition. Irreparable, freedom Died at once amid those unspeakable passions. And, just as the parts of a body wounded by the dangerous bite of snakes Spread the consequent poison throughout the whole body, So that health itself cannot provide what health requires, Even if it spreads itself as far as it can, So Abrahel took over her lover entirely.

And broke him by filthiness-this very wicked woman had designated it thus so that she could bend the vanquished man to any of her stipulations, and he could have absolutely no will \[of his own\] to say yes or no. Straight away and without hesitation she demanded an initial recompense for her violated virtue. \'Play your part\', she said, \'so that your love May be the equal of mine\'. There could be no greater proof of this Than if he conquered Nature and carried out a crime Any by this fresh deed subordinated a father\'s love to his passion. Therefore, since it was already late, he drove his whole flock Into the sheep-folds and finally settled himself in his little house.

First, so that his dear son would put his weak arms round his neck To support himself \[to receive his father\'s\] kisses, he drew out of his bagWhich his son was keen to search, although he had often found it empty When \[his father\] came back from the countryside-an apple and held it out to him. \[The boy\] had scarcely taken his first bite, grinding his teeth because he did not like the sour taste, Than he turned pale and sucked it hesitatingly with the tips of his lips, And lay stretched out on the ground which fell away behind him. If \[his father\] could look at this with equanimity While carrying out his orders with this pledge, It would be strong evidence that his was still cleaving to his new love.

Such an unspeakable crime horrified him to begin with And Nature and passion fought each other in a battle whose outcome was uncertain. But he who introduced a powerful enemy into an empty citadel Hesitated in vain to carry out his instructions, because if he did nothing in response to her first command when she entreated him seductively, The insolent woman immediately passed to violent anger And her will, ever present, was like statute law to him. Now the evening which was obliged to be privy to so great a crime Had brought back to the threshold of his cottage the father entangled in these dreadful things. When his son met him and spontaneously greeted him with a big hug as usual, He groaned, and shifted from foot to foot, and stammered. Yet this did not stop him at all from \[fulfilling\] his wicked promises.

The cruel man Dared to continue to reach for the deadly gifts of murder. Let his son be the victim of an abominable love! His father did not shrink from slaughtering him with his own hand. Straight away Nature, which had allowed herself to be concealed And had withdrawn because of his feigned excuses, came out more ardently and rose up powerfully with grief; And while \[this grief\] fed on the feeble advantages \[he had wanted to gain\] And his ill-considered weeping, the woman stood nearby to give him her advice. The moment he killed \[the boy\], she consoled him And, at the same time, promised to restore \[the boy\] to life and make him live again, If \[the father\] would willingly worship her and, as a suppliant, beg this of her; And he, who had \[morally\] bankrupted himself earlier, Readily agreed to this turn of events, for which he would pay an extremely heavy rate of interest.

And while the fickle man wanted to appease, in any way he could, The gods of his household whom he had dishonoured by the foul murder of his son, He disgraced them even more and polluted them more repulsively Because first of all he threw himself on his knees before the evil spirit And worshipped it forthwith as a divinity. Then he promised the boy to her as payment, If only, with her help, his last-born child could feed himself upon life-giving air once more, \[Begging her\] just as when winds join battle and cast themselves An angry sea, and a sailor trembles in every limb quite uncertain of his life, and is lavish in his pleas to all the gods, And tires them out with his prayers.

The corpse lay on its back on the mound where it had been thrown When life had finally fled and abandoned it, And its mother, very late in the day, began to make haste to bury it. But look! \[The child\'s\] body seemed to stir itself between her hands as she touched him And gradually once again to overcome \[death\] with \[living\] heat. The kind of light those who are half-alive, half-dead show in their downcast eyes, Or which, with difficulty, releases those who have been plunged deep in sleepThese signs of health restored, beyond what people hope, Seize them and give them joy, and with as much eagerness as they can The vigorously warm the powerless limbs And recall now the arms, now the legs, to their living functions.

The boy rose to his feet straight away, then Took a step, can called to his parents in the voice they knew well; Only he was different in appearance from \[the boy\] he had once been, Because he had a face \[rendered\] ugly because the skin was drawn tight over it, And because a gloomy stupidity was in possession of his receding eyes. A foreign life, therefore, quickened the senses which had been deserted And in this apparition restored the breath which had once been there, (As Virbius once obtained the light \[of life\] which had been cut off from him). But the mind was not the same, and the breath Which used to warm his life did not now exercise that same office. An evil spirit provided the mechanism to drive the sluggish bulk, Give it the appearance of life, and imitate the actions of \[human\] behaviour, Breathing \[into it the actions\] which Nature used to carry out for herself. At length, the moment a year had run its whole course And completed its circuit of the dense globe, \[The evil spirit\] abandoned its stopping-place and left the dwelling empty.

It betrayed its flight by a sulphurous smell and a noisy din, And pushed itself out, bursting forth into stinking gusts of air. Then the corpse fell down, thrust away by this second death. There followed a foetid stench and \[the body became\] very heavy. A kind of numbness \[caused by\] unhindered emotion covered the motionless \[child\] Completely with earth, and cut off the widespread strength of the stench So that it could not gain entrance to human nostrils. \[The body\] was carried away from the house by a hook firmly attached to it, And the dishonoured remains were laid under a clean sod cut from the earth, While the father, who had been mad enough to shame Nature this way With his disgraceful act, shuddered at what he had done\'.

Finally, (1) \[The evil spirit\] fashions dead people who are not actually dead, and for this purpose makes use of the not infrequent convenience of natural illnesses known as ¿φóvous \[undead\], as in the case of the apoplectic, the planet struck, or the thunder-struck. These people\'s brain is very badly impaired at the point where all the nerves begin, and this damages feeling and movement in every part of the body; and so, because feeling and movement are impaired this way, \[the people\] fall down and lie as though they were dead.

\(2\) If their xapâ \[brains\] are attacked in the case of the head\'s being beaten, as it were, by a debilitating fever, the humours injure the brain in such a way that the consequence is a stupor and immobility of the whole body; and when deep sleep accompanies this, the human lies with closed eyes, looking like a dead person, sometimes for a very long time, as though he \[actually\] were dead.

\(3\) In the case of those who are afflicted by \[swooning\], that is, a syncope or collapse of the soul, this illness sometimes adds to \[the symptoms\] I have mentioned a disturbance of the artery and a lack of pulse. This affliction makes the human being very much like someone who really is dead and lasts until the excess and attack of cold humours is dissipated. According to \[Paolo\] Giovio, John Duns Scotus suffered from this kind of illness and was buried alive as though he were dead. I should think the Euarchus mentioned by Plutarch was suffering from an illness of this sort, and that the prediction which came from human foresight and medical judgement could not have had any importance.

[Page 224]

\(4\) In the case of women who are putting up with suffocation of the matrix and suffering from jaundice, sometimes what they are suffering makes them lie as if they were dead. Such, we understand from Philostratus, and Eusebius\'s book against Hierocles, was the girl \[resurrected\] by Apollonius \[of Tyana\], and such, too, the girl \[resurrected\] by Heraclides \[of Pontus\]. In the case of Aviola and Tubero, the power of the fires broke up the cold humours of the syncope.

With regard to the inhabitants of Lucomorye, I should perhaps be correct in replying that the author himself tells it simply as a story he has heard from other people, and therefore keeps repeating the phrase \'it is said\'. But if the story he tells is true, it should be put down to conjuring-tricks by evil spirits. \[Such tricks\] are very common in that part of the world, as lycanthropy among the Nervi makes clear, and meanwhile one must presume that the inhabitants have been numbed by sleep after the usual manner of dormice and bears.

From those deceptions by an evil spirit has arisen a ridiculous conviction held by witches \[strigum\]. They believe that sometimes the oxen or rams they have killed, boiled or roasted, and then eaten are instantly brought back to life later on by an evil spirit, and it is not difficult to account for the various ways in which an evil spirit is able to do this.

\(1\) He can do it by binding up the eyes of onlookers and then, of course, sending \[pictures\] into the organ by means of a humour or some other way in which they can be imprinted, or by agitating the \[physical\] spirits in the imagination and bringing them in this state to the common sense and the organs of the external senses to which images and semblances which have been impressed on them by agitation \[of the physical spirits\] and by the object of the senseimpression normally descend. These semblances are usually retained there, but the very process of recognition often influences them in such a way that the external sense thinks it has been equally affected as though it really were being changed by the external object. It is the kind of thing which usually happens to a sleeper in his dreams, but the Devil can also make it happen to people while they are awake, because physical organs obey non-physical substances as far as local motion is concerned. (This is his method according to St Thomas \[Aquinas\]. Read his Evil, question 16, article 11).

\(2\) He can do this by substituting one thing for another, because what prevents an evil spirit from removing the dead ox, along with its skin and bones, and putting in its place a live OX which looks like the dead one, and doing this so quickly that the speed of the exchange escapes the notice of the bystanders? In the meantime, while he is taking away the corpse and replacing it with another ox, by inserting a cloud or \[performing\] some other conjuring-trick he can make sure the bystanders do not see that the place is empty and the OX has been taken away.

\(3\) Several witches \[nonnulli striges as \[Bartolommeo\] Spina says, confess that he can bring it about that when the king or queen of the journey or meeting⁵⁵² takes a stick and strikes the hide in which the bones have been collected and put in a pile. Then some evil spirit immediately gets underneath the skin, joins things together and assembles them, fits them into the shape of an ox, makes the large bulk stand upright, and then takes control of it so that it looks as though the original OX has been resuscitated.

\(4\) He can form a complete ox\'s body from air, with a new hide and new bones; or he can put together another aery body along with the bones left behind \[by the first ox\] and attach it to the rest of the hide and, when the time comes for him to do so, he can keep it intact under the hide, and make it move and bellow. Then later on, when he has to, he withdraws from it, and it will look as though the OX has collapsed and died. \'This\', says Spina, \'is why witches \[strigibus\], as a group, maintain that after such oxen, (which they believe have been resuscitated), are brought back to their masters\' byres, they die within three days, by command of the Lord or Mistress of the transvection, as though some wasting disease were shrivelling them up entirely in a matter of hours, and that after quivering for a short while, what seemed to be flesh quickly breaks up into the material it was before\', (in other words, air). (See Bartolommeo Spina, Inquiry into Witches, chapter 7.)

content:
[Page 225]

But, (to return to the illnesses I was talking about), the miraculous resuscitations of Christ our Lord and of saintly men are easily distinguished from the cessations of those illnesses because, according to the evidence of the Faith, they were accomplished by a simple command or by a prayer poured out to God, not by an intervening period of time or delay. The body had been dissolved by putrefaction, too, and was stinking, as happened in the case of Lazarus. But in the illnesses we are discussing, the body continues to exist without decay and stench, and whenever the body has been restored \[to life\] one can easily see that it has been mangled and has fallen to pieces, sometimes after a very long time, to the truth of which St Maurilius in the case of a child dead for seven years and St Stanislaus in the case of someone called Petricus \[who had been dead for\] three years, testified in the case of the Church against Boleslaus. (See more about this in Miguel Medina, Correct Faith in God Book 2, chapter 7).

Book 2, Question 30

What power does magic have over the evil spirits \[cacodaemones\] themselves?

Books on the subject, written by some of the ancients, have perished. Battiades had written one about familiar spirits and Campester one about people possessed by spirits and spirits of the underworld. (They are cited by Fulgentius in his Moral Exposition of the Content of Vergil according to Philosophers). So, we have to look for help in other \[authors\], especially that touchstone of truth, sacred theology, and in proven histories. I think it is evident to any Catholic that magicians have no power at all over good angels or the souls of the blessed, and that they have no power at all over wicked \[angels\], either, unless they have made a pact with them. Therefore, evil spirits pretend that magicians are compelling them, and \[pretend\] to obey them of their own accord, in order to trap more people and keep hold of them once they have been ensnared. This now needs to be explained a little more clearly.

If you ask about good spirits or angels, I think they naturally have some power to compel evil \[spirits\], or at least to restrain them, but not indiscriminately. They can do this naturally in the case of evil spirits of inferior rank and order, but they cannot exercise this power unless God tells or allows them to do so. In the case of evil spirits of an equal order or rank, however, they have no natural power to compel them, but simply receive is sometimes by God\'s special concession and, so to speak, delegation. The same must be said about the power of evil spirits over evil spirits.

(I find that these are divided into diviners, that is, fortune-tellers: familiars, that is, personal servants or accessories: possessors, that is, those which afflict terribly those whom they besiege and dash to the ground-such was the one the Evangelist talks about-and paraders of dreams\', as Irenaeus calls them more than once, that is, removers of bad dreams or displayers of good ones). All these types pretend to obey magicians, and they all have something in common-some are of higher rank, some of lower. But whereas good angels willingly and eagerly obey their superiors, evil spirits, on the contrary, do not obey their superiors, just as vicious slaves \[do not obey\] harsh masters or a weaker \[person does not obey\] a more powerful tyrant except unwillingly and because they have been tamed by evil.

Consequently, it is also reasonable to say that among evil spirits, the subordination of one rank from which they fell to another is certainly not genuine and not one which is natural to them. The reason is that it lacks the formal structure and perfection of an orderly chain of command which is arranged, via stages of subordination, for one ultimate purpose. In this sense, Job was perfectly accurate when he said that no order is found in Hell. There is only a kind of imperfect or, (as they call it), \'material\' distinction of orders left there, which will last until the end of the world. In this sense theologians, including Cassian, recognise the hierarchy of evil spirits which the Apostle unambiguously confirms in his \[Epistle\] to the Ephesians, last chapter, verse 12, \'Against principalities and powers\', where you see him name two large groups while he is dealing with evil spirits.

content:
[Page 226]

From this natural strength and pre-eminence among the order of evil spirits is also born the strength and power of certain magicians over others, whereby they either impede what the other \[magicians\] are doing or, in their turn, (with God\'s permission), badly injure or kill them by means of their own magic. This strife between them is, as it were, a struggle between the evil spirits with whom the contending magicians are allied by a pact. I told the story of one struggle in Burgundy in Book One.

Here is a second I came across when members of the Faith told me about it. Two magicians came together at the court of the English queen in order to put on an entertaining show and made a remarkably friendly agreement to obey each other in one \[of their tricks\]. The first one told the other to look down from a window, but when he did this, all of a sudden stag\'s horns sprouted from his head and for a long time everyone wanted to pull faces and mock him. Consequently, rendered powerless by the insult and wanting to avenge himself in a more savage fashion, \[the second magician\] drew a human figure on a wall with charcoal, then ordered the first magician to go up to the figure. As he was about to do so, he noticed it was devising instant death for him and, filled with horror, he warded it off with prayer.

The other \[magician\] reminded him forcefully of their agreement and so, under this compulsion, \[the magician\] went up to \[the figure\]. The wall seemed to make room for his body as he approached, but once he had come right up to \[the wall\], he was never seen again anywhere afterwards. In other words, an evil spirit of higher rank had killed him and taken his body away to an uninhabited place or a cave somewhere else.

I shall transcribe a third \[example\] in the words of C, a German, who tells the story as something he heard from someone else. \'In N\', he says, \'an illusionist \[praestigiator\] who came from a good family decapitated their host\'s servant, in a public guest-house, at the request of the other guests. But when he wanted to put the man\'s head back on again, he noticed there was another magician in the room who was stopping him from carrying out his intention. \[The illusionist\] asked him not to do that, but when \[the magician\] would not comply after being asked more than once, the illusionist made a lily grow on the table, and when he cut off its head and flowers, the magician who had been impeding him immediately fell \[from his seat at\] the table minus his head; and straight away, without hindrance, the illusionist put the magician\'s head on the servant and then fled the guest-house and the city to avoid being arrested by the magistrate on a charge of murder.⁵⁵ In this case, the illusion lay in cutting off the first head and replacing it, and also in producing the lily and cutting its head off. The context took place between the magicians\' evil spirits, the one of lower rank being strong enough to hinder the power of the illusion but, compelled by the more powerful \[spirit\]-not unwillingly, in my opinion-to comply with the murder of his client, who was of very little importance to him and who really was killed.

A fourth \[example\] concerns Zyto of Bohemia, a well-known illusionist, who was engaged in a contest with Bavarians. Jan Dubravius tells us what happened. \'Wenceslaus, Emperor and King of Bohemia\', he says, \'was a relation by marriage of John, the Prince of Bavaria, because he had married his daughter, Sophia.⁵⁵⁷ His father-in-law knew that his son-in-law took pleasure in stage-plays and magical illusions, and so he filled a wagon with actors and illusionists and took them with him to Prague. There, while the most remarkable of the performers was displaying his professional stunts to delight people\'s eyes, among the spectators was Zyto, Wenceslaus\'s magician, his mouth gaping open in a great yawn. He came nearer the Bavarian performer and suddenly swallowed him and all his equipment, with the exception of his shoes which he spat out because they seemed to be covered in mud. Looking for a way to get rid of \[what he had swallowed\], he unburdened his stomach, which was heavy with its unusual food, into a bathtub filled with water and restored the illusionist, still wet, to the spectators\'.

content:
[Page 227]

In this case, Zyto\'s evil spirit was the more powerful. The business of swallowing was merely an illusion, but the unfortunate \[performer\] was genuinely snatched away and thrown into the tub of water by the evil spirit, not discharged via the pathways of \[Zyto\'s\] bowels. My fifth \[example\] will be taken from Olaus \[Magnus\] Book 3, chapter 20. Here a magician called Gilbert was arguing with Catillus, his instructor, about superiority in the practice of magic. \[Catillus\] pointed a tiny stick inscribed with Gothic or Ruthenian characters at him, so \[Gilbert\] took hold of him. \[Catillus\] became rigid at once and was carried away, trussed up, to an underground cave on an island in a lake called \'Veter\' by the Ostrogoths.

Saxo Grammaticus mentions a sixth \[example\] in Book 1 of his history of Denmark. It is about an old man who was a very eminent magician, as is proved by the fact that this one man surpassed all the men of Perm who are fierce in their reliance on magic. The story is a long one, so if anyone wants to read it, my indication is that it occurs in Saxo at the point where he describes a battle between Hading and Thuning. In addition to this, I am happy to refer to a story told by the Greeks about a contest between the soothsayers Calchas and Mopsus, which ended in Calchas\'s defeat and death. This, therefore, is the power of evil spirits over evil spirits and of magicians over them.

Book 2, Question 30, Section 2 \[sic\]

Holy people have often received from God an extraordinary power to keep evil spirits under control, as is attested by the innumerable miracles whereby those \[saints\] have got the better of them and overthrown them. This same power has always invested the sacraments, sacramental, and exorcisms of the Catholic Church, and this power is not found outwith her. Certain \[practices\] similar to our exorcisms, instituted in earlier times by Solomon, seem to have flourished among the Jews. This is proved not only by Josephus, Origen, and St Epiphanius, but also by the words of our Saviour when he confronted the Jews on the grounds that they were saying He was expelling evil spirits in \[the name of\]

Beelzebub. \'In whose name do your children expel evil spirits?\' He said \[Luke 11.19\] and learned men have been right in thinking that this is more correctly referred to the Jews\' usual exorcists than to the Apostles, because when this exchange was taking place, the Apostles had not yet been sent to preach, and this power was granted to them after \[they had been\]. The disciples also suffered the same malicious charge as their teacher, as Jesus predicted they would in Matthew \[10.17-18\].

Consequently, the Lord had not used the example of His Apostles and disciples to sufficient effect because the Jews replied straight away that they accomplished these things in the same name as the Master. In my opinion, Solomon had instituted these exorcisms at a time when he was still cleaving to God, and therefore God\'s power made them work. Perhaps, too, they continued to have some power from their \[original\] establishment by God, but not, I think, as much as there is these days in an exorcism \[carried out\] by the Catholic Church. If, however, you argue that they were instituted by Solomon when he was an idolater, you will be forced to attribute the, (as St Thomas \[Aquinas\] and \[Francisco de Vitoria do), to magicians\' incantations, all of whose power rests upon a pact with an evil spirit. But I prefer my first explanation.

Therefore, since the whole power of magicians over evil spirits depends on and arises from the covenant they have made with them, it undoubtedly follows that if a magician has a pact with an evil spirit of higher rank, he cannot exercise this power of this higher-ranking spirit. But through that higher-ranking spirit which is acting as his servant and assisting him because of their pact, he can compel evil spirits of lower rank to do something, or not to do it, and to prevent them from carrying out something they could otherwise have done. This is proved by the complaint of the Chaldaean magician in St Augustine who \'kept complaining that the great effort he was making to be successful in purging his soul was rendered ineffectual because a man who had power over this and was touched by envy had bound the Powers he had invoked with holy prayers, the result being that they could not grant what was demanded of them.\'

content:
[Page 228]

Therefore one evil spirit bound what another could not undo. Eusebius tells us the same thing, and quite clearly it applies to the magician Cynops in Prochorus, (whoever he was), \[who says\] that when \'St John was questioning evil spirits about why they were in the habit of obeying Cynops, one of them replied, \"Because the entire power of Satan resides in him, and he has a treaty and pact with every one of our princes. We, too, on our part, have a pact with him and so Cynops obeys us and we him\". In the absence of such a pact, every attempt made by magicians against evil spirits is useless, since these work only because of the pact, (as I said in question 2.)

Hence first of all comes Apollo\'s lie when he answered the magician: Listen to me. I am not willing, because you have bound me by force\', (Eusebius, quoting Porphyry).

He was replying of his own accord, but he was pretending that he was being compelled by a contract which had been renewed seven times, \[a contract\] he himself had drawn up, as it clear from another passage in Eusebius\'s Proof of the Gospel Book 4, which begins KAnišelv \'Epuñv, \[They call Hermes\], etc. Then there is also the fiction, as if said by a suppliant: Furthermore, release the king. A mortal does not hold a god captive any longer\'.

The utterly vile evil spirit is speaking about himself and is demanding that the magician release him. In addition to this, magicians\' boasting about their ability to conjure up evil spirits and apparitions is worthless. Nor is there any power in the herb \[called\] \'Dogshead\' or \'Osiris\'s herb\', as Apion was silly enough to claim. Worthless, too, were Numa\'s boasting and ceremonies, and other dissembling visions produced-merely as the result of a pact, regardless of the power they had to compel them-by the magician Sicidita, (see Nicetas), Theodorus Santabirinus, (see Zonaras), and John the German.

Let me write down what one reads about that last one in the author of the German adages, because it is appropriate, and not unpleasant, to blunt the boasting of certain people who are themselves morally degenerate, and prattle about the smoky images of their ancestors, and \[say\] they did things they themselves have not done. Hence, they write that although \[John\] was illegitimate, he had a great reputation for learning and was promoted to a canonry at Halberstadt, a post not usually granted to anyone unless he came from a good family. The fault common to good families-pride-made his fellow-canons despise him. He was irked by this and finally decided to remedy his annoyance.

He invited his colleagues to dinner and received them in most elegant fashion; and among all his other pleasantries he included mention of a magical performer and suggested that each man would surely like to see his own parents. They were indeed extremely keen to see them and after a while, by means of a wicked incantation, \[the magician\] evoked the misshapen shadowy forms of a cook, a pub landlord, a professional jester, and a peasant. \[The canons\] admitted they had sometimes seen these faces in their parents\' homes. \[John\'s\] own father was shown, too, dressed as a canon, with a fat paunch. The shadowy forms were dismissed, and then \[John\] said, \'Well now! Tell me honestly, is there anyone\'s father here you think is better born \[than the others\]?\' Thoroughly frightened and filled with shame, each of them went back home and from then on did not accuse John of any imperfection in his blood-line.

Likewise, it follows that one should come to the same conclusion about the ritual evocation of the gods of the ancients from \[besieged\] cities, the form of words for which was recorded by Sammonicus Serenus in Macrobius, \[Saturnalia 3.9.6-7\]. I know God has not infrequently granted this power to saintly people, and I pass over anyone else. St Stephen, Bishop of Perm, \'told the evil spirits, who were turning people away to prevent them from listening to him, to show themselves openly in visible form. They did as they were told and appeared-immensely tall, completely black, with horns \[on their heads\], and breathing out stench and flames\', (Sauer in his biography \[of St Stephen\], under the month of September).

content:
[Page 229]

Book 2, Question 30, Section 3

Secondly, one concludes-and on this point \[Paolo\] Grillando seems to have made a mistake in question 3, number 23, when he talks about compulsion-no words and no physical objects have the power directly and of themselves to compel evil spirits to appear, come, go away, do something, or not do something. No physical objects can equal the strength of substances which are spiritual and different. Therefore, evil spirits cannot be affected by them naturally, although they can be affected supernaturally. Consequently, I do not agree with magicians when they produce various natural remedies against evil spirits, such as Hermes \[Trismegistus\] who said that evil spirits are brought by a suffumigation of aloe-wood or whale-sperm and driven away by one of sulphur. Porphyry and Proclus talk a great deal of similar nonsense, as do some people in Hippocrates who talk even greater nonsense. I do not agree with heretics who disparage all supernatural power in exorcisms and anything which has been consecrated and blessed, contrary to what other people do.

On the other hand, one cannot approve of the credulousness and superstitious behaviour of certain Catholics, either, who ascribe supernatural power to things which have not been consecrated, such as St John\'s wort, rue, horn, goat\'s dung, baths, and whippings, and think that an evil spirit is adversely affected by these and therefore is annoyed and driven away by them. When one whips the body of someone who is obsessed \[by an evil spirit\] too much, the illness becomes worse and intensifies, and so the sick person is made worse.

What is more, anger and sadness serve to increase those states of melancholia which the evil spirit wants to encourage; so while these stupid people want to harm the evil spirit by doing things such as this, they are actually helping him. Nor can you find anything here which is irksome to an evil spirit other than that he thinks he is being whipped in someone else\'s \[body\] and suffers pain in his pride. But this is one thing which should be of no importance at all to these floggers. The saints have sometimes done this, but their \'whips\', such as their voices and the soles of their shoes to help them, would miraculously torture the evil spirit. Baths are useful for purging the melancholic humour, and the leaves of rue and St John\'s wort cure problems with breathing and are wonderfully good for calming the humoral disorder caused by breathing problems.

Dung and goat\'s horn dispel the same problems with their acrid fumigation, and that proud fellow is angry, too, that he is being laughed at and made a fool of in someone else\'s \[body\]. It has therefore been very well observed by Konrad Wimpina and Francisco Vallés that evil spirits more frequently attack those who have too great a supply of black bile, because that humour provides a particularly suitable way of making people frenzied and insane, and evil spirits like it very much indeed. Consequently, they lay siege to melancholics and, for the most part, are the cause of illnesses stemming from black bile. Hence it follows that because they cannot change physical matter unless they connect active things with passive, they treat people badly if, once they have made use of physical things of this kind, the inclinations those people have to malice or deceit are expelled and their opposites introduced immediately.

Therefore, whatever physical things introduce into the sufferer\'s body an inclination contrary to the one the evil spirit needs for his active purpose \[also\] cleanse the physical humours directly and expel \[the sufferer\'s\] physical illness naturally. Indirect causes alone, however, are the reason the spirit runs away and deserts that body, and in the absence of these, he does not do so. On this understanding, it will be permissible for those under siege by an evil spirit to possess and carry on their person stones or herbs which are naturally effective \[in these cases\] without, however, any \[accompanying\] incantation. This is what is generally thought.

content:
[Page 230]

Certain objections are usually raised against this. (1) In Josephus, Antiquities Book 8, chapter 2, \[section 6\], Eleazar draws out an evil spirit by using a particular root. Someone may respond, perhaps this was instituted by Solomon at the same time as his exorcisms, and so it could have been possible that God worked supernaturally in the herb. That is scarcely likely to be true after the introduction and promulgation of Christianity. My opinion is rather that Eleazar was a magician and did what he did as a result of a pact \[with an evil spirit\], and the circumstantial details added by Josephus will easily convince the careful reader of this. The power of the root he dug up in such a superstitious fashion seems to be of the same kind as the one \[Josephus\] writes about in The Jewish War Book 7, chapter 25.

\(2\) There is a passage in Tobit which runs as follows: \'if you put a small part of the heart\' \[of the fish \"Callyonimus\"\] \'on top of charcoal, its smoke will clear out every kind of evil spirit\', and we read later that this was done. My response is that this suffumigation drove the spirit away indirectly. The angel Raphael was the one who expelled the evil spirit directly and despatched him to an uninhabited place. In consequence, the whole action was attributed to Raphael afterwards, \'He (Raphael) chased away the evil spirit from her\'. The power as a natural property, however, is attributed to the \[fish\'s\] heart not in a literal, but in a prophetic and symbolic sense, because it must be referred back to Christ, our Lord, who freed the Magdalene from the evil spirits which had possessed her, and has also freed us from the tyranny of the Devil. This is not my comment, but that of St Prosper \[of Aquitaine\]. At some length, and in many words, he says the following, among everything else: \'He feeds His disciples on the shore fully from Himself, and offers Himself to the whole world as an ixdúv \[fish\], and because our ancestors explained \"fish\" in Latin by reference to sacred letters which they deduced from the Sibylline verses that \"Jesus Christ, Son of God, the Saviour\", is a fish cooked in His own suffering, by whose inward aids we are illuminated and fed every day\'.

You will understand this somewhat obscure saying if you read St Augustine from whom he took it. Certainly, Christ is called a fish by Tertullian. \'But we are born in water as little fish, according to the example of our ixdúv, \[Jesus Christ\], and we are not saved in any way other than by remaining in the water\'.

\(3\) They beckon us in the direction of David\'s harp but do so in vain because in that instance it was not the pleasant tune which was the direct cause of putting the evil spirit to flight. When the King had been soothed by the harmoniousness of the music, as long as David was playing the harp, at any rate, the humours which were agitating him started to settle themselves down to some extent, and in the meantime were in a less suitable state to be affected by the evil spirit\'s stirring them up. This is why the wicked \[spirit\] began to retire at that moment-not because it was pleased or offended by the music, but because it would find it difficult to put up with the fact that its possession of its dwelling-place was being thrown into disorder, so to speak, by this improvement in the mingling of \[the King\'s\] humours. Many Catholics agree with this opinion of Rabbi Moses of Egypt \[Maimonides\]. The notion some people have about the evil spirit\'s inclination for harmony is, of course, worthless. This is where magicians get their nonsense that one should offer Saturn singing which is mournful and the rest of the planets singing which is cheerful and happy. (Guillaume d\'Auvergne refuted this a long time ago). Others take refuge in symbolism and maintain that the evil spirit really was put to flight by the sound of the harp, but that this was done by the power and merit of Christ\'s cross of which the harp was a symbol.

content:
[Page 231]

In connection with this third point, one\'s conclusion is that poets\' beliefsee the heretic \'Palingenius\', \[The Zodiac of Life\] Book 10 or \'Capricorn\', and the Catholic Pierre de Ronsard\'s Hymn on Evil Spirits-that magicians can bind evil spirits fast in small jars, mirrors, or rings the way criminals are locked up in the stocks or tied fast to a board is not true. This is either because a more powerful \[spirit\], or one of higher rank, always compels them to be there and keeps them there by his command, or because they are there of their own accord and pact \[with the magician\] and keep themselves there. Consequently, one must strongly disapprove of the treatise by Hermes \[Trismegistus\] in which he published instructions for binding evil spirits, and the lies told by Apollo and Hecate in Theodoret\'s book on oracles, in which they say they have been constrained to appear by \[certain\] forms of words.

As well as these two authors, Porphyry makes the \[same\] lying claim. This, as I have said, has been attributed to the opinion of the Fathers \[of the Church\] and the Schoolmen. What Heinrich of Hesse said on this subject in his \[commentary\] on Genesis is very well worth noting. \'\[The evil spirit\] pretends he has been taken prisoner in order to take you prisoner: that he has been vanquished in order to vanquish you: that he is subject to your orders in order to subject you to his: that he has been imprisoned by you so that, in the end, he can imprison you. He pretends he has been bound fast in an image or stone by your magic so that, once he has bound you fast by the ropes of your sins, he can lead you to Hell.⁵⁷⁰ (You can read more in confirmation of these points in Gianfrancesco Pico \[della Mirandola\], Foreknowledge of Things Book 7, chapter 4.)

\[Alonso\] Tostado has provided a closely argued, though verbose, argument on this topic as follows. \'It is not possible for a lesser power to subject a greater power to itself, and there is no power on earth which is comparable to that of evil spirits, (Job chapter 40). Therefore there will not be anything in the way of Nature or ritual by which human beings can compel evil spirits to come, to reply to questions, or to do anything \[for them\], unless you object that the Church\'s exorcisms \[do just that\], in which case it has to be said that \[the spirits\] are compelled to do something, namely, to leave the bodies of those they have been besieging, or not to do them harm.

But this is done by God, in as much as He Himself instituted what is done by the Church and therein lies hidden the operative power of God, just as in the working of the sacraments. God, however, is not working in the operations of workers of harmful magic whereby they want to compel evil spirits, because these \[operations\] are contrary to God\'s honour. Therefore, workers of harmful magic cannot compel evil spirits \[to do\] anything. The evil spirits, though, lie and pretend they are being compelled, because herein lies their greatest power of persuasion. If we could not compel them to come or answer questions or do anything, but whatever they might do they would do voluntarily, human beings would stop having recourse to them, on the grounds that they could achieve nothing with their assistance and withdraw themselves from them.

But since human beings think they can compel them, because \[the spirits\] pretend \[to be compelled\], they are very much influenced to acts of harmful magic, as if by these means they can obtain everything they want; and evil spirits are keen that they do this so that, through this kind of error and influence, they can keep humans\' minds in chains. Yet evil spirits cannot really be compelled by human beings through acts of harmful magic. Indeed, if they could be compelled, they would not teach human beings how to do it because if humans really could subject evil spirits to them, they would thereby make the spirits more wretched \[than they are already\]. So \[the spirits\] pretend they have been subjected, (although in fact they have not), so that they can deceive \[the humans\], and are content to act as their servants for the time being, although actually evil spirits would not be willing to be subjected to human beings for any money.

content:
[Page 232]

Nothing is truer than this. But how dangerous it is to imagine one has imprisoned this kind \[of spirit\] and has them under one\'s control is proved by various examples. One, recounted by Johannes Nider as follows, will be sufficient. \'A little before the present General Council, a man of wicked life had a house in Kleinbasel and, as it happened, and had come under reasonable suspicion of performing acts of harmful magic \[maleficiis\]. He had a daughter and married her to a young man in his house, and when at length the old man fell ill, he pointed out a box to his daughter and son-in-law and said, \"Don\'t move this little box, because if you do, you\'ll regret it. Let it stay where it is after I am dead\", and thus not long afterwards the old man expired.

A long time went by. Neither his daughter nor her husband paid any great heed to her father\'s instruction, and when they moved from their former home to another little house which was big enough \[for them\], they carried the box to their new home. During the journey, however, it started to weigh so much that \[the husband\'s\] strength failed him, and he called on his wife to help him. Whether his wife opened the box later in the house, or whether somehow or other she forgot \[what her father had said\] about the box, people agree on one thing-the two of them came into their new house with a small child they had begotten. Well now, all of a sudden, the wife rushed at the cradle like a raving mad woman, with the intention of killing the child. Her husband saw this, forcibly seized hold of his wife, and realised she was under the control of an evil spirit. While the evil spirit was being exorcised, it threatened it would not leave unless \[her husband\] killed her, which he did in spite of the exorcist\'s trying to prevent him. Next day her husband was making his way along a pavement in the town when, quite unexpectedly, he was struck by a stone falling from the upper part of a water-channel which was coming away \[from the building\]. It struck him, apparently with the co-operation of an evil spirit, in the face and rendered him so ugly that he scarcely seemed to be a human being.\'

\[Pierre\] Crespet has much to say about these imprisoned \[spirits\], because sometimes they appear to their masters. Some have to be worshipped with a particular ritual because they are connected with Saturn, others because they are connected with Jupiter, others because they are connected with Venus, and others because they are connected with Mercury, etc. At fixed times in the night, they rouse their owner and, on occasion, talk to him, unless they prefer to do something wicked. In France and Italy, they are for sale and always ruin those who buy them. (Crespet goes into greater detail in The Hatred of Satan Book 1, discourse 12).

Holy men, however, have not infrequently imprisoned or bound up evil spirits in certain things: St Conon, for example, about whom the Jesuit Matthias Rader gives the following account in The Succession of the Months among the Greeks, under \'March\'. \'He exercised such great force and power over evil spirits that he would put some of them in charge of the fields and make them guardians of the crops. Others he would imprison in sealed-up buildings and bury in the foundation of a church he intended to build. Likewise, St Lupus imprisoned one in Sens, afflicting him with thirst and inserting him, wailing and proclaiming who he was, in a small vessel of cold water he had told someone to bring. (This is what his ancient biographer says in Sauer, under the month of September.)

So, we read that Asmodeus was bound by the Archangel Raphael in an uninhabited place, (Tobit 8.2); and that four angels, bound in the great River Euphrates, were released by God\'s command, (Apocalypse 9.14 and 15); and that the Devil was chained up by an angel for a thousand years and sent into the abyss, (Apocalypse 20.2). No one denies Asmodeus is an evil spirit. Tichonius in Homily 7, Andreas of Caesarea, and Bede quite correctly maintain in relation to that verse that these four angels were evil spirits; and by \'binding\' one means \[being bound\] to a particular place and not just in a mystical sense to the hearts of the wicked, as Ambrose \[Autpert\] finally proved conclusively in these words: \'I think one must interpret the binding of the Devil literally to mean he is being held in bondage by the power of God in some place in the abyss, or certainly in Hell, until the day of his release\'.

St Gregory sticks to the letter \[of the text and says the same thing in his commentary on Job Book 4, chapter 12, and Andreas of Caesarea quite correctly adds that in Catholic interpretation \[of the text\], the more powerful operation whereby the malice of an evil spirit is constrained is called a \'chain\', because these means \[of restraint\] are bonds and ropes and are called this elsewhere, (2 Peter 2.4, and Vol. 6 of the Jewish canon). Caesarius \[of Heisterbach\] says that an evil spirit imprisoned in the body of demoniac was forced by exorcism to say that there are three phrases in the canon of the Mass whereby Lucifer was bound up in Hell as if by chains, namely, \"Through Him and with Him and in Him\'. (Read Book 5, chapter 13 of his Discussion of Miracles.)

Saints can vanquish evil spirits as follows: (i) as servants of God, by injecting fear and making threats which an evil spirit knows are not usually ineffectual; (ii) by withdrawing the divine agreement obtained from God which means that evil spirits cannot be moved from a place, (which, were it not for that, they could do); and (iii) by imprinting on evil spirits some spiritual condition and detaining force-\[exorcism\] being an example of this-whereby these non-physical spirits are detained unwillingly in Hell and tortured by physical flames.

The practices and forms of words used in exorcism, with which an evil spirit is sometimes excommunicated and, as it were, despatched to the lowest dwelling-place in Hell and fettered there as I have described, tell us about the first of these methods. Consequently, St Augustine, made use of the language of Honorius\'s edict and proclaimed an interdict. (See The City of God Book 20, chapter 7). Palladius reminds us of the second method in his life of St Macarius in which he deals with Jamnes, Mambres, and their tomb, (Lausiac History, chapter 20). The third method is more frequent and is commonly \[employed\] against all evil spirits because \[it pertains\] to their eternal punishment, on which read St Thomas \[Aquinas\] Part 1, question 64, article 4, contrary 3, Summa Against the Pagans Book 4, chapter 90, and the Bishop of Avila, \[Alonso Tostado\], in his \[Commentary on\] Matthew, chapter 25.

I have found a few \[examples\], however, which seem to attribute this power even to workers of harmful magic \[maleficis\]. But when one takes a closer look at these, they indicate merely that because of the pact the magician \[magum\] has made with a more powerful evil spirit, he can impede the activity and power of an evil spirit of lower rank, and so \[the spirit\] can sometimes be coerced by the magician, whether he is willing to be so or not. This, however, is done by the magician via the vicarious power of a stronger evil spirit, or rather, by making use of his power.

Thus, in St Jerome\'s \[life of\] Hilarion, an evil spirit has to be held fettered by a piece of string and a metal plate; this is how Jamnes and Mambres, in the passage to which I have referred, bound many evil spirits. This is how one should interpret St Augustine when he writes that evil spirits are bound, put to flight, removed, and transferred from certain places and objects on the orders of \[evil spirits\] of higher rank, (The Divination of Evil Spirits, chapter 7), and this is how I interpret Eusebius when he says that evil spirits can be restrained by human beings, (Preparation for the Gospel Book 5, chapter 6). This is why Albertus \[Magnus\], \[Francisco\] Victoria, and every other Catholic theologian thinks they are enclosed, (according to popular belief), in rings as a result of a pact and kept there forcibly by a more powerful evil spirit, (if they actually are enclosed and kept there), or they pretend of their own accord that they are being kept there when a more powerful spirit has not been involved.

One infers that the spirits popularly called \'familiars\' or \'little Martins\' or \'little teachers\' act as servants to human beings entirely of their own accord. The Greeks call them πapéδpous \[those who sit beside you because they are constantly present. (Irenaeus and Tertullian have dealt with these.) Some people thought that Socrates\'s spirit \[daemonium\] was one of this sort. St Clement attributes one such to Simon Magus, Prochorus one such to Cynops, and Aristotle one such to a person from Thrace. In his Chronicles, \[Jean\] Froissard attributes one called Croton to a learned man. Cornelius Agrippa\'s dog was one such, and even if his pupil \[Johann\] Weyer denies it, everyone else quite rightly confirms it. I remember reading in Johannes Caesarius the exemplary story-well worth remembering-of a familiar spirit \[paredri\].

In this story, what one finds astonishing is that the evil spirit demanded five gold coins as his price and gave orders for a bell to be purchased with them for a poor church so that it could summon the faithful to divine worship every Sunday. There was undoubtedly some deception lying hidden here, and the hope of a larger sum of money was blindingly obvious. It is also remarkable that he caused the soldier no harm. Familiar spirits are scarcely ever in the habit of going away without doing harm to their masters since, for the most part, an evil spirit makes a contract for a particular period of time \[which stipulates that when that time is completed the evil spirit can either find another master, or \[his master will submit to being killed by his evil spirit, as Nicolas Rémy tells us in Book 1 of his Worship of Evil Spirits, illustrating his remarks with an example.

But this is enough about magic \[in general\]. Let us proceed to harmful magic.

Preface to the Fourth Volume
============================

As the foregoing sections of the fourth volume of the Mystik round off and conclude this part of the great edifice --- which, founded in the visible and tangible earth, carries that same tangibility over into the two invisible regions --- the work had therefore to be divided into three large departments. One comprises therein those very foundations laid safely and well‑fitted into earthly nature; and this part is the Physiology of Mysticism. The second is that part of the building which, upon this firm ground, rises into those regions which, in respect of root and origin, are indeed above the earth, but are yet in it insofar as they make themselves known and reveal themselves in earthly things; and this section will embrace the Theology of Mysticism, within the circuit of the militant Church. Finally the third part will sink into those regions which lie beneath earthly nature; and although grounded in Hell, yet, in rising, manifest and spread themselves upon the earth --- and here the Demonology of Mysticism will be expounded. The earlier volumes were devoted to the development of the first two; now the third too has found its own, so that this part of the building is closed, and we may set the bouquet on the height.

The work rises on the spot where until now the heap of shards of recent centuries had stood; just as, indeed, its model, the Cross, was raised upon the skull‑place of ancient times. The spot had seemed uncanny in these centuries; for spirits walked there that wandered in their affairs. Thus the site was designated by the police as the place where all filth should be deposited; and since the times produced much filth, and in the movement many pots were broken, the mass of what was brought in piled up mountain‑high; and people comforted themselves thus: the spirits would be well covered, and would lose the desire to stir under the weight. But spirits go through rock and through ruins; they were always on top, as the industrious carters brought more; the gravediggers could not succeed in banishing them by burial. Now in shards and rubble and rubbish the cornerstones cannot be laid durably. Therefore the place had to be cleansed beforehand, and when that was done, behold the whole foundation of the work stood revealed, already carried high above the earth; the diligent had only carted in the great quantity of rubbish because the fortress of enlightenment seemed too threatening. Rumour was set in circulation: there had once stood there counterfeit‑minting establishments which had to be buried. The inhabitants, who ought to have known better, permitted the fable and grew accustomed to approach the place only with caution, and fancied each night they still heard the hammer‑blows. The speaker of the present work, who has some respect for the scientific instinct of the schools of this age, but assigns nothing to their higher intentions and wholly rejects their truthfulness and credibility in such matters, was not deterred by this ban which learned timidity had laid upon the place; he fell upon it and began the work of clearing. Upon the found substructure he then continued to build; and, the stoutest hands of all times lending aid in the work, he in the course of a few years brought it to the point at which it now stands before the eye. Precisely the ill repute of the matter and the secret fear of spirits which surrounded the object kept the workmen from pressing forward. \

Some would not look; others jeered at the folly of the treasure‑diggers; the third, the genuine workmen --- for they always go about in aprons and with the trowel --- cried: Let them dig, the uncritical ones, and, in the Roman‑Catholic sense, go in search of miracles; if they find none, they will rightly be laughed at; but if they do stumble on some, then they have only brought to light the proofs of the spuriousness of their Church! Thus the work proceeded publicly, undisturbed by the world; whereas the crush and crowding of the great market otherwise do not easily allow anything thorough to come to maturity, here the peace of God and the silence of solitude lingered: each matter could be treated with quiet composure, each could obtain its right, confused and led astray by no objection; and so the work gradually rose up to its ridge and now supports and protects itself, and let Nidhauger gnaw at its foundations in vain. For it is a bulwark of Catholicism which those who ought to defend it had abandoned and left to decay. Now it is newly fortified and well preserved; for it rests firm upon its rocky ground and can defy every attack.

As already said, the work is planned threefold: an earthly one, solid and well put together, each projection mutually securing the others; a supra‑earthly one, surveying and governing all; and an under‑earthly one, displaying its secret terrors beneath what is visible; the three covering, protecting, and corroborating one another. Three full, rounded, self‑contained disciplines --- indeed sciences --- are here established; each enjoys an actual foundation such as few others possess. With respect, first of all, to the physiology of mysticism, this foundation is similar to that which underlies the natural sciences. Here are the physicians and the naturalists who offer themselves as guarantors of the facts that belong to them; and if of the whole abundance of the natural riches only some things, and these not down to their innermost ground, are ascertained, this arises from the overarching, hard‑to‑access nature of the object, and induction here has at least the certainty of every medical science, and is daily strengthened by the advancing spiritualization of all physics.

The induction of hagiological mysticism appears incomparably better established. For the fact in question here springs from the soil of the most devout, God‑inspired, most blameless, most truth‑ful individuals; it is apprehended by them throughout in a penetrating, ethically purified and comprehensive spirit as far as possible; it is externally attested by witnesses who are in the most favorable position to discern it from the outside inward, even as they themselves are again discerned by it from the inside outward. They are therefore, as indeed by their vocation and position in general they are called to be, seekers after truth and proclaimers of truth. The ground of the attested --- the holiness of the individual producing the fact --- is further confirmed after that person's death in the miracles which he performs, and this guarantee is then certified by the authority of the Church, which thus likewise sanctions the innermost foundation of the attested truth. What other fact in the whole realm of science --- except perhaps the self‑consciousness guaranteed by the consciousness of God and of nature, which is the basis of all scientific certainty --- may be compared with the assurance of this historical fact? \

In the demonology of mysticism this guarantee---the holiness of the one presenting the facts---indeed generally falls away; but in its place there now steps an ethical necessity which has just as firm a law as the physical one in natural phenomena, and thus affords to its products the same security as those. Error can in both cases lie only in the apprehension, and there again vouchsafe the same credible, practised witnesses who have borne testimony in the regions of that holy mysticism; and to these, strengthening their guarantee, are added the summoned physicians and the jurists. If, then, the certainty of this order of facts by no means attains that of the other, its guarantee nevertheless lies midway between that claimed by the physiologico‑mystical and that due to the hagiological. Thus matters stand with the facts in general; as to the particular selection made from the mass before us, we have already spoken concerning the first two disciplines; here we may only append to what has already been said the necessary remarks regarding the demonological.

First, as to possession: in order to bring the authenticity of the chosen examples---the ones valid in the higher domain---as close as possible, we have preferred those that occur frequently from the Gospels onward throughout the history of the saints. The atmosphere that surrounds a saint penetrates and overcomes the haze of falsehood and the darkness of the gloomy circle that has drawn itself around the possessed, and the same degree of certainty to which the whole life of the holy man lays claim extends likewise to this integrative moment of his. Secondly, those places where a remaining relic of such a saint--- a reliquary, for example---mediated intercourse with him, and where throngs of the afflicted gathered about such a site, have produced a rich practice in which a comparatively significant mass of facts has now accumulated.

We mention first the Camaldolese monastery of Valombrosa, half a day's journey from Florence. Saint Walbert, contemporary of Gregory VII and founder of the order, had there erected an oratory to the Blessed Virgin. In his life he had, when a dying monk was grievously terrified by a vision of a demon, driven it off with a cross which he took from the hand of the dying man. The monks preserved the cross there, and it soon served to test the possessed with it to determine whether they were truly demonic. Later the arm that had borne the crucifix to victory was also discovered; and from that time the Church of Our Lady at Valombrosa became a refuge for the possessed for all Tuscany; indeed, they came in swarms even as far as the borders of France. The healings increased, and since the year 1450 the occurrences had also found someone to record them in writing. \

Responding to the urging of the physician Laurentius, who had been present on the spot, Hieronymus of Raggiolo, an active and very pious man, from what he there found, learned from credible old people, and saw with his own eyes, compiled eighteen books on the demonic healings. The confidence in which the holy place and its founder were held was so great that, as he reports in Book XVII, merely from the Getica region in Tuscany and the surrounding territories, every month---except in the depths of winter---three to four possessed persons, women and men, and people of every rank, came to seek deliverance; and hardly had they obtained it when they were again replaced by newcomers. The tomb of the holy Cajetanus in Naples was just as celebrated as he was helpful to those sick from the demon: hence he was visited even down to recent times by such persons, who filled everything around them with their howling and the lamentations of their oppressed spirits, and hung all the walls with stones, nails, tufts of hair and similar rubbish as trophies of the saint's victories. The relics of St. Ubaldus, who died in 1160, are buried in Gubbio, and from the hour of his death down to the most recent times the possessed were delivered at his grave; some even while they were climbing the mountain. The wondrous healings which there occurred up to the year 1519 have been written down by Stephen of Cremona, who also composed a book on the exorcism and personally practised it there, from his own eyewitness account and from what he heard from those present.

At the grave of Saint Leontius in Mur many were likewise freed; in Teinst in Belgium likewise at that of St. Amalberga, who died in 772; the Helfersberg in the Eichsfeld, where St. Boniface overthrew the image of Stuffo, and Charlemagne raised up the cross which Heizzo had borne in his battles against the Saxons, was likewise thereby famous in central Germany. At all these places a rich source of experience flowed; the temple annals show the holy malady in all its forms and aspects; and the only thing that can be objected to them is that they preserve merely the healings that occurred, and for the most part pass over in silence the cases of local incurability.

All these facts were attested by credible observers, but among them there is still a lack of such as have found this attestation also through the personality in which they manifested themselves. The mass of ordinary possessed persons is entangled by the predominance of a mendacious force; against it a single, but weakly self-assured personality reacts only feebly. To remedy this evil state, a hard-to-reconcile combination of holiness and possession had to be united in the same person; a combination which, precisely because of the inner contradiction, will occur only rarely. It is known that some of the ancient fathers in the desert were in such a way at once holy and possessed; but neither have they recorded reminiscences of their internal condition, nor have those who stood near them preserved any such records. \
