About the middle of the seventeenth century there lived in northern Italy a man versed in both laws and devoted to the study of philosophy; moreover, endowed with a penetrating keenness of mind, and therefore eager to penetrate into the deeper mysteries of things. He had given himself up, by constant association, to learned but unbelieving people, magicians, and men of similar ilk, who initiated him into their arts and doctrines and infected him with their evil habits. He, who now wished to put into practice what he had learned theoretically, in order thereby to satisfy his desires --- which he could not accomplish without demonic help --- allowed himself to be carried away by them to give himself over to him who granted them and to his service, and in turn to seduce others to that service. The relationship had already continued for a good number of years, when one night he was so badly mistreated and almost strangled by him to whom he had given himself, that --- since even his mother had pleaded to God in prayer for that reason --- against his will he resolved to return to God and to call for His help.

Partly on the advice of his elders, partly through the encouragement of Father Carolus von Belitri, Vicar of the Holy Office in Tarvis, finally determined, he betook himself, as to a safe place, to the house of the Office with that vicar, as to a friend. He was now to go there to confession, and for that purpose a pious and discerning theologian was chosen; who, finding him by no means sufficiently prepared, took every pains to bring out what was still lacking by his exhortation and to examine his conscience in a fitting manner. But behold, at that moment his evil spirit again began to seize upon all his senses, and repeatedly to call out from his mouth: I, I am Satan; I, I am this man's lord and owner; he, he may not and cannot make his confession, and I will never permit it. By virtue of the pact which he has concluded with me, he is bound to me and belongs to me; he has solemnly promised me to obey me in all things, never to make a proper confession, nor ever to forsake me. The clergyman was at first frightened by this speech, but then, strengthened in the Lord, he asked the speaker what he wanted here. Thereupon the instigator of all evil answered: This man is the worst scoundrel, who has long consorted with unbelievers, still possesses many of their books, and is always ready for every evil; since he therefore does not commit as much evil as his baseness and wickedness prompt him to, I remain here to watch over him. Thus and the like said the crafty guardian who had plunged him into the abyss of all vices, and who now vaunted himself to be guarding him against greater evil. But when the priest ceased to speak of things that concerned his soul's salvation and turned to indifferent matters, the voice likewise at once ceased to speak through him, and did not hinder him in the use of his senses and faculties. Yet when another time the priest exhorted him with exorcisms not to hinder his confession any longer, the man burst into a furious laugh, and, with face, mouth, and fists, attacked the exorcist, mocking and scoffing at him, so that he appeared utterly mad. If the clergyman desisted a second time, he likewise ceased his rages and his laughter and his taunts, and addressed him seriously and with mature consideration, like a learned and prudent man; asserting at the same time that he from the bottom of his heart cursed all wrongdoing. \

Not that it possessed him in his body, tormenting and afflicting him like the possessed, without extending its power to their souls. Now I, relates Father Brognoli, in the same year, coming from Rome to Bergamo, lodged in a place only a little distance from the city, which that magician inhabited; I was urged by the venerable father‑provincial of that reformed province and by the clergyman of whom I have just spoken to take under my charge the aforesaid jurist, whom the clerical exorcists declared to be possessed by the demon, but whom the physicians pronounced insane. When he was brought to me, I first began to speak with him alone about many matters, and I recognized from his speech and answers soon that he was not foolish and out of his senses, as the physicians said, but of very sound understanding, learned, quick of spirit and sharp‑witted. Now, however, in the presence of that clergyman and of a noble jurist, his friend, I began to invoke the demon with exorcisms. But the one being exorcised was not, as commonly happens with the possessed, tormented by the exorcisms; instead he burst into laughter and threatened me with his fists. When I had seen this, and remembered the pact that he had concluded with the demon, and how he had already served him for eight years and been devoted to the magical being, I judged it necessary to employ other means.

Therefore, partly urged by himself, partly appointed by the entreaties of his friend, the other legally trained man, as well as by the clerics, to take him more closely under my supervision; I went to the place where he himself lived, had from the Father Inquisitor the necessary authority over him transferred to me, and then, after invoking divine help, in the monastery there, in the presence of our reverend provincial, of a Father Definitor, and of the companion of that man, commanded in the name of our Lord the demon: that they in no way hinder the external or internal faculties and abilities of the person, and that they answer all my questions freely and without obstruction. \

When I reminded him to accuse himself of diabolical magic, the invocation of spirits, and other such crimes, he answered: he could not accuse himself of that, because it was an excellent, holy thing worthy of no reproach; he had a pure conscience, unstained by any crime, nor defiled by any vice; and all that he undertook was permitted and right and holy. He told me this often in the words: "I do not want you to cleanse my conscience by confession; for we magicians and necromancers are all sure of our salvation, and do not need confession; because contrition is sufficient for us, as Peter of Abano teaches us in his writings. Thus he referred everything solely to his bodily health, and no desire arose in him to attend to his spiritual health in order to cure himself of the illness that kept him down. After I had dealt with him for a month he was, for the time being, dismissed home by the Inquisitor. Thus had happened to him what I had often foretold him, when I begged and entreated him to return to sound reason.

It falls into the last times of the Thirty Years' War, in which a dreadful barbarization seized upon almost the whole of European society and brought forth the utmost of vileness and abomination, whose miasmas were then carried about everywhere by the undisciplined armies. It was then also this learned doctor of both laws, and thoroughly instructed theologian, whom the pestilential influence seized, and whom they wove into their mysteries in that cave near Genoa. His associates were sorcerers and malefactors, Manichaeans, Anabaptists, Protestants, but above all atheists. Among these, without doubt, all those higher-order questions that moved the times had been discussed, and had led, by divided paths, out into uncertainty.

Protestantism had first awakened doubt, and carried it through all degrees to heathen pantheism, and finally to self-destruction in atheism. The Anabaptists on their part had pointed to mystical routes in order to attain truth in these matters; the malefactors boasted of a practice founded in a world other than the Christian; the Manichaeans promised to unlock this night-covered world, and so the journey to the Genoese cave was undertaken. That the Manichaeans were the ones who played the principal role in the abjuration of the Christian God and the subsequent admission into the fellowship of the evil prince is already shown by the indications of an ordered hierarchy that shine forth from the whole act. There were nine magicians, that is, Manichaeans, who were present at the rite, carrying pitch torches in their hands. Their hidden chief appears in the cave in human form, but wearing the mask of the Goat of Mendes.

They fall down before him, in the usual fashion paying him homage with the kiss a posteriori. Only the first among them, their bishop, then rises from the midst of those kneeling and brings the novice forward. The Manicheans, as they spread themselves in Italy, had united and ordered themselves under a fully developed hierarchy. From the trial of their adherents which the Inquisition held at the end of the thirteenth century in Ferrara it appears that the sect had bishops in all the principal places --- through the Ferrara, Mantua, Verona, Bergamo, Vicenza districts as far as Romandiola --- several of whom are named, as well as visitators, quaestors and messengers. By the zeal of the Inquisition and the crusades in France the league was broken at the beginning of the fourteenth century, but not exterminated. The ruins withdrew from the light of day and withdrew into the darkness that in any case had been their element; and we still see them so late, in the old holy ninefold of their heads, in that cave, a secret Carbonaria, assembling for recruitment.

Before the seat of the Master the question of the terms of the pact is now discussed. The desire of the one to be received concerns treasures, invisibility, the serviceability of demons at his command. The Master of the Rock agrees, on his part, on the condition that the initiate renounce God and His Church, and firmly believe that there is no other god than him, the demon. This touched directly upon that question earlier debated among the Genoese. "The exclusive godhood of the demon contradicts my reason," replies the novice, refusing to make such a profession. In truth this doctrine could hardly have pleased Manichaeism, because it rested on the denial of all that is spiritual, and would soon have to threaten even Satan himself in his existence. The chief magician, who was regarded as a bishop among the others, therefore stepped forward as mediator; and although he himself professed that doctrine, he permitted the novice to hold to it at his pleasure so long as he seriously acknowledged the duality of the divine being: one invisible who created spiritual things, and another who created the visible, corporeal things. \

According to his account these took a Father and two Sons as principles. They left the government of the super-world to the Father; of the sons, the younger had the dominion of the heavenly, the elder that of the underworld. In accordance with this threefold principle they themselves again divided into three parts. Some paid divine veneration to both sons at once, because they were, although often not in agreement, nevertheless children of the same father and would once more be received into grace. Others worshipped the younger only as lord of the higher region, without, however, refusing the older his honor, which they did not withhold for fear of harm from his power. Those among them who attained to the highest godlessness entirely renounced the service of that heavenly one and turned all their veneration to the elder, whom they called Satanaki and the firstborn, alienated from the Father, and acknowledged as the author of plants, animals and all composite bodies, together with all corruption and degeneration. To honor him especially highly, they impute to the heavenly all injustice: he envies his brother and persecutes him, who governs the earthly well, with the bitterest hatred, arousing earthquakes, hailstorms and famine; wherefore they, among all other imprecations, also utter that shameful anathema against him. \

Psellus likewise relates: the demons promised gold, possessions and honours, all of which they were in fact unable to provide. To the initiated they often presented many phantasms and fiery displays of light, which they dared to call theoptia or divine visions; and to obtain these they were obliged to undergo every shameful and abominable thing. He then speaks of the solid and liquid excrements of mankind, which they were bound to taste, because that made the demons favourably disposed toward them. He then explains their secret sacrifice. On the evening of the day on which we celebrate our Lord's Passion they would be brought into a house; there, with lights extinguished, all would intermingle without distinction. After the lapse of nine months they would then meet again in the same place. Four days after the birth the children would be taken from their mothers, all their blood drained off, and they would be burned alive on a pyre; the blood was then mixed with the ashes, and with that they contaminated food and drink, and that was their communion. They believe that thereby the symbols impressed on our soul are driven out and obliterated, so that the demons can gain access to it.1) All their deeds and endeavours are indeed directed to making the demons visible to them.

Later he also speaks of some among them who possessed a prophetic spirit. One of these, speaking of him in an assembly of his own people, once said: "Know that a man will be sent against us who will persecute our faith and abolish its customs! He will, like many others, put me also in chains; yet, however much he may toil, it will not succeed in bringing me hence bound to Byzantium." He described me at that time down to the very countenance, clothing and everything; and that at a time when I had not even passed the suburbs of Byzantium. When I had indeed captured him and asked him whence he had his gift of prophecy, at first he would not answer; but finally, forced to speak, he said that he had learned his arts from a wandering Libyan. This man, he related, led him at night to a mountain, made him taste of an herb, then spat into his mouth, anointed his eyes with an ointment, and caused him to see a multitude of demons, among whom he perceived one that flew toward him in the shape of a raven and entered through his mouth into his entrails. From that time until the present day he could look into the future, as often and in all matters as pleased his demon. Only on the days of the Cross and of the Passion, and on the day of the Resurrection, does he never, even if I wish it, reveal anything to me. But when one of the men struck one of them on the mouth, he said to him, "You will pay dearly for this one blow!" and, turning to me, "but you will suffer much misfortune in your body! For the demons whose service you have overthrown are very hostile to you, and have brought upon you dangers which you will not escape unless a power higher than theirs frees you from them." And all came to pass as he had foretold, and I narrowly met death in the many dangers that surrounded me, from which, contrary to expectation, the Redeemer delivered me.

The ways of the Abomination --- on which, in the deep Orient, they knew how to prepare the sacrament of Hell, under sin and homicide, and the bread of the abyss which, whoever has tasted it, attaches him to the nether-realm and, as we heard elsewhere, never lets him recover --- these ways had also been opened in the peninsula of the West; the deep had foamed its venom into the food, and the unhappy Manichaean had sat at its table. Now the trunk of the good, which springs up in man, had not, as if struck by frost, cast off its green leafy adornment; the axe had not cut away its branches and shortened the trunk itself down to the ground: the stump left behind would then still have been able to put forth new shoots. No --- the last root of what was better had been torn up, the last living germ killed; the higher symbols were all extinguished, and to the dreadful night of death that had now fallen the demons had free access; and the seed of evil, buried down in the depths, could now develop freely.

He was not possessed, now, in the manner in which possession is commonly understood --- an involuntary entanglement with the hostile power, therefore bound merely in the body; rather the soul had surrendered itself in full deliberation, and from it the body was then occupied with its full knowledge and will. The bird of darkness had flown down through his opened mouth into the depths of his heart, and there, finding already the culpable inclination for that youth, had fastened itself to it and made it the center of his whole being. Thus it was he himself who had committed the evil deed, while his suspicion clung continually to others; just as he, thinking himself the possessor of the demons, became possessed by them. Precisely because a reversal of his whole being had taken place, no notion of his condition remained to him; because no object, not even God, was present to him by which, through comparison, he might find his bearings. The ground of his condition appeared to him good and right, for he believed himself to be perfectly oriented; he was certain of his salvation in it. Only a small flaw disturbed his happiness --- the supposed enchantment with the youth, to which he endeavored to attach all the contradictions into which his perverse state had entangled him with the proper order of things. When, at night, one abyss within him called to another, and a hundred voices spoke blasphemies and vented their despair, then he found in their fury a relief for his flaming passion, and believed that it merely poured itself out there. The bondage of his body when the physician approached him, the grim mocking laugh that burst from him, and the grief that possessed him --- it was all, as he knew, the consequence of his own doing; his caprice, however, had only surrendered to vicissitudes; another power, which continued itself alone in his will, had made the choice.

This power had bound him with fetters of necessity, and this necessity was not the expression of a power that binds in love under the law of order; but of a violence, hating and destroying in the division of lawlessness, that compelled him to all evil. Thus he was the true canon of a condition that will hereafter meet us more often; a condition that united him intimately with everything that in any way created evil on earth. \

#### B. Effects of Judaism on the Art of Witchcraft

The Jews, scattered in the midst of Christendom, and having for so many centuries penetrated and in part overgrown it, necessarily had to exert a historical influence in every sphere, despite the hatred long heaped upon them; and thus even that which here demands our attention could least escape their influence. Talmud and Kabbalah had effected the construction and development of a twofold realm of spirits: opposite the paradise, which rises in seven steps, each placed under the ward of an angel, they had deepened a hell, fashioned pyramidally in Dantesque fashion, pierced by seven streams of fire, and guarded by just as many angels of destruction.

Above all these Satanim or Opponents, Schedim or Desolators, Seirim or Terribles --- the sum of all dark powers --- was to them S'maäl, Satan par excellence; whose Schechina, or feminine part, is called Lilith or the serpent; and all of them together sought only to spread ruin everywhere and to restore the state of Chaos. Samael, the alien god, was a servant of the Most Blessed; but since he has made himself a god, the Most Blessed will in time sweep away the fallen and entirely destroy the impious servant. \

Just as there are degrees on the holy side, so also on the unclean; and as there man and woman are contained as one there, so also here; and Samael's consort was the serpent; and from the day when this evil serpent, who is the death of the world, persuaded Adam, she obtained dominion over him, until the King Mashiach comes. For by the poison which she hurled upon him, Satan has gained a permanent assault upon man. Great therefore is the power permitted to Satan by God over the world; the Satanim dwell with man and beside him, and mock him; and their purpose is to do him harm, and they pursue his blood.

Not only does Satan draw to himself those who voluntarily surrender to him; he also persecutes the pious, and disturbs their well-being by the Ruach Thesaṣṣith, the spirit of confusion or possession. The man in whom such an evil spirit has entered does everything he does and says by the inspiration of the evil spirit that is in him. Thus it was also with the serpent in the case of Eve: all that she did and spoke came from Samael. In the city of Ferrara a Jewish woman was thus possessed; she fell into a stupor, and a voice issued from her throat while her lips were without movement, and the voice spoke. In the time of Luria there was a widow into whom a Ruach had entered, and it inflicted extraordinary torments upon her. People went to her, spoke with her, and received answers to what they asked. The relatives of the woman came to Loriah, and begged him that he would drive the Ruach out of the woman. Loriah sent his pupil R. Chaim Vital, and gave him certain holy names with him, and told him what intention he was to observe in the matter. He also commanded him that he should pronounce over the Ruach the small and great ban, and should by force drive it out. When R. Chaim came to the woman, she turned her face away from him. R. Chaim said: Why do you turn away? The Ruach answered: I cannot look you in the face. Then R. Vital commanded that it must turn around, which immediately happened. He now asked the spirit: who are you? whereupon it related its former criminal life. It said it had formerly been a Jew, and had already been wandering in the world for twenty‑five years, incessantly pursued by three angels of destruction. Vital further asked: who gave it permission to enter the woman? The Ruach said: I was in the house when the woman rose in the morning and wanted to strike a fire. When the tinder would not catch, she became angry and threw the tinderbox out of her hands in rage and said: "Go to Satan!" From this word "Satan" I obtained permission to enter her. Although the woman sinned through the sin of unbelief, and did not believe in the Exodus from Egypt, yet the Ruach had no opportunity to enter her until she, in anger, mentioned the name "Satan."

As the good service is directed toward purification and sanctification and the restoration of the original harmony, so opposed to it is an evil service, directed to the unclean and dark --- the discord of that harmony. This demonic service reaches its height when a person, with full will, delivers his soul in a formal covenant to Satan; keeps a personal intercourse with him and his followers; at appointed times delights himself with them by dances, orgies and other excesses; and now he and Satan serve one another mutually. For it is known that all sorcerers and sorceresses make a covenant with the Shed, and deliver their soul to it.

Such a man goes forth from the dominion of God, and yields his spirit to the unclean side. And by the magic words which he utters, when he invites the unclean spirits to his shadow, two Ruchin appear; and they arrange themselves in his shadow, in the form of men, and are contained therein, and communicate to him matters in order to do evil, sometimes also to perform good. All kinds of witchcraft in the world are connected and proceed from the ancient serpent, which is the unclean spirit; therefore all the witchcrafts of the world are called serpent‑arts. There are also women who have made a pact with the Shedim, and at certain times meet with them, dance with them, and attend those spirits which appear to them as bucks. In many states such women are put to death; for although their crime consists in no external, but only in an internal, imaginative act, the death-penalty is nevertheless just, because they have wholly surrendered themselves to Satan.

It also happens, that when a man dreams, female Ruchin come to him, excite themselves with him, solicit themselves from him, and afterwards bear children. In the same way male Ruchin come to women and impregnate them, so that they beget Ruchin. Great also is the power of the evil eye. For it rules over a thing which takes place with pomp and noise, even when it is brought about by a miracle. The Ruchin do not all belong, however, to the more wicked orders; there are also elemental spirits, namely such as consist of the element of fire, invisible but inclined to good, the salamanders of the Middle Ages; others formed of fire and air, the sylphs of that order, likewise invisible, and wise and good. The third class consists of fire, air and water, at times perceptible to the senses, their life being of a plant-like kind, the undines of the middle period; finally the fourth order, in which a substance of earth is added, visible and of a more mineral nature, belonging with the foregoing to the side of Samael. They all dwell in the upper, inner circles of the elements, and know the near future; their food is the incense with which they are fumigated; according to the fineness of their elemental body is also the degree of their spiritual rank.

From all these citations, which reach down from the beginning of the 17th century to the older times of the Zohar, it follows how, besides possessions, also the whole witch- and sorcery-craft, the entire visionary and operative black magic, the incubus and the succubus, and likewise natural magic, were perfectly well known to the Jews; and that all these black arts, entirely analogous to those that prevailed in Christianity, developed themselves --- which of course proceeds from the commonness of the root, but also testifies to the continuing contact of both.

The people of the Jews have, by temperament, been a mystical people before many others; and this temperament has likewise decisively helped their reputation as the chosen people in ancient times. Such a bent made it possible to lead this people out of bondage into a conquered fatherland, and to hold them there for so many centuries, bound under theocratic forms; and the whole history of this realm, and even its fall into death and horror, amid the turmoil of every passion, bears witness to this mystical, full-blooded vein which runs through its otherwise harshness and obstinacy. But even after the judgment had come, and the nation was scattered, this side of their tribal character did not fade; and it especially manifested itself whenever their hope for a coming Redeemer moved their whole mind in its inmost depths. When that "son of the star," Bar Chochéba, for the first time awakened and deceived that hope in them, the enthusiasm for their new king burst forth into bright flames, which could only be extinguished by a bloodbath worse than that which Titus had wrought among them.

In the year 432 that other Moses appeared on the island of Crete and proclaimed that he had been sent to earth a second time in order to lead Israel again into the land of their fathers, on dry feet through the divided waves of the sea. The people, seized by enthusiasm, abandoned their trades, gave away their property, and followed their leader to the seashore; and there, at his command, without wavering in their faith, crowds from the heights cast themselves into the sea and were swallowed by the waves. The survivors explained the calamity that had befallen them by saying that it had been a ruach from the dark side, one of the demons of Samael, that had seduced them.

It was just the same with all the others; and when, at the beginning of the seventeenth century, Sabbatai Zevi in the Orient proclaimed himself the son of David and the long-expected Redeemer, Nathan of Gaza --- who had become clairvoyant, pronouncing past things of which he could not have known by natural means; who saw visions and prophesied of the future --- declared him such. Soon prophets and prophetesses rose up in Samaria, Adrianople, Thessalonica, Constantinople and many other places: men, women, youths and girls, even children, were seized by the prophetic spirit. They fell suddenly to the ground as if epileptic, had violent convulsions, and in that state uttered, both in Hebrew and in Aramaic --- languages of which they had previously not understood a word --- wonderful and extraordinary things, both long past and yet to come. Every such prophecy concluded with the words: "Sabbatai Zevi is the true Messiah, from the house of David, to whom crown and kingdom are given!" \

This impetuous, inflammable people --- which, once kindled, burns long afterward --- had now, after it had misconceived its historical vocation and missed the solution of the problem assigned to it, the fate of seeing itself given over to the captivity of the nations for a third time; this time, so that it, to use the expression of Pope Innocent III, as "the living witness of the true Christian faith" he led his life among them. In Germany they were regarded as chamber-servants of the realm, over whom the emperor exercised authority; likewise in the other kingdoms of the Christian West. The powerful vassals in every case had parcelled the unhappy people out among themselves, and, treating them as serfs and, by the strict letter of the law, stripping them of all personal, property and contractual rights, had added them to their domains. Though the popes, especially in earlier times --- Innocent II and III, Alexander III and Gregory IX --- urged leniency; though the bishops sheltered them against inhuman violences; and the synods regulated their relations with Christians: they served hard bondage, and each year hatred would sharpen anew against them when the observance of the days of suffering recurred, and the people, prone to merriment, allowed themselves blasphemies against the mysteries, or sometimes even ascribed them to the Jews.

As compensation to the oppressed, the riches of Christendom were allotted to them; even the church treasures were not excepted; the day was to come when the consecrated gold would be handed over into their hands by its keepers. The fulfillment of this promise was bound up with the magnetic attraction that exists between metal and genuine avarice, and with the sober cunning and industry of this class of people. Thus they always succeeded in getting hold of the largest portion of the circulating money supply, and they continued to practise usury with it at the enormous interest rates customary for the time and country. The joy in ever-increasing possessions made the lot of the oppressed easier. The mighty, for whose account they in part lent and acquired, protected them; but the people, who felt themselves doubly drained by lords and by servants, burned more and more with fury against the arts of usury; moreover with envy and ill will against the rising prosperity of the ever-multiplying foreigners, who, like parasitic plants, entwined and sucked away the native stock. \

"What I say to you, O King, concerning the Jews," says the abbot, "is well known to all. Not by diligent tilling of the soil, not by lawful service in war, not by any honourable and useful occupation do they fill their barns with fruits, their cellars with wine, their sacks with money, their chests with gold and silver; but solely from that which they win from Christians by deceit, which they buy from thieves at a bad price." If a robber breaks into a Christian church anywhere, if he brazenly carries off candlesticks, jugs, censers, even the holy cross or the consecrated chalices; then he avoids the Christians, seeks out the Jews, and, enjoying accursed security with them, he not only has his den of thieves in their midst, but sells what was stolen from the holy Church to the synagogue of Satan. The vessels that contained the Body and the Blood of Christ he hands over to those who killed that Body and shed His blood; who then, when He walked among mortals, did Him every outrage, and now, seated in the Majesty of the Godhead, do not cease to persecute Him with their blasphemies. Even those holy vessels themselves, which they preserve, as formerly the Chaldeans preserved theirs, remain therefore --- though they themselves have no feeling --- not free from reproach; and they are, as I have often heard from trustworthy men, put to a use which is already a horror to imagine, and an abomination to speak of.

But that is not enough! So that such dishonorable theft and the Jewish fence might be secured, an old, truly demonic law, issued by Christian princes, has prevailed: that if a church utensil, and what is worse, a holy vessel, is found in the possession of a Jew, he shall not be bound to return the church theft, nor to betray the unworthy robber.

Those were burning words, words of reproach for the powerful of the time who, like William II of England, accepted gold from Jewish fathers to deter by threats and persuasions their sons who wished to become Christians; flaming words which, kindling in every heart, explain --- if they never justify --- the barbarity with which passion then acted in that age. The Talmud tells the people of Israel: the shooting lights that fall nightly from the stars are the tears which Elohim twice daily weeps over the captivity of His people; every morning, for the same reason, He roars like a lion, stamping the firmament with His feet. Like a turtledove He utters a cry of lament each day, rocking His head and crying, "Woe! woe upon me! that I have made my house a wilderness, broken and burned my temple, and scattered my sons among the nations." A people that in this way carried all its pride into its humiliation, and laid its sorrow in the bosom of its God, must deeply rage over the ill‑treatment and the scorn it endured, and a violent reaction must kindle in the sulphur‑fields of its passion. Defenceless and long unaccustomed to courage, as the Jews had grown in their servility, this reaction could not rise openly, eye for eye, against their persecutors; it was forced to choose secret ways in order to strike more safely. Hence, from that time forth, the legends of poisoning wells and running waters; the legends of sacrament‑theft, to assuage wrath against the substitute of the Crucified; and finally, in order to wound those hateful oppressors in the depths of their hearts, the seizing of their children to make of them victims of vengeance.

The oldest example of such a robbery appears to be that of the boy William of Norwich, whom the English Jews in the year 1144, in the ninth year of King Stephen, thus abducted and cruelly put to death in Passion Week; to which the French, following this precedent, in the year 1171 likewise sacrificed a boy at Easter in Blois, and were therefore delivered to the fire by Count Theobald; and in the year 1179, when those of Paris crucified the boy Richard of Pontoise. In the year 1181 news again came over from England: the Jews had treated the boy Robert at St. Edmund in just the same way as in 1160 under Henry with the one from Gloucester; the great uprising of 1180 was the consequence of this.

In all these cases, however, there was no formal investigation; the murdered were venerated by the people as saints, and the miracles performed by their relics served as a guarantee for everything that legend told --- a guarantee which was not in all cases irrefragable, since the people brought their own excitement into the matter; and this excitement probably sometimes even produced miracles at human remains, about which the Inquisition later had to pronounce the sentence of condemnation.

The courtiers now told, at the coronation of Philip Augustus, to the young king in their levity: in his father's time the Jews in Paris had every year sacrificed a boy --- as in this case Robert of Pontoise --- to the derision of the Christians; and they were thereupon arrested throughout France, their Christian creditors were released from every debt, and then they were all expelled from the realm, and their movable goods awarded to the king; a decree which, however, was revoked in 1108, because it was felt with regret that one had killed the hen that laid the golden eggs. The Jews, on their side, answered this harshness at Brienne by accusing a Christian of homicide and by taking a bankrupt peasant --- whom the local countess had delivered to them --- and crowning him with thorns, beating him through the town with sticks, and then hanging him; for which 82 of them had to make atonement by death by fire.

From then on the boy-murders recur throughout the whole course of the thirteenth century. When Henry III in England had driven the Jews by his exactions to the utmost, so that they themselves asked to emigrate with their goods, their bitterness produced in the year 1255 the outrage at Lincoln. They had, as the chronicles of the country relate, abducted the nine-year-old boy Hugh from his children's play into the house of Jopinus, there starved and scourged him for 26 days, cut open the wings of his nose, cut off his upper lip, and smashed in his teeth; then stuck him all over the body with needles, and finally killed him with a lance-wound. The body had been drawn up from a well; numerous miracles had strengthened the suspicion against the Jews, who were arrested. John of Lessinan conducted the trial, and since their chief rabbi Jopinus had been promised his life, he confessed everything. He was nevertheless dragged to death behind a horse; 18 suffered the same death later in London, and the remaining 60 escaped the same fate only through the intercession of the Dominicans and Richard, the king's brother. \

After the middle of the century it became notorious that in Hispalis there had been opened a Jewish propaganda directed against Christians; and in secret assemblies, in the midst of apostates, terrible blasphemies were uttered. Two inquisitors were therefore sent there in 1482 to investigate the matter. To their edict, which allowed forty days for the apostates to return, 17,000 of them yielded; the others were sought out, and had either to pay with their lives or, confined in sacks, to do penance. But when Granada fell; when fears of the contagion spreading among the people grew ever stronger; when Jews in the town of La Guardia were accused of having stolen the Sacrament of the Eucharist and committed sacrilege upon it; when they were said to have nailed a stolen child to a cross --- then, in the year 1492, the edict went forth that all Jews must leave Spain within three months under penalty of death; their goods they might sell and take with them. An enormous terror fell upon them, and by the hundred thousands they went over to Africa, Greece, Romania, Egypt and Babylonia; others fled to Portugal, France, Italy, Germany; many perished in shipwreck or at the hands of pirates: it was a calamity greater than that which they suffered in the time of Titus and Hadrian, and it even stirred the compassion of Christians toward them.

In the century that ran from 1394, when Charles VI likewise again drove them out of France, to this catastrophe, we again find the child‑murders reappearing with force, and now by means of judicial inquiry taking on a more documentary character. Outstanding among them, above many others, is the story of the boy Simon, who was born in Trento in the year 1472 of poor parents, and in the year 1475 found his death at the hands of the Jews. At the instigation of the old Moses, who was reputed to be a seer, knowing the day and hour of the Messiah's coming, their elders---Tobias, Angelus and Samuel, in whose house the synagogue was---had resolved to sacrifice a Christian boy at the Easter festival. But since their servants refused the plotted seizure of such a one, Tobias at last undertook it himself, his medical profession giving him the best opportunity to execute the commission. The boy was brought in, hidden for a time in the synagogue, and on the appointed day was most cruelly murdered. The corpse was concealed by the murderers for some time, because the elders searched everywhere for the child with armed men; and finally, as the danger pressed all too near upon the awakened suspicion, it was thrown into the nearby flowing water, and the discovery was then reported to the authorities.

The bishop ordered the most exacting inquiry; the Schultheiß Johannes and the prefect Jacob de Sporo were appointed as judges; they summoned Archangelus Baldin of Trento, Math(eus) Tiberinus of Brescia, Chr(istus) de Fatis of Turlach, as physicians and surgeons, to report on the condition of the corpse and its wounds, and the report sharpened the grounds for suspicion. The Jews were brought in; they chose the most eminent jurists at the University of Padua as their defenders; their statements contradicted one another, torture finally forced the full confession which---being found to agree completely with the circumstances (one had, for example, also discovered the hidden flask containing the collected blood)---now resulted in the judicial condemnation of the proved perpetrators, the expulsion of the Jews from Trento, and the transformation of the synagogue into a chapel of the miracle‑working murdered one. All this is reported by the physician M. Tiberinus in an authentic letter to the senate and citizens of Brescia. The deed had taken place on the night of 23 March; the sentence was executed on 21 June; in the three months between the rumor ran through all Italy. \

On 22 April the Doge of Venice, P. Mocenigo, issued a mandate; it was believed that the rumor of a boy murdered by the Jews had been invented only for certain purposes; he, however, wished that the Jews should dwell undisturbed and secure in his lands; he therefore forbade any change in their condition, and prohibited preachers and other persons from stirring up the people against them. That was without doubt worthy, just and sensible; but when meanwhile the trial had taken its course and led to the result above mentioned, then a second decree of 12 August of the same year revoked that judgment, permitted the carrying about of the images of the martyr, allowed preachers to treat the deed from the pulpit, but even then forbade them to incite the people against the Jews; because those who were not guilty could not be struck by the punishment. \

In September the magistrate of Trento wrote a letter to Venice --- still to be found in the archive of St. Franciscus de Vinea --- in which he reports the affair in complete agreement with Tiberianus, and among other things says: "how the judges, although they were deeply moved by the murder, and well recognized the deceit and guile of the Jews, their cunning, their hatred against the Church, and the corrupting power of their gold, nevertheless dealt with them so moderately, with such gravity and such leniency, that whoever runs through the records will rather complain of excessive indulgence and tenderness than of severity. Torture, it is true, finally wrested the truth from them; but after Tobias had first confessed, all, as with one mouth, confirmed the matter with regard to place, time, circumstances, and those who had been present. It is moreover not the first time that such things have occurred." 1) These and the immediately following, still entirely unedited documents are taken from the work: De Cultu sancti Simonis pueri Tridentini, et martyris apud veteres in --- (title in the Crela sacra) sive de episcopis utriusque Ritus graeci et latini in Insula Venet. 1755. In the appendix five shorter writings of the author Flaminius Cornelins, senator in Venice. The first document p. 63. 2) Ibid. p. 67. Görres, chrihl. Mystie. 1v. 2. 5

Since time immemorial the same thing, it says, has occurred in Speyer on the Rhine, likewise in Dortmund in Westphalia, in Maastricht in the duchy of Guelders. In the place Dutsch, between Cologne and Aachen, two boys were likewise sacrificed; two others in the town of Penigen in Swabia; in Upper Bavaria in Amberg one; in the Palatinate at Alzey another; in Endingen in the margraviate of Baden two, whose parents were also murdered; recently moreover the whole of Christendom has learned what occurred in Sicily." 3) As the multiplying miracles in the meantime further spread the cult of the murdered boy, a breve of Pope Sixtus IV of 10 October 1475 forbade this beatification until the proper inquiry before the papal throne, to which the decision alone belongs, should take place; at the same time taking the Jews under the protection of the Church; and the Doge had commanded that this breve be obeyed in his territory. Several cardinals and other prelates were then appointed commissioners for the examination of the process records; and after these had thoroughly examined the whole business, on 20 June 1478 the entire legal procedure was completely approved as irreproachable; and the veneration was then permitted, although no breve concerning it remains.

Five years had hardly passed since this murder-story in the neighboring Trentine territory, when the Senate of Venice had occasion, in its own jurisdiction at Portubuffaleto in the province of Friuli, to learn by experience that the tales which formerly circulated among the people about such matters were by no means unfounded. The Jews Servadeus and Moyses had set about Jakob, the son of Simon of Cologne, and another of the same name: to procure for them, at Easter time, a boy; and they had, following the suggestion, in Treviso found Sebastian Novello of Bergamo, a seven-year-old poor child, and persuaded him to follow them to Portubuffaleto; where then, on Maundy Thursday, they all together killed him. The perpetrators were brought to Venice, the trial was conducted in all lawful form, and the condemned were then burned on the Piazza San Marco, between the two columns. 5) According to others, five years later, on 5 April 1485, in Marostica, in the territory of Vicenza, the boy Lorenz suffered the same death; and the Jews were on that account expelled forever from that territory. \

News came then from the Orient that they had bought a Christian slave from the sea‑robbers in Pontus and crucified him; and in Crete the syndic Gradonicus had reported that the people there, in derision, had crucified lambs. (1) About the same time, in the year 1486, according to the chronicles in Regensburg, six children were sacrificed in that manner. In the year 1540 the four‑year‑old boy Michael, according to Rader's Bavaria sancta III. B., was slaughtered at Easter in Heitingen; while in the year 1579 it was reported from Lithuania how a boy Sinnat and a girl Elisabeth, both seven years old, in the village Punie lost their lives at the hands of the Jew Joachim Sinerlovicz, with the consent of others.

In the year 1650, still, at Cadana in Bohemia on 11 March, the four‑year‑old boy Matthias was killed, to whom Ferdinand III caused a monument to be erected. Since then the matter was lost sight of until it reappeared in our days in Damascus --- a welcome opportunity for the newspapers and journals to chatter over the subject with their accustomed shallowness and vapidity, making use of the usual phrasemongering, and then to dismiss it as finally disposed of. But these murder‑stories had so deeply impressed themselves on the popular consciousness that they became the subject of popular song; and the strain beginning:

"The rain rins doun through Mirry‑land toune, Sae dois it doune the Pa: Sae dois the lads of Mirry‑land toune; Duhan they play at the ba' . . ."

is a relic of that popular poetry, in which "Mirryland toune" is very likely Milan, and "the Pa" denotes the Po.

In all these mutually provoking outbreaks of fury --- the wolf‑like rage of Christians against the Jews, and the hyena‑like reactions of the latter against the former --- the paw of the tearing beast that sleeps in the breast of man was only made visible; Hell had, by its breath, exhaled nothing but horrors, and the demonic had visibly entered the world. The imagination of the peoples, kept in constant excitement by the oft‑dreamed and sometimes palpable nearness of the outrage, accustomed itself not to recoil before the most monstrous; and, thus poisoned at its inmost root, brooded further upon the abominations with which it had become familiar. In this way blasphemies practised against all that is holy, the atrocious mistreatments of the plundered sacred things, the murderous deeds against children carried out under the most revolting circumstances, penetrated even into the Sabbath --- things that occur all too often to be other than rooted in the morbid condition of imagination of an infected age. \

To the frequently recurring tales of poisoned wells were then joined those of the power of poison‑brewers extended also over the other elements, of weather‑making, and of the devastation of the vegetable world. One knows what power the Jews have ascribed to the Schem‑Hamphoraſch: it not only unlocks the word of man, but makes below the voice of animals intelligible, above the speech of ministering angels and the demons of the abyss; it makes the world of thought accessible and opens the view into the future. He who knew how to bind the Word could create a new world; Moses worked his wonders by it, the prophets prophesied by it, even Jesus --- who learned it from Jehoshua in Egypt --- brought forth wondrous things by it. It embraced not only, like the name Jehova, God's essence within itself, but at the same time also his omnipotence, omniscience, truth, righteousness, and mercy; it was written at the entrance of the Temple of Jerusalem on the stone that Jacob had anointed with oil; but in the burning of the Temple in the time of the Romans it was lost together with the stone; and the later Jews devised substitutes for it, and their legend has much to praise about what their rabbis effected with them. It is the symbol of the higher mysticism and prophetic gift as it existed in earlier Israel, but it retreated with the first captivity, and with the beginning of Christianity it was wholly lost; whereupon deceitful human contrivances and wicked witchcraft took its place.

##### Jewish Magic

All branches of the demonic arts have flourished merrily among the Jews: the interpreters of dreams, rabdomancy, casting lots and interpreting signs, the Iyur, astrology, amulets, the teraphim and necromancy. Everything at all times found its cultivation among them, and even today in the Orient Jewish women prepare love potions for the wives of the harem. The legend of the Jewish Faust accordingly runs through all the centuries of the modern era. The rabbi J. Scheda already boasts in the Sohar how much artistic skill he learned from a demon, a circumstance from which he also obtained his name. The Jew Sedechias, who lived in the time of Louis the Pious, had --- the chroniclers tell --- set himself the task of convincing people of the existence of the elementary spirits, as the Kabbalists interpreted them. He therefore commanded them to show themselves visibly. They did so in all their splendor, and one saw in the air a wonderful spectacle. Beings in human form showed themselves, arranged as if in battle order, now moving in good formation, now standing quietly under arms, or encamped beneath splendid pavilions. Sometimes they had embarked in air-ships of wondrous construction, and the fleet then sailed, driven by gentle winds, through the blue. \

That was the same phenomenon that one has so often seen elsewhere, e.g. in the Scottish Highlands. Thus Walker relates, for example: In the year 1686, during the months of June and July, a large number of people were assembled at the Croftfoord ferry, two miles below Lanark, on the Clyde; they saw trees and the ground covered with caps, hats, swords and weapons. Armed men marched in order down to the water's edge; one troop met another; they passed through one another, crossed, then sat down and vanished, and others then took their places. I myself went three afternoons in succession, and as far as I could see there were among the assembled two who saw, always one who did not see; and although I myself saw nothing, all those who were in my position could not fail to perceive the fear and terror of the seers. Beside me stood one who said: "A pack of damned herren and sorcerers, who have the second sight; the devil rides them, that I see!" At once, however, a complete change came over all the features of his face, and such fear and trembling seized him as any one of the women I saw there; and the exclamation followed: "O all of you who see nothing, judge not; for I tell you, it is all true, and manifest to all who are not stone-blind!" The seers described meanwhile the appearance of the pieces of ordnance, their length and their caliber; the sword-hilts, whether they were narrow or triangular, or furnished with Highland tanged blades, likewise the points of the black or blue caps. And all who saw such things beheld, wherever they might look, everywhere a cap and a sword in the way. I have hitherto tried in vain to discover a foundation for this latter circumstance.

What occurred here in Scotland is the same as what happened a thousand years earlier in France; only that here the cabalist Sedechias was on the scene, who explained to the seers their visions out of the elemental spirits of Jewish doctrine; and the people at once connected the matter with Magonia and the air-ships of that mythical land, which, with Lombardic sorcerer‑poisons, ruined his crops. This same Sedechias, moreover, was the Jewish Faust of the Carolingian era, and Trithemius relates of him that he threw a man into the air, cut him into pieces, and then restored him whole and sound; also that, before all the spectators, he swallowed a cart of hay with horse and man. At the end of the 13th century the Rabbi Fechiel, a great cabalist of his time, was summoned to the French court. The Jews revered him as a saint, but the Parisians shunned him as a magician. It was said that he worked every night by the light of an inextinguishable lamp; the people gathered at his house to disturb his sorcery. Then he struck with a large hammer upon a nail; immediately the earth opened and swallowed the intruders. --- This expresses the popular notion of the Jews' magical powers, which remained the same in the centuries that followed. Rabbi Chanina had, he said, bought from an elderly man a toad for eighty florins in two silver vessels, from which he learned the law of Moses, the seventy languages of the peoples, as well as the languages of birds and four‑footed beasts. J. Karro had made use of a spirit for the study of the Mishnah. Rabbi Elias of Worms, Isaac Hünerfänger, Rabbi Levi of Moravia, Naphtali Lohen of Frankfurt, and others were later called great sorcerers; in the guise of a boy, of an eagle, of a raven the spirit had initiated them into the secret science. Often, therefore, the Jews in large numbers were suspected of sorcery; that Chanina was accordingly burned alive; in Ascalon, on one day, eighty Jewish women were hanged by Simeon ben Sehetah for magical poisoning; Thuringia likewise expelled the Jews precisely on the accusation of witchcraft.

Since the Kabbalah enjoyed such great repute, it was natural that the Jews gave themselves to it with all zeal; but, moreover, the persecution they suffered in that period had to lead them over to their demonic side. If they succeeded in gaining allies in the realm of spirits, they could then easily put an end to the oppressive supremacy of the Christians, and take vengeance for the outrages which they had to endure from them; not to speak of the hidden treasures over which such princes of spirits presided. According to the tradition of the Sohar, the eagle had already brought to King Solomon the two fallen angels who dwelt below in the deep abyss practising sorcery, and taught it to everyone who desired it; and he had learned many hidden things from them. Sacrifices offered to Samael that he should not accuse the chosen people before God on the Day of Atonement were, in any case, already customary. (3) The disposition to every form of ecstasy was, as we have seen, likewise highly developed in that people; their dispersion over all parts of the world brought them into contact with every centre of the art of magic, especially among the Saracens, and above all in the northwest of Africa, among the Moroccans.

The wound of suffered evils burned without ceasing; the perpetration of so many crimes in reaction made them fear nothing; shall we then wonder that the black art in that time found numerous practitioners among this people, and that the literature of magic books is especially attached to the Jews? The Jews, however, were then the general leaseholders of the princes: their revenues, customs and taxes passed through Jewish hands; they were the money-changers from whom all the powerful borrowed; often officials, in order to give weight to their business, and in conducting it protected by special rights. Early already they had also appropriated the medical profession to themselves, and while this profession sharpened its gaze into the nature of things, it also increased their influence on Christian society. \

#### C. The Arrival of the Gypsies

About the year 1417, in the time of Emperor Sigismund, a people of about 3,000 souls migrated into Moldavia; there settling near Szesava, and soon strengthened by those who followed, spreading over Wallachia, Transylvania and Hungary; and the king soon granted them, in written letters, the right to settle around the royal towns and on the royal domains. They called themselves Zincalo, contracted in the plural to Cales, "black men," or Chai, also Romano; at times also Sinti, thereby pointing to India, from whence they had immigrated. This account found confirmation in the language they spoke, the Romany, which takes its foundation from the Samserida and has appropriated many Persian, Slavic and modern Greek roots; which then led the English to search in India for the tribe from which this people had been derived; in consequence of which they recognized, among the native aborigines in the North-Indian mountains, the sought-for root. The strangers, for their part, declared at that time: at first they had migrated from Little Egypt or Chali, where they had previously lived, until, being granted to an enemy of God, they were driven back.

They were thence driven away. For a Pharaoh of the land had, it is said, overcome all the peoples of the world, and finally, in his pride, challenged God himself and his heavenly host to battle. God, however, refusing the challenge, to punish him opened a wide cave in the side of a mountain, and a storm-wind then blew the Pharaoh with his host into that abyss, which thereupon closed over them. Whoever now on St. John's night approaches the mountain, hears the king with his army ever singing and sounding. But since the Pharaoh had thus vanished, all the kings and peoples who had previously obeyed his realm rose up against it; and easily conquered the defenceless people, drove out the vanquished, and scattered them over the whole world. \

They were therefore also driven out, and they called themselves on that account Chat, the people of Chal; or in Hungary Pharaoh Nepet, people of the Pharaoh. Thus they belonged to the raging host, and were in the retinue of the overbearing Ashen‑king Sesostris; but when God overthrew the proud and shut him up in the Egyptian Horus‑mountain, when his rule overthrew the old heathenism, then they were expelled, and the old Tannhäuser went to Rome to obtain from the Pope absolution for his sins. They were therefore driven from their old dwelling-place as the consequence of a religious struggle; and if one considers that some dim notions of the transmigration of souls remained to them amid their religious indifference --- a doctrine which is found only in Buddhism --- then the great wars of the Buddhists with the Brahmins may easily have been the occasion of their expulsion.

From their original Indian homeland they then probably passed over Persia, where Ferdoussi already mentions them in the eleventh century; and then into Little Egypt, probably the Delta, later settling among the pictish and they may perhaps have traversed Asia along the same route which in primeval times the Indians followed, who, according to the Chronicle of Eusebius, migrated into the Nile‑land. There they still live under the name of the Ghaste, and from there have spread through North Africa; Leo the African seems to mention them under the name Zingari, as plunderers of the caravans from Agades to Bornu; and the Dar‑Buschi‑Fals or fortune‑tellers in Morocco, who speak their own language distinct from the Shilha and from Arabic, probably likewise belong to their root. \

In the same way, as they passed through Asia, hordes were left everywhere; and while there the whole manners and customs of certain tribes, the Luri for example, recall them, swarms of them perhaps turned northwards via Astrakhan and spread into Russia. From Egypt the flights of these migratory birds then set out over Syria and Asia Minor on their migration to the third part. Crossing the Bosphorus, they first spread in the Byzantine realm; the whole Hæmus range from Abydos to Philippopolis gained from them the name Tschenghe Balkan; and from there they filled Bulgaria, probably incorporating from their contact with the local peoples Greek, Slavic and Wallachian roots into their language. After they had obtained a safe‑conduct from Emperor Sigismund in Hungary, and thus traversed all Germany to the North Sea, a division actually went via Bohemia and Switzerland in the year 1422 to Rome, to obtain the same from the Pope for the whole of Christendom. Since they, it seems, were at least not refused, they were thenceforth regarded as those on whom the Pope himself had imposed a seven‑year pilgrimage as penance; they were therefore spared and honored as poor itinerants, and from there spread over all the lands of Europe, as far as Spain; where they are called by all the peoples through whose lands they gradually passed the names Moors, Little Egyptians, Bohemians and Germans, and are traced back to Tatars, Persians, Cilicians and Nubians.

A wild, coarse people --- thus these Gypsies appeared to the chroniclers of that time, setting out for booty and carrion like birds of prey; and in this they were akin to the race of pleasure‑seekers, in that they direct all their thoughts only to the next moment and live wholly in it. They therefore at all times showed themselves restless, frivolous and mobile even in their mien, in all their doings as inconstant as air and water; with great cowardice yet, according to the circumstances, madly daring, cringing before every superiority, cruel and vengeful toward the weak, treacherous besides, and hot‑tempered, quarrelsome, vain and boastful beyond measure; besides this inclined to idleness, gluttony and every kind of sensual indulgence. Much cleverness, spirit and ability, however, are ascribed to them; above all, however, directed toward, by cunning craftiness, outwitting and injuring all those who are not of their blood, and whom they pursue with inherited hatred to deadly effect. Musical talent in particular is not uncommon among them; a certain skill too in the few trades they practise, for example iron‑smithing; but even greater deceitfulness in wheeling and dealing in horses and in every form of theft.

Thus these tribes, who on their arrival called themselves by an equally Egyptian word, Roma --- in their tongue "house‑fathers" --- were distinguished from all other peoples by the peculiar, fixed and gleaming light of their eyes; and so they have remained unchanged to this hour during the four centuries since their immigration. Their ephemeral existence, decided in the bare instant and drifting along carelessly with it, never allowed a serious religious idea to arise in them; without faith, without rites and without tradition they everywhere conformed to the religion of the country in which they lived, without further incurring the trouble of observing its practices. The same is true of their conjuring art. When, on their arrival, they wandered through Europe and were still received hospitably --- in and about the barns and sheds, in the neighbourhood of combustible materials they frequently kindled fires, and nothing burned there but the material placed into it --- they ascribed this to the peculiar natural power of the "fire‑root," which grows in Little Egypt on a high mountain, and of which they yearly obtained a large quantity from there. That was one of the elements of this art which they had brought from the Orient; others they picked up on the roads along which they travelled; and just as their language in this way adopted many foreign roots, so these magical roots were gathered into the stock of their knowledge and skill.

When, on these flights and journeys of theirs, the lodestone (magnet ironstone) came before them, their childish imagination saw in it a symbol of their thievish instinct, of sexual attraction, and of the faculty for smelling out hidden treasures; and it so took possession of them that they ascribed to it --- which they call Bar‑Lachi --- all miraculous powers, and believed of one who possessed such a talisman that he had nothing to fear from steel and lead, water and fire; that death had no power over him, that it made him invisible to his pursuers, and that it was excellently suited for love‑potions. They likewise ascribed very similar properties to the Gospels, when Berrow spread a translation of them into their language among them, which they at once carried with them on their thieving expeditions as a protecting charm. "All that our people truly believe they have learned from you," an old gypsy said to Grellmann; and indeed the charms they have to staunch blood, and those which they use every morning to make themselves secure, are not in their own tongue but in the German language. In like manner the acquaintance with the evil eye came to them on the road, in which they place great trust. That misfortune dwells in a house where an unbaptized child is found, but that good fortune attaches to every day that begins with passing through the parish church --- such opinions already prove by their very content a Christian origin. \

Only their palm-reading from the hand, which is bound up with the piercing eye of their women, but otherwise rests on no deeper foundation in their nature, seems to be their own work. La Baht is the name of this art, which has made them famous throughout the world, and which, in the hands of girls, reads the future lover, in those of women the children, and in those of the older the impending rich inheritances. Hokkano Baro, however, the great Psiff, is said by the power of the spell to compel the earth-spirits to give up long-buried treasures; that magnet, fashioned against a piece of steel forged from the hook of the high court (the gallows), likewise cooperates; and thus this Cuenta or art appears so refined that, in the words of one of the initiated, even the Beugui Lango, the lame devil or Asmodeus, would not know what to add.

From what has been set forth here one can easily judge what is to be thought of the view of those who hold the whole witchcraft business to be a work of the fraudulent Cuenta of this people. If one of the initiated of the covenant leads the neophyte into the dark wood under the oak, and brings her a handsome demon; but he refuses the ugly woman because the procuress has pledged to bring him a young and beautiful one; if other accounts speak of riders who, clad in black and on black steeds, meet the women, beg for their favor, and, after they have willingly renounced all the saints, then pay them with a coin that afterward turns into shards;---if we read such things frequently in the protocols, then all this certainly sounds very human, in its generic character, but in manner gypsy-like. \

The people's propensity for cunning fraud, which manifests itself especially in the arts of horse-cheating; their inclination to lust --- these things show through everywhere in such occurrences. Indeed nothing can resemble the Sabbath more than the spectacle presented by a horde of gypsies when they encamp by night in the forest gloom around their fires, and, the flames contending with the torn tree-shadows, they cast a singular illumination over the scene; when men and women there spread out their plunder, dance their dances, and gorge themselves on the fallen cattle, while their chiefs maintain a sort of etiquette. The effect must have been particularly significant in earlier times, when the nature of the people was still unknown, and rural women of the neighborhood were brought into this circle and, by prestidigitation they had seen on their travels, were made serviceable to the purposes of the craft. It cannot be denied that such things may often have happened; but to suppose that in the countless cases where witchcraft showed itself there were always gypsies present to set the machinery in motion would be a foolish assumption, and would never accord with the unstable, fugitive spirit of this people. Among the manifold causes that produced this historical phenomenon, this cause has therefore probably also occasionally played a part; by no means, however, in any way, not even remotely, an exclusive effect.

Very unlike the Jews, their traveling companions over the earth, the gypsies' unsettled mind never seriously delved into the abysses of the magical arts; only what was serviceable to them on their travels have they known how cleverly to grasp and, according to their purposes, to make use of. The outward trappings of the whole discipline, its showman-like aspect, they accordingly appropriated; and whereas what the Jews contributed toward the whole direction was mostly calculated for the higher ranks, they on their part played to the lower orders, the rural folk in particular.

The outward appearances of the Sabbath may therefore well have been taken from them: the light-effects of their encampments in forest solitude; the unboundness and the glaring contrasts that arise between wild nature and acquaintance with the polishes of modern life; the licentiousness that their way of life brings with it: all of this may so often have impressed itself on the actuality of the imagination that it at last recurred again in the visions of the Sabbath. The suspicion of child‑stealing soon arose against them, to which another, also cannibalistic appetite was soon added; no wonder, then, that this suspicion fastened also on the uncleanliness of their kitchens, and that the eating of children on the Sabbath now ran rife. They dance the same lascivious dance in which the Egyptian women likewise excel, and which, according to Swinburne, is called Maquendoy in Spain; it is, as we are taught by explicit testimony, a prototype of the Sabbath dances.

Amulets and magical roots, too, have already played their part in the whole mischief. Their women cook love‑potions from the root of the good baron (la raiz del buen Baron); their men have thrown the Drau, a powder or the like, into the herds so that the cattle fall ill, and afterwards, when called, they may heal them again, or so that the fallen beasts may become their prey. k) When their women make people ill with the evil eye (querelar nasula); when the Moors in Africa, from the Dar‑Buschi‑Fal belief, think they know how to transform a white man into a negro; when they themselves generally boast of the art of witchcraft --- it remains uncertain whether, in these matters, they comported themselves as teachers or as apprentices; probably they were both within their circle, and thus contributed their share to the further spread of this practice.

### Chapter 2. Natural Disposition for Witchcraft and Sorcery

\


Keywords: chapter 2. natural disposition for witchcraft and sorcery
