The human being is born into history; each individual contributes to shaping it in their own part, but is, in turn, shaped by it. Witchcraft is thus also a historical product, and we have, in the preceding, considered and explained the historical influences that contributed to its emergence. But the indirect historical influence presupposes a direct effect; nothing can exist in history that was not previously or simultaneously present in the individuals, who only receive from it what they have previously invested in it. The second moment, on which all sorcery is based, is thus this autonomous quality, which conditions all historical phenomena through the individual. The self of the personality is twofold, composed of body and soul. The consideration of this moment will have two aspects: insofar as it takes its starting point from the physical and its inherent bound life, and then is directed to transition to the free-spirited. The present section shall therefore serve the investigation of the physical disposition and the temporal and spatial conditions associated with it; the following section, however, shall take as its task the consideration of the spiritual and what is connected with it.

#### A. The Obsession with Magic and Sorcery

When the exodus into history first began, the earth, with all its earthly directions and tendencies, was assigned as stage and racecourse to those who were journeying forth; but the demonic world had its provident care concealed at the very moment when the higher world of spirits withdrew from the fallen: both were to draw near to the wanderers in their continued influence only under the covering of earthly conditions and of powers limited by the earthly; and help or temptation, so that the scales should not be too unequal, were to come to them only in the binding and guise of the earthly medium. \


Keywords: a. the obsession with magic and sorcery[Page 58]

\]

This is the ordinary course of the world; the abysses over which man walks are closed and sealed in the bosom of the deep; upward the bound gaze may well reach into the spaces of the stars, but not beyond these into the spirit-depths. Thus, being dependent on that which is like himself, he must above all see to it that he does not fall through his own fault; the assaults from below will then be powerless against the upright man, because the higher protection binds them back from him. But if we see that individuals or whole masses turn aside from the path and knock at the closed gate in order to seek help from the monstrous shadows of the abyss, then something in them must have become disturbed and displaced from the ordinary order of things; a darkly falling shade must have dimmed and clouded the cheerfulness of life in them; so that between the darknesses of those nocturnal realms and their own inner ones a certain sympathy exists, and in it powers awaken which stand in a certain rapport with those of the abyss. If this overshadowing first occurs in the bodily, it will, having become habitual, form a morbid disposition that turns away from the ordinary toward the unusual; an idiosyncrasy that takes pleasure in bitterness, a delight in what is not pleasurable, and ultimately even a liking for evil. This disposition, however, will take root as a disease in life and in its organs; and preferably in the central organ of that life, in the ganglionic system, and in it slowly develop into a craving of its own.

When, in the first of these mystical books, we spoke of the organic inner structure of the body and of the currents that connect all these subdivisions among themselves, we also treated of the articulation of this ganglionic system, and it there divided itself for us into a threefold group of organs. The first, its head part, is connected to the distributions of the sympathetic system which, issuing from its upper cervical nodes, run along the carotids and vertebrals, join with them in the vascular circle, and from there, as the peculiar center of a distinct and yet in the general circulation opening system, lay its vessels through the whole brain. Its second or trunk part is formed by the 24--30 ganglia connected by their commissures, which run down along the vertebral column as a second sympathetic spinal cord, and with their nerve outgoings supply the vessels of the whole torso. Its third division finally presses together into the visceral part, the brain of the lower belly, and the so‑called semilunar ganglia gather together. Around it are arranged: stomach, liver, spleen, pancreas, kidneys, testicles and the intestinal canal downward; lungs and thymus with the pharynx and windpipe. Through the diaphragm this lower brain sends its capillary vessels to all the organs, and with a peripheral, branched ganglion it serves the fecal excretions; while the two encircling \[ganglia\] supply the respective accompanying secretory parts.

As these viscera are therefore divided into twelve organs, so the corresponding brain will likewise divide into twelve ganglia which, connected among themselves by commissures, form a cooperating mass; so much so that each for itself, and yet all together, supplies each of the named organs with its nerve outflow. The highest organization of the system in the head is thus formed circularly and crown‑like in its central ground; the lowest in the depths of the viscera, from the plurality of separate centers, plastically united into a compact central mass; while the connecting middle one, the subordinate central ganglia from above downward, binds them together into a descending line and into a strand. Now in life there is nowhere dead rest and rigid torpor; everywhere there is current and motion: and everywhere an overwhelming flow must, in a compelling way, hold the individual within its bounds. Accordingly, in the whole system such a flowing current will circulate without interruption; and this will appear divided according to a threefold modality. In the head the current will, in its innermost ground, close upon itself in a circle; as most currents in the brain-system indeed proceed in a ring. The current within the viscera will, to and from a contracted centre, take place massively along three mutually perpendicular axes. The third, finally, will run straight down along the spinal column, descending from the first to the second and from the second again rising to the first; thus alternately lowering and raising itself, sinking the upper into the lower, and, in turn, raising the lower toward the upper. All three then unite in one and the same great current, which corresponds to the circulation of the blood down in the depths.

Each ganglion in this great circle then completes its subordinate circle, in which it, from its centre, governs its peripheral expansion through its nerves. All such subordinate vortices of separate activities that thus form are again encompassed by the three larger vortices --- the wreath-like, the plastically operative one about the formative axes, and the penetrating, up-and-down oscillating one --- and in health all are kept enclosed within their boundaries; the equalization of the threefoldly different movements of life itself, however, is entrusted to the implanted conservative power of life itself. Just as the heart is charged with the regulation of the entire circular movement of the blood, so the heart-ganglion also seems placed as guardian over the equilibration of these different movements.

This ganglion is therefore placed in the very midst of them all, where they appear drawn closest together at their innermost starting-points; near at half the distance of the vascular wreath from the celiac ganglion, and three nervous radiations bind it to both and at the same time to the third intermediate member which links them. The whole system is again submitted to the higher systems, and if affected in its members these will in turn draw those affections into their own, and its currents will play over into theirs. Thus there will be an intercourse between the visceral ganglia and that part of the spinal cord and brain which serves life; another between the middle sympathetic system and that which, of the two, operates in voluntary movement; and the third system, finally, with the head insofar as it performs intellectual functions.

From such diversely held streams, poured forth through the manifold articulations of the life-system, the great movement of life is assembled; and everything that happens and occurs within its circle appears in its origin to be determined thereby. The alternation between sleep and waking appears especially brought about by the perpendicular ascending-and-descending; and when, in the first state, the lowest circling has become dominant --- when life has entwined everything into its natural unity --- then this closedness becomes a point of passage into another state. When we spoke of somnambulism, we distinguished two kinds of waking of the system: in one it reaches over into the external physical world and perceives and acts and performs its functions; while in the other it opens itself to the world of spirits. \

From the first waking-world into the second, and from this back into the former, the transition, however, passes through the state of sleep; and we have furthermore explained how the gradual inward awakening of the system --- advancing by the threefold order of sympathetic movement --- marks the steps and degrees of magnetic elevation up to clairvoyance. But the matter can also be considered from another point of view. Although the whole movement of life appears of earthly character, the part of this movement in the circumference of the skull nevertheless expresses the solar element in it; the other, in the region of the lower entrails, the lunar; and only in the middle sphere does the properly kernel-like earthly show itself distinctly. If now the slight overturning of the life-movement in general --- from outward waking into the inner, in general toward the side of nature --- constitutes the predisposition to magnetically somnambulistic states, then this lightness, when especially attached to the upper mode of motion in the head, will establish a predisposition to a sunlike life-magnetism; whereas, when lying upon the lower mode in the entrails, it will evoke a moonlike magnetic disposition.

The Sun is the lamp of day, radiating light and warmth, the two greatest goods of nature; the prophets of the old service of nature, whose inner being had opened itself to the power of the luminary, recognized themselves as children of Helios, descendants of the radiant Apollo; and, mindful of their inspiration by him, they described the path that his prophetic ray takes from the pit of the heart to the oracle-speaking mouth. The Moon, however, is the lamp of night; what she conceals in her womb she partly unveils with her borrowed light; coolness and moisture are the media in which her effect most gladly reveals itself. Those, then, in whom the lowest vital movement has the impulse to sink into the nocturnal seclusion of this luminary, called themselves children of the Moon, proclaiming prophecy under its influences. The mild Sun, however, becomes an angry one when, by excess, she makes her gifts destructive; and the beneficent Artemis becomes grim when her blessings are in the same way transformed into poisons. The Helios-seers of the first order are thus likewise changed, and the benefactors become corrupters; while those inspired by Artemis, now thrown into frenzy by the Angry One, go about as the helpers of Hecate in nocturnal gloom.

As the mild Sun, now bountiful in giving, is, in her anger, kindling, enflaming and consuming --- her nature therefore pointing to the masculine, as in the choleric temperament --- the Moon, on the other hand, in her good mood is receiving, fostering, preserving, and in gentle light begetting; but in her dark aspect she unleashes every nocturnal horror, stiffening and binding all life. In this effect of hers she thus behaves as feminine, as in the melancholic temperament alternatingly; so will it also be with the double chorus of those inspired by them. The sun-mania, in which the Helios-servants shine forth radiantly and again burn scorching in grim fire, will predominantly be the affair of the male sex, and have the choleric temperament as its organic basis. The moon-mania, which, like the Moon in her phases, alternates between light and shadow and thus between sorrow and joy, will be found chiefly in the female sex and will attach itself to the alternation of the melancholic temperament. \

What here in the circle of nature acts as a closed system is introduced into the cacodæmonic or agathodæmonic circles; when, as there, the system, instead of manifesting in outwardness, awakens into the inwardness of physical nature, it opens into the inwardness of the spirit-world; and now, in place of the forces of nature, evil or good spirits set themselves into rapport with it. The transition, initiated by various intermediate stages, already appears clearly in magnetic somnambulism; when the lower life, ceasing to play with the forces of nature, is lost in the deeper circles of the spirit-kingdom that are akin to it; and now the double nature of all human drives, divided into good and evil, successively or simultaneously---attracting the homogeneous in these circles and repelling the heterogeneous---falls into states which outwardly bear all the signs of a higher ecstasy and then also those of an incipient possession. The same was already the case in ancient times with their nature-enthusiasts; and while, in the better mysteries that guided and initiated them, a higher, ennobling ray shone in, the worse ones in their abominations assumed altogether a demonic character. The demonic, then, breaking into these natural states, finds in them a predisposition that favors such an intrusion; just as the better, when promoted by them, finds its access facilitated.

Now sun and moon, and thus likewise sun-sickness and moon-sickness, do not, in life, behave at all exclusively as salutary and harmful in the physical, and still less as good and evil in the ethical; yet they do present themselves to the intruding intelligences in different ways. The moonlike, in space bound twice---by the earth and by the sun---has therefore the condition of being bound as one of its essential characteristics, and can accordingly be more readily mastered by the objectively evil as well as by the good. The sunlike in the regions, however, being predominantly binding and only subordinately bound, adapts itself less readily to being bound---just as in double stars it only, as an exception, associates with a similar body; whereas the planetary cannot exist without such an ordering. Moon-sickness is thus more easily mastered because it is already in itself divided into phases of light and darkness, and so more readily divides itself into those of good and evil and, at last, becomes aligned with one or the other; whereas sun-sickness, not so easily dissolved, offers greater resistance to the power of the objective.

The lower visceral life, to which the one (i.e. moon-sickness) is tied, is thereby---like the lower, night-covered nature---by it brought nearer to the spiritual under-realm; while the system to which the other (i.e. sun-sickness) adheres, being more remote from these regions, approaches the higher physical; so that even the spiritual can, at least with less strong separation, more readily break through. For the same reason that in the physical domain lunar floods and ebbs are greater than the analogous solar movements of the element, there were in ancient times more enthusiastic moon-women than sun-seers; more Thessalian enchantresses than male sorcerers; and in later times more female seers than male---and therefore also more witches and sorceresses than sorcerers. The reason lies, plainly expressed, in the natural relations of the sexes, in the melancholic and choleric temperaments in which their difference stands out most sharply; and thus it comes about that this difference of physical constitution, according to sexual difference, has likewise been impressed upon the realm of witchcraft: the witch-nature being especially attached to moon-sickness, where possession found a fertile soil; while the natural substratum of the male magical nature preferred to take root in a sun-sick disposition. Notwithstanding the full moral freedom of the sexes --- to which therefore also the entirely equal accountability attaches --- nature nevertheless disposes, once choice has been made, the execution more toward the form of one or the other side, and the modality is then again conditioned by the course taken.

#### B. Sidereal Influences on the Natural Constitution and Epidemic Outbreaks

\

In the nature-belief of antiquity it was especially the sun and the moon that stirred the drives in the realm of instincts tending inward and upward; they were the queen about whom the swarming flights of bees assembled. The sun, the great light of day, was also, in the outward vivification, the root of the works which, with prudence, are accomplished by day; just as the small light of night exerted its influence upon the plastic works of the nocturnal world. Clearly delineated natural beings, and acting as such in these reflective states, they were, on the other hand, mystical powers in the unconscious, naturally ecstatic states, awakening and stimulating those states by their effect; and since above all women most frequently and most easily fell into these states, it was, beside Apollo Helios, especially Luna --- the one most closely turned toward them --- who exercised this mystical power above all, and gathered them about her in the stirrings and movements which she produced in them. She was indeed the Lilith of the Hebrews, the lady of darkness; the Artemis of the deeper Orient, the Alilat of the Arabs and the Melitta of the Assyrians; the two-horned Psḫat or Bubastis of the Egyptians; Diana, formerly Jana, the mother of hidden life, and as Trivia the goddess of the ways who leads her retinue over forests and mountains, thus the Norse Holda riding over the heights; the Lydian girls danced and rode for her on Tmolus, and the Spartan maidens performed the Carga before her. She was, over the whole earth, the mistress of female life; she ruled all the waters of life that flood within it; and in her was represented the great heart of nature, through which she pulsed all things, and from which she then first poured herself into the individual human heart, and thereby ever kept it in general union with the centre of nature. Beside her was then that Helios, the source of all the higher nerve-spirits, so to speak the sensorium and common nervous centre of the all; leaning more toward men, among whom especially the kings were regarded as sun-born. They were mystically illumined from above, so that they might again radiate what they had received, as human Heliads, upon their subjects, and in higher states move the nervous systems just as that All-Mother moved the vascular tissue, in manifold stirrings.

In that nature-belief, however, the contradiction of good and evil also referred back to the hidden grounds of the all, and communicated itself to all beings that arose from its depths. Both were branches of the same life inherent in the unity of nature, which in them was only split in different directions, and could, possibly, also restore itself again out of them. Thus wrath lay alongside mildness, dread was joined with friendliness, life with death, suspicion easily allied itself with goodness, and cheerfulness was united with horror. The same Helios who awakens the whole earth to activity with his rain of light also sends forth the poisoned arrows of pestilences. The goddess of the night, the leader of her retinue over the heights of heaven and through the depths of the earth --- as the moon is always divided between light and shadow, so she separates herself into the mildly shining Berecynthia, who traverses the Maenalon, and the dreadful Hecate of the dark nether realm, attired with all its terrors; as also Ceres, giver of the harvest, the earth-mother opened to the light, who bore the subterranean daughter and queen of the shadow-realm, Persephone. \

This division continued also among the daughters of the earth, magnetically linked with them in choirs; and just as day and night, summer and winter, sowing and harvest ever alternate upon this many‑cleft earth, so too is the life of the earthly drawn into these alternations; and to the ritual choirs of the Destroyer there always succeed those of the Builder, and the round dance thus ever passes its turn down into the depth, and rises again to the height. The mysteries which the sex therefore celebrated for life and the fruitful nature‑deities were thus split about midnight, according to day‑night and night‑day; for that which is to germinate must first perish and be buried that it may attain to resurrection. The secrets of destruction in all generation, spiritual as well as physical, therefore formed the subject of one half‑chorus; generation amid all destruction the subject of the other, and both made themselves known in everything in which, in the realm of appearance, the two directions were revealed.

Thus the women's choirs which, in the Romance South even in the first Christian times, were gathered about the Night‑Queen, their mistress, plainly reflect the nature of their leader. They held, under her presidency, these their assemblies in nocturnal leisure, to consult about the fates of the night‑realms; the mistress's ministerials were chosen there, offences were punished, and fostering deeds were richly rewarded there; at the banquet the mistress then shone mild and gracious through the nightly coolness. When the following, led by her, set out at the turn of the year in the great procession through the dwellings of men, then it was the play of Diana and of the good mothers that took place; it is the good and wise women who move in it; indeed they are also called the good things. Men open to them kitchen and cellar, and they taste of the offerings thus presented without diminishing them; and in return give yearly fertility and blessing and prosperity. For Abundantia or Satia is the name of their mistress, and where she goes the fullness of good things springs up at her footsteps. But if she turns to the other side, she becomes the Wrathful, the Fury‑burned, the Perfidious and the Harm‑doing: then her retinue likewise turns; the dark nocturnal side appears, the earth is smitten with barrenness, the house with misfortune, the children wither and life fades.

At the moon‑table, which stands beside the sun‑table of the ancient Ethiopians, the gentle goddess had given drink and food to the needy; now the hating one pours forth the poison of Colchian‑Thessalian witchcraft. Now the monsters of the old night spread their dark brew over the timorous. Even beauty is transformed into a ravening beast. Lamia, the daughter of the ancient Bel and of Libya, in the land of terror Africa, wins the favour of the Olympian, and he brings her to Italy, where the city named after her is built. Juno kills, in jealous anger, all her offspring, and she in envy and rage again slays all the births of other women. Now the Lamiae, the dread of children, go forth; they who may transform themselves into any thing --- into birds, dogs, mice, even flies --- inclined alike to sensual pleasure and to cruelty, and kindling beforehand into heat those who would consume them. The daughter of that first Lamia, however, was the African clairvoyant Sibyl, the old Saga, from sagire, to see sharply; the ancestress of all those who, probing the mysteries of the nether realm, bring them to light; while the striges of the Latins circle about the cradles, and suck the blood of sleepers, and rend their entrails. \

To these terrors, which have been raised up from the south, others move against them whose origin is in the north. In the realm of Holda the same division holds, as we have already seen; if she is kindly disposed, then her host likewise brightens. They help the Mistress spin the threads out of which, over meadow and field, vegetation weaves itself; they help her preserve the children in the deep well and bring them forth into the daylight; they fill the jugs with mead and wine. But if the purpose of the goddess is perverted into malignity, then the fair ones about her are likewise transformed into monsters; the thread on the distaff becomes confused and tangled, the fruit is smitten with drought and blight; storms rage through the once-still air; the midwives become child‑stealers and practice child‑devouring; hunger and want take the place of riches.

Now Christianity came into the world and put into general force a previously prepared doctrine. The idea of the Godhead was held to be the absolutely Good, altogether incompatible with any kind of Evil and incapable of being stained by any touch. In connection with sin, however, the origins of this Evil were laid in the will of the rational creature; which will, according as it kept itself freely in the likeness of God or in apostasy received the evil into itself, was divided in two directions --- taking between them the irrational, and therefore also in its irresponsibility only by communication capable of evil but not of sinning, the physical nature, --- and assigning to it above and below the mixed human nature capable both of apostasy and of union. Before this doctrine the powers that had earlier assumed the masks of natural forms, as the Egyptian gods assumed animal shapes, were compelled to unmask. If they had previously passed themselves off as gods whose essence manifested itself in them in good and evil, they must now appear as demonic powers that, by fraudulent usurpation of the essence of the Godhead, had practised robbery against God. With them fell now all their worshipers and confessors whom they had found among men, and in whose associations their falsely divine natures had incarnated themselves in good and evil, down to the same level of reprobation; it was the Evil, therefore, which had thus taken shape in grievous deceit, in the uprising of the creature against its Creator; and therefore it had to fall into dissolution to make room for a better formation.

A strikingly significant hint of how this relationship was thought of from the beginning of the modern period into the later Middle Ages is found in the life of St. Taurinus, the bishop of Corbeil, in the earliest period of Christianity there. He bound in the year of Diana the demon who there played the Night‑Goddess. The spirit, because he rendered willing obedience to the saint, is not sent to Hell: rather his punishment is allotted to him in the very region where he had previously ruled. Henceforth he must appear in manifold forms without doing harm to anyone; by the people about there called Gobelin from that time until now (the Life was written in the middle of the twelfth century). The folk had had manifold experiences of the doings of the so‑called kobolds; the ambiguous, good‑naturedly malicious mixed nature, the helpfulness of these beings combined with teasing wilfulness and evil craft in these ghostlike natures, had awakened their reflection; and the question about their origin and their relations had been repeatedly raised. The introduction of Christianity at last set this inquiry on a track: the holy man had driven away the old mistress of the night, and she had yielded to his exorcism without resistance. The natural power, referred back to the spirit dwelling in it, now becomes a ghostly apparition which, where it formerly exercised dominion, has now sunk to servitude; and for a small dwarf's wage helps to carry on the household affairs.

Now the canon attributed to the Synod of Ancyra also speaks of the criminal women who, having turned back to Satan and, through the deceits of the demons, been led into delusion, rode in troops on beasts, in the retinue of the heathen Diana, through the stillness of the night, across wide distances, on certain nights called to the service of the mistress. For there are now demons transformed into women who formerly rode with the once well-named mistress, but who now take the likenesses (larvae) of neighboring women who meanwhile sleep in their beds, as St. Germanus made proof. The company of night-women is now, even where it brings good, a confederacy of witch-women, which, abusing good for evil ends, robs the Creator of his honor and turns it over to the fallen spirits. Holda, in whose service they rode northward, has become a she-fiend; a name with which the language likewise names the Devil. Her company have shared in the same transformation; the white Alrune has become a treacherous enchantress, the old Asine a Here. They now go through the houses, light funeral candles, and know only how to steal children who, at their banquets, at the command of the mistress, are either torn apart and eaten, or---out of a sudden fit of pity---are carried back to the cradle; they torment the sleepers in every way and practise every sort of evil. \

Through the Greek lands the Gellones now pass, they who enter through closed doors and suddenly destroy the children;---as such a one, in Byzantium, according to the account of his mother, often carried the newborn Emperor Maurice out of the room, but was unable to harm him. In Italy the old Matres and Matronae have become Mascae; the old fairies or fates, for whom the Neapolitan women set out the tables so that they kept the children and kept the house pure, are deceiving phantoms; and these gather in bands around the dethroned mistress, called Queen Mab in Ireland, in Brescia also la Donna del Ginco, in the so‑called Tregendas, to the lordly place. For, says Bartholomew de Spina, from the confessions of those who ride we know officially that they, before anointing themselves at night, first wait for the noise of the mistress as she passes with the great throng of those rejoicing; only then do they anoint themselves in order to join the throng, until they all arrive at the appointed place. This place is above all for Italy the walnut‑tree of Benevento, there where the old Lombard tree with the golden dragon stood; in France la croce d'el Pastiecio, in other countries other \[places\]: everywhere, however, they are those spots where the old pagan mysteries of the gods were celebrated at the feet of their images and in the surrounding groves.

The Herodias who takes the place of Diana, and who under the name Radodese long was the terror of children in the Venetian region, and who in Ferrara also bears the name of the Sibyl, thence conducts her following beyond the sea to the Jordan. This happens twice in every week, and all their striving is directed to the single aim that they might but once touch the waters of the stream; to her, who already is mistress of one third of the earth's circle, it would---if she succeeded in that---fall to possess the whole world. But the river draws back before her, and would sooner dry up than permit the touch. All this is perfectly fabulous, and only wishes to assert: that if the unholy could force itself upon the holy by violence, nothing thereafter would be able to resist its power. But that can never succeed, and so the mistress each time abandons the useless, yet ever-repeated task; and all the more becomes enraged, so that everyone must flee from her wrath.

Thus, at the turning-point of history the whole doctrine was reversed; humanity was to be torn from the bonds of nature, and to enter a higher, serene kingdom of God. But these bonds held fast; for in that part of it which belonged to the earth the higher, guiding consciousness had grown dim, taken root, and had grown up with it. With all instincts and dark drives the ancient belief in Nature was confirmed; the sun acted in it, the moisture of the earth greened in it. When the seed sprang up in the fields, and the groves about the temples put forth leaves, then the enthusiasm for Nature rose also inwardly; and the night-veiled realm within man germinated, greened, blossomed with the kingdoms of nature. \

stories.title: The Opening of the Elves' Dwelling in Frisia

content:
[Page 66]

\]

Most closely bound in this union with Nature was the tilling population; and in their midst, again most strongly, the sex of women, in whom the root of human growth sinks into the earth. One knows with what tenacious attachment the old rural folk clung to their belief in Nature; so that, in opposition to the new doctrine, it was branded with the name of paganism. Even in Italy, the centre of Christianity, it was able only slowly and gradually to take root again in that portion of the population. In the fourth century the more mobile cities had for the most part turned away from it; the countryside, however, especially in the mountains, had remained entirely heathen; and Bishops Gaudentius of Brescia and St. Massinus of Turin therefore bitterly reproach the possessors that they allowed their castalds to persist in the old heathenism. At Monte Cassino Benedict still found an Apollo temple where the people offered sacrifices in the very solitude of the forest. That old Lombard tree near Benevento stood down to the end of the seventh century, an object of veneration, untouched; until at length the holy Barbatus, bishop of the place, one day took an axe and hurried out with an escort to the sacrilege that called itself arbor sanctiva, and having felled it at the root he heaped earth about it, so that no one might find even a trace of it.

By no means, however, was the matter thereby settled in those relatively early centuries. Even at the end of the fifteenth \[century\] the inhabitants of Arezzo still highly honoured a spring over which, from the times of paganism, an altar had been erected in the darkness of the wood; whither the people, according to old custom, went on pilgrimage as to an oracle of Apollo, to obtain answers to secret questions or healing of the ills that afflicted them. Here, too, it was the holy Bernardino who finally destroyed the ancient belief in Nature. One day he preached on the subject, then exhorted his hearers to accompany him in the work of destruction; and at once, provided with axes and other tools and accompanied by the people, he went to the spring, stopped its flowing source with stones, and overturned the altar, so that thenceforth the memory of the thing perished.

How much the councils and synods in France, Spain, and Germany had to contend with similar matters is known from their acts and decrees. Especially in the latter country it was again the mountain people, and the tilling tribes of the Saxon lowlands, who most stubbornly held to the old ways; and this returned with force as soon as even a cloud of heresy passed over the sunlit mirror of the new doctrine.

Thus in Frisia, in the time of Emperor Lothar, the teaching of Arins and Sabellius had spread; immediately the old natural faith of the Æsir-doctrine reappeared. The country became full of cries: on that hill the old elves' dwelling had opened; they, whom one also used to call witte wywen, the wise women, in the vernacular. Their house was an underground cave; from it one heard first a dull murmur, then an immense lamenting and weeping of people; then again children's cries, and alternately music and notes of joy. Night-wanderers and cattle-herds were carried off, mothers with their infants were seized; and therefore the women in childbirth and their children were kept under strict guard, lest they should thus fall into the hands of the elves. Saint Odulphus had to instruct the people against these deceptions; and they vanished only when the people had been newly confirmed in the faith. \

From then on we see, at every any significant change of religion in the countries, similar appearances break out, as it were epidemically. Thus everywhere the old inclinations had remained behind, but their objects had been taken away; a great upheaval had cast down into the abyss those things which had formerly been objects of the people's veneration; no wonder that it was difficult and slow to accommodate itself to the change. Indeed other affections presented themselves, in part at the same localities; but even where people gradually resolved to accept them, the old recollection still long continued to work; and the new comers still had to contend late with the remnants of earlier habit, and to share the worship with the expelled. But when, in the course of time, they gradually carried off the victory, and the godless worship of the powers of nature was really regarded as robbery against God and as demonic worship, the dim transitional period, which had lasted many centuries, had prepared the way: that which otherwise in itself contradicts human nature was led over to the veneration and service of the evil principle as such; and when Manichaeism set itself up as the representative of this principle, it everywhere found in men's minds a basis to which its otherwise paradoxical teaching could attach itself. \


Keywords: to, the, and, of, had[Page 68]

\]

The memories and echoes of the old paganism thus cooperated with the errors of later times; the darknesses of the ages that had sunk backward into a glooming past; the darkness of nights, of forests; the spiritual obscurities and the moral cloudings: they all flowed together into one abyss. In its midst the idea of a Satan's realm on earth now developed, which was to have its right, its law and constitution, form and aspect alongside the kingdom of God; in it the old, inexpiable claims of matter against ensoulment, of the flesh against the spirit, were to be represented; and the old, irreconcilable struggle of both powers was to be continued until the end. Into this strife there entered, however, the material counterpart, with the whole real weight of its palpable corporeality. What human nature enclosed in itself of such dark, bodily forces and appetites, in opposition to the rule which the spirit at all times --- and in the new doctrine more than ever --- had assumed, found itself disposed to take part where, as it seemed, the contest was for its emancipation. This had to happen most decisively again among the lower classes of the people, where all these vigorous, fleshly instincts had been preserved most solidly; and where the higher light, on the whole, had still made itself a way most sparingly.

In this domain, then, it will again be chiefly the farmers, shepherds, and seafarers --- those who in their daily intercourse with physical nature also strengthen and exercise most the forces most closely akin to it --- who will be preferentially inclined to that side. Again those whose seats lie in the high and middle mountains, those whose dwellings are in marshes and swamps, remote from the great currents of intellectual intercourse; those who, settled in the spirit of the seashore, by the barrenness of the land were driven over to the moving wave; --- once they had been won to that cause, these would again be its most natural and stalwart allies in the service of the Nether-Realm. Finally, men and women again, according to their different temperaments, will be disposed to that side: women, by virtue of their constitution more closely related to Nature, and the closer union in which their powers stand; by the greater mobility of their whole being for external impressions; by the changeable inconstancy of their will comparable to the element of water; by the forward play of the powers of imagination, and by a tougher, more enduring passion --- will incline most to this side. Thus even way of life, locality, and sex must operate together with historical memories to realize the idea of Evil as such in a large fellowship on earth, and to make it the guiding principle within them.

#### C. The Endemic Influence According to Earthly Localities

From what has been said it now becomes intelligible why witchcraft and sorcery, in their whole diffusion, are bound, just as they prefer certain times, likewise to particular localities. That they belong, according to time, to the periods of transition --- both of the natural faith and of the spiritual --- and in the latter from one form to another, has been made clear above. That spatially they attach with equal preference to those conditions where the natural still manifests the most persistence and most powerfully plays over into the higher life, will likewise be evident, even on only a superficial survey of the existing relations. History shows that in all places and in every situation where the old paganism was longest preserved; where, for the same reason, perhaps later the Manichaean heresy struck its deepest roots; --- there subsequently the greatest development of witchcraft and sorcery was attained. \

The great mountain-parallel that runs from east to west through the old world will indicate to us the line of its progress. In the west, therefore, France and Italy will especially attract our attention. As to France, Alphonsus Spina already names in his Fortalitium, at the beginning of the fifteenth century, Gascony and the Dauphiné, "ubi nimium abundant tales perversae mulieres"; and Alphonsus Tostado about the same time adds the neighboring Spain: thus, from the Dauphiné through the whole of the Basque country, even into the Spanish mountains, witchcraft has spread to a great extent. It is therefore the inhabitants of the Pyrenees and the Alps who have done most in this direction; to which Lorraine must also be added, where Rémy found great material. The Basques, however, are already known as the most tenacious adherents of custom, habitual way of life, homeliness, old manners and former conviction; and in this sense they are the only ones among the present Southern Europeans --- although a small people --- who have preserved their old language unchanged; and their most ancient forefathers would be able to make themselves understood with them in it, and to find their way among their customs. \


Keywords: to, the, and, in, of[Page 70]

\]

From the midst of that people of French allegiance, from the little district of Labourt, the charge of a generally spread witchcraft and sorcery was now in many ways brought against Henry IV; and in the year 1609 he appointed a commission consisting of President Espagnet, Councillor of State, and the councillor at the Parliament of Bordeaux, De Lancre, to carry out the inquiry on the spot and to bring the guilty to trial; subject to any oppositions and appeals that might be lodged. They remained four months in the country, and soon convinced themselves that the accusation was not groundless. The great number of the proofs filled them with dread, and the strangest facts came to their knowledge. Their arrival, moreover, had produced a panic terror throughout the whole country. Everyone fled by water and by land; pilgrimages to Montserrat and to St. Jacob were used as a pretext; Upper and Lower Navarre and all the Spanish frontier provinces filled with fugitives; and the Spanish inquisitors stationed themselves on the border to turn the runaways back. The investigation proceeded in the meantime, and its results De Lancre summarized in a book which he gave the title: Tableau de l'inconstance des mauvais anges et démons, où il est amplement traité des Sorciers et de la Sorcellerie. Paris, 1613. In the first book, Discourses II and III, he speaks of the character and circumstances of the country and people in the following manner.

\"The land of Labourt is an office composed of twenty-seven parishes, with a population of about 30,000 souls, without trade or industry. The inhabitants live along the sea, stretching inward into the mountains; and speak, like their neighbours, the peculiar Basque tongue. The country is therefore at once a mountain-land and a frontier-land of three kingdoms: France, Spain, and Navarre; the meeting-place of three languages, and likewise belonging to two dioceses, and likewise divided between land and sea. The sea, however, makes them rustic, coarse and ill-mannered; the spirit as well as the prosperity of those who give themselves to it is tied to rigging and to movable pennons, and thus movable like the wind; millet, which the mountains produce for them, and fish, which the sea provides, compose their food; the sky meanwhile is their covering, and the sails are their tablecloth. They are so accustomed to see the inconstant element in tumult and storm that they fear and dread nothing so much as its calm and its stillness, entrusting all their welfare to its waves, which rock them up and down day and night. Hence it comes that the nature of the sea imparts itself to their manners, their intercourse, their speech, and even to their faith; which likewise does not leave them even when they again set foot on land. They are then always as if striking in waves---hasty, choleric; at the slightest whim that passes through their heads they throw themselves upon you and set a dagger to your throat.

The land, moreover, would not deny them its produce, were it not that they have turned their inclination preferentially to the ocean and to the sea, that lawless, untamed element, the navigation of which is a veritable and plain despair. Now consequently their soil has become meagre, barren and poor to them; and they themselves are also sluggish and idle when they have returned from their voyages; and their idleness leads them, before they have grown old, to a beggarly state which presses heavily upon them again; because, as immediate neighbours of the Spaniards, they feel an extraordinary amount of their pride and presumption within themselves. They have moreover not even a secure harbour in their country, and must, when they arrive from Terre-Neuve, Canada, or the two Indies, put in at St. Sebastian or Fontarabie; where they are under Spanish authority, which makes them yet more dependent.\" \

These privations kill in them the love of their fatherland, and their long absences on their sea-voyages moreover stifle their love for wife and child, who have been left behind alone with the old people, and make them indifferent and cold. Even if their wives wish for their return, on account of the small earnings they have made; yet it is only the winter season that brings them home; in which, since they pursue no trade at all, they consume what has been earned in the inns, without giving any of it to their families; whereupon in the spring they sail out again as poor as they were before, and frequently --- meeting with misfortune --- do not return. They do not even properly know their wives at all, because they live with them only half the year; and as to their children, the custom they have of taking wives on trial for several years before they actually marry them is also detrimental to their relationship with those women.

As for the women, they in turn live in a like, or even more distressing, condition with regard to the men, whose company they enjoy only half the time, and whom, divided by expectation, doubt, and uncertainty, they regard only half as their husbands. They are no support to them or to their families, and treat them only temporarily as their wives; whereby many, upon the husbands' return, are forced to let it happen that the mothers choose another father for their children. Just as the Indians of Hispaniola inhale the vapor of a certain herb called cohoba, which confuses their minds; and when they have taken it, slipping their hands between their knees and hanging down their heads, remain for a time in ecstasy; whereupon, rising, they tell wondrous tales of their false gods, which they call Cemis --- just as our people do when they come from the Sabbath --- so do these women behave with petun or nicotiana, which each plants in her garden, however small it may be; and whose vapor they use to clear their brains and to somewhat stave off hunger.

Now I do not know whether this vapor stupefies them as that plant stupefies the Indians; but I do know that it makes their breath and whole body so foul-smelling that no creature not accustomed to it can endure the stench. They, however, practise this fumigation four times a day, and thus, accustomed to this smell and to the sea-smell of the men, they dread no other. Formerly, as girls enjoying the freedom of the mountains, already reminded by the manner of their head-dress of the nudities of paganism, they have, in the close relations of the sexes, too often listened to temptation for those other demons to frighten them. Neither they nor the men, moreover, have been raised in the fear of God. Even their priests have in part given themselves to the service of Satan, and have even profaned their churches. For we have judicially established that the Sabbath has been kept in the church of the Holy Spirit on Mount Rhune, and in the church of Dourdar. \

Thus, instead of promoting the congregation and bringing it to a better path through churchly aid, they rather lead it astray; by repeating at night everything that they practise in the church by day in the service of evil. The women again take their part in this; for they have free access to the churches under the name of the Benedictines, who undertake the outward household, decorate the altar, keep the linen in order, and exercise similar duties. One such woman must already be in the church before daybreak, just as the last must be there in the evening to clear away the altars and extinguish the lights; which, in a land of such loose morals, can give occasion to many things that do not respect the sanctity of the place.

From all this is explained whence the great spread of witchcraft in this country comes. The men are light and agile, both in body and in mind; decisive and hasty in all their actions, ever with their foot in the air; inclined more to revenge and homicide than to theft --- for I have never seen one of them condemned as a thief at the parlement. Yet, since they are poor and needy, and too proud to go begging, they find themselves all too ready to yield to the devil's deceptions. The women, for their part, given over to idleness because they have little to keep them at home or to manage, and eaten up with deadly boredom, likewise readily surrender themselves to his promises; when he blinds their senses and holds out to them pleasures and marvels which would be their portion in his orgies and at his Sabbaths, and displays to them all his pomp and all his glory, so that they believe an earthly paradise will be their lot, into which only the most chosen and select will be admitted. Satan's greatest exertion is directed against the poor children, who, regarding the churches as true houses of God and the pastors as their protectors, fly into them as into asylums; these \[places\] are profaned, and the pastors themselves are found in part infected by the evil. Yet no other refuge remains to them, and one sees them sleeping in troops in the houses of God; and it seems to them that the devil has no power over them to tear them away from there and bring them into his accursed assemblies.

From that point the evil, spreading further westward, overspread the whole Spanish peninsula. About the same time that the French commission was at work in Labourd, striving by fire to cauterize out the cancer, the Inquisition in Spain did not remain idle and joined in the efforts. In November 1610 there took place an auto-da-fé at Logroño in Castile, which was solemnly held over those found guilty; a report of this act was printed at that very place, from which de Lancre gives a detailed account. Fifty-three persons were brought forward; twenty-one men and women went as penitents bareheaded, with a candle in the hand and a rope about the neck. The same number, with paper mitres on their heads as a sign that they had been expiated, followed them. Then the bones of five deceased persons, with their effigies, were carried, and six others closed the procession last, wearing the habit of Saint Benedict and the mitre on their heads, indicating that they had once before been released by the Inquisition. The five effigies with the bones, and the six who went last --- among whom Maria de Rocaya, distinguished above all as a mistress of witchcraft, stood out --- were handed over to the secular arm and burned in the fire. \

Among the others were especially twelve sorcerers and sorceresses who had been tried; others were charged with different crimes. Of these, twenty-four were subjected to various corporal punishments; eighteen others, who acknowledged that they had associated with witches all their lives and begged for mercy with tears in their eyes because they wished to return to the faith, were received as penitent and actually reconciled. They were from Navarre and the neighboring Spanish towns, and in part connected with the refugees from the French Basque country. As in this instance, so has the Inquisition throughout Spain --- the land of the ancient Priscillianists --- acted. Another focal point for France falls in the Alps, namely in the Dauphiné and the neighboring districts.

"The Dauphiné," Michelet says in his survey of the French tribes, \"lies like a fortress under the lee of the Alps, and its inhabitants are called Francieur by the Provençals, by which they mean that with them begins a series of Gallic tribes different from themselves; a series which thence runs through the lowlands of the Bresse, over the ridges of the Franche-Comté, and through Lorraine as far as Belgium. A vigorous spirit of resistance and opposition marks these provinces, and a stock of severe, analytical minds has arisen from them. A lively and free simplicity, in the manner of all mountain-people, which appeals to everyone, characterizes these Dauphinois; their women, in turn, are likewise distinguished by a manly, vigorous spirit. Old age is highly honoured among them; for their dead a funeral feast is held each November, and everyone is presented with his share of the funeral food, made of eggs and flour. Each year the land sends forth not only swarms of masons, water-carriers, teamsters, chimney-sweepers into the neighbouring provinces, but also hordes of schoolmasters descend into the surrounding plain to offer their services in the lower elements of learning to those eager to be taught. \


Keywords: - arins and sabellius teachings in frisia[Page 74]

\]

The inhabitants of the lowland appear less noble, given over to demagogy, and inclined to satire.\" While the sea-facing Provence, and still more the inward-closed Languedoc, in their Iberian blood more inclined to pure, crude Manichaeism, which broke out in the Albigenses and drew its demonic nature from that source: in that other tribal grouping rationalism will predominate, and the dark streams will flow more for that reason. But rationalism, in the spirit of that opposition, tears itself away from the tribe of original tradition; grounding doctrine on free understanding itself, and morality on arbitrariness of the will. Thus the boni homines of the Middle Ages descended with the bands of wanderers from those heights --- westward into the lowlands of the Rhône; and eastward the Waldenses poured into their valleys. Such teaching is of course averse to all spirit-beings, but only insofar as tradition is rooted in them; if, however, it lends a hand to the preservation of its own existence, it by no means casts them off.

While, therefore, the misunderstanding of personal freedom in that land of the Allobroges through the fourteenth century was driven on to Turlupinism in the societas paupertatis and to the disorder of the Beguards with their saying, ubi spiritus Domini, ibi libertas, Calvinism founded its school of prophets on the heights of the Dauphiné. From there that school then spread further into the Cévennes, the connecting link of the Alps with the Pyrenees; taking root in the kindred popular spirit of the inhabitants there, and in the excitement which the revocation of the Edict of Nantes had aroused in them. All the symptoms of ecstasy in the course of the Cévennes war manifested themselves en masse in those mountains, and testify to a predisposition to clairvoyance among these peoples.

And as now the phenomena of heresy and sorcery likewise rest upon the same basis, so they too have there attached themselves to it; on the one hand, in one cluster rooted in Manichaean doctrine and a licentious life; on the other hand, in a second cluster based on intellectual, rationalistic pride and the bold defiance of the mountain peoples. Thus it spread over Burgundy and the county palatine, on the one side toward Savoy, on the other as far as Lorraine. Thus Remy at the end of the fifteenth century found the evil generally widespread there among a bold people, partly living solitary in the mountain forests, and, as his folk-songs prove, thoughtful and inwardly given to mourning, besides poor and meager; so that he felt called, within fifteen years, to hold nine hundred trials.

From there it spread down the Moselle into the Trier region, and by the Meuse over into Belgium and Flanders, where in 1459 a similar slaughter had occurred. The rest of France had by no means remained untouched; the plague was so widespread, or the suspicion so keen, that Crespet (de odio satanæ), in the time of Francis I, on the testimony of those involved, could set the number of those entangled in sorcery throughout all France at at least 100,000.

Parliamentary councillor Florimond de Remond, however, relates in chapter 7 of his Antichrist: vice is so common that the prisons, like the time of the judges, did not suffice; and horror seized them at the dreadful things they had to learn in the interrogations. Understandably, the confused spirit that moved this land also opened an outlet into England. The accusation in 1303 in Rome against an English bishop, that he had concluded a pact with the Evil One and, in the usual way, rendered to him feudal homage, shows that this had already occurred early. The teachings of Langham of Kent, Wycliffe and others showed that the heresies, in rationalistic as well as dualistic form, had likewise forced an entrance, and that those aberrations had thus also penetrated. \

The religious agitation which, in the wake of the Reformation, seized the minds in this country as in Scotland, soon likewise loosened here the predisposition to the second sight, wherever it was found among the people. Patrick Walker, who wrote under Charles II, relates: that time was marked by wonderful visions in lonely, desolate places. In 1668 and the years about then those assembled at such places, when the Gospel was preached to them there, had the vision of pitched tents, about which men and women were gathered, and from which voices were heard.

Especially on the first night, when John Dickson preached east of Glasgow, the people, as they made their way to the spot, saw, off the road, such a vision; and a voice came from the tent which loudly cried: "This is the eternal Gospel; hold fast to it and confess yourselves to it, and then it will never be taken from you!" When they went up to it, everything was vanished. Others, who came along another road, heard in a sweet voice the 93rd Psalm begin to be sung; so that they stood still until the singers had finished. Still others, who had stayed at home in various places, heard the 44th Psalm and the 46th; so that, when the first returned, they received them with the words: "Where have you been so long? the place of the sermon was so near; for we heard the Psalm sung, and can tell you of the sermon." John Blackadder questioned many honest people about this, and they all attested to the truth of the matter. Likewise at Craigmad in Stirlingshire, where A. Stirling heard the 121st Psalm, and saw a white horse with a red saddle among the singing people; and in Darmead, where the 59th Psalm sounded. The people were at that time so excited that they believed of the bishops of the High Church: they had claws on their feet, and cast no shadows; the soldiery that pursued them wore impenetrable armor, and rode on horses which, like foxes, could climb the rocks; the justices of the peace, however, were believed to be seen in great intimacy with the demon. All these regions, moreover, were in the time of James also the scenes of witchcraft; the records and the parliamentary acts in England from 1541 to 1682, where the three last witches in Exeter at the gallows expiated, as in Sutherland 1722, give testimony to that.

Those two French stocks, the Pyrenean and the Alpine, have meanwhile, from their own soil, certainly modified and increased the evil; yet they by no means called it forth from their own ground: rather it came to them, with the general migration of history from east to west, from neighboring Italy. There, as we have seen, Manichaean and rationalistic heresies had earlier spread in the towns and in the countryside; to these the demonic disorder afterwards attached itself. In the continuation of the French Alps there dwells also an Italian people, comparable to the Iberian Basques and to the Gallic Dauphinois; full of stubborn spirit and courageous mettle, who, e.g. the people of Como, Bergamo, Brescia, etc., make among the best soldiers. Bernard Retegno, whom Pope Julius II in 1505 appointed as inquisitor, found records of the Inquisition concerning witchcraft in the diocese of Como that went back to 1350. So great was the zeal of the local inquisitors for the extirpation of the evil, that Spina relates: the number of those who annually fell under the investigation of the local inquisitor and his eight to ten vicars amounts to a thousand, and that in single campaigns as many as a hundred of them were burned. \

In the nearby county of Burbia the bewitched had eaten children; the Inquisitor Cumanns was called upon by one of the inhabitants, who had thus lost his child, to intervene; as a result of the process he instituted, in the year 1485 forty-one of them were delivered to the fire; the others fled across into Tyrol. Camonica, the open spring-valley of the Oglio above Lake Iseo, is inhabited by a robust people, mostly composed of shepherds. According to Thevet all are mighty sorcerers who occupy themselves with incantations, and practise everything by the power of the simple means furnished by the vegetation of their mountains and valleys.

Theodor von Folengo in his Orlandino, first canto, stanza 12, mentions this magic-cry of the local people, which has been preserved down to our times. Around 1517 an inquisitor took note of it; the consequence was that many made satisfaction in the flames. The same bold spirit which may perhaps have led some from natural magic into the demonic would not, however, brook a procedure that, in turn, confused one of these magics with the other without distinction. The people took up arms, and appealed from the Inquisition to the court of the bishop. The bishop summoned the jurist Alciatus, as seems to appear from his writings, to report; the government in Venice intervened; the Council of Ten annulled the proceedings of the ecclesiastical court and ordered a review, whereupon the people quieted down.

A similar forcible self-help seems to be the outcome of an earlier incident in the diocese of Como, related by Bernardus Comensis. He tells, namely: When about fifty years earlier, that is about 1460, Bartholomew de Homate was inquisitor there, Lorenzo of Concoretio was podestà, and Johannes de Fasseto was notary, and they were inquiring into heresy at the Comacine place Mandrisio; one day the podestà wished to satisfy himself whether the heretics really and in bodily person went to the Sabbath, or only in imagination. He therefore arranged with one of the initiated that she should lead him to such a spectacle, and so on a Thursday he went, with the notary and a third man who had been summoned, to the spot pointed out by that woman. The three there saw many persons gathered round the demon, who had assumed human form, and how a great lord sat among them. At first, as Prieras adds to his version of the report, the master of the chair took no notice of the intruding strangers. After the meeting ended, however, he gave a sign, and then suddenly those present fell upon the spectators and beat them with cudgels so that all three died within fourteen days. The matter, Bernard adds, is still in many persons' remembrance in Como. That in these valleys the whole activity was likewise connected with the heresies, and that action against the evil, when it was shown by an impartial and dispassionate inquiry, had the mass of the people on its side, is shown by the following remarkable account which Giussano has preserved for us in the Life of Saint Borromeo. \

The valley of Mesolcina, which belongs to Graubünden, was, at the time of this archbishop, besides the heresies and other evils already recounted, also filled with those who practiced malefices and witchcraft with the help of the demon, to whom the abandoned wholly surrendered themselves, and who now committed great and intolerable wicked deeds. By their sorceries and malignities they harmed both people and beasts; for they not only brought various sicknesses upon adults and children, but even sentenced them to death: and it happened that people and whole herds threw themselves down from the mountains; which caused the populace great distress and harm, all the more because they could find no remedy. In that year 1583 the communities therefore assembled the common council of the valley to discuss measures by which the evil might be remedied; and those assembled resolved to take refuge with the archbishop and to beg him that he would grant them counsel and assistance in this matter. They therefore sent some of the principal persons of the valley to Milan to lay the commission before him, and they were received by him very kindly; and, rejoicing that God was opening the way for him to be active in the service of these communities, he kindly promised them his assistance; and he offered to go personally into the valley in order better to learn of the situation and to take precautions for what was necessary. With this he dismissed them comforted.

He then considered the importance of this affair very maturely and cautiously, and judged it necessary first to send a judge under the name of an Inquisitor, who would, within the bounds of justice, initiate the inquiry against the malefices and witchcraft. For this task he chose Francesco Borsatto, a famous Mantuan jurist who had shortly before put on the clerical habit; and, drawn by the public reputation of the archbishop, had come to Milan to receive the holy orders from his hand and to learn in his school the practice of ecclesiastical discipline. Borsatto carried out the necessary investigations with great prudence and agility. He found almost the entire region infected by witchcraft; and, what is worse, he discovered that the provost of this valley himself, who resided in the collegiate church of Rovereto, was as it were the head and leader, after he had transformed himself from a shepherd into a ravening wolf. He therefore instructed the judicial processes, and conducted them with so much humanity and goodwill that he won all hearts, and was then able to dispose of all things according to his judgment.

These wise efforts proved very useful for the visit the Cardinal wished to make there, and served as the best preparation for greater matters. But since the Holy Man knew with what caution one must proceed, how fiercely one must contend with the infernal enemy, and what difficulty commonly presents itself in the destruction of evil diabolical arts, and still more of damned heresies, he deemed it necessary, after having in accordance with his custom first taken refuge in prayer, to choose some men distinguished by kindness and learning to assist him in various functions in his undertaking. Among these were Father Francesco Pignarola, a Milanese noble and very celebrated preacher, who afterwards became Bishop of Asti; Father Achilla Gagliardi of the Society of Jesus, a man of great authority and experience and an exceedingly learned theologian; and lastly Bernardino Morra, his general auditor, who was afterwards made Bishop of Aversa by Clement VIII, after he had in the most honorable manner endured many hardships for the Church. \

After he had put all these matters in order, he left Milan at the beginning of November and went to settle in Rovereto, the chief town of the valley, where he was received with jubilation by the people there, from which he drew great hope for blessed fruits. When Borsatto had finished the instruction of the processes, he reported to the bishop. Since the latter now knew that people of that sort are very hard to advise, on account of the special friendship and the close contracts into which they had entered with the devil, he therefore tried, with great patience (supported in this by his subordinates), every means so that the bound ones might see their grievous errors, renounce the devil and his false arts, and turn their hearts to God. His efforts were not in vain; for he converted a sufficient number of them; at one time he was able to obtain more than 150 abjurations, who then confessed to him and received communion. Eleven old witch-women, the leaders of the others, who had wholly given themselves over to the devil, and who perhaps no longer deserved God's mercy on account of the exceedingly grave offenses they had committed against Him, remained hardened in their sin; and since all effort with them was in vain, they were delivered over to the secular arm and punished with death by fire.

The same obduracy was shown by the provost of Rovereto, who was the head of that wicked sect; and however much the cardinal and his subordinates labored, they could never soften that seduced heart to a true recognition of its faults. Therefore, out of obedience to the holy canons, they found themselves compelled to proceed, by public act, to his degradation, an act accompanied by the cardinal's tears and deepest sorrow; in which he also delivered a sermon to the people lamenting the offender in person, and expressed his oral regret that he was compelled by the command of the law to an act so far removed from his mercy and clemency. "You see, my sons," thus began the sermon, "the decision of the holy Church against her servants who have made themselves unworthy of ecclesiastical service;" and he then went on to show how unwillingly the Church, as the mildest of mothers, has recourse to such decisions. It cannot be told what care he took for the conversion of the heretics as well as for cleansing the people of their superstition; for he had spent much time in making these persons receptive of the truth. Even with the lowliest he showed the utmost patience, although some proved themselves most obstinate and gave him exceedingly unseemly answers. He did not, however, act as if he felt it, but persisted in his long-suffering and zeal to gain their souls for God. In this way he reformed that entire valley and brought it into a wholesome condition; a result that seemed more wonderful than natural.

The whole Italian chain of the Alps was thus, just as much as the French, infected by the same evil; and while this, in the direction of the Apennines, spread southward over all Italy as far as the walnut-tree of Benevento and beyond to Sicily, it likewise overspread all Germany to the north. In the Bernese territory, toward the end of the fifteenth century, according to the testimony of Nider, witchcraft was very common; and Peter of Bern, a secular judge, raged against it. The cited examples all belong to French Switzerland and the diocese of Lausanne; into these regions the evil had penetrated from Savoy, where the Inquisition at the same time found itself much engaged. \

But the German Switzerland was at the same time also seized by it, and Nider mentions an entire succession of reputed sorcerers in that region who, judging by their names, were of Teutonic stock. At the beginning of the fifteenth century there was, namely, a certain Scaf or Schaf notorious as such, who boasted that he could, in order to escape the hands of his enemies, turn himself into a mouse; nevertheless he was killed by them by an unexpected assault. His pupil and the inheritor of his secrets was a certain Hoppo, who is also known to Sprenger, and who in his turn initiated, in the third generation, one called Stadelein, whom that Peter in turn burned. They boasted of making weather, of shifting grain, of smothering children; they could render men and cattle barren, strike the horses under their riders with madness; ride through the air, repel their pursuers with stench, disclose hidden things, see into the distance, and foretell the future. The authors of the Hexenhammer, Sprenger and Institor, likewise found much work in German Switzerland, and from there, by way of Basel and Strasbourg, traced the tracks that led to the Lower Rhine; whereupon Kalteisen pursued them further into Belgium and Holland. In East Franconia the evil showed itself at various intervals, and from 1627--29 the flames consumed 158, among them 14 curates and five canons. To Austria and Bohemia the Lollardy had already, at the beginning of the 14th century, carried over its Manichaeism, to which a century later the Hussite rationalism was added; no wonder, then, that the demonic practice went over with it and now infected the whole North, which had already been prepared from the Netherlands by the Stadingher; and in Friesland, Mecklenburg, East Prussia, everywhere now, in the midst of the Protestant lands, the funeral pyres flared up. The plague penetrated even into the Scandinavian mountains; after it had earlier run its course in the region of Elffdale and the fire there had set its bounds, it broke out suddenly in 1669 and so in Mohra and the surrounding places, and the inhabitants begged the government for measures against the same, in order to restore the peace. A commission of clergy and laymen was sent there, and this, after it had examined all witnesses and taken statements, found that in the village of Mohra there were 70 witches who had seduced about 300 children. Of those, on voluntary confession, 23 were \[condemned\], of these 15 were sentenced to death; 36 children had to run with birches, 20 with rods in their hands, for three Sundays in succession stand in the church doors --- a punishment to which those 36 likewise had to submit for an entire year.

Ethnographically determined nodes, in which the threads of the web of witchcraft spreading over the earth are entangled, are not to be mistaken throughout all this; and these points fall near those germ-centres to which the confluences in the forms of paganism attached themselves, and to which afterwards the newer heresy again established definite relations. The Orient is therefore also the first original point of radiation; and as the Alps pass into the Hæmus, and this into the Taurus and the Caucasus, so to the Alpine tribes the first germs of Manichaeism came from the Balkan peoples, and these in turn from the Taurus mountains and Lesser Armenia --- which finally run together in the cave of Manes, and the older Mithraic peoples of the yet deeper East converge. \

The mysteries of demonic service have followed this guidance; other currents in other channels have joined them: and blood and temperament, and direction of thought, and circumstances in history have here and there taken them up preferentially, and the fire has run on in the innermost marrow of things, in the tinder that presented itself to it, and thus this solfatara in history has been formed. History has therefore taken them up here and there in preference, and the fire has continued in the very core of things, in the tinder that was offered to it, and thus this solfatara in history has been developed.

#### D. Morbid Intensification of the Predisposition From Within

If the predisposition is present in individuals at the outset, it then easily increases from within through subjective affections, and mysterious states develop in which the decision whether they were really formed in this way, or objectively introduced from without by an injurious influence, is subject to great difficulty. A remarkable story that occurred at the beginning of the 17th century in Danish Zealand at once places us in the midst of this mode of operation and the question connected with it. The mistress of the house in which the affair took place wrote down the report of it; and Brunsmann, rector of the school of Herlof, later published it and supplemented it from the judicial records of the town of Køge, near Copenhagen. The events occurred between 1609 and 1614, but the publication was first made in Danish in 1674, while a daughter of the household was still alive. Later the book also appeared in Latin under the title: \[Enarratio Cagiensis?\] sive admirabilis historia de horrenda cacodæmonis tentatione, quacum in urbe Coagio \[a most honest and most reputable family\] for some years was afflicted. Second Latin edition, enlarged and corrected, Leiden. Leipzig, 1695.

The affair created a great sensation on its appearance, and Becker in his Bezauberte Welt explained it in his shallow manner; on the spot no one thought otherwise than that the narrative, as the woman had written it down, was perfectly true; and Brunsmann, in the second edition, repelled the suspicion of any fraud having occurred with proper scorn. \
