"The demon," Anna begins her account, "called malum domesticum, first made himself felt when I once went to bed in the evening with my husband. We heard under our heads a sound like the cooing of a hen calling her chicks. Startled, we rose and told the matter to our friends the next day; who then advised that it was due to snakes and other natural causes." We therefore examined the bed, pillows, and straw sack most carefully, but found nothing. Soon afterwards one evening, when I went from the room into the cellar, I saw a toad on long thin legs as if coming from the door; but when, frightened, I called the household together, we found nothing. The following night my youngest child gave a terrible scream, and when the maid lighted a lamp to look after him, she herself went pale and said: the demon had attacked her; she therefore fell ill from that time on, so that we had to hire another maid for her service for half a year. My little eight-year-old daughter then suddenly ran, frightened and crying, to her father: she dared not sleep in the children's room, for at nightfall there always came a strong man, in a silk garment, with a mustache and frightful eyes, before whom she was terribly afraid. We scolded her for her timidity, and she had to go to bed. But when her father had left her, she broke out into great weeping and screaming; we hastened to her, and found her deathly pale. She then became ill, and caused food and drink to be expelled again through her lips; yet she afterwards recovered.

Soon after my husband had to travel to Germany, and two weeks after his departure a great terror came upon our house. A young man, called Jakob, a nephew of my husband, began to be beset with fear by the spirit of temptation. For when he went to bed at evening he began to lament and to cry, and said he could not sleep in his room because of the demon and the ghosts. So we made his bed in ours; but when he lay down there he began again to bewail himself; and when we ran to him his whole bed trembled; and the boy's eyelids were so widely torn apart that they could not be closed or brought together by anyone; his mouth, however, was so tightly shut that no one could open it. After he at last came to himself and began to speak, we asked him how he was. He answered: God knows it; to me it is unknown. At last sleep came over him, so that he rested the remainder of the night, and slept until the tenth hour on the following day. On rising, however, he looked so corpse-pale and emaciated that it was a terror to all. That evening, as he stood at the table during supper, I said to him: Take something to eat, Jakob! Lie down, and commend yourself to God's protection, so that you do not again behave as on that accursed night, whereby we all were thrown into terror, and finally must leave the house! As I spoke these words, the doors of the chamber and the kitchen were torn open of themselves, and so violently that they struck against the walls; the youth, however, was torn from the room into the hall, where he was raised two ells high into the air, hanging suspended; without anyone present who supported him or held him aloft. His arms were stretched up, his eyes wide open, his mouth drawn together, his chin twitched up and down as if it were about to be torn off. \

We tried with all our strength, grasping him by hands and feet, to pull the one hovering down; but the limbs hung so motionless that we could not even shift him or move him from the spot. We therefore all, kneeling in the hall, called to God that He would remember His mercy. Then the youth was released and set again upon the ground. But his mouth was still closed so that he could not speak, until we made him vomit with a silver spoon. Then he sighed, and his tongue was loosened, and his speech restored; and when we asked him how he was, he said: I hope that, with God's help, I will now grow better; for when you called to God on your knees, he went away, and moved from the well to the wood-pile. When I asked, "Who has gone?" he answered, "Satan." When I further asked whether he had then bound himself to Satan, he burst into tears and said, "You do me a great wrong, mother, in holding me capable of such a crime; my years have not taught me such things!"

While he spoke thus, a great noise was heard in the entry-hall, and a monstrous voice was heard, which however no one understood. The young man said: it is the voice of Satan, who speaks with him. At that moment a great fire flared up in the entry-hall, running about here and there. The young man said: Satan had spat the fire from his throat. We then took him into the room and read to him from God's Word until two o'clock after midnight, whereupon sleep at last came upon him, which lasted until the eleventh hour the next morning. He was, however, soon assailed again, and the terrors in our house increased day by day; all the more because I kept the matter secret until my husband's return. Of him Satan said: he had dogged him for fourteen years, but on account of the great man (so he used to call God), whose assistance he invokes day and night, I could do nothing against him; instead of him you are now delivered to me! The young man wept as he told this, and lamented that he had ever set foot in Denmark; for he was a German, and his temptation by Satan grew worse and worse thereafter.

At times he crucified him, bowing his head and crossing his feet one over the other, as Christ is represented on the cross: then no one could bend him, or move him from the spot, or alter his stance and appearance; he turned the whites of his eyes outward as if he were dead. At last my blessed husband returned home, and was informed of what had occurred. He caused prayers to be said for us in the town and the neighboring churches. He appointed the three successive Sundays as days of penance for the whole household, on which none, neither man nor beast, should eat or drink anything.

On the first of those days it was as if Satan would force in the windows, and the young man wailed that he would carry him off through the open window; the Evil One also appeared to some as a raven, to others as a goose. --- For a month the afflicted one had not slept soundly; now he began to enjoy some rest and awoke cheerful; likewise nothing had occurred in the house during the whole night, and the awakened man related that during the night his angels had told him he would get better. Yet he announced at eleven in the evening the return of the Evil One, who indeed appeared and remained with him until Easter. \

A little white puppy lay in our parlor; it was lifted by the head and struck against the floor, though no one was visible who could have held it. It then hid itself under the bench, and was drawn out from beneath it by the head, and, resisting with its hindquarters, was dragged along the floor. The next morning it was frantic, tried to bite everyone who came to visit us; and we were obliged to kill it. When at last the time came in which the tormented young man was to be freed, he rose in bed and wrestled with Satan, using God's Word for the conflict; he recited many prayers that the neighbors we had summoned listened to; finally he lifted his hands to heaven and cried out: Now be God praised, who has delivered me from Satan! Then, turning to the other side, he extended his hand to someone we did not know and said: Hail to you, angel who standest at the right hand of God; forsake me now never, whether I travel by water or by land! He spoke other such words, reached out his hand again after kissing it; then wrapped himself in his blanket so that we saw nothing but the crown of his head; and we heard him, like a small boy with a clear voice, sing: Glory to God in the highest and peace on earth to men of good will. Now he rose up, and was completely well again; before, without our help he could do nothing, so bent and contracted was he, and he could not straighten himself up; henceforth he felt nothing more of all that affliction, and we were joyful and all thanked God.

But God, in his unfathomable counsels, sought to visit us even more harshly. My husband now began to be assailed day and night, harder than anyone can imagine; namely from eleven o'clock in the morning and evening until two o'clock after noon and after midnight. It began when I had stayed at home from the Sunday service because of a boy's illness; thereupon such a terror seized us all that we altogether fell upon benches and chairs, or upon the floor. We came to ourselves again, and after we had prayed the evil vanished again. The maids and the children, however, again saw apparitions; and my husband, who had already been sorrowful for three weeks, became all the more downcast when he learned of it. Once, when I adjured him by God to at least tell how he was, he collapsed; and when he came to himself again he said: God, who is always gracious and merciful to those who call on him, may he also be mindful of me and of ours, and bring us help! So sorely am I pressed by Satan day and night that heaven and earth seem to lie upon me with their weight. You will not long have me with you further as a husband, and my children will soon be orphans. From that time on he was harried more and more fiercely; according to his account something lay upon him daily at that hour like a sack of fruit; and at times swellings, as large as hen's eggs, would break out at his side. I again had prayers held in the churches, and also drove by carriage out to Mr. Johannes in the parish of Norderup to solicit his assistance. But when, on my return, I entered a wood the carriage became so heavy that the horses could scarcely move it; the trees crashed about us, something as high as a tower rose up before us, and a dreadful voice was heard which we could not understand. When I, having come home, went to bed and, my right hand bowed over my head, fell asleep, it was as if a mouse were gnawing my finger. However I cried and for a quarter of an hour tried to pull the finger to me, I could not; the finger seemed dislocated to me, and although nothing could be seen on it, yet I could not move it for a whole month. \

On the following night, when I lay in bed with my husband, a heat seized us, as if the bed were standing in flames; so that we could not sleep. But when we rose the next morning, there lay on the lower sheet, from the pillow to the feet, a hanging of filth, two and two as masses united in a link of the chain, as if they had been strung on a thread, and so numerous that one could scarcely see the sheet beneath them. Our neighbors looked on this in amazement. Ingeburg, the wife of Mejer, who had come over, heard a loud laugh but saw no one. When she, frightened, withdrew again, my husband fainted. We brought him to bed, and sat in the front room until the ninth hour; but when I then wished to go to bed, he was no longer in it, and at last we found him in a small room, weeping and lamenting. This continued until it finally ended as the whole affair had begun: in my husband's head-pillow, into which the spirit had thrown itself, and from whose lower side, when it was removed, it had torn a piece out of the covering so that the feathers flew about the whole room. My husband was then freed.

When we gave thanks to God for this deliverance in the churches, our nine-year-old son fell ill. Yet we could not fathom his sickness; he said something living ran through his body, gnawing at him here and there. We tried baths and other remedies, but he grew worse. A surgeon we consulted likewise could give no explanation, and directed us to a woman versed in healing who at that time visited our town. She said the boy was possessed, and that nothing would help but prayer. Meanwhile, as the boy lay in his willow-woven bed, the bed together with him was lifted two ells into the air and was moved hither and thither. When I therefore called my husband, the boy had meantime been pulled out of the bed and stood on his head, his feet turned upward and his hands outstretched; so that we could hardly get him back into bed. Something continued to run through him; his body sometimes swelled horribly, his tongue was thrust out of his mouth, and then again was wound up like a cloth, while blood pressed through his lips. His limbs were drawn so together that four strong men were not enough to pull them apart. He grunted like a pig, clucked like a cock, and howled like a dog. At times it carried the boy onto the beams of our room, or on a pile of wood, and left him there; so that he did not know where he was and wept bitterly. It also threw him over the wall into the gateway of our neighbor Mejer. Sometimes it drew his eyes and cheeks so far back into his head that they were no longer visible. The boy became rigid like a log, and we set him up in this condition against the wall, where he then stood motionless like a statue; so that even the most hard-hearted were moved to tears at the sight of him.

Once, when I myself was at the evening sermon on a Sunday, it ill-treated my mother, who had stayed at home; the spirit, taking my likeness, pulled her shoes from her feet and struck her with them. She therefore received me on my return home weeping and with bitter reproaches. Although women the next day assured her to the contrary, she could scarcely be persuaded until the spirit, speaking from the boy's mouth, told my husband about it, adding: Had the Great One permitted it, I would have treated her so that the whole town would have wept for her. When we in the evening prayed the 46th Psalm, he neighed like a horse to it; he spat upon my husband's face so that it ran into his beard. He placed bare knives upon my breast; but when I said he should strike in the name of Jesus, the knives fell to the floor. He said to my husband: Be not too hasty, you will not drive me from here until those who brought me here receive their deserved reward! That is the will of the great man; even if I am a liar, he at times compels me to tell the truth. I would wish the time were already come when I could leave the house. When my husband asked when that time would come, he answered: Only that great man knows, not I.

My husband, after having borne so much himself and for his family, was now delivered from all misery; he himself passed to the other life, and left me alone, entangled in combat with the raging enemy, who would not cease to speak from the boy's mouth. The affliction continued for two years after my husband's death. Magister Glostrup held prayers for us in the church, often came to our house, spoke with Satan, and reproved him harshly. He also tried to speak with him in Latin; but the reply was: he would not burden his head with Latin. At last God would not permit him to continue his persecutions; he had to desist, and our house became as free from spectres as it had been before --- for which may the holy Name of God be praised, who does not abandon His own in their distress. I have written this down as a memorial of what happened in our house, and it contains, so help me God! the pure truth.

This is also known to M. N. Glostrup, then our pastor, now Bishop of Opfloe; likewise to P. von Duebrodere, Bartolo Foannis; to Peter Mann in Ferse, to the pastor Jakob in Nordrup, Caspar in Roeschild, Lorenz in Liemarch, Nicolaus in Vallensby --- several of whom still live, others are already dead. Magister Nicolaus had the boy in his house for half a year; the boy afterwards recovered, once the authors of our misfortune had expiated their guilt, and lived until the year 1620, when the great mortality carried him off.

One might, on reading this account, imagine that every member of that worthy family went mad in turn; but it would not be proper to attribute the participation of all the named pastors to the influenza as well. The censor of the book, Fan Berharod, who, after reading it, believes it will help to confirm Scripture's teaching about demons, likewise must not have escaped the contagion. Then there are the two burgomasters of the town, father and son, and the senator Pomeyer, who officially and before God declare to the author Brunsmann that there is no reason to suspect fraud in what is contained in the woman's report; that they have had the truth of the matter confirmed by their predecessors, and that it also appears as such in their records, which they have placed at his disposal; they too must be regarded as having suffered from the same malady.

The circle of this strange mental disorder grows still wider when one reads the extracts Brunsmann has made from these records. The householder Barscher had taken suspicion of the authors of the mischief in his house, and this suspicion had fallen upon Johanna Thomana, with whom he had formerly been in business relations --- relations he broke off when she was accused, by Christina Capserin (who had been executed for witchcraft), of being implicated. Her grievance had been increased when he had pre-purchased a house on which she had bid. For this reason he had taken an advocate, and by him caused the suit to be prosecuted before the town council. The investigation was instituted and carried out; on 8 June 1612 sixteen judges of guilt were appointed at the Ting of Køge, who are named in the records. They were charged to pronounce only such judgment as, according to the laws, they could justify before God and men. From 8 June until the 3rd... \

The trial lasted through August, during which the lay judges, their hands laid upon the Holy Scripture, declared: As we desire---may God and His holy Word prosper us for good and for salvation---so in this matter we could find nothing otherwise than that Johanna Thomana had been the cause of the mistreatment of the servant in the service of the merchant Johannes, who is reported as possessed; and we can see and discern nothing else than that she is in truth guilty of diabolical sorcery. She confessed, and was executed on 11 September. One sees that the lay judges had judged according to their conscience; and one must believe that they had previously verified all the factual circumstances that underlay the case. Whether, however, they judged rightly in attributing the evil --- that is, the objective influences --- absolutely to that cause, is another question which we shall consider later in general.

In general there are many and various complications into which a person falls when the disposition for night-visions, which sleeps within him, is awakened and, by a particular un-favorableness of the providences of his life, comes to full development and makes him a suitable instrument to receive inspirations from below. We shall cite only one example of such a talent of a negative character which, as one easily sees, with some cultivation could readily have been brought to considerable virtuosity. In a neighboring region, where at a famous pilgrimage-site all sorts of human afflictions converge, and where, therefore, exorcism is also practised as a remedy for one kind of them, the contemporary exorcist made the following experience, which he roughly set down in manuscript in the following words; and which, by the uncanny intervention of spirits into that disposition, may furnish an immediate transition into the next consideration.

In Holy Week, 1836, three brothers of Protestant confession came from Rheinbischofsheim in the Grand Duchy of Baden --- Jakob, David and Friedrich --- bearing a letter from a Catholic parish priest from the Lower-Rhine Alsace, who recommended them for exorcistic treatment because they, their younger sister, and their whole household were continually tormented by evil spirits. From the conversations I had with the three young men in consequence, roughly the following emerged. Descended from common peasant parents and occupied from youth with agricultural work, they had always been healthy and strong. The eldest, Jakob, learned the smith's trade; the second, David, entered service in the army; the third, Friedrich, always remained at home. While Jakob was still abroad, David was one time seized by a very strange condition: he felt as if blown upon by a wind, and such a compression arose on his chest that he began to spit up blood. He was medically treated and was sent to the hospital in Karlsruhe; but all remedies applied were in vain, and he finally received his discharge. Arrived at home, his condition was not at all better, and at the same time extremely strange things happened in the house and in the stable. At the same time Jakob, while abroad, had begun to perceive what was going on in the paternal home; and now the younger brother Friedrich soon also began to be tormented, just like David; and also a younger sister, though not to the same degree as the brothers. In the house there were intermittent rumblings and bangs in a dreadful manner, and in the stable the cattle perished in an unnatural way. When the brothers went across the fields or drove with the cart, stones were often thrown at them from the air. Sometimes, they said, a thunderstorm suddenly stood up in the clearest sky; and on several occasions an unknown animal walked ahead of them and then, at a certain spot, suddenly vanished. \

Physically Jacob suffered little, but he was a kind of visionary, and saw, as he said, the fiends coming. A moment later the brothers would be as if smitten by a breath, and feel an inner motion that increased to the point of hemorrhage; yet so that, when the attack had passed, they felt their strength restored, as if they had never lacked anything. Often it seemed to them as if they were beaten by invisible but still palpable hands; often as if they were pierced through the belly. They ascribed these things neither to the devil nor to actual spectres, but to wicked people. The seer insisted that he had positively recognized the apparitions as persons still living and even related to them; and the strangest stories were adduced in proof.

They had at the outset sought diverse medical help, but found none anywhere; what wonder, since they sought to drive out sorcery by sorcery, and went to those who were reputed to practice such arts. These assisted them on several occasions by sympathetic means, but only for a short time; because, as they alleged, the helpers were better paid by the others. What opinion I should draw from all these accounts as to the real ground of the matter I did not know. I regarded the two younger brothers, David and Friedrich, as hysterical; for their condition, especially that of the latter, pointed to a high degree of suffering. They otherwise appeared to be anything but timid, superstitious people; so that, since I noted they were Protestants --- among whom such things, especially in that district, occur even more than among Catholics --- I was inclined to ascribe the whole affair to a play of the imagination; yet on the other hand their calm narration, their ingenuous answers to embarrassing questions which I put to them, utterly disabused me of that view.

After I had at last deliberated, and after I had to some extent explained to them the meaning of the church benediction, I gave this to them repeatedly once or twice a day. They testified that they felt easier, indeed they seemed entirely free from their plague. I therefore dismissed them in Easter week with a letter to the pastor who had sent them to me; in which I begged him, in consideration of my ignorance concerning the true nature of the affair, to make on the spot inquiries into the relations of the family, into the circumstances of the people among whom they had been raised, and in general into everything that might throw light on the matter; also himself, notwithstanding the general prohibition of exorcism, at least to employ the exorcismum probativum.

At the beginning of June the brothers, to my no small astonishment, returned a second time and brought with them a letter from the pastor, who wrote that he himself had gone to their parental house in Bischofsheim; that he had there examined and investigated all the circumstances, but had discovered nothing significant as to the cause of the matter. He had had the brothers examined by physicians, and these, as the enclosed certificates showed, had detected no bodily disease. Twice he had written to the Vicar General for permission to perform the exorcism; but the latter had only answered evasively. He had now blessed the house, and it had indeed been freed from all haunting; the half-dead cattle were now well too; only the three brothers continued to be tormented, and he therefore repeatedly begged me to apply the exorcism. The medical testimonies ran as follows --- first, that of Dr. Kühn: the three brothers had, several years before, suffered from pulmonary hemorrhage and had been treated by him; but the prescribed remedies had been without effect, because the causes of the ailment could not be sufficiently ascertained. \

Secondly, that of the physician Humann in Herrlisheim, who declared that he had examined the brothers stethoscopically, but had found nothing in them that pointed to an organic defect of the sick person, or to a physiological disturbance of the functions of her body as a whole. The brothers, once they reached me, now assured me that when they had left here on their earlier departure they had remained free of all attacks for two days; upon which, however, the evil had returned, and they were again as before in distress. During their previous absence everything at home had been topsy-turvy; there had been terrible noise, and all the cattle in the stable had seemed as if they were about to die. The distraught father had at once run to the Catholic pastor for help; but since he was prevented from assisting personally he had given him blessed palms; and when these were burned in the stable the animals immediately became healthy and rose up well.

The pastor had afterwards come and blessed the house again, whereupon nothing adverse had occurred since. Only they themselves suffered from the old malady, and begged me piteously to help them, since they firmly believed I could. I had therefore to return to the work, whether I wished to or not, which weighed on me greatly because of the obscurity of the whole affair. I had them tell their stories again, I asked fresh questions, I had them set their answers down in writing; but I could come to no foundation, any more than the first time. Their accounts partly confirmed what had been stated earlier, and partly added new details.

I have again forgotten many things; I will therefore set down only some of what I have written from Jakob before me. He wrote: when he was yet away in foreign parts, a man often came to his workshop by day and by night who showed him how matters stood at home; he always demanded that Jakob should throw money to him, and he would show him what he could do. If Jakob then wished to leave, he could not stir from the spot; nevertheless he was not otherwise prevented from working. The matter soon took a worse turn: the visitors became more numerous; they planned all sorts of things with him, and forced him to swear at night; he often had to carry coffins, was himself laid into them, or had to dig up corpses. They crucified him; but when it was over it appeared that it had been nothing.

Naked women appeared, carried out all manner of mischief with the others, sat on his face, etc., whereupon he then had actual pollutions. They would also have carried him off, it was to him as if he went out through his own eyes, and they led him to games and debauchery. They showed him how they had poisoned the well-water at home, and promised that if he married one of them they would make it right again. Thus it went on as in madness, and when the apparitions presently threatened to devour him, shot at him with pistols, beat him, tore one another's hair, then again came driving up with carriages and horses; another time a man loaded with golden and silver chains would appear and two golden rings would be placed about his arms; when they then rode with him into the clouds, climbed Mount Sinai, gave him nine golden keys, made three garments, set up a white bed before him; meanwhile again firing cannons, making music, launching an assault on Paradise, and desolating and destroying all things --- who could be wise after all that? He complained that these phantasms appeared to him almost every night; whereupon, every time, certain afflictions befell the other brothers. \

He also wrote much about this, from which, however, likewise nothing rational could be drawn; the assertion remained steadfast: the principal persons were close relatives; among others, the father's sister, a notorious woman, with her equally notorious daughter. It was precisely this latter who was to marry Jakob --- but he did not want her. Even their own pastor was said to have been among the fiends. The thought occurred to me: since that notorious aunt had christened all three of them, perhaps the first cause of the evil had been laid then; and for that reason I renewed with them the baptismal vows. I continued to pray with them, instructed them about the churchly benediction, and pronounced it over them.

At last I resolved also to speak the exorcism contra maleficia over them. I can cite nothing remarkable of its striking effects; for the fact that Friedrich once or twice perspired under it, so that the sweat fell in drops, could well be explained by his suffering state. They likewise assured me this time: after each prayer over them they felt lighter, but it would come back again anew every day; it already brought relief when they were even only in the convent. They always thought: if I took it to the highest degree, it would surely be better, it would be altogether well. Almost three weeks thus passed, but no thorough help had been attained; the people's money ran out, and by their long absence from home the accumulating tasks demanded their presence ever more urgently; I could not and would not detain them for a single moment with empty promises. I therefore dismissed them with a letter to the pastor, in which I communicated to him everything that had occurred, and how I had never found a sure sign of a demonic influence. That the exorcism had remained without effect might well be due to the fact that the young people lived outside communion with the church; this defect could indeed have been supplied by my faith and my trust; but since that is only a divine gift which God bestows on whom He will, no one could accuse me on account of the lack of success. A magnetic treatment by a reliable and religious physician might perhaps be advisable in this case; the pastor himself might also, after careful consideration of all the circumstances, privately, and without telling the people what was going on, apply the exorcism.

They went away with this advice, and the narrator, when he wrote this down, had heard nothing further of them since. One must regret that this story could only be observed so incompletely and with so many gaps; for, had it been followed on the spot with attentive eyes for the requisite time, it would have afforded a profound insight into the nature of a most wondrous condition. As it stands, it appears as a popular, and, as one can hardly doubt, sincere report on the modalities of a disposition as it often occurs in witchcraft; and although it lacks sharpness of observation and the investigation of all the circumstances that occurred, it nevertheless, intelligible to a physiological tact, affords many revelations.

It becomes clear from this account: the house of these people, with everything that was bound to it in some relation, has been transferred out of the natural state in which it previously was into a counter-natural one; in which other laws than those of ordinary life prevail. In the midst of this new condition stand, to begin with, the three brothers, who had previously been healthy and strong, but are now reduced to a hectic appearance; and to them the younger sister attaches herself in the first instance. All are united to one another in a physiological bond, and within it stand in reciprocal interaction. \

In this association --- and thus also drawn into the shared suffering --- is also the household's stock of cattle; which, so to speak placed at the circumference of the sphere of action, nevertheless, according to the testimony of the pastor, takes part in everything that occurs within it. Within the house itself things happen that wholly belong to the domain of haunting, and, however one may explain them, they show that this domain has been pushed to the border of two spheres. At the apex of the solidaristic connection stands the first-born; against his will he has become clairvoyant, farsighted and foreseeing; he therefore sees through the whole relationship that attaches itself to him as the members to the head.

Immediately beneath him stand the two brothers, again placed like members to the central organ; they are not seeing themselves, but when he becomes seeing they appear affected; they are, in relation to his knowledge of their condition, as if breathed upon, and are at once seized by an illness in which this knowledge becomes real in them. Congestions of the lungs appear which end in bleeding from the lungs; whereby, after the termination of the attack, as in all maladies of this kind, the powers rapidly restore themselves. The younger sister is also, though less deeply, drawn into this relation of action and reaction; the cattle, as if struck by the outermost emanations, give notice of their participation by rapid falling ill and recovery; and the haunting stirs itself each time as well, and seems to form the medium in which all those effects occur.

Yet the first impulse of the movement by no means proceeds from the centre of the association, and the knowledge of the deed is not realised by the deed alone; rather this realisation also comes to it from elsewhere. Even the clairvoyance Jacob possesses is not entirely his own; there is a man who comes to him and shows him things as they occur. He finds himself bound and held by its power, although it does not prevent his work. It seeks to master him, and employs against him alternately terror and bribery. Desire too it makes its ally; involuntary sympathy it is able to extract from him, only the accession of the will is lacking; and yet all this likewise shows, as the crucifixion does, finally as a haunting.

Opposed to the household association there thus stands another association, which actually effects the realisation, and this association is of demonic nature, its head being that objective apparition; for even the church's actio in distans opposes it and hinders its effect. The members who belong to this counter-association stand in a certain relation to the house itself; it is the ill-famed woman who took the brothers through baptism; it is the pastor who baptized them; it is the woman's daughter who suggests marriage to the seer, and who draws him out with her own eyes, as she had previously bound him, and leads him to play and feasting.

From this counter-association, then, issues the realisation of what is seen; it is the hostile demonic principle that works in it, and it is by no means strictly necessary that its members be aware of the particulars of the matter. They need only, perhaps by their moral demeanour, stand to that principle in an ethically sympathetic relation of some depth: and this principle can, by virtue of the will-less natural force that lives in them, make use of them as instruments to exercise its effects through them; as the like may happen through any natural mischief. Just as this kind of evil, exercised by the haunt-spirits in the frightful manifestations, nakedly comes to light; so, in those fable-like ghostly proceedings, the haunting has only entered into these persons and has personified itself in them. Thus the whole points only to an order of things higher and more intensified than that in which the foregoing phenomena stood. \

There have occurred there the spooky (spukhaften) events, without their actual inner cause having come into view. Here this perception, as clairvoyance bound to the disposition, found itself appended. Now the thus-perceived world presses upon the seer, so that he who hitherto has behaved passively will now also put his will into it, and truly unite himself with it. He resists with all his might, but give such a disposition likewise the perverse will that meets the impulse, and one will fully understand that a tacit or express compact may come to pass. Merely for this reason, because the episode marks a moment of the advance on the path of deepening into the region of night, we have inserted it here, notwithstanding the fragmentary and obscure character in which it has remained for want of keen observation. If the natural disposition is lacking, then it will, in the further advance along the road of evil, be artificially evoked by those natural stimuli of which we have spoken in detail elsewhere.

Nature also has its orgasm, which first manifests itself in the plant kingdom. When the spring sun in that kingdom awakens the sleeping natural impulse, and this then, overflowing through the plant's veins, raises the swelling green toward the warming star, until finally in the blossom the driving force pours itself into fertilization; then those juices and compounds are mixed and boiled out in which the orgasm that produced them rests enclosed, and which, when brought into a higher organization, imprint in it the same quiet natural frenzy that begot them. This intoxication, which in the lower nature expresses itself plastically, becomes in the higher, nervous nature a sensory image which, arising from the sea of senses ordered in the circles of dizziness, opens the murky prospect into higher regions; and, if oft repeated, at last produces in organs thus frequently carried away into intoxication the facility even, in the absence of the exciting agent, of setting themselves from within into that drunken state. That these states, when evoked to evil ends, are directed immediately to the ultimate object of all these ends, and that the Sabbath with all its appurtenances then always stands at that goal, we have already learned from the manifold statements of those who were in such a case. Those, however, were mostly women, and indeed such as belonged to the lower ranks, where self-deceptions of the grossest kind might be suspected. Therefore, in order to supplement what has been said above, the experience made by a man who belonged to the higher ranks, as Prierias has preserved it, cannot be passed over here.

After the author in the first book had established the possibility of demonic influence in an Aristotelian fashion, and the reality by means of the Malleus, he relates at the beginning of the second book: A marvelous event was wont, as experienced by himself, to be told by a resident of Piacenza; who, if he has not recently died, still belongs as a Benedictine monk to the congregation of St. Justina, and there bears the name Jerome. This man, then still worldly, had a love affair with a girl whom he had won with the help of a sorceress; in return for this the sorceress had him promise to attend the Sabbath. She contrived it, however, in such a way that he kept his promise. Naked, he anointed himself between the hand and the arm with a certain salve which she had given him, making at the same time a certain sign which she had taught him. The same was done by the teacher and by the girl whom he had already abused. \

All three were at once lifted up and carried away through an opening in the roof; and he, as it seemed to him, was sitting on a swift horse. Thus they reached the walnut tree of Benevento, and indeed with such speed that the quickly cleft air sounded about them with a sharp noise. Beneath the tree thousands were gathered; a scant light illuminated the scene, and they amused themselves in many ways. After the merriment had ended the witness returned by the same way home, and on the journey he saw many rivers and places, among which he especially noted Venice, which he had never before seen; and later, when he visited it, he recognized again what he had seen in that vision, which also occurred to him with other places. Having returned home, he was---after he had indulged in the pleasure with the girl---horrified at what he had done; and either kindly by nature, or because God had mercy on him, he confessed everything that had happened to the bishop or his vicar, and returned to the Church; who then received him into that order in which he probably even now leads a pious life. Whoever wishes to have full certainty in this matter may turn to Brother Andreas of Genoa, a man of great learning and pious conduct of life; I cite him here as a still-living witness. From this example it becomes clear how everywhere the rinculum must join to sin's clairvoyance in order to impress upon the condition the character of the demonic.

The free, conscious will, in its downward aspect, has two sides in us. With one it is directed toward all that is unconscious in our life, and through this toward the bodily. This unconscious in us, subject to the law of necessity, leads us, if we follow this necessity back to its very source, out of ourselves and over into external nature, which is wholly obedient to its law. If we then proceed further within it, following the direction of this law, we are finally driven toward the innermost unity at the center of this nature; which receives this law from a higher power above, and binds all that is its own downward in it. The will is, in everything that it must accept as inevitable, likewise bound in its expression by this unity; and what is allotted and apportioned to us has obtained its measure from there. \

The same will, however, just as it is set toward God by all that has remained good and uninjured in us, is with its second, downward-going side directed toward that which has entered into us as corruption. In this corruption clings that moral fatality to which everyone succumbs who gives himself up to sin; so that, bound in it, he delivers himself over to that servitude which every sin exercises over the one who has become its servant. If we follow where the bonds of this servitude lead us, we are likewise led out of ourselves into an objective world of evil; and in tracing the traces of the inner connection in this realm we are finally driven toward its innermost concrete unity, in which all the radiations of that ethical necessity converge as in a focal point; a unity which we are accustomed to designate as the root-like evil by the name of Satan. Now if the unconscious in the individual becomes conscious and clairvoyant through temperament and the development of life, or through art, then it comes, freed from what binds it in ordinary life, into closer intercourse with outward nature; the roots in which it connects with her become sensorially potent; but it is thereby by no means demonic. Only when that other side of the will, which descends into corruption, joins to it---when this corruption sharpens in that somnambulistic loosening, and the clairvoyant faculty is made to gravitate toward that other center---only then does the demonic appear.

Every sinful thing which, adding itself to the mass, increases the fund of perdition, then acts as a means of appropriation and as a band that strengthens the pull of the radical evil; so that the operation of the same, in ever-accelerated motion, grows as it approaches. To the loosening which Nature has effected in somnambulism there then attaches that other spiritual factor which effects the ethically nocturnal influence; the entanglement becomes ever deeper, and the encompassing ever more narrow. To the feudal tie into which man at first places himself with the evil principle succeeds the relation of that principle's absolute autocracy in him, under which the lost one has sunk down into unconditional bondage.

### Chapter 3. The Meeting and Confrontation of Humanity and Evil

In the foregoing we have surveyed the ways which, from the evil side, lead up to the threshold of the spirit-realm. Now the question presents itself: How is the enclosure that surrounds man broken from without inward; or how is the barrier which shuts off that realm overthrown from within, so that the two realms may have closer intercourse with one another? Demonic asceticism has already answered this question for us in general; we need now only demonstrate the particular application of what was there said.

#### A. The Approach of The Spirits. Again the Kobolds

\

Two modes there presented themselves to us in which intercourse between the two realms can be mediated: namely, either the invisible realm presses into the visible, or the latter intrudes into the former. We found the first beginnings of their mutual approach where the region of night, as it were with its outermost hem and limbus, passes in a kind of half-shadow into the region of light; and the depth, overflowing as if in jest and caprice, mingles itself in a coquettish, ironic, at times humorous fashion with the play of life. It is the region of poltergeists and kobolds, of the Norse tricksters and the folletti of the Italians, who here produce the arabesques of this half-dreamlike realism. These beings may in part be what they appear to be --- the demonic and harmless plays of a middle world lying between light and darkness, in which the jesting wit that lies in things, and reaches down into the seriousness of nature, tries itself out in burlesques --- Bambocciades that make sport of the respectability of life's prose; but something else may lie at the bottom of it. All wit in itself is already of twofold nature, and the corrosive fire of sarcasm shows how far down one of its veins draws; and the wittiest of the old Norse gods, Loki, is also the most malicious --- his name already expresses the consuming blaze of his demonic temperament. The harmless may therefore be only a mask to conceal this temperament; and then these will-o'-the-wisp forms will furnish the most suitable agents for linking day and darkness. All experienced and discerning exorcists therefore warn against the deceptions of this errant and confused world of hauntings, and forbid entering into any confidential relationship with its ambiguity. Stephan Colett has allotted a whole section of his writing to this subject. "I speak here," he says, "of those spirits commonly called in Italy folletti or household spirits, and whose familiarity one must shun as one must shun that of the evil one. They begin this familiarity with teasing: small things from the domestic circle are stolen, especially such as belong to the one to whom they have attached themselves, and are then mostly returned to him; so that everything seems to be an innocent game. But it is precisely against the playing, flattering spirits that one must guard oneself most. To some they appear visibly, in various forms, by day or by night, or only at certain times; to others they never show themselves." Mostly, when they make themselves manifest, they are of small stature, hop about in the corners of the room, laugh, make a racket, steal to the beds, and pull the coverings off the sleepers. Such beings do not wish to possess the person they pursue; they only press themselves upon him for intimacy, most eagerly upon women in the bloom of life. They are wont to promise them something, express love for them, bring them now this, now that, and are then most commonly visible in the shape of a handsome youth. At first the person suspects no guile or deceit; but woe! if she is thus pursued and does not immediately put the adversary to flight --- as happened to the one of whom I am now about to tell.

Not long ago a country girl came to me with her father, who told me how the evil spirit had insinuated himself into her confidence in such a fashion. He had appeared to the girl more than once in the guise of an ugly man, and had then followed her as she fled. At times he stole something from her, especially bread which she either had with her or had laid elsewhere. Whenever the bread portions --- the people were poor --- were set down, it was always the portion that fell to the girl, and no other, that was taken, and most often the stolen thing was brought back as if in jest. The same happened with other things that belonged to her. But the girl was ashamed of this game, and so were her parents; for they mistrusted the outcome. They therefore soon came to me and earnestly begged that I free them from this burden. I instructed the good girl, in the presence of her father, in all that was necessary; then I commanded in the name of Jesus that the demon should no longer show himself, should steal nothing more from her, nor otherwise be troublesome. And so it happened, and the girl still lives today unmolested by all demonic temptation. All of this are not dreams, for those awake do not dream; nor phantasms, which do not as a rule occur to persons of full understanding. \

The attaching (or attaching itself to the young) was also observed in many other instances, in the two cases of which M. speaks in the following words. I recall the following incident in Bologna. A certain citizen, who had much to do in his house with spirits, so that he had to consult theologians, and the matter itself came to the ears of the local bishop. Whatever one did, one could not get rid of the pest. He was, as people believed, in love with a girl of the house; followed her wherever she went; played a thousand tricks and jests around her; and whenever her mistress, in whose service she stood, did her any harm by deeds or words, he immediately caused some mischief in the house. Once, when he learned of some ill-treatment received by the girl, he was enraged and tore a dress from her from head to foot. When the girl was greatly distressed at the damage, he restored the dress in such a way that one would by no means have guessed it had before been so torn. The household, who wanted to be rid of him at any price, at last --- on the advice of their neighbours --- put the girl into a state such that one day she ate beyond all measure. That enraged the invisible one; and after he had previously made his displeasure known to the girl and the householder, he left the house.

Likewise there befell another citizen the same thing. With him was also a girl of about thirteen years with whom the spirit had to do. He played pranks, and sometimes caused great damage by breaking jugs. He piled up stones and threw them down before the master's room, so that the house seemed about to fall into ruins, and no one in it felt secure in his life. The householders tried all manner of things; "they themselves led me," says Menghi, one day into their house, "showed me their affliction, and conferred with me about means to remedy the evil." But although many strove, none succeeded in removing it; until the girl left the house, whereupon everything grew quiet.

It is understandable how a continued confidential intimacy with such originally ambiguous, then decidedly manifest beings may, in the end, lead to an alliance for particular ends --- an alliance which in such cases is by no means merely one-sided. Extremely remarkable from this point of view is that maid who, one of the last, was executed in Salzburg about the middle of the previous century on the accusation of such an agreement. The report is contained in a letter drawn up in the Latin language by a member and superior of a religious order, dated Salzburg, 8 March 1751; and which, for many reasons, the Italian editor to whom it was addressed says deserves the fullest belief. He, however, reports the case in these words:

The notes concerning the execution of the accused that were requested some months ago could not be given until now, because P. G. N. had not yet received them from the councils and judges. Having returned from Rome, I asked a privy councillor of our prince for inspection of the proceedings; he did not give me the process itself, but only related the species facti \[the outline of the facts\], as contained in the enclosed sheet. From this it will be shown, it seems to me, that one in the matter has acted neither too credulously nor too hastily. As to the verdict, matters in Germany are disposed of in few words, which run roughly as follows: "Since you are convicted and confess to the crime of witchcraft, we condemn you from life to death, that you be executed by the hangman with the sword, and that the body be placed upon the pyre." The following narration of the facts reads thus:

It was the 23rd of January in the year 1749, when in a smith's workshop at Mülldorf, in the Salzburg territory, they perceived how the objects there suddenly moved in an unusual manner; sometimes the tools, tongs, hammers, etc., at other times pigs' feet, pieces of brick, and sometimes also objects that had not before been seen there, flew about and fell down. One man was struck from above by a hammer; another by a flying brick --- however, everything so lightly that whatever fell seemed to have lost its weight and therefore caused no pain. All wondered at this; some were seized by fear, thinking readily that something supernatural was afoot. Only the smith's maid, named Anna Bayerin, who served there as nurse to the child, laughed and said that she feared nothing and that no harm would come of it to her. Clergy were called to bless the house and to free it from the devil's assaults; but there was no remedy until the said maid was ordered to leave. As soon as she was out of the house, it became quiet again. These occurrences, and new disturbances which took place in another house where she passed the night, caused the local magistrate to have the more respectable citizens sworn concerning the facts, and thereafter to order the imprisonment of that maid. I do not wish to defend the interrogations made of her to the hair, or to claim that they were entirely in accordance with law; nor that the confession of the accused always bears the stamp of probability. \

The following, however, cannot, without prejudice to the truth, be denied. After the interrogation had, at least for the sake of precaution, been begun again from the beginning --- and that without the torture having even once been threatened either at Mülldorf or at Salzburg --- this crafty, and not, as some falsely spread, simple woman, after many evasions at last made the following confession: She said she had been seduced by a seamstress from Neumarkt (a little town between Öttingen and Landshut), and had devoted herself exclusively to the Devil by the words written in blood: "I am yours and you are mine!"

She further confessed that she had committed a sacrilegious abuse with the Holy Host, which she had often received and immediately taken from her mouth; that she had several times been carried off, by the Devil's help, to nocturnal dances together with her teacher, the aforementioned seamstress, and others; and that she there had received a lump of sugar, which she afterwards threw into a peasant woman's vat. Thereby it came to pass that the cream of the milk --- however much trouble one took in churning --- nevertheless did not make butter for over half a year; until the peasant woman --- who swore to all this on oath --- sold her cow and bought another; whereupon she made butter without difficulty from the milk of the newly purchased animal, while the purchaser of the old cow likewise made butter from that cow's milk. Finally, she declared that, with the Devil's help, she alone was the cause of the disturbances in the smithy.

I am not one of those who take delight only in the new, often to the detriment of the truth; nor have I sworn by the ancients, who are often credulous to the point of superstition. I know that the judges of past centuries, of whom it is told that they frequently condemned the accused to the stake on mere confession, are charged with a hasty and credulous procedure in matters of magic. Nor is it unknown to me that sugar is ascribed the natural power to dissolve cream so that no butter can be made from it. Nor do I mean to deny that the nocturnal dances and journeys from place to place are not always founded in truth; rather, especially among women, they are represented to them in dreams by the help of the imagination, so that when they awake they cannot be dissuaded from them.

However, just as I cannot, without exposing myself to presumption for want of reliable information, either approve or still less condemn everything that our predecessors have done; so it is nevertheless known even to those who otherwise know nothing that the public laws, and among them the penal procedure of Charles V, condemn magicians to the fire; and that only a hardened and unwise person could call their existence into question after a many-hundred-year calm observance. That the use of sugar, without the Devil's assistance, may, now and then, hinder the making of butter from milk is comprehensible; but that a small piece should possess such power that it could spoil a vessel for more than half a year --- a vessel which in the meantime had been cleaned several times --- and exercise these powers so long that the cow which had been in possession during the application of the sugar could not be sold, no reasonable person will concede. Whoever believes that those nocturnal dances and flights through the air really took place as often as simple women tell, and that they themselves were present at them, may be considered even more simple than the women themselves. \

Only when reasonable witnesses, elevated above all doubt --- several of whom were present, awake and by day --- testify from what they saw with their own eyes that they were led away in their presence, and that they with their own hands drove them out of the house; if now against this authority of ocular testimony one man asserts: this never happened; I know that such a one, as one who shamelessly and without reason denies everything according to his own liking, as they say, deserves the philosopher's rod of correction.

Among the others those also seemed to me foolish, and asleep with open eyes, who, wishing to gain renown from the novelty of an empty shadow and to embrace a vain appearance instead of the truth, assert that the said seven witnesses might have been deceived in the repeated interrogations, by believing that the hammers and tongs moved without human hand, that they struck them and yet did not wound them; although they testified separately that they had seen these movements in no way caused by the above-mentioned maid, nor in any other way than a supernatural one. For with the same presumption I might then assert: a man who has been robbed only, carried away by his fancy, imagined this, but never possessed the stolen things; the thief dreamed the crime, and the witnesses were falsely persuaded that they had seen the theft.

It should be noted that the Bavarian seamstress, the teacher of the woman from Mülldorf, taken in at Neumarkt, confessed under the same circumstances that she had seduced ours and that she had gone with her to nocturnal dances; although neither could have had knowledge of the other's confession; whereupon she was also beheaded, and the body burned on the pyre. Nevertheless one might well have hesitated at Salzburg to condemn the other merely on account of the agreement of the confession, if the credibility of the witnesses had not testified to the materiality of the crime and removed all reasonable doubt; so that the truth was as clear as humanly possible. Yet no one should consider the maid simple; for by way of deceit she tore out a leaf from her prayer-book, which she had with her in prison, scratched her skin with a piece of wood instead of a pen, and wrote with her blood: I am yours and you are mine! --- with the intention of making it believed that the devil had restored to her what she had previously given him. She carried this off so slyly that it almost succeeded and one would have believed her. Nor should it be overlooked that both, the woman from Salzburg and the one from Neumarkt, at least to all appearance, received the announcement of the death sentence cheerfully; and both humbly requested the assistance of clergymen for their impending end and strengthening with the holy sacraments.

But even in this, as P. Laymann wrote a hundred and some years ago as something common to gentlemen, they were alike: that each of them, on the day before the punishment was carried out, complained to one of the assistants that she was being condemned unjustly, and sought counsel whether, under such circumstances, she should suffer the death-penalty or should proclaim her innocence to the judge, even though without hope of pardon.

The report here given appears sufficient to form a general notion of the course of events in this affair; but it is not detailed enough to get to the bottom of the matter. That those Folettis played a prominent role here is plain; the fact itself, even if --- as we have seen --- it were no more than sufficiently corroborated by its frequent recurrence, would here, in matters that concern life and death, have been completely proved by the judicial testimony of seven authentic witnesses. \

Even the remark already made about the moment of motion in the throws that proceed from those hurlers --- by virtue of which a momentum, despite the great speed with which considerable masses, hammers, &c., travel along, yet sees its force, contrary to all physical laws, dwindle into a ghostly minimum; as if absorbed mass and movement, instead of strengthening one another, rather mutually --- would make the matter credible.

The woman who stood opposite them had the life-course, manner, and physiognomy of an old-fashioned witch. She herself had made a full confession of this, not extorted by the threat of torture. That confession had been corroborated by that of the other woman at Neumarkt; and both, although completely independent of one another, in different places, and without prior collusion between the confessors, nevertheless agreed with one another. The two women, the mistress and the pupil, had together, according to ancient custom, attended the Sabbath; and the bond of fealty had been sealed with blood in the formula: "I am yours and you are mine!" whereupon, likewise according to old usage, the story with the peasant woman and her cow occurs; and the sacrilegious proceedings with the host made the once-knotted relationship a lasting one.

On the one side, then, that ambiguous spirit-realm approaching in those enigmatic shapes; on the other, the woman of sly temperament, who mutually offered to one another their nocturnal aspect. That those spirits, in their fashion, clung to the maid seems certain, for the disturbance abated in the house and ceased when she was removed from it; but it appears to have recurred in the place where she again stayed overnight the first time. Whether, however, the relationship was truly a reciprocal interchange does not emerge with clear evidence from the material at hand. She herself, by her earlier boasting and her later admission, has taken it to be real; she, to whom, it must be admitted, the best judgment on the matter belonged, must therefore at least at that time have believed it to be actually present.

Here, however, indeed the possibility of self-deception with respect to the fact, or of self-delusion with regard to the consequences of the confession, comes into play. Just as she may later have fraudulently imitated her later statements, so the first supposedly real one might have been produced by self-deception; and the same relation between her initial boasting and her subsequent confession might, by still later denial, be annulled again. The reality of such a relationship must thus, in this case, since it is not proven by the account, remain undecided; but the possibility of it is evident.

The two circles of human depravity and spiritual perversion have drawn near to one another until they nearly touch; one cannot see what, if the approaching tendencies are mutual, should prevent their ultimate confluence. This confluence has, on the part of those perverting powers, been effected in innumerable cases in possessions; which are precisely nothing else than the breaking-in of these powers into the sphere of individual life, even where the latter, by the resistance of the will against such intrusion, keeps itself closed. There is no reason to state why, on the other hand, if that will is unanimous, from the side of the perverted individuality such a connection might not be sought, and this opened to the circle of spirits.

#### B. The Exercises of The Preliminary School

\

As we have already seen, the practice of magic has kept its higher schools and its initiations under the rein of a certain discipline. An analogous example of what there had taken place there is afforded by the prophets' school which prepared the uprising in the Cévennes, and which, having arisen from more than ambiguous motives, permitted a conclusion as to the manner in which the affair there unfolded, where the leaders frankly and freely surrendered themselves to evil. The peace of 1682 had been very injurious to the cause of the Calvinists in France; by the thousands the people in the south had returned to the Church. The most resolute among its leaders had, in the following year, raised an insurrection in the Dauphiné and in the Vivarais; this, however, proved very unfortunate, and the chiefs had taken refuge in Geneva, in Holland and in Germany to seek help for their cause. Jurieu, one of them, had in 1685 written an exposition of the Apocalypse to prepare the minds; therein he announced the overthrow of the Church within five years and the return of the Reformation in France. This produced the greatest excitement among those peoples in whom the new principle is rooted; and the signs of ecstatic states which appeared here and there in consequence of it probably suggested to the mass of the exiled heads of the Confession in Geneva the thought of ordering and disciplining these states and of making them an ally in the renewed war.

The scene chosen for this prophets' school was a glassworks called Peyra, in the mountains of the Dauphiné, amid woods and rocks. At its head they selected Du Serre, one of the most determined Protestants in that district; he, a native of the country, being often engaged in the affairs of the works, frequently came across to Geneva; there meanwhile a committee had been formed which promoted the insurrection; and two preachers, Henry and Perrin, were sent over to stir the people by their sermons. Du Serre now had fifteen boys entrusted to him by his co-religionists in the neighbourhood, while the same number of girls gathered about his wife. First he instilled in these a pronounced hatred of the Church, and then he revealed to them: that God had communicated his spirit to him, that he gives it to every one according to his good pleasure; but that he had chosen them in order to transform them into prophets and prophetesses, if they would prepare themselves to receive so great a gift in the manner prescribed by God. The children, in their innocence, were willing, and had now to submit to a strict discipline, in which especially regularly recurring fasts, continued for three days at a stretch, played a principal role; while lectures on the Apocalypse and on the Antichrist in Rome, and his near downfall, directed their minds that way, and familiarized them with the language of the prophets.

Under this training there gradually appeared in most of the pupils the phenomena of somnambulism; they threw themselves backwards upon the ground, their eyes closed; the region of the pit of the stomach and of the throat swelled, and they remained for a time in this rapt state. When it had come to this point, then the master --- his apprenticeship being, as he said, at an end --- assembled the whole fellowship, placed the person to be proclaimed in the midst of the company, and told him: the time of his inspiration was now come; then he kissed him with a grave and mysterious mien, breathed his breath into his mouth, and announced to him that he was now receiving the spirit of prophecy. The others had witnessed, full of astonishment, the birth of the new prophet, and were moved by the longing soon likewise to attain, in like manner, to the same consecration. After he had thus absolved them all, he sent them out, each to his own place, admonishing them to bestow again upon others the gift of prophecy whom they found fit for it, and who had gone through the same training as themselves. Among the young pupils of the prophetic school two were especially remarkable: a young man of twenty-five years, Gabriel Astier, from the place Clien; and a young shepherdess from the village of Crêt, called the beautiful Isabelle. While the others remained in concealment, both of them, toward the end of the year 1688, chose respectively a larger scene of action; the one went over into Vivarès, the other to Grenoble, at the very time when the Prince of Orange crossed over to England. The Calvinist people were ready to believe the prophets who proclaimed to them the victory of their creed, and thus a great excitement arose in those regions. The vigilance of the authorities, however, prevented an uprising in the Dauphiné; the prophetess was arrested in Grenoble, and, afterwards being brought to a recognition of her errors, returned to the Church. Astier, in Vivarès, having grown more cautious, retired into secrecy, and first consecrated his whole family to the prophetic office, and then others; and when the matter nevertheless became notorious he fled to Boutières, into the wild, inaccessible mountains, and thence began to hold nightly meetings with the inhabitants.

On the mountain-tops the people gathered, in numbers ranging from a few hundred up to three or four thousand, sometimes at different places simultaneously; on the day appointed by the prophet men, women, and children assembled. The prophet stood among them in a raised place and opened the meeting with the loud cry: Mercy! Mercy! The people answered with the same cry, prostrate on their knees, and the mountains echoed it back. Then a prayer was said, and a psalm sung by all present. Now the presiding officer rose, the assembly did likewise, and after he had cried out, holding his hands over his head, "Throw yourselves backwards, without danger!" everyone threw themselves backward; while the prophet, as the number of those falling increased, let his arms sink lower and lower accordingly. The circumstance that sometimes three to four thousand persons thus hurled themselves on their backs without being hurt was regarded as a gift of the prophets. In the midst of the prostrate the prophet himself then fell into the ecstatic state; he was brought back to himself from this state by the candidates for the prophetic office who lay first around him; he then began to prophesy, and went up to the best-prepared among the neophytes, breathed into his mouth, and said: "Receive the Holy Spirit!" He at once surrendered his place to the newly consecrated man, who likewise began to prophesy and to communicate the received gift further.

That the matter did not rest on imagination and artifice, but was rooted in physical states, was shown by the shudders that seized those who fell, the contractions and extensions in arms and legs, the convulsions that made them foam, and the swellings they experienced. They also declared that the spirit communicated itself to them when they had previously taken the fallen upon their laps; and that it usually entered through the loins, which to them seemed as if made of iron. The country soon became covered with branches of the original school; a general uprising was to be feared, one which could easily spread over the whole south as far as Gascony. Serious measures were therefore taken; in the first encounter the delusion of the excited men was scattered: they were not invulnerable, nor could they, with the cry "Tartara," put the armies of their opponents to flight. Several other encounters followed, the armed bands were dispersed, Astier was taken and tried, and the province thus pacified. \

Sparks of the conflagration had meanwhile been blown as far as the Cévennes, and in the year 1688 there was a first outbreak, which however was soon suppressed. But in the year 1702, with the outbreak of the War of Succession, the smothered flame broke out anew and raised the Cévennes War, which was led by the Prophets. They were here arranged one above another in four ranks. The lowest comprised the awakened; the second those who obtained the Spirit by the breath; the third those who obtained prophecy; the fourth those who simply possessed the gift, and were no longer occupied with worldly things, neither prophesying nor sitting on the council. All that had been seen in the time of the Manichaeans and the Anabaptists repeated itself anew in this memorable war, which the mountain people waged with great courage and resolution; wherein, however, they also all too often stained themselves with coldly calculated murder and cruelties, and fell prey to manifold deceptions; from which, as from the outcome of the whole enterprise, it equally proved that the spirit in which they trusted had not been a good spirit.

##### The Life of Magdalena Bavent

One may say here: the people fought for their conviction, even if erroneous, against a faith that had been forced upon them; and their leaders, though they made a grievous abuse of their power of enthusiasm, had at least for the most part passed through the same school, and had themselves been enthusiastic before they roused enthusiasm in others. But where from the outset pure depravity, recognized as such, lies at the root; where the leaders have given themselves over beforehand to the absolutely evil for its own sake, and now from it become seducers of others whom they wish to win for its realm: there the demon himself is present, and the whole act becomes demonic, and shows itself as such in its consequences. So it went in the tale of the seduction of Magdalena Bavent, which she set down in her memoirs, and which we will relate in her own words.

"Born in the year 1607 in Rouen, I lost my parents at about nine years of age; I was brought up by an uncle until my twelfth year, and then remained until my sixteenth in the house of a woman in order to learn to sew. At that time a convent according to the rule of St. Francis was established in Louviers, to which saint I had always had a special devotion. I therefore wished to be received there; my relatives interceded for me, and I obtained admission. I entered the convent with the intention, as I can swear on my soul, of serving the Lord there with all sincerity, and began my novitiate in that intention. But we had a terrible man who guided us, the priest David. He read with us the book of a Capuchin about the will of God; but he interpreted this in a most peculiar manner, in which our mistress-novices entirely agreed with him. Under the pretext of obtaining perfect obedience, which must also overcome the most severe and nature-contrary things, he introduced atrocious practices. He said: one must kill sin by sin, in order thereby to return to the innocence of our first parents, who before their fall did not know shame. Those among us were then regarded as the holiest and most virtuous who appeared quite naked in the choir and in the garden, and in that state performed dances. We were accustomed to touch one another; to practice every kind of unnatural sins as paganism had known; to abuse the image of the Crucified and the sacrament of the altar in every possible way." \

The author took what he reports in this book partly from his own observation, partly from the records of the Parliament of Grenoble and from the testimonies of the arrested prophets, especially of the beautiful Isabelle.

At first I resisted these abominations, and was therefore regarded as a disobedient, headstrong, malicious, and refractory person, who was possessed of her own will. When once I was to go to Communion naked down to the belt, I had refused to do so, but I had to yield; when I wished to cover myself at the small grille with the altar-cloth, this was snatched away from me, and when I then used my hands to cover myself, David ordered me to fold them. My conscience kept making constant reproaches to me about all these things; David said these were not sins, and another confessor whom I asked for was not allowed me. I therefore left the convent; but inexperienced as I was, I took the position of a gatekeeper (pförtnerin) of the convent that was offered me; and so I remained, entirely given over to my indiscretion, in that office, albeit outside the convent, yet continuously connected with it.1) I had left at the end of January; at Candlemas David travelled to Paris, then returned at the end of Lent, and died on the Monday of Holy Week. Nothing had occurred between us, except for some licentiousness; but before his journey he had entrusted to me a little casket with the prohibition not to open it. Curiosity, however, drove me to disobey his command; and I found a paper in it, written by him in an unknown hand, but I returned everything to him on his return. I then tended him for a short time during his illness, which appears to have been a syphilitic sore; and on the day of his death he gave this paper to Mathurin Picard, and appointed him his successor in the convent, in his sense and spirit, and in a private interview recommended me to his care. This paper was the paper of blasphemies that was always used on the Sabbath. \
