\"So I was in the office of porter, but Picard was confessor and director of the convent. I had now fallen into worse hands than before; his insolence toward me grew quickly, and though I tried to defend myself against him, I could not; for he held me fast in the chains of hell. At Easter I was to make my confession to him; but scarcely had I begun when he would not hear me further; everything I brought forward he said were not sins. He feigned a passionate love that he harbored for me; he begged for reciprocal affection, and began to caress me. Since that confession I had no other kind with him; all were like that sacrilegious and damnable one. Yet I never loved that unhappy priest from the heart, and I do not know by what power he bound me to him and thus kept me bound. It is a misery when one does not leave to souls the choice of their confessor, and binds them to one who can ruin them.

Our relationship was known in the convent; even outside, many pressed to pull me out of the danger; but in the convent they would not allow me another confessor. It is true that I myself did nothing about it --- whether from timidity or a tendency to an unbound life --- which I ought to have done. He pursued me continually, and did not cease from me even in a violent illness, when I was senseless and more dead than alive. Yet because of my resistance he did not succeed in gaining his whole will with me all that time; except once, when he was ill, or only pretended to be ill, and then using force rather than persuasion he wrested my consent from me. What has been said about a similar occurrence in the church is, thank God, unfounded except for one attempt on his part.

That, however, was not the only thing he intended against me to rob me of my honor; there was another thing I did not suspect because I did not know his devilish arts. While I was ill he had me sign a paper whose contents I did not know. Once at the altar he put a host into my hand, and then, pressing my hand, he broke it so that the pieces fell to the ground. Likewise he wanted me to drink of the wine which he had left in the chalice after the completion of the Mass --- which I, however, never did. Once he said to me: 'My dear, I am building this church; after my death you will see miracles; will you not agree?' I said yes, without understanding the meaning of his words. \

I was concerned only for my honor; he feared on his side that I might be pregnant: therefore he consented that I should go back into the convent, which was no difficulty, since he furnished a sum of money for it. I found there still the same filth in the novitiate as before, although Picard did not come and go among the nuns as freely as David had done earlier. Hardly fifteen days had I been there when he sought a pretext to come into the garden where I was with some nuns. He followed us, and after he had come to a certain spot he produced a host from a book he had with him; with it he picked up some drops of blood that had fallen to the ground, for I was then menstruating. He wrapped them up, called me out into the churchyard, and used my finger to push them into an opening near a shrub. He never spoke to me further about the matter; but I acquired a strong inclination to go repeatedly to that spot, and there I had many filthy temptations and practiced much impurity. Later --- I believe soon after I had taken my vows --- he demanded a copy of my profession; I wrote it while he dictated.\" \


Keywords: - confessions of magdalena bavent[Page 104]

Then he said, when I was about to sign them, that I must now bind my purpose to his; if he should die before me, I must be willing to die likewise; if he were damned or saved, I must choose the same fate for myself. I was terribly frightened by this, and after much resistance I gave only an outward assent, up to, as I believe, the point of damnation. Meanwhile I continued to suffer many pangs of conscience, and I wished to make my confession to the confessor of the sick in the hospital we visited. Picard, who perceived this, hastened to put his design into effect. One day, when he handed me Communion at the grille, he touched my breast through the veil with his finger, and instead of the usual words said: "You will see what will happen to you because of this." I went to my place in the choir, but restlessness drove me into the garden, where I sat down beneath a mulberry tree. There appeared to me a cat which set its hind feet on my knees and its forepaws on my shoulders, and then barred its dreadful jaws over my mouth, as if it would take the Communion from me. Whether that actually happened I do not know; for I sat there for perhaps an hour, unable to make the sign of the cross or to drive the creature away. Picard saw me that same day, and when I asked: was that all the glory I was to receive that day? he answered: "You will see quite other things yet!" Two or three days later he said: "My dear! we have now seen one another; do you not wish that we should see one another again?" I said yes, to the ruin of my soul. In the night, about eleven, after I had already slept, I heard what sounded like a nun calling me. I rose, and when I reached the door I lost consciousness and felt myself carried to a place where, besides Picard, several clerics and nuns were present. He at once said: "Beloved, did I not tell you we would see one another again today?" I answered: "Yes; but I did not think it would be outside the convent; this assembly is also unknown to me." He said: "You must not trouble yourself about that," and so he drew from me a formal assent to everything that was there to happen and that he in particular would do --- the one and only formal assent he extracted from me. Yet my conscience would never be entirely pacified; Picard knew this well, and therefore never quite trusted me, nor did he ever initiate me into his secrets. The day after that event I disclosed everything to the confessor Langlois; whether he was aware of the matter or not, he did not tell me that I had been led to the Sabbath, and left me without counsel. Six months later I told him of my more frequent abductions; which was the easier to do because he had been given the monastery confessional, and Picard, on suspicion, had been removed from it. I had resolved to make a general confession, and had already made three quarters of it, when Picard learned of it and had me called to the confessional grille. He asked why I had stayed so long with the new confessor. I answered: to make a general confession. "Well," he said, touching my hand, "you have begun, but you will not finish!" He had spoken truly, for, as he afterwards confessed to me, he had cast a spell between me and the confessor; when I began, it was as if the confessor closed my mouth and drove the sins back. He seemed to be bound in my presence; I, however, as soon as I entered the confessional, was terribly tormented. It pressed down upon me with great force when I tried to begin; it struck my head against the walls and threw me to the ground. One could hear the blows I received; people saw me swollen and black and blue from them, without knowing whence they came. \

After the Communions I was turned over, my feet pointing upward, and I was compelled to vomit up what I had taken. I wrote to Father Benedict, but the letter was taken from me. I wrote to the Bishop of Evreux; my letters, some of which still remain, did not make an impression until the fifth year of my torments.

If one considers this hair‑raising story of seduction, which embraces the events of many years, and in which many transitions may have dropped out owing to the unfaithfulness of memory, the horror that besets these depths of human nature will whirl and confound the spirit that looks down into them, unless it rests on the most secure foundation. If among the sacraments the Eucharist must be regarded as first, because it subordinates itself as the essence and core of the whole house of healing to its centre, then after it priestly ordination will follow first in order; for it must prepare the ways and the little rill in which the streams of this and all sacraments flow. Just as things stand concerning the sacraments in the Church of Light, so do they stand concerning the execraments in the demon's midnight church, in which the real substance of the sacramental is transformed into an ape‑like, lying mockery. Thus the deepest negation is implanted in the Sabbath's Eucharist, which therefore also holds the apex of these execraments; while the next place in the sevenfold order is occupied by the witchly ordination, which opens the ways through which the curse of hell comes upon the world. If now the consecrated of the Lord, priests and his brides, are to be transformed into the consecrated of the demon, his sorcerer‑priests and his paramours, then, before their luciferization takes place---to use the phrase of one from their midst---first their debasement must precede; only immediately, and indeed only after the full and unambiguous assent, the uncoerced joining of their will has taken place, will the reception and immediately the promotion to the priesthood occur.

To this end the asceticism that those priests of the abyss introduced into the novitiate was calculated: the novices were to pass, by an indifferent state of nature, into the contrary state, and sin was not to be combatted by good but to be killed by suicide through itself; so that, after shame, set as guardian, had been extinguished, the access of nature on that side would stand open. David had gone so far when Picard took his place. He had been pastor at Mesnil‑Fourdain near Louviers, and was regarded as a man highly experienced in the spiritual life. But, as Father Esprit du Bosroger, who knew him, related, he had been in league with a sect of false Illuminati; and he knew how to control his mien, gait, speech and all his actions so well that one might have taken him for an angel of heaven. His serious bearing, his downcast eyes, the long beard, the pallor of his face; the mildness of his words, to which those who spoke with him accommodated themselves; the warmth of his zeal, the measuredness of his actions, the restraint of his ideas despite all reserve, sometimes exalted by flaming words about God or Paradise; his sighs and his contemplative expression, the long duration of his Masses, during which he appeared beside himself; his prayers of thanksgiving interrupted by sobs and deep silence---all gave him the appearance of a great friend of God and a consummate spiritual man; and yet he was nothing but a great Pharisee and hypocrite, a wolf among the sisters of that convent.

He continued where his predecessor had left off. Nakedness, he said, was originally the sign of true innocence; for all sin is not in the body and in bodily actions, but in the discrimination of human craftiness. \

"He who distinguishes is accursed and damned," says the Apostle; he who does not see sin has not committed any, for the spirit, closely united with God, has committed none. All human cleverness and earthly understanding, even shame, must therefore be mortified; the spirit must not crawl into reflections, meditations and distinctions about its actions; but, abandoning itself to passions and earthly faults, give them over to tear themselves to pieces in confusion, and then fly with the eagle to the sun.

No wonder that the woman Bavent, a spiritually limited but passionately bold girl, fell into the pitfalls of this gnostic; three or four others who had listened to him had, as P. Esprit relates --- who later for a long time was confessor in the convent --- the same fate; the others would hardly all have escaped him, had he not been led away by trials to Rome and Paris, and, after he returned, had not illnesses removed him from their path.

It is a general law of nature that opposites, so long as they are not abolished, only tighten themselves the more. Thus cold cuts most sharply when it meets increased heat in the organ, just as positive stimulants act most strongly on negative dispositions. The seducer proceeded by this law in his work. As the sacraments possess a sanctifying power, so there lies in the counter‑sacraments a desecrating one; the latter in an eminent degree where its effect is combined with the profanation of the former.

He therefore first abused the sacrament of confession, in order by it to tie on those physical bonds through which such things always begin; bonds which finally led to the satisfaction of his lusts, and, given the nervous state of Bavent, for example, as one cannot mistake, brought her organic life into magnetic rapport with him. Now further steps were taken to obtain the attunement of her will to the other covenant. At first he was content with forged signatures and ambiguous consents to participate in the new Church. Later he comes nearer to his goal by forming, with her blood contained in a host, a new vinculum that ritually binds her to him. Thereupon the taking of her vows, the analogue of priestly ordination, is used to allot the same to her in the church of the abyss, and to win from her a formal consent to a bond of life and death; only when the extension of that bond beyond death is to be made does nature recoil in terror. Therefore one now proceeds to initiation into the deepest mysteries of the night, and the Eucharist, the holiest thing, must be helpful to the unholiest. He offers it to her, and as she swallows the morsel, the evil enemy has also entered into her. She now becomes clairvoyant, and the cat that she sees, and afterwards the incubus that pursues her, is the first available expression of the new relation she has entered. The initiate is then --- but only after she has once more explicitly given her consent --- introduced on the Sabbath; where she must once again, in the circle of the inner life, give her formally and afterwards also in writing confirmed assurance of full attunement. She has made her covenant with the seed of the dragon; now only enmity must be set between her and the seed of the woman. \

Therefore, when she looks back toward the church she had left, because the impulse to make her confession of sins in the confessional has risen in her, the evil spirit who has seduced her sets himself, in all his acquired power, between her and the priest. The ecclesiastical element awakens cramps and convulsions in the inward-turned nature, and she is forcibly prevented from the confession of sins and flung back into the mire. Thus an iron band has been forged about the unhappy woman, and a demonic-magnetic pull chains her to him who, as the representative of the evil enemy, stands opposite her.

Now if the simple force of nature --- that organic gravity and mutual attraction which runs through all life --- in vital magnetism binds the magnetized to the magnetizer, so that the latter lives only in the former, thinks his thoughts, and, from a distance and to a certain degree, moves and makes him act according to his will, then incomparably more must a magnetic natural force thus directed and rooted in her, and strengthened by the power of the demonic, take effect. One cannot say that the acceptance of such an irresistible force is incompatible with human freedom and moral accountability. For the prior surrender of that freedom is the absolutely necessary precondition before the efficacy of this power can enter; and even then, with the withdrawal of that consent, return and liberation are possible, though exceedingly difficult.

With the surrender of the will, therefore, this rapport immediately manifests itself in all its power; the one who renounces is entrusted with it to the foreign spirit, and at once a spiritual community of goods arises between them --- a common production of thoughts, in which he, in a state of demonic ecstasy, stands as father, and she confronts him as mother. That will be especially the case in the vision of the Sabbath, which takes its first origin from him; from him it is then received, and in her carried and brought forth into the night. It is therefore he who first called her to the Sabbath, and continually gives the initial impulse to the work. Invariably she thus appears to be bound to his person; she always finds herself near him, speaks with him, learns what is going on there, as it were through his mediation; the whole act appears bound to him, and has no existence without him. Thus, when he died, she was no longer led to him; she is a widow who has been made wingless, who can no longer get there by her own power.

Very remarkable, therefore, is also what occurred at his death. She relates concerning it: "When he lay in agony and I went up the stairs to the gallery of the sleeping-chamber, I saw Boullé (whom he had appointed his successor in office) enter the court as if he were going to the chapel, with a dreadful countenance. At the same time the window through which I had looked down to him was broken before me; and I had a demonic seizure, being dragged through the dormitory and very badly treated. When that same evening I sat in my cell, there was a violent knocking on the beams, and I heard in a hoarser voice: 'We have our booty!' It was, as I afterward heard, precisely his hour of death. Since he died, the steward of a monastery well known to me has always appeared to me at night, a man whom I had never seen at the Sabbath and did not otherwise know. He always urged me to break the promise I had given to Picard, to wish myself to the place where he was, and soon to follow him."

#### C. The Demonic Under The Mask of Holiness

The swiftest progress along this precipitous path will be toward the goal when, as happened at the first seduction, the sensual delight of pride -- to be like the Elohim -- adds itself; and the presumption to risk everything that can lead to the gratification of each of the two. This, therefore, is the great danger that immediately presents itself at the divergence of ordinary life-roads, and which he who penetrates more deeply from there must above all withstand. For the natural way divides itself at this point of departure, in that what in it had been intertwined with one another there separates; and from thence two distinct ways proceed, each in a different direction: one of which rises upward to the light, the other leads down into the night.

Just as at the divisions of lands and waters, it depends on a small elevation or depression of the ground whether the waters flow to the north or to the south, to this or that sea; so at these great forks of life there works a thrust of the deeper nature which takes refuge behind pride, and the titillation at the call of holiness, so that the downward way is chosen; at first under the delusion that it is the one which leads upward. In place of the serpent of salvation and light there is then the dragon of the abyss, which, having seized its tail with its mouth and appropriated self-consciousness to itself; and as it illuminates with its false, glittering light the inner being that it entangles, the deluded one imagines himself to walk in the light of Godhead itself. Examples will here most clearly set forth this unhappy relation, and we cannot choose a more striking one than that which occurred in the first half of the sixteenth century in Spain. There lived at that time Magdalena del Cruz, a Franciscan nun in the convent of St. Elizabeth at Córdoba; born in 1487 at Aguilar, entering that convent in 1504, and, having rapidly attained to great reputation for holiness, chosen abbess in 1532 and again in 1536 and 1540; but in 1541 brought before the Inquisition, which then instituted proceedings against her. \

A witness in that same process may be heard concerning the reputation in which she stood, as follows. "The good repute which she enjoyed made acquaintance with her desirable to me; for everything I was told of her excited my admiration, and I heard all the world speak of her holiness. Not only the people held this opinion, but eminent persons: cardinals, archbishops, bishops, dukes, scholars, men of the orders of every kind esteemed her highly. I learned in particular how Cardinal Alphons Maurique came over expressly from Seville to see her, and in his letters called her his very dear daughter; how the Inquisitors of Córdoba showed her the greatest respect, and how Cardinal Quignones, General of the Franciscans, made the journey from Rome to visit and speak with her. Also I myself had seen how Jean Reggio, the nuncio of the Roman court, had arrived in Córdoba to satisfy his curiosity; and our Empress, the consort of Charles V, had called her in a letter her very dear mother, and the happiest being on earth. That letter, in addition to her portrait as a memento that she should remember her in prayer, was accompanied by the veil and the baptismal shirt of her newly born prince, Philip II; for the purpose that she should pronounce a blessing over both. People spoke of her throughout Christendom; the preachers praised her from the pulpits, and all others paid her homage in the same way, without giving room to any doubt about her merit and her holiness."

She was the object of the most tender affection of all the confessors of the convent, and of the provincial of the order; and those who were furthest advanced in piety believed they saw in her way of life a new path to attain sanctity. In truth she was amiable toward everyone, loving with modesty, compassionate and so good an example that she urged everyone to serve God; and indeed her company led many persons to enter a religious life. Her skill in conducting affairs was so great that people pressed from all sides to hear her counsel, and her convent was comparable to an office.

Other witnesses who testified to the same matters also spoke of her ecstasies and her raptures; they brought up her prophecies and the prognostications she had made: among other things, how she foretold the death of the Marquis of Billen, the cardinal's hat for her order's general Quignones, the captivity of King Francis I, and his marriage to the widowed Queen of Portugal, the sister of Charles V. All this had led to a biography of her being printed even during her lifetime. So it stood with her outwardly, and now one may marvel at the labyrinths of the human heart: she herself appeared on the 7th of May 1546 at her Auto da Fé to hear her final sentence, after the secretary of the court had read the extract of her trial, from which the following results concerning her inner life emerged. \

Magdalena had testified that when she was in her fifth year the demon had appeared to her in the shape of an angel of light, and had proclaimed to her that she was called to become a great saint; at the same time urging her to lead a devout life immediately. The apparitions had thereafter recurred often. Once the spirit had assumed the form of the Crucified and had urged her to crucify herself with him; which she performed with the help of nails that she drove into the walls. But when he then invited her to follow him, she fell to the ground and had two ribs broken, which the spirit, always in the guise of the Lord, afterward healed. When she had been seven years old, the demon, continuing the deception further, encouraged her to begin an even stricter life. Burning with great zeal, she therefore one night left her paternal house at Aguilar and went to a nearby cave with the intention of living there as a hermit.

The next morning, however, she had found herself again in her father's house without knowing how it had happened to her. One day the spirit, constantly pretending to be the Lord, married her, and as a sign of the union touched two of her fingers; announcing to her at the same time that the growth of the touched fingers would henceforth be arrested; which accordingly occurred, and she resolved to relate the incident to many people as a miracle. At twelve years old she was already regarded as a saint, and to secure herself in this reputation she performed many good works and false miracles. She had visions of spirits who took on the form of those saints she especially venerated; such as St. Jerome, Dominic, Francis and Anthony. In their presence she fell to her knees, thinking them to be saints; at times she even believed she saw the Holy Trinity and other extraordinary things; and all this only increased her desire to be esteemed a saint. When this vanity had at last become predominant in her soul, the demon showed himself to her in the guise of a very handsome young man, confiding to her that he was one of the fallen seraphim, and that he had accompanied her since her fifth year. His name was Balban, and that of a companion he had was Pithon.

He made her understand that if she continued to stand to him in the same relation as before, she could enjoy every pleasure whose notion her spirit could conceive; and that it would then be his business to spread still further the reputation for holiness which she had already attained. Magdalena accepted the proposal on the condition that she should not be bound forever, which Balban granted without scruple. There followed a formal pact with the demon, in which she promised to give herself up to his counsel. From that moment the spirit, as an incubus, clung to her, until the extrajudicial confession which she made in her convent in 1543. Once he appeared to her in a black, hideous form; and when she, terrified by it, cried "Jesus!" that drove him off. He, however, soon returned, vehemently reproached her for her mistrust, but then reconciled himself with her again when she promised not to be frightened again should he appear to her in the same guise; which thereafter happened several times. \

After she had taken the habit, whenever she went to Communion she gave a cry and feigned ecstasies which her fellow-sisters took for real. On one such occasion her feet were pierced with pins; she did indeed feel the pain, but restrained herself so as not to lose her reputation. For the same reason she several times had herself crucified in her cell, and inflicted wounds on her hands, feet and side. With the help of her spirit she sometimes left the convent and visited some other place; there she saw everything that had taken place and then told it to others to display her secret knowledge. Once she was said to have been in Rome, and to have received Communion from the hands of a priest who was burdened with a mortal sin. Meanwhile no one in the convent noticed her absence; for Pithon had entered there in her form in her stead. Her spirit foretold to her many future events: for example the captivity and marriage of the King of France, the wars of the Communeros and other things; yet not all that he thus proclaimed came to pass. She fell out with him from time to time: once, when he had made to her a shameful demand and she had rejected him, he in his anger tore her up very high and then let her fall back to the ground; so that she was carried back to her cell in a very bad state.

With regard to the deceptions by which she contrived to set herself in the reputation for holiness, Majolus's account points more to supernatural states, only intensified on the wrong side; whereas the extracts that Florente made in his Wunderscheu rather seem to betray a crafty trickster who was at first deceived and then deceived others and herself. The former assures us: on feast days she was often seen hovering three or more ells above the ground. Whenever, on the appointed days, she went with the other nuns to Communion, one of the hosts --- previously and carefully counted --- was always found missing from the priest who distributed them; it was then ultimately found, visibly to all, in her mouth. Often she carried the image of the newborn Redeemer in her arms, showering it with her tears; and in doing so her hair had grown down to her feet, and in like manner gradually receded again. Florente tells either a different incident, or the same in another way, when he reports that she, in an abusive apprehension of a mystical idea, made the nuns and others believe that she had conceived the child by the Holy Spirit on the day of the Annunciation and had given birth to it at Christmas from light. She then wrapped the newborn in her hair, which then, black as it had previously been, became red; but the child left her some time afterwards. \

People now wanted the hair as relics in many places, and she gave some of it to several people. One day, when she was in the choir with the nuns, her demon, it was said, came in the shape of a dove and sat close to her ear. She then told the sisters that it was the Holy Spirit, and they thereupon threw themselves down to worship it. She confessed that for eleven years she had tried to make people believe that she took no food and contented herself only with the Eucharist. But this had been false; for during the first seven years she had secretly eaten bread and drunk water, assisted in this by some nuns trusted by her. During the last four years she had eaten various things that others knew how to procure for her. In addition she had persuaded others to eat meat on fast days, or even to work on feast days, because it was not forbidden; she had also made those with whom she associated closely believe that many priests and monks kept concubines without offending God, because it was not a sin to have such companions. She confessed many other false revelations, apparitions of souls, angels, and demons; many false prophecies, healings, and in general manifold abuses which she had made of her reputation for holiness.

She had carried on her charade for thirty‑eight years with success; at last her pretence that she did not eat became the rock upon which she foundered. Some convent sisters had grown suspicious, looked more closely, and in the last year of her office as superior discovered the fraud. They revealed what they had discovered to the provincial, the guardian, and the confessors; no one would give credence to their statements, and all declared the accusation to be slander. On the day, however, when a new election in the convent took place, the party of her opponents gained the upper hand, and one of them was elected abbess. This happened in 1542. Until then the alms that had been brought to her had been immeasurable; and she had applied them to the advantage of the convent, which she had almost rebuilt from the ground up. Now, since she no longer stood at its head, she used what she received as she pleased, because the donors had left everything to her discretion.

In the following year she became seriously ill; her conscience awoke, and after hard struggles she now made a confession, by word and in writing, of all the deceptions she had practised. The letter of a nun dated 30 January 1544, in the records, gives an account of what took place on that occasion. The physicians had declared that her condition left no room for hope and that she must prepare herself for death. When her confessor appeared to prepare her to receive the last sacraments, she was seized by a convulsive trembling whose violence put everyone in alarm. She begged him to return the next day; but when the convulsions recurred that day and the next, the confessor concluded that a supernatural cause lay at the root of it, and he exorcised her. The power of the exorcism forced the demon to speak through her mouth. He said he was one of the seraphim, that at his side stood a companion, and that several legions obeyed him. He had possessed Magdalena almost from her birth, and was of the firm resolve not to leave her; because she belonged to him, and he lived in the hope of dragging her down with him into Hell. The confessor then gathered all the convent sisters and asked them, in their presence, to confirm what they had heard. She then declared that she had had several demons since her childhood, and that she had kept them willingly since her thirteenth year, in accordance with a pact she had concluded with them on the condition of attaining the reputation of sanctity. \

She added to this confession the account of a host of particular circumstances that aroused astonishment. The confessor reported what had occurred to the provincial of the order, who arrived at the convent before Christmas 1513 with several other members of the order. The inquisitors of Córdoba, having been informed of the matter, now intervened in the affair and asserted that the investigation belonged to them exclusively. The provincial had meanwhile put himself in readiness to administer the sacraments to her; and arranged that she should sign in her cell a statement in which she confessed several of her deceptions. Magdalena then received the viaticum and thanked God that she had been able to perform this act without an outward and striking incident; although she nevertheless always doubted that God would show her mercy.

The convent sisters had withdrawn; Magdalena was alone with the one who had recorded all these circumstances in her letter, and who had stayed behind to make the preparations necessary for the Last Anointing. Suddenly the sick woman told her that she felt much better, expressed an extraordinary desire to take food, and urgently begged her to bring something to satisfy her hunger. When the sister now brought her some nourishment, she seemed to return to life with joy. When the confessor visited her, she wished to continue her confession orally; the confessor prepared to set it down in writing in the presence of Father Peter of Vergara. But Magdalena opened her mouth only to retract everything she had previously declared; whereupon the two priests left her displeased. The nuns then urged her, for the sake of her own peace, to make a sincere confession, and she at last promised them. The confessor then acted as if he were dismissing everyone; but they positioned themselves so that they could hear everything without being seen by the patient. Magdalena then made various declarations, the confessor wrote them down, and obtained from her the promise to sign the written statement in the presence of the convent sisters. They appeared at once; but as they drew near, trembling and convulsions returned to her. The confessor therefore resumed the exorcisms; the evil spirit again began to speak in her and declared that he still possessed her person. Finally, on the 14th of December the patient calmly repeated in the presence of the provincial the confessions she had made and confirmed them; and the agents of the Inquisition immediately arrested her and led her to the prisons of the Office.

To the circumstances as Florente here relates them from the records --- though of course only in extract, passing over everything that seemed to him incredible --- Majolus adds some others, which likewise have no other attestation than this very testimony. During the investigation the demon, who --- according to another reporter --- usually took the form of a Moor, by no means abandoned his outward performances; he was present at matins, to the astonishment and consternation of the nuns, in her form, and undertook many other ministrations on her behalf. The nuns therefore conceived such an abhorrence of their former abbess that, after an inquiry into her case, they by many entreaties finally brought it about that she be removed from the convent, so that the haunting might at last cease. \

In order to judge how much cunning fraud, self‑deception and indeed demonic besetting on their part have cooperated here; how much the credulity and partiality of their surroundings have contributed, one would at the very least have to have the records themselves before one; and even with their addition it would be difficult to assign to each of these moments --- which probably all acted together --- its definite boundary. She was, moreover, condemned to proceed from her cell in the religious habit, but without veil, with a rope about her neck, a gag in her mouth, and a burning candle in her hand, to the cathedral of Córdoba; where a scaffold for her Auto da Fé had been erected, in order from there to hear the reading of her sentence, as well as the customary sermon that followed. The sentence ran as follows: that she should be enclosed in a convent of Franciscan nuns outside the city, there to pass the remainder of her days. She was to be excluded from the assemblies of the community, and exercise no voice therein; she was not to be permitted to wear a veil, and every Friday was to dine with the penitents in the refectory. Without the permission of the Inquisition she was never to dare to speak with anyone, her fellow‑sisters, the confessor, and her superiors excepted; and only after the lapse of three years was she to be admitted again to the Lord's table, unless in the case of serious illness. The sentence concluded that, if she transgressed even one of these prescriptions, she should be regarded as a relapsed offender, and as one who had renounced the holy Catholic faith.

Section II. Personal Conditions of Those Entangled in Witchcraft and Sorcery
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

He who, by any one of the previously described ways, comes to be bound to the principle of root‑evil has entered into a new circle of existence. He has, as it were, undergone a transmigration of the soul, and in making himself active in a new realm his whole nature and being must conform to the relations prevailing there, and be transformed in a thorough metamorphosis. For the new principle seizes him in all spheres of an existence into which it gradually penetrates; it masters them progressively more and more, entwines them ever more closely in all their members; and thus appropriates the whole more and more exclusively, remodelling it according to its own law.

But this transformation cannot begin unless previously the will of the one to be appropriated has consented, and the partition which is set between him and the hostile principle has itself been removed. This consent may well be procured from below; but it may also be the consequence of a free resolution which seeks its welfare by these unusual paths. In either case such a self‑determination, repugnant to the natural man, cannot occur unless peculiar conceptions have paved the way for it. There must be a peculiar perspective in force which, with regard to the standpoint of the entrant, misleads the optical relations of that realm; and while he threads its paths it confuses him more and more, leading him from one abyss to another. There must enter a special worldview which makes the friendly appear hostile, the hostile appear friendly; which lies to the loathsome by giving it an alluring side, and which knows how to make that which is contrary to nature acceptable to him.

Intellectual weakness laid the first foundation for such a worldview; perversion of the will fostered it; objective demonic influences from without strengthened and carried it forward; the sophistry of the human intellect straightened out that which contradicted it; and at last it has come about that human nature has learned, in an entire reversal, to make friends with the most hostile. \

This is best shown by the self-confessions of one such person, who has come to the utmost by these ways; confessions from which the mimicking catoptrics of the great magic mirror are easily discerned, and which therefore may most fittingly introduce us into this investigation. These memoranda were written by Johanna Fery. \


Keywords: two-year exorcism of johanna[Page 116]

\]

Born shortly after the middle of the sixteenth century, in Soignies on the Sambre, she then became a nun in the convent of the Black Sisters in the town of Bergen in Hainaut, belonging to the diocese of Cambrai. In the year 1584, when she counted twenty-five years, and Louis of Berlaimont was Archbishop and Duke of Cambrai, it was perceived and noted in her that she was possessed and taken by evil spirits; and the archbishop decreed that the ecclesiastical remedies should be applied to her. The struggle lasted nearly two years; at last she was entirely freed after hard resistance, and shortly before, in obedience to a vision, she wrote her self-confessions, which we here communicate in extract.

I know that by my father's curse I was delivered to the Devil. In my fourth year he appeared to me in the form of a handsome young man, desired to be my father; and because he brought me an apple and white bread, I consented to his request and took him for my real father. As long as I was still a child, I had beside him another who took care that I would not feel the blows when I was punished. That continued until my twelfth year, when, weary of the convent in which they had me educated, I returned to my mother. From there I was soon again bound out to a seamstress in Bergen, so that I should learn to sew there, where I then had almost my free will. Now my alleged father came to me, saying: because I had taken him as father, I must necessarily live by his will. Hitherto I had lived like a child; now, however, it was fitting that I live as he would show me; and like all people lived, even if they did not say so. If I did not do it, he would inflict upon me the pain which he showed me; if I consented to what he required of me, I should have silver and gold whenever I wished, and of food and drink whatever my heart desired.

At first I refused, then I yielded to him, and granted everything he wanted. Now a great throng of them appeared before me, whereat I was somewhat terrified, because I had never seen more than two or three of them together. They then made me take paper and pen and write down that I renounced baptism, Christianity, and all the ceremonies of the Christian Church. After I signed the document with my blood, they made me swallow it in a bitter orange. It seemed very sweet to me up to the last bite; that last bite, however, was so bitter that I could not endure it. From that time on I have been everywhere hostile to the Church, had a great dread of it, always sought to flee and avoid it, and to hide myself from it; otherwise, however, I have always lived in every wickedness and all sins.

When I had grown somewhat older and they began to speak to me of receiving the holy Sacrament, it was most abhorrent to them; and they tormented me almost until I promised them that, if I got hold of that, I would act according to their counsel and will. First I had to give and present my tongue to one of them, so that in confession before the priest I would say nothing more than what they deemed good. When I was to go to the Lord's table, they had made the holy Host altogether loathsome to me, and had made me abhor it; yet I was to comport myself with a false heart and flattery about it, as the others among whom I lived did. \

Even during and throughout Mass I ate much sugar and confectionery, to the shame of the most venerable Sacrament. When I then received the Host at the altar, I immediately stepped to one side; and because, as long as I had it in my mouth, I was sorely tormented in my throat, I took it straight out and wrapped it in my neckerchief. At home I laid it in a little white linen cloth; though they wished that I should cast it into some unclean place. Afterwards, however, it was by a higher power taken away from my person. I could not comprehend why people of such wicked sort showed so much reverence and adored it: and no one could give me any satisfactory account of it. My questioning angered the evil spirits; they blasphemed the holy Host to the utmost, and I had to draw up a document for them in which I renounced that loose, vain Communion, together with the false god on the cross. I also cursed the sacrifice of the Mass, and vowed that whenever I saw the Host lifted up I would, with my eyes fixed upon it, spit in Christ's face, and blaspheme and revile him. In return I bound myself to worship their gods henceforth, and to observe all their ceremonies.

They put the writing, written with my blood, into my body; a third writing, to abide with them forever, they kept in their custody outside my body. Thus I was wholly and entirely separated from the Catholic Church, as if I had never been in it. Since it did not at all times suit that I should be able to remove the Host from my mouth at Communion, I agreed with them that they should all depart from me on that same day. For they could not endure the burden of the holy Host; it pressed upon them too strongly, and they held me on that very day to be unclean and unfit; but on the following day they tormented me all the harder for it. Whenever I wished to go to church, they made my limbs so heavy, as if I were dragging masses of iron behind me.

When I entered the order, I once more set up for them a new writing: in which I granted them full power over body and soul; I bestowed upon them both of my free possessions forever, and entrusted them wholly to their protection and shelter. Thus they had almost swallowed me up, and wholly transformed me into themselves; and I could do no good work any more, lived quite brutishly without any knowledge of God; yet they let me go on carelessly and without seriousness in performing what the order required. On the night before I took the customary monastic vows, they made me write a protestation: that my vow should be only a sham; instead of yielding my obedience to God and to my superiors, I gave it into their hands, to deal with it for their favor. I am, they said, not a nun at all, and would never be one in eternity; as proof of this I delivered to them the profession which I had made. Thus the longer I was with them, the more perverse I became. If sometimes good thoughts came to me, they tormented me with many godless things, and I had now to put my heart in writing to them as well; so that they might lay the writing upon what had been written, and govern it thereby according to their pleasure.

Now a cursed spirit came to me, who at first threatened me most severely, and demanded of me that I should grant him alone as much power over body and soul as all the others together had. He also brought three others with him, whom I was to permit to enter and depart my body at their pleasure; in return he promised to furnish me so richly with art and skill that I might confute everyone who came against me. I was rashly curious, and would gladly have learned the art which he almost loudly extolled to me. \

I was also persuaded, and gave to the first of the three my memory, to the second my understanding, to the third my will; and they each carried them into me and placed them in their particular seat. Thus all my senses were bound, and I was transformed from a person into a devil. The loose knave then brought me another one, who was called the Enchanter; he had the shape of a Rübezahl, almost fair and pleasant to look upon. When I held this in my hands I saw and knew whatever I could desire. By means of it I also had knowledge of all evil and unjust doctrines and religions in every place and corner; I also saw and knew all their ceremonies and the falsely supposed worship of God that is practiced everywhere; of that one could write an unspeakable amount. To this I was moreover obliged: that, if every earlier obligation should become powerless, the one, strangely written in foreign and unknown characters, and as comprehensive as the others, should remain hidden and valid. After him followed another, called Freilehre; he gathered blasphemers, heathens and Saracens about him. He asked me why I still carried a piece of the Cross on me. I had to tear it from me with terrible railing and cursing; they made me trample it with my feet, and I had to renounce the crucified God who allowed himself to be hanged on it, and his blood, all the articles of the faith and the holy sacraments.

They set before me now meals of all sorts of foods, and I held myself the happiest person on earth; in this they greatly strengthened me, and I was entirely willing and ready. After some time they accused me that I had never asked any favor of them; I should desire to receive baptism in their fashion and manner, which I then did, so that I would become wholly and entirely their own. They then took off my garment, anointed all my limbs with a precious oil, as it seemed to me, together with other great pomp; then clothed me again in quite different garments, and I chanted with them their loose, doggish Mass and cursed devilish words. Since they also said they had no power to fasten me entirely in their service until I renounced all the graces I had received from the Church, I had to deny the sacrament of Confirmation. I was now also to receive Communion, in their fashion and manner, from their hands every month, and beforehand abstain for three days from every other food, except that which they gave me. They then took a morsel which had a very pleasant and sweet taste; with that they played much mockery and pomp. They did this upon a high elevated place, pronounced a blessing over it according to their opinion; then they gave it into my mouth, and that they called their Communion.

Against the Christian Communion they spoke blasphemous, scornful words; I had to throw the holy Host to the ground, and they spat upon it; yet I am quite certain I remember that I could never bring myself actually to hit it. They also let me take a piece of the holy Cross; I set it upon the top of a credenza, fastened the holy Host to it, and then said: if he were the right, true God, he must show it, and would not allow himself to be so miserably dressed and tormented! And I know well that I did all this with particular rage, scorn and hatred. I, wretch, held this pious God worse than the thieves who were crucified with him; for I could not once get into my head that a God should thus allow himself to be nailed to a cross. Therefore when I once saw a procession with the holy Sacrament pass by my room, and then saw the people with their many lights and great devotion and reverence, I wondered greatly how it came about that so many people would strive to accompany such a thing, which to me was so utterly repugnant, indeed an abomination. \

And I began almost to laugh and to deride: Behold a wonder! how is it that the one whom the Christians worship is carried about by men; and moreover so mockingly and always in the shape of a naked man. Meanwhile they set up before me, by the one who called himself a sorcerer, all manner of panels and images, and they placed these their idols aloft with great reverence and diabolical singing; which, at that time, sounded very pleasing in my ears, and then I offered no canonical hour or prayer except what they put into my mouth.

When these their idols thus stood forth in their glory, they made me step up to the first tier; thereupon they raised a great clamor and shouting; and I pledged them my fidelity, and never to worship any other god than those to which they should point me. After such an oath they embraced me with great joy, praised and exalted me to the highest --- thinking they had never bound any creature so firmly to themselves as they had bound me. They also often gave me great feasts, and told me with what unspeakable joy they would lead me from this life into that life.

They were exceedingly angry at the images of the saints; and I had to suffer severely if I uttered my customary prayer, which they had taught me, in their presence. They otherwise held very rigidly and strictly to their statutes; I also had to confess my transgressions to one of them; thereupon I was punished without any mercy; and one after another came and inflicted some torment upon me. When a commanded fast-day occurred, they brought me meat and forced me to eat it; even unclean animals they thrust into my body when I acted against their command. All high feast-days, the Christians' times of joy, were fast-days for me; I had also to perform all sorts of practices contrary to Christian rites. If I had not observed one, then they made me so hungry that I became as if furious and raging about it, and yet everything I tried to enjoy I had to give up again, until they were satisfied with their sport.

In such heavy servitude I led my life; one after another who called himself a god I had to obey for a day or a week at a time. Yet one always remained with me who brought me every sort of delight, joy and diversion; and that pleased me well, and I was of good cheer. Another, who called himself the spirit of true freedom, likewise kept close to me; and for several years they contrived so that they would gladly have brought me out of the cloister, but they were not able to do so.

Now one came to me who gave me an image, wondrously prepared, and said: if this is to be the true god, to whom you shall sacrifice and serve, he shall be called Ninus. Such a proposal pleased me exceedingly, for he recounted to me in splendid words his power and authority in the world. Upon my assent he bade the others prepare the place for it. A whole host of them appeared, to whom I devoted my body, so that they might do with it altogether according to their desire and will. The wretched sorcerer-devil, whose services I had employed in this, now presented to me a palace by his specter. But to me it was nothing else but as if it were a glorious, wondrously beautiful temple; and in my eyes it seemed that no church could be compared to such temples. \

content:
[Page 120]

In these temples I worshipped the idol which I myself had made by diabolical craft and instruction, and which thereafter was burned by the priests in the fire. Now one came to me who called himself the spirit of blood, saying: so that you might be altogether perfect and without blemish, you must not offer a dead but a living sacrifice from your own body. At this proposal I was appalled; I had never before seen this god of blood, as he called himself, and I rejected his demand.

Then he threatened me strongly: he would make me a shame before the whole world; and the cursed villains tormented me so miserably that I had to obey their will at any time. Then a devil came with a great retinue who called himself Beleal, and to whom I was to sacrifice the victim. They set him with great reverence upon a splendid throne and waited on him for service. The blood-devil placed me before him and demanded of me that I, of my good, free will, give him power and authority to enter into my body, and from the same freely and unhindered take out the victim. From three parts of my body a piece was to be cut from each, which could not be done without gruesome pains, but great grace and rich reward would follow; for this work would have greater force and effect than anything I had ever done. I would then become like God, and they would afterwards cause me to be worshipped in God's stead. To such high promises I yielded to their will.

They now laid me upon a table, upon which I first had to spread a white linen cloth in order to catch the blood; and now, with my miserable pains, a piece was cut out which I wrapped in the blood and brought as an offering to Beleal. The same game was played with me for the next two days. Ah, what a painful sacrifice that was --- pain upon pain! --- and I also had to put on an outward show before the people as if I were burdened with some other bodily infirmity!

Meanwhile many pious and Christian people often spoke to me worthily about the most holy Sacrament; I thought to myself: if I might see a sign of it, I would straightway worship it beside my other gods as well. That displeased the devils, and they punished me bitterly for it. They bade me take a host, of which I always had a supply; and I took it up to a place in the house. "Now we will, make and command thee," they said, "that thou now, in our presence, curse and deny it, and with drawn knife, out of spite and mockery, stab it through; then thou wilt see what little power it has, and how weaker it is than we." Then, with a hardened heart, I drew my knife and thrust it into the most worthy Sacrament. After that stab the blood immediately began to gush from it, and the chamber was filled with a bright radiance which surrounded the holy host; which then again was transported back to its place where the others were. Then I was very frightened, especially since all the bystanders at once fled away with frightful howling, tumult and trembling, and left me half dead behind. I then began to weep and to consider that I had truly been deceived and seduced by the devils; and when I reflected properly on the sign I at last fell quite into despair. \


Keywords: two-year exorcism of johanna

content:

Then the devils came raging to me, saying: they had indeed hitherto certainly deceived and seduced me; I had pierced the true God, whom they themselves acknowledged thereby; the sin which I had committed could not be forgiven; nothing remained for me but to do as Judas did and hang myself. Since they now also threatened to take my life, I consented to be hanged by them. They bade me go up upon the roof of the house and put my leather belt about my own neck. I did so, and gave them full power to deal with me according to their pleasure. There were a great number of them who disputed over my soul; they hoisted me up to strangle me. But however they attempted it, it was impossible for them to draw the belt tight about my throat. They ascribed this to the protection of a sodomitical wretch --- the so‑called St. Mary Magdalene --- who defended me; and said I ought to yield myself to the loose harlot.

I said it in plain words, for it seemed to me I was already half dead. But however cruelly they tormented me, and thrust into my belly, they nevertheless never were able to kill me. The murder-devil then said to me: I should thrust the knife into my throat; thereby I would inflict on myself the due punishment. But it was not possible for me to accomplish such a thing; for I could not bring my arm to my neck, however firmly a whole swarm helped me thereto. The girdle I had to give them, and they afterwards always kept it with them.

I then returned downstairs, tired, weak, shattered, and half broken; was exceedingly sad, and ceaselessly what I had seen lay upon my mind; and I had to lie down to recover. They sent for the physician, and gave me medicines; but by bodily means I could not be helped. From that time forward it lay constantly on my mind that I would gladly have sought the opportunity to learn the truth concerning the venerable Sacrament. But because I was not myself, and could not use any of my limbs according to my will, they hindered me whenever I came before a priest; and caused that I straightway spoke the opposite, and set forth all manner of subtle, captious things.

From that time on, whenever I went to the holy Sacrament, a trembling and a shudder assailed me: and it was finally perceived that I did not lead the life that a believing Christian and a person of the Order ought to live. Then counsel was taken in the convent to keep me confined in a separate room, and to consider counsel and means to reconcile me again with God. Yet at that time they could have no knowledge of all that had befallen me; and I led the most miserable life, desiring only to drown myself or to kill myself, if I could have found the opportunity. The nuns of the convent who saw me in that evil state had pity on me, comforted me, and spoke kindly to me. My words in return were so exceedingly awkward, rough and unfriendly, that they appeared unpleasant to them; therefore they had to leave me in my condition. \

My lord, the Archbishop, came to our convent, and I wished to take refuge with him; but they so blinded my face that he appeared to me very stern and terrifying. They also once showed me the abyss of Hell, together with the punishment that I would have to suffer for each of my sins; I saw in a deep pit nothing but fire, darkness, intolerable stench, hellish dragons and serpents, one of which I must swallow, because I had received Communion on Holy Maundy Thursday. They have done all this to me out of their great malice, and all this is not fancy or imagination, but truly happened thus; for I know and confess that I committed the sins written above with my own body and my limbs, as I have told.

But the power and mercy of God, who never abandons his creatures in their distress, did not regard that I had gone far from him; rather he caused me to seek and run after help, and sent me Saint Mary Magdalene, who did not forsake me in all my greatest anguishes. To her praise and honor I have related what sort of life I led at the instigation of the devil; so that it may be made known to all the world what grace and help I obtained from this my intercessor and protector. As witnesses of this I take my God and Lord, the pious Lady and all the heavenly host; on earth, however, the Most Reverend Prince in God and Lord Archbishop of Cambrai, and all his priestly coadjutors; then all my fellow-sisters who have seen me.

Thus far the unfortunate woman's own handwritten report; but what occurred during the two years she was under spiritual treatment outwardly seemed to confirm completely what she afterwards reported about the state of her inner life. In her delusion she had at first made a prostration before the archbishop and begged his blessing. There her patron saint had appeared to her in great splendor, and to her terror, and to the consternation of her spirits, had received the blessing in her name. They then pronounced the exorcism over her, and compelled one of these spirits of hers to speak; and he confessed in all their names that they would be forced to depart by the merit of these saints.

When it was soon noticed that the patient was utterly and entirely without faith, priests were appointed to her by the archbishop to instruct her in the knowledge of God. She, however, showed herself stubborn and contentious and disputed every point; and the archbishop had to have her sign the Creed with her own hand in order to move her to grant him some belief. She was then instructed in her conventual duties; the original of her profession document, which had been lost, had to be procured again, and she was required to make her profession a second time.

They led her then through all the churches and to all the relics of the diocese, and bathed her in holy water, through whose power and effect all manner of base and abominable things then issued from her: tufts of hair and many little creatures, like smoky worms, came from her --- all of which caused a very great stench. To curb her malice and to weary the enemies, she was put into a dark and narrow prison. But as the evil only grew, she was brought back into the sick-room, and Sister Barbara Deruillers was assigned to her as keeper. There the evil spirits tormented her severely again, so that she often screamed for three hours at a stretch. In the presence of her keeper she was hurled from the bed into the room, and with head, arm, or the whole body so fiercely thrown against the floor that one saw the marks everywhere. \


Keywords: two-year exorcism of johanna

content:
[Page 123]

She could often eat nothing for three days, and then they filled her mouth with poisonous vermin. Once she was dragged to the brook that runs just behind the convent and thrust under the water. The keeper cried for help, and they could not drown her; the fellow sisters pulled her out alive. Another time she was cast from her chamber out of the window onto the courtyard; again she was led to the highest rooms of the house in order to hurl her down from there as well. To guard against this, they resolved to bind her with strong straps and ropes to a stout wooden chair and to lay her arms crosswise in a stock; but all in vain. She slipped her body, arm and leg nimbly out of the bonds without any knot having been loosened or any wood having been displaced from its place; and then at midnight she was led to a part of the convent that is very narrow and to which few people ever come, where, after long searching, she was finally found.

Then for a time she was made foolish so that she knew no one, and constantly said: "I will die, I!" and therefore would neither eat nor drink. Then she fell utterly silent and wept without cessation; at last she could neither sit nor lie down, but went like a madwoman pacing up and down the chamber. When a fast-day came, she could not take any food on the previous day; then on the day itself such a dreadful hunger came upon her that she would have eaten her own flesh. Thereupon, again in the presence of the priests, raw carrion was brought to her; and they filled her mouth with fetid blood and rotten flesh so that no one could endure being near her.

Now, following an apparition of her patron saint, a kind of wall was built around her in her chamber; which prevented the spirits from coming to her past the middle of the room. Soon, in confession, they learned from her the pledges she had made to them, and these were wrung from her by the exorcism. Fourteen consecrated hosts, which she had gradually put aside, were returned; and among them was one with a bloody mark where the stab had gone through. A piece of the cross also had to be fetched again.

She finally relapsed once more, and pledged anew to her spirits that she would never abandon them; but soon after, by a new apparition of her patron saint, she was again brought back to the right way. Now the images of silver and of bell‑metal to which she had sacrificed were surrendered. When they immediately learned also what had been done with the cutting out of a piece of flesh from her body, the spirits were compelled to speak about it. At first they denied it, then said that the injury of the wounded would be mortal if they left her. But when the exorcism continued, the three pieces, wrapped in the cloth, were placed at the spot assigned to them. She was then tormented the whole night with unheard‑of pains, until at last in the morning they left her. \

content:
[Page 124]

She remained free for three weeks or longer, during which, in the last nights, much blood and putrid flesh came from her. An almost strange condition in several places of her body then continued for another year and 23 weeks, with much pain. Her evil spirits were now by the exorcism gradually entirely separated from her. Only one, who had been the first and had then taken the father's place with her, would absolutely not depart. He told her that whatever she had hitherto said and done had all happened through him; if he therefore left her, she would come to notable shame, because she, who had all along been counted a reasonable, sharp‑witted person, would then no longer be able to speak a single word of her own.

This moved her heart and distressed her so much that she threw herself at the feet of her exorcist, begging him to let her at least keep that one. When he refused, she cried amid many tears: "O what a bitter parting that is!" Only when he promised her that he would be her father in the place of the one expelled---whom she afterward additionally set beside the archbishop as grandfather---did she permit that he too be expelled.

Now the liberated woman had become truly natural, purely innocent, childlike in simplicity; she had become entirely ignorant, without any knowledge of God or of creatures; she could not utter any other words than: "Pater! Haus! and beautiful Maria!" With the image of the latter that was handed to her she played like a child with its doll, and spoke to it. They therefore had to take her again like a child into instruction, and first teach her to make the sign of the cross. By the archbishop's blessing her tongue had to be unloosed again to restore to her the use of speech. The same had to be done to all her limbs so that she might be able to walk properly again.

A whole year was still appointed to her as a year of penance, during which she, being exposed to outward attacks of her spirits, had to suffer severe torment. Meanwhile she was taught again to read and to pray. At a comforting apparition of her patron saint, on the anniversary of the former one, her mind became keener; and she then received instruction, in part from the archbishop himself, in the catechism of Father Canisius, not without much wrangling and resistance on her part. For occasional relapses still occurred from time to time; in one of these she rushed so furiously with fists and feet at the archbishop that he had scarcely enough to do to save his life from her.

When she came in the catechism to the doctrine of the Eucharist, she absolutely would not give credence to the truth of it; and it required a private vision to remove all her doubts. For four months she was then taught the choir-singing, which she mastered completely. Meanwhile her bodily injuries, arising from the suffering, had in silence again become so serious that they were obliged to summon the physician Cospeau and some women knowledgeable in female conditions to see whether they could not procure her some relief. The counsel which these, together with the physician, held amounted to this: the injury is mortal; the prescribed medicines, however, only caused her further torments; and it came to pass that within a few hours her death was expected. But after first many pieces of rotting flesh had come away, she was restored to her former state. After several times more demoniac ecstasies alternated with others of a higher kind, at last the crisis drew near. \


Keywords: to, the, she, of, her

meta.keywords: to, the, she, of, her

content:
[Page 125]

\]

She gathered all the clergy about her who had hitherto stood by her; they likewise summoned her convent-sisters so that all might be present with their prayers; and in the afternoon, at three o'clock, the struggle began in the presence of her patron saints. She faltered and trembled, and behaved as one in the last agonies; she spoke from time to time with her tormentors and answered their words. At times she cried out: They tear me apart, they tear me apart! Then she was again plunged into the utmost fear and pain. Thereupon she suddenly cried: Ah, how will it fare with me yet, I can no longer endure it!

They comforted her and strengthened her with prayers. Finally there came a tugging at the ceiling and a delirium like that of a dying person. When she was asked what she was beginning, she answered: She herself then lay down upon her pillow and lay there as in wide stillness, and the struggle was decided. The parts of her body which had been cut away and thereby separated and set apart were again joined together in their natural places, and all her pains ceased. Those present sang "Herr Gott, dich loben wir" (Lord God, we praise thee)! She displayed many wounds which she had received in the struggle, and showed the shirt that was full of blood; then prayed her hours and went with the sisters into the refectory to supper.

On 6 January 1586 she had yet one last convulsion, in which Mary Magdalene appeared to her, and she was wholly and forever freed. The course of events was then written down; that and the sister's writing were read before the apostolic and royal notary Godfried von Liere; in the presence of the archbishop, Dr. Fr. Buisseret, the official, the canon Goubille, Dean Hollo, Mansent, the canon of St. Germain, Banay, canon of Andemie, the confessor of the convent, the sister Deruillers, former attendant of Johanna, the present abbess, the liberated woman herself, the physician Cospeau, one of the midwives, and finally some of the old convent-women; all of whom, so far as concerned them, confirmed the truth of what had been read as eyewitnesses; whereupon the summoned notary, with his own signature, on 6 and 7 February 1586 ratified the instrument. \

Thus the external authenticity in this truly wondrous story is well secured; but how shall it stand as regards the inner authenticity? One will immediately reply: a religious monomania in the best form! But if such a method is madness, then there remains no mark by which its train of thought could be distinguished from that in the most regular exercise of reason; and folly would be only a variety of reason. Well, one will go on to say: so then it is the deceitful, phantastic fabrications of a warped imagination; outwardly supported by the arts of a crafty natural, practised against superstitious and guileless, and therefore unwary people. Such a supposition, in that it, in order to avoid an objective Hell, transfers its flames into the person, robs that person of the only thing which excuses the first fall of sin in man, and yet leaves him open to salvation --- namely, that he fell through the seduction of an already existing evil. Thus, in destroying the moral nature of the one and abandoning her hopelessly to perdition, it must equally utterly negate the sound common sense of all who surround this one person --- here the whole convent, all the clergy, physicians and midwives. For two years these have allowed themselves to be fooled by her without once coming upon the suspicion of fraud; a suspicion which otherwise, as a rule, is the first thing a man is led to in such cases, and which in fact was not wanting among some individuals in this instance. And such depravity, not only in sin but also in amendment, would, with such stupidity, have had to coincide in all the countless cases in which one has seen and experienced the like; so that Nature would already have allotted in advance to every villain his number of good‑natured victims. \

One must therefore, to escape these improbabilities and contradictions, descend one step lower; into those regions of the naturally unconscious life where such riddles at least find a necessary explanation; without, however, being obliged to exclude altogether the occasional imposture and deception which lie entirely on the same line with the chiefly active agent. We therefore see in all these occurrences a repetition of that act in which the first woman fell. As there the seductive evil objectified itself to her as a serpent, so here it appears in the shape of that handsome young companion of the younger daughter, and the curse has formed the first bond which links her to him. He offers her an apple, fair to behold, and wheat‑bread, good to eat; he will be her father, she is to cling to him as a child.

She is thus already clairvoyant at that age; but this condition of hers, instead of, as with the mystical saints, rising toward the glorified, is in her reversed into the infernal; and while in those the objects of the heights are mirrored in the camera clara, in her the objects of the depths, lighted by her flames, are depicted in the camera obscura. Having become accountable at her twelfth year, the grown woman binds herself to live according to his will: an act comparable to the betrothal of the saints with the Redeemer; only that in theirs bitterness and the thorn of suffering go before and sweetness follows; here the latter go before, to yield afterwards to the former. The state of former unawareness is now over, her eyes are opened; she has attained the knowledge of good and evil. The Good stands before her as the Church, from which she now freely has renounced; and she is filled with dread of it, and seeks to avoid and flee it. In that she, in equally free consent, having eaten with the seed of the dragon the bitter‑orange (Pomeranzapfel), his church stands objectively before her; she feels an inward pull and sympathy toward it; for every evil disposition within her has now awakened to its peculiar demon, and he stands before her visibly as her seducer, and she on her part yields to the seduction. The first of these seductions is directed to increase the hostility between her and the forsaken Church, so that the friendship with the newly chosen may be strengthened.

Before the sacrament of confession she must bind her tongue to lying; the sacrament of the altar is made loathsome to her by cramps in the throat, every church attendance by the heaviness in her limbs. At Mass she must spit in the face of the Crucified. On entering the order she must surrender her obedience to the demons, and sign over her heart to them, so that they may obtain power over body and soul; thus that henceforth she is a nun in the fellowship of the abyss. As a sign that she has thereby entered into perfect obedience, she must finally also pledge will, intellect and memory, and give herself wholly up to her superiors, as the magnetised do to the magnetiser.

The order of the abyss is, however, the order of sorcery; the sorcerous devil therefore now makes himself objectively present to the new convent-sister, and she receives, as her wage, the art of evil magic, symbolised by an instrument. But since the false skill rests upon erroneous knowledge, another demon, that of error or heresy, has joined this demon; and the eyes of the fallen are now opened, and she is in possession of all evil and false wisdom on earth. \

To advance further she must now be initiated still deeper into the mysteries of the abyss, and all its sacraments are to be bestowed upon her. In its Eucharist she has now admitted the demon into herself, and she must venerate him as her god. From the various spirits and powers which are of its essence they now, with the help of that magical instrument, make tablets and images, some cast in silver, others of bell‑metal; probably ancient idols which were found in the earth in their neighbourhood --- the land of the old Nervii --- and which they have contrived to procure for themselves. She must now worship before them, celebrate their service festively, and, as a temple‑slave, submit to all the pressure of servility; for the demon of so‑called true freedom has likewise entered her. All the abominations of the old idolatry must now reappear around her; Ninus is therefore, characteristically enough, the demon who now presents himself to her; and his image is set up in a rich idol‑temple, the building of which stands each time before her in ecstasy. She is to become like one of the Elohim, and to obtain adoration as a goddess; but for that she must first sacrifice a portion of her own. The blood‑devil is especially busy in this, for the blood‑scenes of the old Indian Shiva‑worship are to be renewed; just as the servants of Kali sacrificed the limbs of their bodies on their altars in order to regain them tenfold, so shall it be now. From the most secret parts of her body she shall bring three pieces of flesh as an offering to those idols. Something similar to what the priests of Attis and Cybele did is now repeated; for the altars of the Baal‑priests are again re‑erected.

But the utmost abyssal immersion has not yet been reached; the submerged one must cause the holiest thing, from which she has renounced, to undergo the same that she herself has consented to. Now she stands at the goal, but now the catastrophe also occurs. The horror at the abomination --- doubtless again enacted in vision --- forces from the companion the confession of the practiced deceit; she, however, is seized by despair, because the curse of death is about to be fulfilled upon her. But as ecstatics do not burn in fire, so they are not strangled by the rope; the rigid hands cannot bring the knife to the throat. In the analogous case this succeeded only for Christina of Stommeln, when she likewise attempted to defend herself in the vision of violent assault. Now, however, with the crisis the reversal approaches. \
