A higher guardian watched over her in the dangerous hour; the vision of Hell finally makes the fallen woman collapse within herself; she looks about for her redemption, and the Church comes to her aid, in the authority of the Redeemer. Immediately the work of her restoration begins, and proceeds, only in the reverse direction, along the same series of stages which the work of her corruption had taken before. When Evil had become an object to her, she herself had been subjectively wholly transformed by it. The return must begin with the undoing of this transformation; the organic reaction, on the other hand, makes itself known in convulsions, in flinging about, in being carried away, in wrenching herself free from all applied bonds, in ravenous hunger, in the taste or smell of carrion in her mouth. Within the space of a year, by the exorcism, the evil spirits --- previously shut off from her as if by a wall --- are finally separated from her, and sink back, in the same order in which they had become objective to her, into their unconsciousness. Her ceded faculties are restored to her, and at the same time the organs which had previously been bound are loosened, and she regains authority over those freed. When the spirit among the spirits, he who was first among the others, who had occupied the father-place with her, must likewise give way, then she sinks back into the mental condition of a four‑year‑old child: for her whole development had been the work of the spirits; now that these have left her, the whole structure falls to pieces. She must now rebuild herself anew from the ground up; the bonds that are to connect her with the Church gradually wind themselves about her; and her bodily wounds heal slowly, in proportion as she drinks from the healing fountain. Amid alternating demonic and higher ecstasies the final struggle at last breaks upon her, under whose throes her complete rebirth into the Church is finally accomplished.

But if in this case it has so happened --- if a secluded nun, in the solitude of her cell, has been able to make for herself such an access to the abyss that, as in that ladder to heaven of the old patriarch the spirits of the heights descended to him, so here the powers of the nether realm, climbing up to her on the ladders of the pits, converse with her in all that is loathsome --- then the question arises: Has such a relation not also seized whole masses, and in like manner connected them with the depths of the world? Has there not existed a species of such natures which, like the rhabdomancers with the metals and minerals that sleep in the womb of the earth, stand in a bond with them and feel them through all surrounding masses; and, penetrating still more deeply, also feel the spirit‑kingdom of the night, which hides behind these natural forms in the veiled interior of the earth, and set themselves into rapport with it? If such is really the case, and an entire series of facts speaks for the reality of such a relation, will not the whole of witchcraft and sorcery rest upon this foundation? \

If what here in the concrete case befell a single personality --- if, that is, it spreads en masse over an entire order of natures inclined in this direction --- will that not fully interpret and explain all the oddities of these facts; and will it not light a lamp which illuminates the steps of the mind in these dark regions, so that it, without losing itself in the byways of their labyrinthine paths, attains an overview of the bewildering relations? It is indeed really so with this matter, and witchcraft truly rests upon this basis, and is only the extended image of that which we have here seen in full and most concentrated form. Heathenism, in its boundless degeneration, has led across into these regions; and the stages of the path it traversed are the same that are marked in the life of this nun. Then Christianity entered the world, took the fallen into its care, and led them back in the same sequence of steps by which this lost woman also attained restoration. The restoring Church, however, could not prevent the relapse of those who, abusing their freedom, preferred the downward-leading ways; the nun was one of that kind, and she belonged to an entire people settled in the regions of magic.

To demonstrate the firm grounding of this account in the mass of available facts, we must above all examine these more closely, and see whether they contradict one another and the supposition, or whether they, obedient to it, coalesce into a picture which, in its essential features, reproduces what has been stated clearly and as a model.

In doing so we shall again proceed according to the interrelation of the regions; assembling the material at hand according to the same type that in the higher orders also unites the individual into a whole. The mass-like, popular element will first occupy our attention, and we will not allow ourselves to be misled in our understanding by what is coarse and crude. For the people apprehend impressions in a popular way; just as their wit has taken the form of the Eulenspiegel, so the demonic will also present itself to them in the most massive forms, and their imagination will, in its manner, grasp sharply and help fashion the things. The facts will mostly furnish us with those judicial persons who were active in the witch-trials; chiefly in France, where those proceedings were still conducted with some deliberation and a certain form. De Lancre, in his book on the disorder in the Basque country, will here supply the richest store of such experiences; Nicolaus Rémy, in his book Daemonolatria libri tres (Frankf.), who conducted about eight hundred such trials in Lorraine, will next be added to these; and to them will then join the English and Scottish records and the German acts, and Bodin with his Demonomanie. Scattered items from the higher estates may then of themselves be found in their proper place.

### Chapter 1. Special Conditions of Organic Life in Witchcraft and Magic

\

Just as food serves as the means for natural life, so the witch‑salve and the magic potion serve as a stimulant to one unnaturally excited in the realm of magic. On the natural side of these stimulants natural magic has already spoken; and we have there seen that they are chiefly plants with milky juices, and such as are commonly lumped together under the general name of narcotics, which are generally applied to this use. Just as the higher region in man, which rises above the middle, stands in closer intercourse with the higher region of the world, the heavens, and from there all that is unity and onefold comes to this middle; so the lower, pressed down beneath the middle, is in reciprocal relation with the lower region of the world; and since this is multiplicity and variety, everything divided, ascending from there above itself, comes into the middle and toward the height. This lowest region, however, now rests in its depth on the plant-like substratum of that realm, and, in like manner, another plant-like nature lies over it and follows it in its solar elevation and in its depression toward the arctic and antarctic --- its aerial nature toward the heights and its watery nature in the lowlands, in every angle of inclination of its position with respect to the incoming light, and in every relation to the sun's situation in the season; by this variety the greatest diversity of productions in this domain is conditioned.

The realm of plants, however, is a realm ruled by sleep, which fetters all its members to their sleeping-place, the earth. Yet it is not the iron stone-sleep that holds nature beneath it almost motionless; autonomous movement of the juices stirs within it, and above the bound half another (half) rises toward the light. Therefore, although nocturnal darkness deepens this plant-sleep into rootedness, the sun by day lights and illumines it at the greenness of the leaves, and the blossom will appear like a dream of this half‑sleep; and in its surroundings a kind of somnambulism is aroused, especially in sunshine; just as in this state in the sensitives a rudiment of higher movement appears.

In the plastic (formative) realm all these states also will be embodied, each in its own product; and with respect to the higher, animal life these products, sometimes serving as food, sometimes as excitants, bear in themselves the signature of half‑sleep or double‑sleep. For, as has been said, an analogous plant-like substratum forms the foundation on which this life rests; and through its mediation the external must enter into the supervening. According to the diversity of the natural condition from which the incoming thing has arisen, it will, being taken up into the interior in diverse ways, introduce an analogue of that condition into it; and whereas one product may therefore act only as soporific, another will break the sleep of life also into a half‑sleep.

Just as the vegetable substances are innumerable, so too are the functions and organs of life a great wealth, and each substance exerts a specific influence on the organ toward which it is directed; so it will be likewise that, as there are cardiacs, aphrodisiacs, etc., so there will also be magnetics which, directing their action toward the ganglia, impart into them that disposition which is required for this state. The life that subjects itself to their action is by them raised above itself in a natural way; and the matter can now, like any other natural condition, be viewed as an unusual modality of life. Or it can enter into the ethical life, and since Christianity scorns this natural augmentation whereas the demonic certainly includes it in its calculation, such choice will therefore always incline to that side. The natural remedy in such cases then becomes a magic potion and a witch's salve. \

He in whom the impulse is strong by nature will require no aphrodisiac; and if one, perhaps in early youth, were to awaken the sleeper with it, then, once awakened, he would soon make the awakening agent superfluous. Likewise it will be with the means that introduce one into the witch‑sleep. If a disposition to put oneself into the sleep‑waking state of its own accord is present by nature, then the ointment will not be needed. If that disposition is lacking because the exterior so plastically envelopes the interior, then nevertheless, with continued use of this ointment, and with the more frequent recurrence of the separation of the two from one another, likewise the use of the natural stimulus will soon become unnecessary. Therefore there seems to lie between the state in which the individual still needs the ointment and that in which he is beyond that necessity a middle state, in which more depends on the magical preparation than on the ingredients themselves.

De Lancre says on this point: in Labourd one has consistently been of the belief that the ointment is prepared with the fat of children murdered before receiving baptism; and it has therefore been customary that novices in the witchcraft are allowed to have the prepared ointment shared with them by others; but that the further advanced must prepare it themselves, in order thereby to drive them to child‑murder. With still further advancement of the initiated, the ointment then finally became altogether needless.

The fiend Necato of Urrugne, the same reporter relates, as a prisoner went every night to the Sabbath; and I can assure you that she had neither grease nor ointment, nor the possibility of procuring any. For she sat confined alone in the chamber of an honest house; with her were 20--25 witnesses, who almost all likewise went to the Sabbath and slept in two other rooms of the same house. Three witnesses testified that they had been with her on the Sabbath at Lacua, on the coast of Hendaye, on the penultimate and the last July, 1600. They were answered that they were prisoners, and that therefore their statement must necessarily be an error; for they themselves had been in confinement on those nights and had had no ointment. We therefore confronted the witnesses and the accused with one another.

A girl called Gastagnalde testified against Necato that Necato ordinarily brought her to the Sabbath herself, and that on that night she too had been carried through the air to that place, where Necato stood by her as godmother and struck her very hard. The accused at length admitted the charge as founded; the complainant had received the blows because she herself had struck a toad that had been handed to her to keep. Cristoval of Garalde, aged 15--16 years, added that, as a reward for having revealed everything the day before, he had, although like the other witnesses previously confined, been led by the fiend Marissans of Tartas to the Sabbath. She had swung him so high into the air that he did not recognize the place of the Sabbath. There he was cruelly mistreated, and he had also seen Necato strike that Gastagnalde; to which he added certain particulars. \

The third, Aspileuetta, added that she, together with the previous witness, had been brought there by one who formerly used to lead her to the Sabbath, and had witnessed the same; which Necato in fact confessed anew upon repeated accusation. She further asserted that she had been brought one night toward Hendaye, where a small Sabbath was held. There also appeared Detsail, whom the judges already knew from other statements, that he there habitually carried the basin into which every attendee placed his offering or his penance; and he too sat then, in accordance with one of their dispositions, likewise in prison.

The Necato had accused him, and he therefore struck her hard in the assembly. At that time Monsieur Laurent de Moisset, advocate at the Parliament of Bordeaux, who sat with the rest of us in Bayonne to try these women, happened to be in Hendaye. There two women came to him who reported: Detsail, although in prison, had been at the assembly on the previous night, and there had struck the Necato with the utmost severity. Two girls from Hendaye, not far off, living near the place where the Sabbath had been held, had recognized her by her voice. They wished to be doubly sure of the matter, and had the Necato brought forward. She repeated the confession she had previously made. They also had Detsail brought forward, and she stood by her statement before him; at the same time averring that she had always seen him with the sacrificial bowl.

1)  In the first case one might suspect an agreement among the witnesses, since they had been confined together; but the voluntary confession of the accused contradicts that suspicion. What remained of suspicion is again diminished by the cross‑test. The striker of before is now herself the struck one; and that she did not speak untruth is corroborated by the testimony of the two women, from the remote place, the scene of the whole transaction.

Whatever therefore underlay it, it could not have been mere frenzy or malice; there must have been a condition present in all these people in which they all stood in an inward rapport; from which they then drew the truth and the concurrence that appeared in their statements. This condition was not here produced by the artificial means of anointing, since they all could not resort to the same; it must therefore have been habitual in them, and that is what we wished here to establish. This condition, whether brought about artificially or naturally, now begins with a sleep, to which there always follows an awakening; so that it is a lucid sleep that befalls those seized.

We asked, reports de Lancre, especially Maria Dindart of Sare, whether one could go to the Sabbath while awake. She replied: the truth is that one never goes to the Sabbath awake; one had slept beforehand; which is why one also goes to the churches, to keep watch there through the nights, and so prevent the departure. But it is perfectly sufficient to have only one eye lightly closed, and in the instant one is borne there. For it requires only the span of a nod of the eye, and however distant the place may be, whether it lie in the Terra Nova or at the end of the world, the sleeper finds himself transported thither.

Their statements, however, indicated that upon the preceding state of sleep another state of wakefulness follows; and that the rapture or transport then takes place in a perfectly waking condition, and not as an illusion, but entirely and wholly real. The women therefore, who, as we have already stated, sat spinning in the streets on summer nights until eleven o'clock in the evening, each named to herself the coming Sabbath; apparently wished one another a good night, then went to bed, and rose later to be borne to the Sabbath --- each in her own fashion, or several together in a group or individually, gathered together to set out. \

They told me at the same time: the lady of Chantocorena was on the night of the 28th... Sept. 1609 had been at the Sabbath; but she positively denied this, because she had kept herself awake the whole night. This, in fact, was the practice of all our prisoners: they all made every imaginable effort to remain awake, in order to convince us that they had not been carried off, because they were all of the belief that one cannot be abducted with waking senses. Therefore the children flocked to the churches to pass the nights there sleepless. One sees that so long as the will succeeded in overcoming nature and forcing back sleep, the inward awakening required for the disclosure of the whole condition could not appear. But if the bound person succeeded in freeing himself even for a moment, he would suddenly swing inward, and the individual was, in an instant, transported to the place of his desire. The clearness of the outlook in this inward-going will naturally depend on the circumstances and on the disposition of the individual on these paths. The demonic realms are by no means places in which clarity prevails, and aerial perspective has no validity there; yet the cloudiness will nevertheless be graduated step by step. In beginners it will appear more disturbed and confused by the natural illumination, and only in progress, as the inner eye becomes more accustomed to the darkness, will it loosen and distribute itself more to the gaze.

A remarkable statement to this effect is that of Johanna Michaelis before Remigius. She was examined in the year 1500 and said: that those who were at the Sabbath by no means had their true, natural sight; but that everything appeared as if it were in confusion, so that one could see nothing certain or sure about it. "It is exactly so," she added, "as when one finds the eyes dulled by drunkenness or sleep, or also by fear, or sees badly for any other reason, or is otherwise blinded by jugglery." Dark notions of various degrees of depth of entanglement in that state already occur. Thus de Lanere relates from his interrogations: if the women wished to go to the Sabbath only in image and contemplation, they lay themselves down on the left side. If they then awoke, the demon caused them to emit a thick vapor from the mouth, in which they then perceived everything that occurred at the Sabbath, as if they saw it in a mirror. But if they wished to be bodily present there, they anointed themselves with an ointment of child's fat.

Others said again: artificial ecstasies, like those which the Indians produce by the herb cohoba, showed them the visions repeatedly. Then the spirit led the thus-initiate physically to the place; but even there it sometimes left them in doubt whether what had been shown to those led had happened in truth or by illusion. Thus three states, arranged one after another in gradual progression. The mere vision, brought about by a reflection, in a dark cloud that rises before the now clairvoyant inner eye. The deception in this image then approaches the truth by presenting itself as a reality; yet so that a doubt as to its reality remains in the seer. The image then, at a third stage, finally shapes itself so plastically and tangibly that the doubt disappears, and the beholder gains conviction of the reality of what is seen; because no means remain to demonstrate an error in it. Moreover, of physiological interest is also the testimony that a husband gave to Judge Remy: his wife, on the night before Friday, whenever she had gone to bed, would each time be ice-cold. \

In man, double-natured as he is --- an outer nature that encloses an inner, and moreover both divided into an upper and a lower --- there lie four different states beside, in, and above one another. Two of these are states of sleep, in which the lower predominates; two are waking states, in which the higher is predominant. Of those two sleeps, one is ordinary sleep, in which the life that predominates below, being closed inward, has an impulse, according to ordered intervals, to issue outward again from its withdrawal. The other is what may be called the magnetic sleep, which precedes the sleep‑waking, in which sleep the life, closed toward the outside, has the impulse in itself to enter inward, in a determinate sequence, into the spiritual regions.

About and above these two states stand the two awakenings, such that one outwardly encompasses the first sleep‑state, the other inwardly encompasses the other sleep‑state; and the encompassed appear as the veiled germs out of which the encompassing develop. Thus natural sleep will pass over into the ordinary waking state, where the higher powers, like the life that they discharge, spread themselves into the external world. Magnetic sleep will in turn pass into somnambulistic awakening, where those same higher powers, together with the life from which they disentangled themselves and which they now in their turn control, sink more deeply into the inner world. \


Keywords: - performing marking on sorcerers[Page 136]

Both worlds are objective, both are equally real: one, in its outermost, embracing the world of substances governed by necessity; the other concerning the causalities that determine themselves in freedom. To which side any individuality inclines depends on its constitution, the circumstances, and the predominant life‑impulse in it --- whether this impulse that begins in sleep directs the life predominantly toward the external world, or whether that sleep, originally or accidentally determined to be magnetic, awakens into the inner world. The same relation that here forms itself toward the two natural regions can likewise form itself toward God. Man can fall asleep in that twofold sleep of the world, in its outer or inner region, and awakened from this double sleep into God, can now, either by the outward way of the Church or by the inward mystical way as the saints pursued, raise himself to Him. But God is now the most real Being, for he is the Creator of all that attains reality, and therefore he himself must be that. This awakening in God must therefore be a wholly real condition, and the world of actions and facts that then opens to him must appear as a world of reality pure and simple; whatever unreality mixes into this condition can only arise from the imperfection of the individual who is in it. The descent from this condition into the ordinary world of appearances, however, can by comparison be regarded as a falsification of that original, solely true reality through the admixture of semblance; for he who sees things in God recognizes them only in their truth; he who perceives them in the mirror of the world recognizes them only as they give themselves in the reflector. Here, too, it will be constitution, impulse, choice and direction that decide for the individual to which side he turns; whether he will hold to the radical truth in itself, or only to it in the husk of appearance. What therefore holds upward in relation to God will also have its validity downward toward the abyss; and the world and Satan will here form the opposites. Here, likewise, sleeping and awakening may be directed toward one or the other of these opposites. Man can, namely, awaken from the sleep of life into the outward Church of Satan which has built itself on all vices and crimes on earth; and then feel himself, in the fellowship of this bond, as a member of that association. Or, if he awakens inwardly, he can penetrate into the interior of that realm, and deepen himself down to its concrete head. But if God is the most real Being, then Satan will be the most unreal. For all reality that is in him he has from God, namely the reality of his being; everything else he has from himself: a reality only of third order, because it rests as a mere accidental upon the substantial ground of this gifted existence. The reality of the state of immersion in him, and of acting in his power, is therefore likewise only a reality of third or fourth order; and while natural immersion can be clouded by error and mistake,

it will be this satanic one that is falsified by lies and confused by striving toward an evil end. There is therefore indeed a truth and a law in this condition; but it is only the general lawfulness of Being which keeps every deviation within certain bounds. Those who are in it have looked into the magic mirror; and to the semblance that has already flown toward every truth in the world-mirror there has now been added the deliberate perversity that proceeds from lying, and in it the image has finally become distorted. This, then, is somnambulism in the magical realm---true insofar as no empty phantasy lies at its foundation; untrue insofar as it is the negative realm of malice and of falsehood in which it has taken up its dwelling as its region. Again here the impulse in the constitution and the ordering of life-circumstances have been decisive, and have given the individual the direction into the sphere of that self-blinding mode of being.

#### A. The Mark of the Lords and Their Men

\

But once the impulse has decided and the lots have fallen that the way downward is to be taken, then upon entrance into those realms a kind of manifest notification must proclaim to their inhabitants the resolved determination. Everyone has the right to designate all factual property that belongs to him---his whole inheritance, real and movable goods---with his name, mark or seal; the powers of darkness will claim the same right. \

They can, however, exercise it only upon such persons who, by giving themselves into the slavery of Evil of their own free will and with premeditation, abase themselves to the affair, and having thus sold themselves into serfdom, are justly counted among the remaining estate of possession and, like the slaves of the Romans, are marked with the signet of their lord. As is therefore said in the Apocalypse, that the followers of the Beast are bound to bear a mark on the forehead or on the hand, and that no one may trade, buy or sell without it --- so in those regions where the Apocalypse is thus being realized in the hidden darkness, it is already done to newcomers at the very entrance to their gates. All are marked, in order to distinguish them from those who do not belong to the fellowship; and this mark can be covered, but not removed without higher assistance than they possess.

The mark, however, consists in small spots on the surface of the body, never larger than a pea, which are insensible, without life and blood, while all around them they find themselves surrounded on every side by living flesh. They are sometimes recognizable by a red or black spot, or by a depression of the flesh, but sometimes also externally indistinguishable; and then only by knowledge of the place where they are usually set, or by an inner instinct of the experienced can they be found. If one pricks them with a needle, neither pain follows nor any drop of blood; whereas both appear immediately if one pricks round about them, or if one has gone deeper than where those insensitive bloodless spots lie.

Such numbed spots differ from those that have arisen from some disease in that the latter are widespread, usually lie on the extremities, the flesh softens and dissolves, and they remain visible in all cases; whereas the former often become invisible, harden in the flesh, in no way hinder the use of the organs, and can extend over the whole body. In Lorraine some had this sign on the forehead, others at the back of the head, on the breast, on the back, on the hips, on the eyelids, on one of the shoulders, and on the most secret parts of the body. They had received it without pain, at the hour when they had become apostate from the faith; and the marked spots were as rigid and bloodless as limbs struck by lightning. In Labourd more than three thousand such marked persons had been found, among them a great number of children who had been at the Sabbath. To many the marks seemed also to have a certain external shape: a small cloud, a toad's foot, a hare's paw, a spider, a dog's or a horse's hoof; which, however, Maria von Sains denies.

The mark that de Vaulr in Stablo had on his back was, according to the testimony of the investigating judge Oranus, in the shape of a black cat; when pricked it was insensitive; but if one threatened it from behind with a finger without his noticing it, then it pained him so that he broke out in lamentations. The Palud was, according to Gaufredy's account, marked on the head, heart, belly, thighs, legs and in other places; and Maria von Sains declared that, since the marking often recurs and also indicates the rank of the marked person in the synagogue, the place where the sign is attached depends on the abomination which the marked one practiced. Concerning the manner of the marking the various testimonies did not agree; for most had taken part in the act in youth and could no longer remember whether it had been the women who performed it upon them, or whether the master himself had impressed the mark.

Among the sorcerers from Castile he had used a needle of counterfeit gold. Gaufredy reported: a special demon was charged with it, who with the claw of the little finger presses the mark; one feels a slight warmth which penetrates more or less deeply into the flesh, according as the act was more superficial or more penetrating. According to others it was the horn that performed the service; and one sees that all agree in the fact of the signing, but differ among themselves about the manner and mode according to their subjective apprehension, the degree of their vision, and according to the notions they have formed of the whole matter in their testimonies.

If we hold to this fact, we here see presented the counterpart of stigmatization. When the inner life, the lowest region in man, makes its covenant with the Lord, then it wills to free itself from the power of spiritual death which has entered it through sin, and now, like a disseminated vacuum interrupting its steady continuity, leads outward through disease to physical death. But if this life turns to the other side and unites itself with the lord of darkness, then it itself, being given over to inner death, may be scattered into it, entirely lose itself to that chosen lord; so that, that death remaining victorious alone within it, all inner struggle and contradiction would be dissolved, and then, as dying ends, undisturbed immortality in non-being would begin.

In the first case, therefore, the life of the holy person is transformed into the higher source of life with which the covenant was made; so that, having been assimilated by it after the expulsion of the intruding evil and the malady, he may be inspired and exalted in his life, and thus a broad, light- and life-soaked wave may pulse through the great organism. In the other case transformation and assimilation occur in the opposite direction; the good and the living are expelled, while the evil, the night and death are drawn in; so that life may arrive at consolidation in the ice-streams of the abyss, as the depths permit.

The ascending life-spirits have therefore there taken a new course; the higher ganglion which they have begun to brim is the Crucified; five fountains have been opened to them, corresponding to the five gates through which the higher life streams forth; and in the outflowing and the inflowing a new circuit of these spirits is formed. The surges and circulations in the blood which the nocturnal constellation excites in regular recurrence have linked themselves to another constellation and bound themselves to ecclesiastical periods; and the fluids, heavier and less mobile than the nerve-spirits, follow their currents, at least in their beginnings, by bleedings.

For the life-forces descending into the abyss the contrary will occur. The heart and center have been carried away into the depths, and they seek with it to balance themselves in a new current. But it is a heart turned inward; that which in it should be giving has become taking, namely life, and it takes from everything that allies itself with it; whereas that which should be taking, namely death, rather gives to it, without itself being warmed by it. Those who have entered into the new union therefore become only poorer in life and richer in death; and since life manifests itself in the blood by rapid circulation, and in the nerves by lively alertness, in them both the one and the other are diminished in the transformation into the power to which they have given their heart. \

This transformation, however, will not take place here in the quintuple number of the currents; rather, as with the flagellation, it will be the whole outer surface over which those points of death will appear distributed; but not there bleeding and painful, rather failing blood and insensible. That mobility and power over the lower life, which appears in the higher ecstatic states, will also make itself felt in those of lower order. Maria von Sains said before those who examined her case, from 19 May to 10 June 1613, eighteen times in succession: that she had, during the preceding night, in the synagogue anew obtained the stigmatisation. There were usually seven, five or three places which she specified exactly; and if one followed her indication, and did not sometimes probe too deeply, one always found the places lifeless and bloodless, although very near by the blood would readily swell up. Notaries and many witnesses were present; also three physicians were present, who exhausted themselves in hypotheses to explain the apparition.

As with the wounds of the higher raptures no suppuration appears, and no true inflammatory process runs its course; so too is the sign of the deeper ones, because imprinted with death but round about surrounded by life, not the consequence of such a process; the spot is only small, no pus shows itself on it, or some putrefaction, and the flesh hardens much more. In Lorraine one found, as with the stigmatic marks, that the scar was at times surrounded by a fine rim or slight moisture; and it is only to be expected that Maria von Sains, in the repetition of the stigmatisation, should bear marks corresponding to the sins practised: the sexual and sodomitical ones upon the respective organs; the hands as marks at the sacrilegium; the head, however, as the sign of companionship with the synagogue. It is comprehensible that death enters at those places where sin has found its consummation; and an eruptive---or rather implanted---disease is thereby produced; a kind of eruption in which the interior casts the morbid material to the outside. By the reception the impulse is now at last unchained, so that it may freely follow its desire.

#### B. The Sabbath as Orgy and Feast of the Sorcerers and Witches

The whole drive, conceived as a totality, is now a complex of many drives, which all enter into the same underlying ground that unites them. If, then, the drive in general is directed towards a certain side, this direction will spring from the common ground, and this will press all those subordinated drives into that direction. The state which has been produced by the action of this diversion must therefore be best recognized and described if one, in order, investigates and sets forth the modalities in which, one after another, all these drives make themselves known in that direction, and in the course of this presentation follows the order in which one after another develops from the common root. Since we are therefore at present in the sphere of organic life, the life-drives that have their roots here will be the nearest objects of our consideration; and we must first look about to see how they behave in these infernal states, to what ends they are bent, and to what they are bound. Here then first presents itself that drive of life-preservation, which, as the drive to nourishment toward matter, to the self-generation of bodily life, is directed. This drive goes, like every other, here toward the abyss; and wishes, together with its master, to link the first beginning of a community of life. \

He must therefore eat of his bread, and drink from his cup; so that, in taking this his portion from what is willingly set before him, a physical bond may weave back and forth between the master of the bread and the one who is sated. In this relation, then, Satan becomes steward of the meals in the household of those who had attached themselves to him, and they will sit at table with him.

Upwards, in the attitude of the mystics toward the Lord, the corresponding relation appears in the same realm. Between the two there is to be woven such a bond, and it is in the Eucharist that, in the naturally waking state, life with life is now linked in this bond. In the state of the mystics this bond is likewise present, but worked out more in its inward relations; and it is the center of the banquet of love which the souls united about their master celebrate. This meal, however, is a symbolic one; all the foods are therefore of symbolic nature, grown, blossomed and ripened in that garden which stands above the vault of heaven; and with such fruits we have constantly seen the tables of ecstatic saints covered. But those who have turned downward toward the realm of the abyss have set themselves to entwine the root of their being with the roots of the radical evil that dwells there. They therefore seek a bond that might unite their substance with his substance. That is the same fruit which in primeval times already gave such a bond, and whose enjoyment effects a beginning of transubstantiation in the one who eats. Because they still walk in the body, sin needs a bodily covering in which it offers itself to the bodily; the fruit is therefore of symbolic nature, enclosing its spiritual substance with a seeming-body in which appropriation takes place by the life directed toward it.

With such fruits, then, are the tables at their feasts of love or hatred covered; grown in that garden which brought forth the first ones, while the saints rejoice in the fruit of the tree of life. Those, however, who enjoy the curse-laden fruit also drink from the cup of the woman who sits upon the apocalyptic beast full of blasphemous names; and the chalice is filled with abomination and impurity, and the nations intoxicate themselves therein. They too drink their drunkenness from this cup; but it is not the pure flame of enthusiasm in which those glow who above have drunk the water of life; rather it is the dire fire that hell kindles in every one who has tasted of its Stygian wave.

If we hear the testimonies of the initiated about it, we hear them tell much: of rich banquets which they find prepared there; the tablecloths seem to be of gold cloth, and the boards are set most lavishly with roasts and pies, with fish and game; white and red wine are found in abundance, and are drunk from golden and silver cups, or even from little flagons. They sit at these tables, illuminated by green pitch-lights, higher or lower according to rank and means. But it is suspicious that in these feasts no salt, and indeed no bread at all, is to be found, and instead at most a cake of millet. Salt, however, is the enemy of all rot and decay, physical and, symbolically, moral; thus, as a symbol of the preserving principle, it may not be found at the dining-tables of the Destroyer. Every nourishing and satisfying food, upon which blessing rests, has already taken that first principle into its service; thus to the other remain only such things as serve neither for satiety nor nourishment. \

Hence the testimony of many runs again in this way: when one seizes the outwardly inviting dishes, one finds nothing solid behind that semblance; all is but wind, and the deception reveals itself; those who imagine they have eaten and drunk at such meals afterwards feel as hungry as wolves. If in such cases there has been a lying semblance which mocked the partakers by making something completely non-existent appear to be apparently existent, then in others there will be something that was indeed once present but is now decayed or putrefied. The putrefaction is thus now clothed with the alluring deceit. Therefore other reports again run thus: these hellish dishes are prepared from carrion; the flesh of salted horses, pigs, dogs, cats is used; and the lack of salt and the insipid taste peculiar to these dishes point precisely to that. Still better, however, such substances will be suitable for the purpose when some crime has brought them into that condition, or when the feeding on them can only occur in a way contrary to nature. Human flesh will therefore be the most suitable for such banquets; especially when it has, as in the case of the hanged, been brought into the state by the person's own crime; or, as in the case of the murdered, by another's guilt, or by that of the revellers, into the state of death and putrefaction. That such cannibalism formed the blossom of these meals is attested by many statements of those who boasted of having been present at such things. Above all, for easily understandable reasons, the corpses of unbaptized dead children are prized; and, in their lack, also those who have received baptism, who are counted as the greatest delicacy. Johanna d'Abadie of Siboro, sixteen years old, testified that she had seen the corpses of several such children consumed; among others one which, as she said, belonged to Lieutenant Jean de Lasse. From him Maria Balcon had eaten the ear; yet never is an entire child eaten at the Sabbath of one parish, but of the same child only one quarter is consumed in Siboro, the three other parts in as many other parishes. All children whom they can seize are therefore carried to the Sabbath and there consumed. The crowning point of the whole matter is the eating of one another, and the devouring of the corpses of the dead from among the circle of the initiated; those, ever fed with such costly food, must in their turn serve as the most fitting nourishment for those who come later.

In the year 1610 in Logroño in Castile a number of people accused of witchcraft were tried; and these said among other things: On the night when a member of their association died, they go into the church and dig up the corpse. The father, the mother, or some other relative is accorded the honour of opening the body to take out the entrails, which are then reburied; the remainder is brought to the Sabbath. There the master commands the corpse to be dismembered, and then distributes the pieces. If anything remains over, the king of the Sabbath takes it with him and prepares for his friends a feast with it on the following day. As for the bones, they are put into pots until the following night; there they are boiled with a special herb which makes them as soft as turnips. They also boil soups of human flesh, with which they overload themselves to the point of vomiting. \

In the case of small children they suck out the blood through the head or the navel; heart, lung and liver belong to the master, and the remainder is reserved for the king and queen of the Sabbath, that Satan may tear it into small pieces, and distribute these among those present according to his pleasure. Jeanne d'Abadie added: to those whom he wishes that they should never confess anything in court. Such exhumations and such child-devouring may, in individual cases, have taken place in sober reality; likewise, according to a report by R. Cessac (December 1609), a woman from Labourt was proved by witnesses who had seen her turn a portion of a child on a spit; and the convicted woman was therefore, as for other maleficia, sentenced to death. As a rule, however, when the intention of the covenanted ones is directed to a death of that sort, the action occurs for them immediately in the vision. All these hell-meals are therefore visionary acts; and inner, spiritual feedings are meant by them. In the foods consumed in them the truly substantial thing is the sin, the abomination and the unnaturalness that adhere to the spiritual element; the sensible is only the symbolical husk which, in passing through the bodily, wraps itself about this core; thus only the accidental, subject to appearance and fraudulent deception.

But whoever now eats food from the hand of Satan, which, taken, hardens into stone, and whoever drinks from his bowl the bitter, wild water, may also breathe in his atmosphere. For as the one ascending in God lives and weaves and breathes and is, so the one sinking downward into the vapor-circle of the abyss would live and weave and breathe and be. Just as nature converts taken food, through the life-air of the atmosphere, into blood for the flourishing of the body; just as mystics cause the fruits of life they have eaten to grow into spiritual blood in the breath of the divine Spirit which they draw into themselves; so to the demoniacal the enchanted food they have eaten is, in the mephitic exhalation they inhale, transformed into a poisoned psychic blood. For, as the specific substance of Satan is evil, so the dark aura which surrounds him is death --- not a mere absence of life, but a power truly hostile to it which contends with his, and, if victorious, overwhelms the one overcome. Those, then, who breathe such not-life but death-air take spiritual death into themselves; the bearer of this death is a poison which now itself circulates in their veins in the form of blood, and by degrees kills the life in them. The impression of the struggle of protecting, life-bringing forces with intruded hostile and destructive ones is, in organic life, fever and fever-heat. In the inner life an analogous feverish condition will therefore arise, and a glow of the evil fire will spread inward into the organism. In possessed persons we have sometimes seen such a blaze break out; in cases of obsession it too will not be wanting, although there, as in those cases, it only appears in rarer instances. As a rule the burning will be confined within the spiritual sphere, and only in self-objectification, as something thrust outward, will it show itself in the vision.

Those accused of witchcraft at Logroño recounted: at the Sabbath flames had leapt up into which they had thrown themselves, and in which they remained without danger or harm, not even their garments being affected. They had only been made to understand thereby that these were the summoned hell-flames which had blazed about them to take from them all fear and anxiety of them. But they were the spiritual flames that burned in them, and which therefore in the vision came forth from them. \

As the mystical fire of a good sort in the saints consumes the flesh as the bearer of evil in man, so the fire of an evil signature, among the fiends, will undermine and consume the flesh as the bearer of what is good. Hence, in both cases there will appear a wasting and decay of the bodily in which the spiritual flame is kindled; yet this burning will become life for some, and death for others. The same glow will also burn in the other life-drives, especially the sexual drive; and if they are still green and vigorous, it will inflame them beyond all measure, or, if age has perhaps dulled them, it will bring them again to awakening. The ignition has taken place from within; the satisfaction must come by the same way. The organ appears only in inverse relation to the whole organism, and is indeed drawn into the sufferings as the objective element; but it plays only the second role, because the indwelling vital drive has taken the first. This drive, once kindled, now seeks to gratify its lust; and finds itself driven toward the same region where hunger and thirst had previously sought their satisfaction --- toward the abyss in which the instincts recognize a hearth of that volcanic life-fire which also glows within them. The spirit to which the maenad has bound herself is also to provide counsel and help here; thus he will, just as he was formerly master of the foods, now become host to harlots; and, as his feasts there proved to be visionary, so will his orgies appear of like nature, and all their proper reality will be contained only in spiritual substance.

For if a higher spiritual sense has detached itself from its organ and hovers free over it in ecstasy, then it can perceive an equally detached spirituality and be perceived by it without the organ immediately intervening --- which is required only where knower and known are latently bound in it to such an one. The same will now happen with the lower life-drive when the inwardly resident force of its organ has parted from it; it can then perceive like things and be perceived by them without the immediate interposition of the bearer. There will therefore also be a vision in these realms that concerns the sexual relation; in which the bodily indeed co-operates, but which in reality is effected in the demonic region implanted in it. This relation can then reach over into the purely spiritual regions, or the drive may seek satisfaction in mixed natures. In the first case it will strive toward its complementary opposite among the spiritual powers, and the bodily will be drawn in only one-sidedly. In the other case the dissolved interiors of both will meet, and the exterior will then secondarily enter into a magnetic interplay.

In the natural sexual relation there will now attach either the blessing of fertility, in a harmoniously ordered germ of life, or the curse of barrenness, and possibly a disharmoniously constituted and monstrously developing foetus, to the act. In the vision, however, when the spiritual in this drive is exalted and chastened, and, in ascending symbolism, casts off all that is bestial and turns to the source from which it flowed forth; and as, for example, in the physical order the earth unites with the sun, so it joins in an ordered mystical marriage with the universal spiritual source of life --- then the outpouring grace in this marriage will reveal itself as the blessing of fertility; and the birth will be a spiritual being, in which the mother, as if by overshadowing, only receives, nourishes, and brings forth bodily into the light. \

That then will be the mystical marriage of which that ecstatic Magdalena Buttler of the monastery of Buken reports: how she had concluded such a one with the Lord, and how to him, in due course, seven children were born --- Chastity, Poverty, Obedience, etc., and just as many virtues; the nature and being of which she then describes at length, even down to their clothing. But if the spiritual, being undisciplined and let loose, after the higher light in it has gone out, glows in a dark flame, has descended into and become fixed in the mere bestial impulse, and in its narrow containment is kindled to madness, and then moves downward where it feels the hearth of that flame, and unites itself with the principle of the depths to fornication --- then the curse will flow in this connection. The birth will indeed also be a spiritual one, but sin in it has become merely flesh, and appears throughout the whole brood of vices, only specifically graded according to family likeness. As those virtues there are poured in as graces, so here these vices will transfuse themselves as temptations; and the whole action will mean nothing more than the begetting-act of these vices in their living ground; just as that higher mystical symbolism would indicate the conception of those graces. For virtue and vice, if they are to dwell vivified in man, must have a principle of life in him; this was implanted for evil at the first transgression in the germ, and is then bequeathed to the following as hereditary guilt.

Since the Sabbath is a popular festival in these mystical regions, it is understood that all accounts coming thence to this side are in every respect popular in character, and occupy themselves exclusively with the grossly fleshly act in its kind. De Lancre adduces circumstantial statements made before the commission on this point; of these we will here cite only the general and instructive, passing over the particular, repulsive and obscene.

He reports among other things that the girls and women of Labourd, instead of blushing over the damned affair and bewailing their offense, had told the court all the circumstances and the filthiest detail with such shamelessness and pleasure that one saw how they took a pride in it, and found a special gratification in the telling, because they preferred the filthy caresses of the demon to anything else. They did not redden in the least, whatever slippery and unclean question was put to them; so that our interpreter in Basque, who was a priest, felt more shame in translating our questions to them than they did in answering them --- and these were girls of thirteen to fourteen years, answering quicker than one could ask. That, however, applied only to the girls who had known nothing else than that school; and in their ignorance they may have believed they had to do with a god, and therefore told everything outright. Among them there were indeed also some who could be brought to loathing of the vice; and who then, as far as they were able, strove to free themselves from Satan.

The old Hauber-women, however, took care not to disclose the matter; and if they were pressed sharply about it, they endured everything as if they had the best of causes to keep. One must be thankful to the one from whom Maria Dindarte of Sare testified: that she had, when Satan took liberties with her, begged him first to give her another shape; which he also granted her. This remainder of shame, which, it would seem, is ineradicably implanted in man, and even in these scenes of prostitution is not entirely displaced, showed itself also in that, whereas everything else otherwise happened openly, the affair was hidden from the children present by a thick cloud which rose between Satan and them. \

At the assembly it was, moreover, just as on earth: the most beautiful and the youngest were considered the most valuable; the most distinguished sat in splendid dress at the side of the master of the chair, and were regarded as the queens of the Sabbath. When therefore the meal and the dance were over, he took them, or whoever else pleased him best, aside; brought them, according to the testimony of sixteen-year-old Margarethe von Sare, to a silken bed; and then did with them as he pleased --- the more unnatural and hateful to God, the better. In every pleasure, especially in those unbridled ones, there lies a sting and a barb; that likewise took hold of them in this case and pressed.

In the statements it is expressed in a very graphic manner. All confess, as Remy also assures us, that nothing colder and more unpleasant could be imagined than such deeds; and Nicolea Morelia affirmed that whenever she was separated from such wretched dealings she had to lie down and rest, as if she had grown weary from prolonged driving and hunting. They all complained that, completely against their will, they had to have dealings with the spirits; and it did not help them, however much they might struggle. Moreover the spirits were jealous; none would tolerate another courting their own. Nicolea Morelia's husband testified in this connection that when she became of age, and there was much ghostly activity about her, she was consequently often and severely beaten by her own family.

Unmarried persons were not readily chosen, because otherwise the opportunity to commit adultery on the side would be lacking; they were therefore kept for later. Just as everyone had to give themselves up to their master, so were they dependent on one another in him. Jeanette d'Abadie testified that she had seen men and women mingle without distinction at the Sabbath. The Devil gave, she said, the watchword, assigning each person to another who most violated nature and custom: the daughter to the father, the son to the mother, the sister to the brother, the baptized child to the godparent, the confiding penitent to the confessor --- without any distinction of age or status. That had happened to her herself countless times; she, who outside the Sabbath never incurred a misstep, there, since her thirteenth year, at Satan's command did everything he ordered without hesitation, because the responsibility then fell on him. It was a continual filth in which all wallowed; and it is understandable that here a kind of virtual practice of all that a certain class of books sets forth theoretically appears.

Besides, according to the same witness's testimony the same was true here as in intercourse with the demon; the fundamental motive in all of it was simply depravity; and Remy records Petron, the shepherd of Dalheim, as confessing: whenever he embraced the Abrahele, he immediately became rigid in all his limbs --- a testimony that fully makes clear the nervous, convulsive state in which the participants found themselves. Since the act takes place in a manner contrary to the order of nature, no natural offspring can proceed from it. That same Jeanette also stated explicitly that from those unions, whether with the master or with the other persons present at the Sabbath, no one ever became pregnant; a statement to which, however, others objected. On closer inspection it soon appears that either popular interpretation and interpolation has crept in, or that this phenomenon of demonic, magnetic elective affinity plays itself out only from conception to birth. \

The first occurs with that belief which is expressed most clearly in a statement by Remy, where it says: one calls the children that spring from such debauchery "children of Adam." They wept day and night, were heavy as lead, sucked dry, misshapen, always hungry and emaciated, and nothing thrived on them, even if five nurses took them to suckle. Those are the so-called Kiel-kröpfe, children afflicted with rickets or cretinism; a natural evil whose cause Bolk believed to be found in such demoniacal relations. Proceeding from the principle that all evil has come into the world through evil, this opinion --- which, as is well known, Luther also cherished --- forgot that once such an evil exists it reproduces itself according to laws of necessity, and in its separate appearances by no means always needs a special causality through whose perverse action it arose. In this way, it seems, that delusion was formed which, to the misfortune that pressed upon these helpless creatures, now also added the evils of mankind's loathing; this, in turn, was alleviated among the people by the belief that the misfortune was derived from the house through them. Many of these unfortunates have nevertheless become victims of this delusion; for it was then customary in Lorraine that midwives quietly got rid of them.

The other mode reveals itself in what is recorded elsewhere in many confessions about the so-called elves or evil things. These were worm-like or entozoic formations which many of the arrested women confessed to having received on such occasions; and which, after they had carried them in an apparently regular pregnancy, finally came to light, whereupon they were buried in the earth. That the impulse toward the same, indeed an even more intensive inflammation --- which externally ignites in nymphomania --- excites in the organs a process that, immediately entering the rhythm prevailing there, runs through all the forms and symptoms of a pregnancy without any bodily foetus being present, is easily understood from what has been adduced earlier, and such a process has its analogue in the domain of nature. This pregnancy will then be able to advance in the realm of vision just as it had its beginning there; and in the same way it will there also be brought to an end.

What such women under these circumstances thus declared about themselves was taken from the history of the course of this spiritual pregnancy; it was the vice of unnatural debauchery that had become alive in them because it had implanted itself in the ground of their inner life. That which had been conceived within them had passed through its stages, with all the symptoms of an ordinary pregnancy; but it falls into their inner life, drawing the outer only into compassion. The process must end in a delivery which, however, because the fruit was conceived in the intus-(inward) reception and therefore takes place in the inner world, becomes visible to the outer world only in vision; hence the accounts run to a burial of the thing born. It is moreover not necessary, not even probable, that the whole occurrence remained without any external envelope. The dreadful inflammation of the forces must also have brought about a volcanic burning of the organ; and these organic processes in it, as in the possessed the inflammatory condition of the entrails, give rise to --- Görres, chridl. Monte. 1v. v. 15 --- whose extent and nature we are not able to measure. It is an unholy disease that has seized the individual in this region, and can now form concretions of the kind of hydatids which perhaps arise in the closely closed chambers of the brain, and in which the temporal evil both finds its course and finally its crisis.

A life that thus passes its days in abominations of every kind will also outwardly express the inner tornness in a corresponding distortion, which is expressed in the popular saying: "ugly as a hag!" To this first belongs what popular belief has preserved concerning the characteristic features of witch-physiognomy. The traits of this portrait must have been taken from such specimens as had brought that matter to virtuosity; and were then, given the hardness of the human heart, found and applied everywhere where age, poverty, misery, ill-treatment, in prison and on the rack, among old unhappy women who either did not at all or only very superficially partake, produced similar, and accordingly interpretable, features.

A canonical example of the first kind, however, seems to have been that Necato of de Lancre, of whom he tells us much and whom he thus describes. She, whose name already anagrammatically and hieroglyphically pointed to her fate and her kind, had set aside the nature of her sex in order to make a man of her, or rather a hermaphrodite. For she had altogether the expression, the speech and the bearing of a man; indeed of an exceedingly rude, dark-hued and sun-tanned one, like a forest-devil or savage who never left the woodlands and the open fields. She was bearded like a satyr, had small, deep-set, wild eyes, with an expression of ferocity like a wild cat; at the same time so flashing and dreadful that the children and maidens whom she brought to the Sabbath, and whom we confronted with her, could not endure her gaze; although she, out of consideration for us and in view of the justice, made every effort to moderate it, and by taming that natural savageness to move it toward some mildness. One believed one could plainly discern in her that she was accustomed to rest her eye upon that fearful object, after whose model she had adopted her raging and dreadful expression.

Another consequence of the inner dissolution is the smell which those initiated into these mysteries emit from their mouths and whole bodies; which thereupon communicates itself to their clothes, and transfers a pestilential stench onto all who come near them, and fills the houses, the air and all neighboring places so that it endures for a long time. In these words Brognoli has described the condition of the demoniacs; and the testimony of all exorcists agrees with this result. Not only is the whole body infected with this stench; every single secretion from the mucous membranes, the kidneys, &c., is marked by the same infection. Opposite the odor of holiness on the good side therefore stands, in full truth, the stench of unholiness; which proclaims itself so decisively that the elders accordingly called them the Foetentes, and the Gascons called them the Fetilléres. Just as the sweet scent of the saints tends to increase with every holy action they perform, so the stench of the unholy will increase and decrease with the degree of depravity to which they have sunk; and with each manifestation of them will only be concentrated.

We have ascribed that sweet scent to the production of an ethereal oil which develops in the simplified life-process, under the influence of a higher illumination, like the aromas in a blossom. The foul smell must therefore likewise be ascribed to the production of a putrid and inflammable animal oil, which is generated in the depressed life in the flames that burn through it; as the sharp and caustic or stupefying juices are produced under the sun's burning in poisonous plants. \

Sharpened emanations tend already in ordinary life to accompany every deviation from moral harmony, which is immediately met by a corresponding natural dissonance; for the sharpened sense of the saints testifies to this, who, as we have seen, have smelled the sins of those who approached them, particularly the sins of the flesh; whereas the expression "stinking pride" seems to render this vice intelligible to the common understanding. A habitual intimacy with evil will therefore also render such a production permanent, and will thereby increase it both qualitatively and quantitatively so that no specially heightened sense is needed to perceive its presence; rather it forces itself upon ordinary powers of perception.

While, therefore, to the saints a conservative power is given which remains dominant even through frailty and sickness, and preserves in them the sweet odour even in conditions which otherwise unavoidably are associated with foul smell, yea even preserves them uncorrupted after death; in the demonic a destructive principle seizes, piercing even through their health: so that their healthy body already, like a cancerous ulcer, is foul-smelling, and, at death, rapid and swift dissolution and putrefaction follow. This is already hinted at in life by the uncleanness into which they must be brought; for the statements of many in their interrogations ran as follows: the unclean spirit does not allow them to wash themselves in the morning. It was therefore even believed that daily washing of the hands, and commending oneself to God's protection before going out, gave security against witchcraft; and Mugeta von Essem warned her husband earnestly about this, even before her burning at Remy.

### Chapter 2. Personal States of the Psychical, Middleman in Witch and Sorcery-Being

The transition into this region is effected, from the sphere of life, by the systems of voluntary movement in the torso of man. This torso is indeed built up from below by life, and is maintained by life in its existence; but it is destined chiefly to serve the psychical man as carrier, and as an organ to be borne and ruled by him. In the ordinary relations of reciprocal subordination it now rests firmly upon the support of the earth; and the column about which it is gathered is upheld by the rooted lower extremities, though it is also moved from place to place. But if the relation is annulled by the inwardly supporting (principle) obtaining predominance over the outwardly supported, then the dynamic in the organ becomes preponderantly powerful over the outwardly heavy, material; it withdraws into itself, and, concentrating more deeply, it masters the externally downward-drawing forces more and more.

In contrast to the common centre of gravity of these forces, another such point is found for the totality of the opposing fighters; and in the conflict of both points, on the one hand the position of the first is drawn more upward, and on the other hand the sum of the forces set upon walking and moving is outweighed by that of the winged, and, in the midst of the increased mobility, the possibility of flight movement may develop. Thus it must be the case in every inward-turning (process), whether its final aim be directed toward height or toward the abyss; the opposite modality will only appear with the externalization, where in the latter case the inwardly supporting is bound by the outwardly supported, and the whole act appears more in the character of a mere lower natural performance. An analogue of this will show itself in external nature, where with the earth's gravity a higher or deeper gravity, in the sun- or moon-gravity, connects, and now the union or counter-effect of these moments alone determines the total effect. \

This total effect will then manifest themselves in the flood and ebb of the sea, and in the flood the earth-element, freed from earthly gravity, will rise in ascent; not only, however, where the other acting moments intervene at the zenith, vertically and in opposition, upon terrestrial gravity; but also at the point diametrically opposite, where they, though apparently confirming it, reinforce their effect by their own. If, therefore, the evil spirit has become the center of attraction for the spirits turned toward him, then the effect of this spirit-gravitation will also become visible in the realm of the physical in man; he will in part be unchained from it, as is the one who has surrendered himself to the Lord. But if the latter gains release from that power, so that it may be the expression of his higher, inward liberation, then the other is only torn away from his natural bent in order to sink into a more shameful servitude. Just as the Kabbalists call the bearer or organ of a power its chariot, so the Elijah-chariot of the mystics is the higher power, while the fiery chariot of the demonic is the lower --- Satan, who carries them over into his realm.

#### A. The Witches' Ride

The demonic, in organic life, by the nature of the process taking place there, predisposed to a specific lightness, and therefore belonging to the family of night-birds, are further driven in this direction by the distribution of forces in the organ of motion; so that they, too, like the possessed, do not lack the flight-membrane of the inner man, whose swing the outer must then follow. This character will therefore be characteristic for the whole class, and whatever in any way touches this region will already appear tinged with it. It has accordingly been remarked that even children who once took part in the Sabbath have already acquired this tendency to become buoyant.

Remy gives a clear example properly attested by witnesses, which we will cite from him here on account of its singularity. Franziska Haquart, who stood before the court in the year 1587, had, when her daughter Fana was only seven years old, given her over to the unclean spirit, so that he would thereafter leave her untroubled. She immediately reported this to the judge, and the daughter's testimony agreed with the mother's statement. On account of her youth she was released, while the mother had to atone with fire. A respectable matron thereupon took the child in hand and urged her to the fear of God, to bring her back from the godless condition. It succeeded so well that at last people entirely came to believe that it had been altogether accomplished. \

Then it happened that, one night when she lay in bed between two maids, she was suddenly borne aloft, as if the spirit would take her with it. How likely --- it would indeed have actually happened --- had not the maids prevented it by their cry: "Lord Jesus, help!" When the spirit thus saw his work disturbed, he left his prey hanging up among the beams, and departed. The maids did not invent this; the whole neighborhood attested to what had occurred. For at the cry for help from the maids everyone hastened in and had seen how everything was arranged. The stiffness in which the little maid was found, her pitiable condition, and the fact that for eight whole days she took no food, remaining continually awake and silent, proved that no deceit had crept in. The very rigidity in which the child was found testifies that her condition had been nervous; that in the seizure she had spasmed locally, and was then borne aloft as far as the space permitted. What of demonical in the matter there may have been remained behind from the former direction which the mother had given the child, and was therefore accidental. The Bishop of Pamplona, Pr. von Sandoval, relates in his History of Charles V, on the occasion of a witch-trial that was held before the royal council in Navarre, the following fact. He wished to satisfy himself by personal inspection as to the cause of the circumstances there occurring, and therefore promised clemency to an old witch, from among the others, if she would perform her sorcery in his presence. The old woman accepted the proposal and asked for her ointment-box, which had been taken from her; and then she, in the company of the commissioner and many other persons, climbed up a tower. There she placed herself at a window and, with the ointment, rubbed her flat hand, her loins, the joints of the elbow, the underside of the arm, the shoulder and the left side. Then she called with a loud voice: "Art thou present?" Everyone present then heard a voice in the air say: "Yes, here I am!" The witch then began to descend the tower, head downwards, using her hands and feet in the fashion of lizards. When she had thus reached about the middle of the height, she took flight into the air; and the eyes of those present followed her until the horizon hid the flyer. All remained full of astonishment at what they had seen, and the commissioner caused it to be announced that a considerable sum of money would be given to whoever should bring the escaped woman back. After two days the shepherds brought in the one found. The commissioner asked her why she had not flown farther away in order to escape the inquiries of those searching for her. She answered that her master had only undertaken to conduct her three hours' distance, and had then left her in the field where the shepherds found her. Llorente relates in his History of the Inquisition the course of this affair, which ended with whipping and several years' imprisonment for the 150 participants involved. \

The example of the Indian brahmin, who, according to the testimony of many English witnesses, sat suspended in the air upon a staff, appears akin to this fact. Where such occurrences take place, therefore, it is not absolutely necessary to infer demonic agency; other natural forces may also intervene in such cases. Thus Rémy relates from his records: Once, in the German Vosges, near Huncaria, a violent storm arose with thunder and lightning; the shepherds, for protection against the tempest, had withdrawn with their cattle into the woods. There they suddenly saw two peasants hanging high up in the tree-tops, and their minds were so stunned and distraught that one could clearly see they had not climbed there intentionally but had arrived by some accident. The state of their clothing, covered with dirt as if they had been dragged over stick and stone, meanwhile aroused the suspicion that demonic force had placed them in the trees; and this seemed to be confirmed when, after they had sat there for a while and no one was watching them, they came down and vanished. Afterwards arrested, they freely confessed what the shepherds had asserted of them.

Likewise, once in Bellmont during a storm two men --- a certain Rothar and another called Amantius --- fell from a cloud onto a roof. The first had expressed great concern in that position about how they might come safely to the ground; the other, however, had replied laughingly, "Be calm, fool! for he who has us in his power can do still more." And indeed they were seized by a whirl and forthwith brought down to the earth uninjured; whereby the whole house trembled so that it seemed shaken to its foundations. The inhabitants were all unanimous in their testimony as to the circumstances and the day on which it happened.

Again, Cunin, a magistrate of Roncas, in December 1586 had been attending to business out on the meadow; and since the sky proved very stormy, he set out in haste for home. Suddenly a lightning strike had uprooted six oaks around him, and a seventh, which had remained standing, was torn and riven as if by claws. As he now hurried home all the more, having only lost his hat, he saw on the top of the oak a woman who seemed to have been set down there from the cloud. He recognized her, and called to her: Are you the ill-famed Margaretha Warma, upon whom, as I now see, suspicion of witchcraft has not been groundless; how then have you come here? She answered: Conceal what you have now seen; no smallest ill shall from me befall you and yours in the future! Cunin swore to his statement before the judge, and Warma confirmed it by her confession, without the use of torture, and at the last moment.

Del Rio relates a fourth case as equally beyond doubt. He was at Calais in 1587, when Archduke Albert took the town; on the bridge toward Boulogne, where the enemy lay, the Walloon outposts were posted. Two of them saw in the evening, under a clear sky, a blackish cloud approach; and heard confused voices issue from it, without being able to distinguish anything. Because they mistrusted the matter, one fired his arquebus; and then a drunken, naked, rather stout woman of middle age, wounded, fell from the cloud at their feet, who acted foolishly and could hardly say anything but: Are enemies or allies about here? \
