In those first cases there are sworn judicial attestations; Del Rio appeals to many eyewitnesses; there must have been some basis of truth in the facts. Natural explanations, on the other hand, must be admitted as long as they are not found to be insufficient. Storm and bad weather were, except in the last case, always involved. It is contrary to natural instinct that people should have sought shelter on trees and roofs for the purpose of shooting at them; but it is possible that they were perhaps whirled up by a waterspout, which would have produced their bewildered state of mind and, because of the violence of the occurrence, led them themselves to believe that it had been the work of the devil. If this interpretation is rejected by the circumstances, then that which arises from becoming suspended in magnetic states comes into play; and only when the person's previous life also accords with it will the assumption of demonic influence be justified.

If the impulse to hover seizes simultaneously many who are connected in demonic rapport, and if these impulses are all directed to the same distant goal, to the place of the Sabbath, then thereby the excursion will be formed; and the next question must now arise: are the participants in this excursion bodily and physical, in real locomotive movement, to that place, or are they present there only outwardly in appearance and in a spiritual manner; that is, are they present in the one place without being at the same time present at the other, distant place? Some have accepted both kinds of presence, and in order to prove the reality of the former have repeatedly adduced facts which, as invented out of the air, can be dismissed; rather, a more exact inquiry is required. The two most important \[cases\] to us here must be those that Fr. Bartholomew de Spina has set forth in his book. An eminent physician of Ferrara, who in that city is especially devoted to the care of the poor sick, called Sozinus Bentius, has in the last days told me the following with the most sincere truthfulness.

He said that three years ago he had been in the country to look after his estates, and there he had by chance fallen into a conversation with his farmer about the witches. The physician had maintained that all that is told about them is mere imagination; especially, he said, if one believes that they physically set out on the ride. The farmer, however (who is still living and is called Thomasinus Pollastros, born indeed in the district of Mirandula, but now residing in that neighborhood in the place called Clavica Malaguzzi), answered that he knew a peasant who lived nearby and who himself, with his own eyes, by night had seen men and women in great numbers who danced and gave themselves up to all manner of lusts. The doctor was astonished at this remark and begged his bailiff to bring that peasant to him. He came, and, when asked about the matter, gave the following account. \

One night, when I had risen three hours before dawn in order to bring my oxen and my cart to my tenant to assist him in some business, and had thereby come to that plain to which he pointed with his hand because it lay near, I saw from afar many fires in different places, like great lights; and between them a great multitude of men and women who as it were quarrelled among themselves, or else danced together. But when I came nearer I beheld, in the bright light which the fires shed around them, more than six thousand people; and there were tables set up at which many sat and made merry with food and drink; several danced and practised various games; others took out things about which it is indecorous to speak at greater length. Among the crowd I saw some men and women already known to me, and I spoke with several. But after an hour all rose at a certain signal, hurried away, and vanished as if in a mist.

On this testimony the physician changed his opinion, and held that what he had formerly declared to be delusion was not only possible but really did occur. The same author reports: Brother Paulus of Caspan of his order assured him that a priest, J. Ant. von Palavisinis, an honorable man who lives at Caspani in the Veltlin, had told him the following. When, before dawn, he rises as usual to perform divine service or to attend to other business, it has often happened to him that he has seen a great number of men and women in a neighboring plain running about with lights as if in play, and he has recognized them as witches and sorcerers in their assembly.

In both accounts the persons, the place, the time and the occasion are exactly specified; the witnesses who give them are not suspect, and they have taken down what was told; one must believe that they saw what they testify they saw. Yet their testimony by no means proves that the company seen was actually present at that place. One has, namely, neglected to verify whether the seers did not possess the second sight, and whether the Sabbath observed was not seen in a vision. The vision of the tenant of Glenarz and of a son at Inverness on the Gairan bridge has arisen from this source. The seers have, in the very content of the vision, seen an actual rider on the road whose horse the teamsters seemed to urge on with bayonets. Just as these saw an army, so could his Italian seers behold a revel without its being spatially present at that time. The statements of witnesses in judicial inquiries that they saw dancers under the trees as they passed by can in part be interpreted in the same way.

As is well known, the circles in the grass around trees, chestnuts for example, in which not a single herb ever grows, have been regarded as witch-circles. Various natural explanations of this phenomenon have been sought, among others the supposition of masonry existing beneath them. But at least this explanation Strozzi Cicogna has found to be invalid. At Castelnuovo in the Vicentino such a circle was found. Strozzi had excavations made; one found nothing but earth, like in the places beside it. \

Many other narratives circulate concerning such gatherings, said to have been held truly and bodily, remote from human intercourse, into which eyewitnesses accidentally stumbled. Besides the fact that in these reports it is never clearly shown whether what was seen was not either merely too corporeal, or not rather a vision, all these accounts lack the external authenticity that would be required to admit them as testimonial evidence. There is the peasant from the Sabine country, near Rome, whom his wife persuaded to anoint himself. He is at once led under the walnut tree near Benevento, where he finds many gathered who eat and drink and make merry. He does as the others; but since the unsalted dishes do not please his taste, he repeatedly asks for salt. He finally receives what he demanded, and then says: "Praise be to God, now that this salt has come." Immediately everything falls apart, the spell vanishes, and the man is left alone. He must painfully beg his way home; he then accuses his wife along with others whom he had seen there; they confess and are all burned. Grillandus, who relates the story in the first book of his work De sortilegiis, gives no names and adduces no witnesses; but even if the matter were best investigated on that side, it would not prove what it sets out to prove. For the peasant had been anointed, and thus was subject to all the enchantments that commonly accompany that condition.

The women who rode out used to put the men at their sides to sleep by applying the salve, so as not to be disturbed by them in their proceedings. Bertranda, the barber's wife in Forbach, confessed that on such occasions she, with her anointed right hand, plucked at her companion's ear, whereupon he then fell asleep. Exactly the same thing occurs in the trial of the witch of Loches in Bodin, who calls it a matter still quite fresh in memory. She and her husband are transported from Loches to the heaths of Bordeaux, fifteen days' journey away. The husband says: "My God, where are we?" Immediately everything scatters; there is a trial, and the woman confesses everything without coercion. Thus in the year 1525 a girl from the duchy of Spoleto, thirteen years old, is led in by a witch; the girl, amazed at all she sees, cries out: "Blessed God, what is this?" Everything has vanished; in the morning a peasant finds her in the field.

Torquemada, in the third book of his work, relates: a sorcerer persuades a man to ride with him, and the latter consents. He then takes him by the hand, and they fly through the air very far off. There they find the Sabbath assembled. But the newcomer loses patience and cries out: "God --- what a great noise!" Immediately a whirlwind and a storm break in, and everything is scattered. It takes him three years before he comes back to his native place. The generality and indefiniteness with which these narratives are framed proves that they rest upon popular legend. This legendary character appears still more plainly in what William of Newburgh relates of an incident that happened, when he was still a boy, in the province of Deir, not far from his birthplace. \

From a place near the eastern sea, where the river Vispe is situated, a peasant had gone to visit his friend in the neighbouring village and returned late at night in a not entirely sober frame of mind. From the nearest hill, not far from the road --- the one I have often seen --- he heard the voice of a merry company. He wondered who could make such a noise so late at night; and when he saw a door in the side of the hill, he went in to look. He found there a large, brightly lit chamber, and many men and women sitting as at a feast. One of the serving attendants, when he saw him standing in the doorway, brought him a cup, which he took; but, because he hesitated to drink, he poured out its contents; then he tucked the cup away and withdrew. Thereupon there arose an uproar inside on account of the cup; the guests pursued him, but he escaped them thanks to the excellence of his horse, and reached his home safely. The cup, of unknown material, unusual colour and peculiar shape, came to the elder Henry, King of England; then to David, the brother of the Queen, and long preserved in the Scottish treasury. A few years ago, as the legend says, it was handed over to King Henry II, who wished to see it, by the Scottish William. The hill in this tale is the old Benusberg, into which the Wild Host rides every year; the cup, however, is the Oldenburg drinking-horn which Count Otto won in the hunt from the maiden who, emerging from the Osen- or Asen-mountain, offered it to him filled with a draught which he poured out; the horn, spurring his horse, he carried away. The Teutonic legend, transplanted to England, there received only local colouring. \

But this legend takes another turn again in an inquiry conducted by Remy, where it appears as if it were a historical happening. In Lützen, at the foot of the Vosges, in May of the year 1580, the neighbours celebrated a kind of carnival; and Claudius Chotey had returned at night to the place Wisembach. He had already half climbed the mountain that lay between the two places; then, in an otherwise clear, calmer air, he was seized by a vortex and now looked about him, astonished at what might be happening around him. There, at a place apart on the edge of the cliff, he saw six masked women dancing around a table set with many silver and gold vessels, flinging their heads about like the possessed; with them, on a black ox, sat a man who watched their revels. When he stood there, to look at the matter more closely, all was lost to his eyes. He went forward, and when he had already come over the crest of the mountain, he saw those women following him, still silently swaying their heads. Before them was the one with the dark face who made at him a clawing look; but he defended himself against her with his sword, so that the assailant fled. The women in the meantime returned with their leader a third time, and Chotey, now bolder, went nearer and recognised Desiderius Garete, to whom he then gave his word that he would keep secret what he had seen. Another vortex or mist seized him again and brought him to a distant place, from which he at last reached his home. He had reported it to the magistrate. The same had, however, nearly in the same words been told to the magistrate by Barbelina Careta, one of the women, adding: Desiderius had purchased the witness's silence with much wheat and two grown calves; and it was not true, as he had said, that they had attacked him because he had come too near the table, but because he had attempted to steal a cup.

One sees that a private carnival-night lay at the root of the whole scene; it was held in the darkness of the forest, and night and wine did the rest. This is also confirmed by the third form of the tale, as told by Joachim Kämmerer of Bamberg. A butcher was walking through a little wood at night; there he hears a noise and a dancing, goes up to it --- and the dancers vanish. He now sees silver goblets standing there, takes them, and brings them to the authorities. They thereupon arrest, as witches, those whose marks were upon the goblets, together with others who had been denounced, and execute them all together. That they, says Lerchheimer of Steinfelden (who tells the story), were witches is to be inferred from the fact that they had accused others whom the devil, in a dream --- as if they had been together there --- had shown to them. They had lain at home and slept; meanwhile the devil kept watch, and carried the goblets from their benches to that place. Who would willingly keep a feast and dance by night in the rough, dark wood, in the wind, in cold and rain? Their goblets were found there, therefore they had been there. \

By the same line of reasoning it once happened that, in a distinguished city in Germany, the authorities were deceived so far as to hang an innocent locksmith because his lock-picks had been found at a place where money had been stolen from a chest. But another had taken his lock-picks and used them, which he afterwards confessed. Yes, some --- those who ought to admonish judges to fairness and leniency --- are so perverse toward the poor man: when the husband testifies about his wife that she was on that night, the very night she is said to have been at the dance and to have been seen there, never out of bed and lying on his side, then they say and argue: in the bed lay a specter, but the true body had been outside. Dear sirs, why do you not invert this and interpret it --- not to the devil's discredit, but for the good of man --- so that the true body lay in bed and the false one was outside? Is it not a principle with you that, in doubtful matters, one should always prefer the milder to the harsher? --- One must say there is good and sound common sense in these words. Meanwhile many of the accused themselves had voluntarily sworn: they had left their child's pillows in the bed in their place; others a broom, a scarecrow, or even their own spirit as a succubus.

The age that entertained such an excess of belief that the ordinary, prosaic world thereby stood in danger of disappearing in the same way as the invisible world is in danger now through present unbelief, accepted this account without the smallest doubt. What Binsfeld, an upright and very reliable man, relates from the Trier records may well demonstrate the possibility of such real abductions; but it does not suffice to establish the reality of such assemblies. He adduces, first, a noteworthy example of an invisible child-abduction to prove the power of imperceptible forces in the matter. The wife of Johann Eysenkopf, a burgher of Wilmar, called Margaretha, had borne a little boy named Conrad. A spirit often stole him from the cradle, before and after her laying-out \[i.e. the funeral-like rite?\] --- from the feast of the Resurrection to that of the Departure of the Apostles --- and carried him to other places. Once he laid him in the mother's bed, another time he hid him beneath the steps of the cellar-stair; at times he carried him to the loft or to the privy. But so that no harm should befall the child in these happenings, he always placed cloths under him which he had likewise secretly stolen from the parents.

Once, when the mother destroyed such a bed as the spirit had prepared in the bathing-room, her face and hands swelled up, as far as they were not covered by her clothes, and her skin peeled off. At times the spirit would also rock the little boy, and he always cried when his mother had put him into the cradle, but was perfectly calm when the spirit had carried him to another place. The dean of the place, W. Lyndner, wrote to Binsfeld for remedy, and the latter advised the use of sacramentals. They were applied, and the older people also undertook a pilgrimage, whereupon the matter subsided for a time. But soon the consecrated objects were found torn away, and the invisible one began his game again. All that was told had, at the dean's request, been authentically recorded by the local notary. \

One sees that here again one of those spectral apparitions was at work. Binsfeld then relates further. On 22 September 1589 the peasant Michael from Longen, in the Amt of Pfalzel, was executed for witchcraft; he confessed among other things that he had been led at Christmas to the Sabbath at the cross of Longwich, on this side of the Moselle, but had only arrived there after the dispersal of the assembly. Thereupon he cried out, "Lord God, it is already over!" In the same instant he had fallen down into the field, and about eleven o'clock at night had gone to the Moselle, put himself into a boat across the stream, and gone to bed. In the year 1591, on 4 May, Martin of Corlingen was burned there; he confessed that twice, on the return from the Sabbath, he had been thrown into the bushes near Pellingen because he had said, "O God, how did we come to be here?" Once, he said, when during the dearth he had bought a sack of wheat in the town, he had been carried over the wall together with the purchase. Anna Meisenbein of Cologne had gone to the assembly on the Hetzenrodter heath; after its conclusion she quarrelled with her daughter and beat her in the presence of her son. The mother, the daughter, and the son had all given this account in complete agreement.

One sees that these statements are entirely authentic; the people express their full conviction. But in order to draw from them a decisive conclusion as to the tangible reality of the occurrences, it would first have to be determined whether what they report as having followed the Sabbath actually happened in such objective reality, or whether they did not experience it only in vision, perhaps in a lesser degree of the same. Thus, after everything is carefully considered, among the facts adduced for bodily excursions there is not a single one that has been clearly and incontrovertibly established as proof of what it purports to prove. Only a few related cases: for example, where the servant of a woman in Oostbruck, in the reed-swamp, was found with his feet dislocated, whom his wife had thrown down during Ascension; she, being taken in and examined by Judge J. Culemberg of Utrecht, confessed the matter without evasion. This and some similar occurrences seem to indicate that in rare cases, as a consequence of a specific lightness (a levity) occurring in demonic states, just as in ecstatic ones, such sorties may indeed take place. But the circumstance that such things have, on the whole, only rarely occurred among ecstatic persons; and still more, that there is not a single example on record in which a number of them ever assembled together in such a way, for instance to celebrate a communal act of worship; ought to have made contemporaries cautious and to have restrained their judgment: since it is by no means credible that the devil and his prestidigations should be allowed a wider scope than the Lord permits Himself to take. Thus the only generally admissible supposition remaining is that the excursion took place in the vision. Whoever has entered into the state of ecstasy finds himself transferred into a region more interior than that in which he was situated under natural conditions. In the latter case his spiritual inwardness is, throughout the extent of his bodily outwardness, present everywhere; and it accomplishes his will, with more or less freedom, throughout that whole sphere. \

In the other case another sphere, surrounding that outwardness, is drawn into his domain, and is as it were embodied and subjectivized; and he rules, within this circumference that has fallen to him, as he formerly ruled in his body; if not absolutely, yet with respect to certain powers. If therefore he directs his intention to a certain point which lies within the sphere that has thus newly grown for him, then he will be spiritually present at that place; and since for that he does not need to separate himself from the body in order to get to the spot, because the object rather comes to him, he will also feel this body as present just there, and in spiritual optics all around him everything will appear perfectly as if he had truly gone to the place in person. The body meanwhile remains fixed and petrified at its place; for it has, in its outward relations, become an object, like one among the others that surround the personality.

But with that very thing the awakening of the inner spirituality is purchased; and this now begins, upon the basis of personal and impersonal outwardness, the interplay of higher forces which govern space and are not governed by it. This, as we have seen before, has been the case in many ways in the higher ecstasy, where the spirit, torn away from itself, enters into the inwardness of the Lord. It will happen just the same in demonic ecstasy, where the spirit indeed has been pressed down beneath itself, but in the abyss of the same finds, though negative exponents, in an imitative reproduction of the ascending positives --- which rise one above another upwards, but downwards in the others are reflected not as in their image and likeness, but in the full opposite, the non-image and the un-likeness. In this distorted un-imageness everything that issues from the new relation --- thus being and present-being at a distance --- is now effected. In the higher ecstasy this being is not merely truth; rather, because it occurs in the root of all truth, it is root-truly true, from which all ordinary truth is first derived. Here, however, because it occurs in falsehood, it is in falsehood, but with the full semblance of truth; and because it clings to a concrete reality, it intrudes with all its evidential force. The personality thus altered, or rather depressed, will therefore fancy itself present at the place of its intention, and will be spiritually truly present.

If several such personalities, bound by the same rapport to a ruling centre, are also united in their intentions, for example directed toward the same locality, then they will likewise find themselves transported toward that place; and as the directions of their striving converge on the same point, they will assemble about it in a circle which people are accustomed to call the Sabbath, or also the Synagogue, and which they reach by the outing --- the act of putting oneself out of oneself and of transferring oneself thither. \

The critical days of the Sabbath are well known to the initiated; they therefore urge one another not to miss the gathering, and are also sometimes admonished by their spirits. In earlier times much is also said of the noise of the procession which, led by its queen, swept past the houses of the laggards and reminded them to join. They anoint themselves when they still require it, or when it pleases them so to do; but those who have attained greater practice need it in no way --- as many examples shown in the arrested, and many witness statements, attest. The ointment was rubbed on the naked body, sometimes also applied to the clothes, which nevertheless appeared no less clean and neat on the Sabbath. Maria d'--- of Handaye had testified against Mariacho de Moleres: when they wished to set out, she had anointed her hands, loins and knees with a thick, greenish water, and the witness then, seizing her, led her away. One sees that each must either have been in that same state of ecstasy, or the anointing itself must already have belonged to her. Occasionally already a very lively desire is sufficient to produce the rapture.

Catharina de Landalde, thirty years old, from the parish of Ustaritz, confessed that when she sat in the evening by the fire such a desire came upon her to go to the Sabbath that she had never felt so violent and irresistible a longing for anything as at that time. She then always went there on foot, without any sleep, dreams, or illusions having been produced in her, nor could any doubt arise in her about the reality of what she had seen. It is readily seen that in her a favourable disposition had been well formed by long practice; only an instantaneous, scarcely perceptible passage through the sleep-state was required, and she awoke inwardly with such clearness of what was seen that, as she with equal swiftness passed into the waking state, the memory of what had been seen, likewise without visible transition, attached itself to the circle of ideas of the new sphere. \

The going on foot, as it showed itself in her, is moreover the one and first type of outing. Maria de Ralde, twenty-eight years old, confessed that she sometimes, in the company of all her neighbours, went to the Sabbath on foot. They then advanced so swiftly as if they had flown, and in a moment arrived at the place. Each time, when she thus found herself united with her companions, she felt a marvellous contentment; for the devil binds the will of those who have been in the assembly only once or twice so firmly that no other desire or longing easily comes to equal it. Other accounts by such persons, who in this way went to the Sabbath or returned from it leading children by the hand, confirmed this information. They were conscious of all the circumstances of their going, which people they met, whom they called upon; and all together affirmed the full reality and corporality of the perceptions they had experienced. But this was not only the case in the Basque country, but elsewhere as well. The Lotharingian women of Pangra likewise asserted that they always went on foot; only when they came to a body of water did the spirit carry them across. If Satan was present there, he as a rule appears as the guide of the travelling witch-women. He summons them or has them summoned at the appointed hour; those who happen to be asleep are inwardly awakened, and then behold the leader in the form of a horse, ass, ox, pig, poodle or billy-goat, and sometimes of a bird, which takes them upon its back. At times even that is unnecessary; any object to which the vision can attach itself---a stick or broom, a spindle-distaff, a pitchfork, anointed or unanointed---already suffices. Sometimes they imagine themselves winged and skim over wide countries. Sometimes only the crown of the head is anointed; children taken by the armpits must sit in front and are carried in that way. Occasionally several of those bound in closer fellowship mount the same pack-beast, and it then proceeds with the cry: "Up on and nowhere!" into the air; most beloved is it in the smoke of the element which, among all, by its nature rises upward from their hearth; sometimes, however, it also goes from some crossroads to which they repair. If meanwhile rain falls, the cry among the Welsh---"Haut la coude Quillet!"---causes the beast with its tail to shield the carried ones from all wetting. The crowing of the night watch and the early morning messenger is exceedingly hateful to the riders; nothing can be more hostile and vexatious to them than his cry when it rings in the ears of those prepared for the ride. Likewise hostile to them are the ringing of bells, and the utterance of the name "Jesu" likewise breaks the charm. Yet the outing must by no means be regarded as effortless; for those led in it grow so weary as if they had traversed a long, rough road on foot; and Barbara Ragel often had to keep her bed for three days after such a journey, and could not stand on her feet.

#### B. The Sabbath as the Court of the Witchly Retinue

\

The Sabbath is as a rule held upon the mountain which is visible at the greatest distance round about in the district. There is appointed, there, a desolate heath without access, path or dwelling in the neighbourhood, preferably not far from a lake or running water, as the place of meeting. More spacious must these places be for the larger assemblies; in the Basque country the largest was on Mount Rhune and was called Aquelarre, the billy-goat slope. Closer assemblies are held in narrower and more secret places. Often they are open spaces near towns, by large buildings or churches, near the main gate, opposite the high altar when the church is built in the centre. Sometimes they are solitary churches and chapels, in the neighbourhood of which the meeting is held; sometimes even within them, as in the Blessed Spirit Chapel on the Rhune, or in the church of Dordach according to judicial testimony. Sometimes they are old masonry, the ruins of fallen castles scattered on the heights; remote churchyards, or otherwise conspicuous objects, as in the Basque country the so-called Portuguese Chapel at St. Jean de Luz, which serves as a beacon to the ships. A regular order is observed in the selection of all these places. The most private gatherings, at which only the nearest confederates are present, are held in the houses about their centre; often, as the investigation showed, to spite the courts, in the very buildings inhabited by the judges.

Those for whole parishes are celebrated in their vicinity, so that a single parish will often have several; and after the conclusion of one at a given place, the participants will often move on to another in order to begin a second, to which other participants then join themselves. Provincial assemblies for entire provinces are then gathered on prominent mountains, whence comrades assemble from the wide district. (1) The Master of the Chair insists that every comrade remain steadfast to his own fellowship. A girl who lived in St. Pée was, according to the testimony of fifteen witnesses, never seen at the Sabbath there; she had to move over to Sare, the place of her birth. (2)

At times it is some other object which attracts the general attention of an entire region, and then becomes the common point of attraction for the whole neighbourhood. Such is, from Lombard times, the famous walnut-tree of Benevento, around which the bona societas of Italy gathered for their games; and thus many old thunder-oaks will have become sabbath-oaks. One sees that any object, conspicuous enough that the intent of many can be directed toward it, is fit for this purpose; best when it belongs to the church, because the curse is wont to cling to the blessing. Therefore the whole arrangement of the infernal Sabbath is modelled on the ecclesiastical one. Just as the churchly order rises from the household meeting to the brotherhoods in chapels and oratories; just as the populace of a town and district collect into parishes, and these into deaneries, which again are gathered into a bishop's diocese: so is the anti-church society subdivided in the same sequence of stages, united in likewise increasingly prominent meeting-places.

Therefore the times on which these gatherings fall are appointed in the order of the ecclesiastical festival calendar; as the old Bacchic orgies probably submitted to the phases of the moon and their conjunction with the positions of the sun. As the Turks celebrate Friday, the Jews the Sabbath, the Christians the Sunday, so these above all have chosen Thursday; and the Sabbath then falls about midnight, from eleven o'clock until one or two, preferably on stormy nights. Sometimes, however, the night from Friday to Saturday is appointed. So in France; in Castile, according to the statements of those from Logroño, three days---Monday, Wednesday and Friday---are set aside for it. The smaller gatherings, however, are held on almost every night; on Sundays rarely, because it is believed that the sorcery loses its power on that day. Midnight is not, however, absolutely exclusive; the Spaniards already went at nine o'clock in the evening, stayed until midnight, and vanished at the first crowing of the cock. Catharina von Naguille even testified that she had been there at broad daylight, because after a night watch in the church she fell asleep at eleven in the morning. All these small festivities which they held in parishes at individual places they nevertheless call merely "merriments" (esbats), celebrated on the spot. But four times a year, at Easter and at the other great church festivals, the great procession to the Bockshaide is undertaken, in mockery of their service; which, according to the records, was already held in Labourd in the year 1567. (k) The most solemn of all nights, however, was that of St. John the Baptist, about the summer solstice; above all others a night of the greatest dissolution and licentiousness.

Blokula was the name of the place of the Sabbath among the Norse in Mohra and in Elfdale. It was a beautiful pasture; so large that no end of it could be seen. A spacious house had before it a smaller enclosed pasture, to which a large painted gate led; there they let the animals on which they had ridden walk. The human shapes that served for this, however, lay sleeping, leaning against the wall by the door. In a large room of this house stood a long table at which they took their meals. Adjoining this room was another chamber in which stood some finely dressed beds. One sees it is a Swedish country-house, as magnificent as the imagination of simple folk could conceive; elsewhere there is sometimes talk also of gardens and palaces. All those, then, who, directed by their inner intention, meet together in the same space --- just as they, in the exalted sense, behold the whole spatiality, with all its circumstances, rocks and waters and trees, and, on awakening from their rapture, are able to give exact account of all the circumstances --- so they also recognize one another, insofar as they stand in relation to one another. Therefore the reports about the frequency of the Sabbaths all agree in large numbers streaming together there. Even at the festivals of a lower order Katharina Kuffa, from Vellen on the Moselle, counted more than many assembled, and indeed far more women than men. At the larger gatherings it was once estimated --- on the heath of Hunderalse near Handaye --- that the number of those present exceeded 12,000. So many people streamed in from all quarters that one who had been there testified in court that so many had crowded together there as there are stars shining in the sky. Janua von Banno in Lorraine, however, said that, on account of the multitude of those present, it astonished mankind. \

One sees that demonic vision, as it plunges deeper into the abysses of things, embraces not only great masses of outward objects but also distinguishes them down to the most particular; it is therefore by no means necessarily unclear and confused. More women, however, are present than men; because more of the weaker, more mobile sex, disposed in degeneration toward sensuality and revengefulness, incline to these ways --- for the same reason why, in the Fall, woman fell first. A part of those present appear open and unveiled; others are wrapped in veils and to the rest indistinguishable; as some interpret this, to make the assembled mob believe that there were mighty and rich people in their midst. In truth, however, it is the same symbolic mode of expression that is found with those endowed with the second sight. Those who are only imperfectly in the bond, or who have entered it only with reservation, appear veiled; because the sense is closed to them. The same symbolism also appears in the frequent metamorphoses of form which prevail at the Sabbath. To the inner sense only the innermost in every thing stands and remains; the outward, as the accidental, is subject, in great mobility, to facile change.

Jeannette of Belloc, twenty-four years old, who had been present at the Sabbath since early youth, related: it is there like at a fair. Many walked about in human shapes; others were transformed into dogs, cats, asses, horses, pigs. Yet she added that she had never been able to learn the manner of this transformation, and had only seen all those animals running about there; they could also, at will, make themselves very small, and again as tall as houses.

Jeannette d'Abadie, however, testified how she had been present when this one and that one were transformed into a wolf, a dog, etc.; how they washed their hands in a water which they had kept in a pot with them. They would then at pleasure resume their former shape; and all this not only on the Sabbath, but on the way to it and everywhere. They thereupon vanished so that one saw only a shimmer of them. Both witnesses agreed: there is a constant coming and going; some flew up into the air; others still higher heavenward, while others settled lower down on the land. Some plunged into kindled fires like rockets or lightning; they also went in crowds to do this, and on return related how they had been in Newfoundland within the past two or three hours; how they had sat upon the mast of this or that ship, but could not step aboard because it had been blessed; instead, there they raised a storm in the rigging. They had seen all their own beyond, and which of their relations, who were notoriously in America, had been in their company.

One sees: it is a host encampment of mythical fowl, to which the power of metamorphosis has been given. The Sabbath likewise has its herds and its shepherdly order; those are formed by toads, while boys and young girls make the shepherds who tend them. In the Parsee doctrine they are the devouring kharfesters: snakes, scorpions, and toads, created by Ahriman, the principle of Evil. The shape, kind, and nature of these animals are so fashioned that the disgust with which they fill men appears to him as a warning of a treachery lurking within, which the first two are also completely justified in by the poison they brew. The toad, for its part, since it also seems to possess the entire apparatus for that purpose, has at all times kept suspicion awake against itself. \

Abbe Rousseau relates in the tenth section of his Remed Secretorum how he had kept one of these animals enclosed in a glass, with the intention of letting it die in its prison, as he had already done with some others. Once, after watching for a while the most strenuous efforts the toad made to get out, it suddenly turned upon him, rose up, swelling itself in an extraordinary way, lifted itself up on its legs to a great height; and then blew, without moving from its place, around itself. The enraged creature looked at him with eyes that, imperceptibly, seemed to become quite red and fiery, so that in that very moment a weakness came over him which made him swoon. A cold sweat ensued, and a flux set in, both of the bowels and of the urine; and his condition was such that his people thought him dead and lost.

The account proves, if not with certainty the physical harmfulness of the animal, at least the injurious effect produced by the deeply rooted belief in its poisonous nature. Thus it will be the most apt symbol in the northern countries to express the inward-closed, poison-swollen, treachery-breeding power of Evil and of witchcraft. Just as doves and other birds, lambs, hares, stags comported themselves tamely toward the saints, so the toad will in particular be the beast of the monsters. It will furnish a suitable ingredient in the poison-kitchen, and appear as the most fitting form into which the witch herself is metamorphosed, or in which the evil spirit hides itself. Therefore the toad has always played a large role in the witchcraft realm. Peter Grey of Toulouse already relates: an unhappy priest from the diocese of Soissons had asked a witch in what manner he might most effectually take revenge on his enemies, and she had advised him: to baptize a toad under the name of John, and then cause it to eat a consecrated host. After that he was to tear it apart, and might prepare from it a poison that would bring death to all his enemies; which indeed happened. The affair was discovered, and she was handed over to the flames. That took place in the year 1460. Therefore it is these creatures that form the flock of the Sabbath. There they are herded by children at a brook, to whom a white rod is given for the purpose. The animals are clothed in red or white velvet, have a small bell at the neck, and sometimes on the feet; and witnesses testified that they had seen the daughter of the Lady of Martibelsarena dancing at the Sabbath with four such animals; she carried one so clothed on her left shoulder, an unclothed one on the right, and two similar ones on her fists, like a huntsman his hawks. \

They dance before their masters on the Sabbath, and present their complaints when they have not been well kept. That is the idyll of the Sabbath; they are the little lambs of the local Pegnitz-shepherds. "I too have been in Arcadia," his initiates can attest; and naive innocence still maintains, in the midst of a debauched life, its right, lavishing all its tenderness on the most unlovely of all animals. But not only those bound together in the same principle recognize one another in the vision, and all that in nature belongs to their circle; they also peer into the realms of spirits, to whose powers they are attached, and the depths of those realms are opened to their exalted eye.

Yet this glance into its home is not granted to the evil eye alone; the good eye is likewise not denied sight of the regions where ruin has taken up its dwelling; and we shall do well, with it, first to inquire what it beholds of them and of their circles, before we allow the demonic apparitions to pass over us. Herbert, a contemporary of St. Bernard --- round whom a whole world of visions disclosed itself --- tells us something like this of a friend of his youth, the hermit Dominicus. He had formerly lived in the Cistercian monastery Carrezeda near León, and was then dismissed by the abbot into solitude, dwelling near that city in a mountain cave, practising the strictest continence; almost shut off from all intercourse with the world, devoting himself to contemplation; burning with love of God, and in a wonderful way endowed with the gift of tears.

Once he sat at the entrance of his cave, his gaze turned toward heaven, attentively following the light of a sunbeam to its source. Suddenly he perceived the shape of a burning dragon, which, descending in that very ray, in a violent plunge threw itself toward his face as if to devour it. Terrified by the apparition, he crouched inward; called on the Lord, and made the sign of the cross against the assailant. Driven off, it was yet able to do nothing against him, but it flew constantly about him and would not leave him. He then shut his eyes and covered his face with his garments; but that availed him nothing, for he saw the figure with closed eyelids as though with them open; and this penetrating, subtle being could not be repelled by clothing. When he saw, therefore, that he could not escape the sight, he opened his eyes again, and let them behold that whose attack he could not prevent. Then other demons likewise came to light in serpent form and other animal shapes, in hordes, and filled the dwelling from top to bottom.

Among them there was so great a diversity of dimensions, such variation in their properties, and such ugliness in their forms that it cannot be described, and many of them were fire-colored. They swarmed about him like bees, flared up like fire in a thorn-bush, dashing at him with angry movements and attacking him with blows. But although they appeared fiery, they by no means had the power to burn. For though they flew around him in a circle, and, sweeping past him at the swiftest speed, often struck his face, they did indeed press upon him in every way, but never harmed him with fire. When he then again went out somewhat before the door, to breathe somewhat from the oppression; there also appeared to him whole heaps of demons, in great swarms traversing the air, and filling everything from the earth to the heaven. These too were so manifoldly graded, so terrible through their extraordinary appearance, so gruesome through their ugliness: that human senses could not endure such a confluence of monsters, had not the power of Heaven assisted them. \

He shared with me at that time the observation: these impure spirits had not laid aside the spiritual forms in which they always appeared to him in the air before the sign of the cross; but rather those into which they had fantastically transformed themselves. From then on, until the day of writing it down, the man of God saw these visions daily while awake; both in daylight and in the nocturnal darkness, with closed eyes just as with open. But the terror and the distress which he had at first entirely vanished; so that in the end he made no more of them than if they were flies or other vermin. For the light-spirits also visited him, and filled him with their consolations; however, about their forms he never, out of discretion, spoke to me.

These perceptions found themselves confirmed by others, from a monk of Clairvaux, whom Herbert does not name, because he was still alive at the time; who however had spent 40 years there in all holiness, and among other gifts also had such a lively inner eye: that with it, at a dying fellow brother, he saw the soul going out like a smoke from the censer, which then, when it had fully risen, remained hovering for a time in a round-clumped little cloud, transparent and about the size of a bushel, four to five ells above the corpse; until the brothers who had hurried there completed the funeral rites.

This one now, as often as he looked up into the air with a sharper gaze, likewise beheld, with his bodily eyes, in broad daylight swarms of demons roaming everywhere; in such numbers that their count could not be estimated. They appeared in manifold forms; one of these misshapen ones however was predominant. According to their bodily outlines they seemed to be monstrous men, of giant stature, black as Moors, nimble as serpents, wild as lions. They had thick heads, misshapen bellies, and were besides crooked and hunchbacked, with long and thin necks; while arms and legs likewise stretched themselves beyond all measure in length. When they halted somewhere in the air, then he could distinctly distinguish their forms, limb by limb; but if they roamed about in it with agile movement, then he saw nothing of them but mere larval shadows and tangles of whirlwinds.

On bright days, when the sun in its full power shines through the airs, then he was accustomed to see these visions the best, and to distinguish them the most clearly. When however he once also spent deep into the night in prayer, suddenly the hairs of his body began, in night terror, to bristle; and he saw masses of these demons crowding through the doors, and filling the whole house; so that piled up everywhere, they struck at the one praying. He made use of the sign of the cross and the angelic salutation, and thereby drove all the boisterous guests out of his oratory. In the following night he heard them again striking violently against the wall; and when he looked up, he saw in the window One, winged like a griffin or ostrich, standing, threatening him with its assault, which he however drove away in the same manner.

These views of spiritually sensitive men are presented here, as one easily recognizes, with the same fidelity, simplicity, and the same color and physiognomy of truthfulness, as the reports of a naturalist who has perhaps sharpened his senses through an especially light-strong microscope; and now recounts to us his observations made on the winged infusoria of the air, which he has discovered. One does not see why one should grant belief only to his report alone, and not also make the others the object of closer investigation; since nothing stands in the way except the unusualness of the matter. \

Those now who have seen these appearances had their intention originally not directed toward them; it was much more turned away from them by them; they had with all the power of their will armed from Above opposed themselves to the approaching ones, and so they had had to seize flight before them. But the demonic ones have now sunk this their intention entirely into them; they are devoted to them with all their affects, and lure them toward themselves. Before these, therefore, they do not flee; they, winged as they are, carry off the ones sunk into them well themselves with them, lending them their own wings, to those nodal points on earth where the demonic entwines itself with the natural, and in the meshes of the great net the threads of the one cross through those of the other.

This out come in the spirit, it is the sally forth; the place to which it goes is the site of the Sabbath: that nodal point which the fleeing shadows circle, where the settling, permanent ones have already chosen their seat. To them the ones striving into this realm are led by those messengers, and admitted to the community of the settlers. Their companionship they will now likewise behold in the spirit; according to the measure of the type which appears implanted in human nature, and in whose forms it must grasp the ideas offering themselves; the good ones in beautiful, inner harmony, the fallen ones in distortion and in dissonance. Let us see what the judicial testimonies about these types report to us: varying, as is comprehensible, in the apprehension of them, according to the turbidity or clarity of the beholding.

Maria de Ralde, who since her tenth year had visited the Sabbath, but for five years had given up the abomination, testified: she had there seen the Satan for the first time in the form of a tree stump, without feet. He seemed to sit on a chair, with something that looked like a human face, but as if covered with darkness. From there downward she saw him more clearly, in the form of a man, either of red or black color. Usually it is a stone that stands in the middle of the place, on which the one whom they call the Lord or also the Master sits.

Beside that tree-like form, like an old cypress or oak struck by lightning, and dried up from the top downward, it is now especially the form of the goat that he loves to assume. But if he appears in human form, then he presents himself in the form of a tall, black man, red and flaming like a fire that bursts from the oven, whose forms appear only halfway; with a broken, inarticulate, but commanding, noisy and terrible voice; often done in such a way that it is hard to distinguish whether it is man, animal, or tree trunk. He sits in a chair, apparently gilded, but glowing; the queen of the Sabbath, whom he has taken for himself from the initiates, in all splendor and glory at his side. Everything around, persons and things, appears in a false nothing; all forms in the enormous, gigantic or dwarfed and shifted. Jeanette d'Abadie saw him with six, sometimes eight horns, a long tail, and a double face. Sometimes there are two of them present: a Grand Master Leonard, and a smaller one, whom the Basques called Master Jean Mullin, and whom the former, in his absence, substituted in his place. \

The prisoners from Logroño saw him sitting on a black chair, so terrible and abominable that it cannot be described. He had a crown of black horns, among which three were very large, like those of a goat, the others smaller; two at the neck, one on the forehead, which illuminated the entire Sabbath with a light stronger than that of the moon, weaker than sunlight. His hair was disheveled, his face is pale and distorted. He has round, large, wide-open eyes, glowing with it and terrible to behold; a goatee beard, the form of the neck and the rest of the body ill-shaped, half human, half goat; hands and feet shaped humanly; the fingers of the hands all of equal length, tapering to a point and clawed; the feet like goose feet, with a donkey's tail besides. On the Sabbath he appears under a kind of throne canopy, of poor cloth, but fitted out in strange forms. His voice is terrible, but without resonance; when he speaks, it is as if a mule were braying; his tone inarticulate, biting and hard to understand. He maintains, however, always great gravity and haughtiness, combined with the bearing of a melancholic person who is always bored.

One sees that our poets, who in recent times have greatly endeavored to depict for us the personality of the King of the nocturnal realms, have devised nothing more striking in form and bearing than these women from the common folk have beheld. There must well be a ground of truth underlying their visions on both sides, which they have only further elaborated; and which then again other youths strive to express as mimetically as possible in their bearing. Beside this Master, however, there are still many other demons of every order present in the lodge; and indeed, as one who belonged to the higher ones testified, more in number than humans. They undertake manifold tasks, set the tables, procure all necessities, consort with men and women as succubi and incubi, serve as cupbearers, assist at the sacrifice, transform themselves into animals, manage the musical exercises at the Sabbath, and as attendants are often assigned to the women in the form of toads. Many of the latter had closely observed these their spirits, and said of them: they had a dark, black face, deep eyes sparkling like flames; a wide, deep, always foul-smelling maw, exhaling like a sulfurous vapor; rough, hairy hands with sharp claws; feet with cloven hooves, and in their shape always without proportion, either too small or too large, and otherwise without all measure.

Aleria Belhora of Blamweiler saw them sometimes without a head, sometimes with only one foot. These spirits, although according to another account they know many languages, yet always speak in the vernacular; and from it are also taken the names which they bear: Misfortune, Torment, Featherbrush etc. in German; among the Romance speakers, however: maistre persil, Solybois, Verdelet, Sautebuisson. But their voice too has something artificially made about it; three witnesses compared it to a sound coming forth from a barrel or a broken pot, small, soft, lisping. They are at the beginning quite kind and pious, and accustom one well to the like. To Mallot his one advises: to abstain from gluttony, unchastity and every wrong; he should always keep God before his eyes, give alms, fast twice a week, and not forget his daily prayer.

These figures are true goiters, begotten by the spirit as incubus with these women. He has impregnated her inner sense, and the female nature has then surrendered the material for the development of the germ; and since evil and falsehood can only incorporate themselves in disharmony, disproportion, distortion of all relations; so these acephalous beings, monstrosities, elves and evil things have emerged, in the sharpest consequential justice of the visionary formative nature.

#### C. The Homage Paid to the Master and the Round Dance Around Him

\

If the Sabbath in the relation first described was a cookshop of the evil principle and the Venus mountain, whither the inflamed life pressed to enter as a guest with the food master, and to intoxicate itself in lust from his beaker; then the scene now passes over into the throne room of the imperial palace. The emperor, or his plenipotentiary, sits crowned on a golden seat, the chosen empress at his side; and the estates of the realm appear, to present their homage and to obtain investiture. But here the contradiction that lies in the whole relation steps forth most glaringly, and manifests itself in the sharpest irony. On the throne sits a goat or a goatish figure; for the inner essence will not and cannot hide itself. Just as the good fragrance in such an atmosphere yields place to the stench, so every beauty to ugliness. Where the immoderate holds sway, there can be no question of measured bearing, dignity and majesty; the opposite of all that is therefore demanded there by the circumstances. The homage will thus also be, in its forms, a sarcastic parody of all submission to the higher; nevertheless, it will express the surrender into the blindest servitude. The act of homage is fulfilled as the homage-payers kiss the posterior and anterior parts of the goat.

The face of man is held upright, his eye drinks in the light, his ear the sound-ether; while his mouth inhales the air, and in the exhaled air inscribes the thought in the word. Extremely characteristic is it that the goat-figure of the evil spirit is assigned a second face, turned downward; initiated into the night-realms of the depths; closely connected with all the excretory organs that open downward, and with all the paths through which life purifies itself in the refuse. On the middle of this face the kiss is pressed; and the kisser thereby pledges himself to eternal servitude under the absolutism of evil.

All who newly enter the circle---whether as children introduced into it by their mothers and relatives; whether already grown and led up for the first time by an earlier initiate---must begin by performing this homage. It repeats itself with all of them in every great celebration, which opens with this hand-kiss and only admits the most intimate to the kiss of the mouth. Every one who enters approaches the chair with fear and trembling, falls at the master's feet, and embraces his hips with humility; or all kneel before him with their backs turned to him, hands clasped together behind, and remain in this position until he bids them rise.

All who have performed the homage in such a manner have unanimously confessed: that once they have surrendered themselves to the devil, there is no more separation from him, and that their apostasy is punished with severe penalty; wherefore none of them ever dares to escape his tyranny. He indeed promises in all things the opposite of the Sermon on the Mount of the Savior: riches to the poor, joy to the sorrowful, power to the weak, beauty to the ugly, knowledge to the ignorant. But---and herein the falsehood of the matter steps forth most sharply---experience shows that there is nothing more wretched, more comfortless, more hateful, more ignorant, more tormented than those who have thus given themselves into his servitude. Never has one of them become more beautiful than she was before, or more insightful and lovable. \

The money that he gives is an ideal one; it has validity only in the inner world; it is not even paper money, only a fabricated golden shimmer, like a will-o'-the-wisp hovering around a rotting plant, a moss, a shard, which in the real world immediately fades and vanishes. Not always does it seem permitted to them, on the other hand, to close their spiritual balance in the same coin; for there are some among them appointed to collect the penalties; who, for common or personal advantage---as is evident from the records---also exact them with sober courage. The rich in general buy off their offenses with an ox or a sheep, which is then offered up in the form of a sacrifice. Thus Desiderius Foucant, at St. Deodat, annually during the dog days on Mount Hupella in the Vosges, offered something of the sort to his spirit, though it had to be black. The poor give young chickens; some also their hair, small birds, money made of leather; and if they have nothing at all, then perhaps a straw, or whatever else the spirit provides; it is then already enough if they only willingly submit themselves to the Fendallasten. If one refuses, then it is scolded and beaten, falls into weakness, its children die, and its livelihood fails.

It is a common complaint that the Master always seeks pretexts to punish them mercilessly for disobedience or other faults; so that no peace is ever to be found with him. One is beaten to the point of death because he appeared late or not at all at the assembly. Another is kept suspended over the Moselle for so long, and threatened with drowning, until he promises that he will bewitch and kill another. Others must atone with severe strokes because they have caused no harm; often so harshly that they can scarcely breathe; for the disciplinarian has iron hands. At times they are scratched, of which Rosa Gerardina showed the marks. Often they are struck with illness; one must ruin her own livestock because she spared others; indeed, a third must carry out the imposed task---since she cannot execute it on the neighbor---on her own ten-year-old daughter. For that is their law and their way; and if several have drawn his retribution upon themselves, then the lot decides between them. Everywhere, therefore, the harshest and most burdensome servitude; and in this realm of the imagination, as they now customarily call it, the ironclad consequence reigns with oppressive tyranny. Therefore a woman from Biarritz, in the Basque country, forty years old, let herself out in streams of tears before the judges concerning the Sabbath: those are to be deemed fortunate who have never seen the Sabbath, or wished to see it, and who have never beheld with their eyes the Lou Peccat, as she called the Devil in Gascon. \

He who binds himself to the Lord seeks to escape the dominion of fatality, whose tyranny has entered into him through sin, so that he may regain the freedom of the children of God. But he who holds to evil must stake the freedom that has still remained to him from that fall; and to the fatality that previously had only partially bound him in its chains, he will now entirely fall into serfdom. The realm of the Sabbath is therefore a realm of the most unlimited and absolute despotism, in a scope such as even the Orient does not know; more so even than the realm of Nimrod, the great hunter from the land of the Cushites. The well-ordered state seeks, through the power of the united good in men, to curb and master the evil that dwells in them; but this state, fashioned in the image and likeness of Hell, unites the evil in the bond of its center, in order thereby to bind and suppress the good; so that it is tolerated at most only as a means to lead to an evil end.

From a semblance of the freedom of the companions can therefore never be spoken in it; they must blindly surrender themselves to the perverse ruling will as tools; and this one, armed with them, rules and governs in this armament according to its pleasure. The despot on the throne is therefore the unconditional lord over the body and soul of his servants. Of both sexes, as evil is, the entire companionship of the Sabbath fills his harem, and he has set his favorites in it as kings and queens of the day; his chancellor with the staff watches over the order of the assembly; all the forces of the assembled are reined and bridled to him, and he directs them like the rider the horse that he has mounted. As now the heavenly bodies, one higher than the other, all however ultimately obey gravity; as the spirits of evil, opposite those of the good, stand ordered in their hierarchies; so it is also in the arrangement of the children of the night on their Mayfields.

The number nine rules in these hierarchies, and so it will also be the ruling one in these assemblies. Johannes de Vaulr von Stablo, questioned in his interrogations about how many lodges there were in the vicinity, named nine of them: Stablo, Hufalise, Trer, Tasgine, Cher, Malmedy, Salm, Valle; each had again designated various places where they might assemble; Stablo had four of them, among which Croeff on the Mosel belonged. All are subordinate to one another, like the hierarchies, from whose midst spirits preside over them; but the highest is the main lodge, and with it the council days are held, in the assembly of all superiors, and the resolved is then communicated to the others.

Just as this locally limited number of nine seems again to be a subordinate member of a higher number of nine, since de Vaulr also speaks of a further assembly at Utrecht, where he often went; so downward from the bodies of each individual assembly is again divided according to another number, which seems to be the number three. Three tables are accordingly at every Sabbath: at the first sit those who are called by de Vaulr *les brarsz hommes*, with their wives. They are the actual sorcerers and sorceresses, twelve in number, under the presidency of the directing spirit with two associates. At the second table find the initiates of the second order their place, who occupy themselves with maleficia; while at the third the novices assemble, who are occupied with the household of the Sabbath; and because they thereby come into frequent contact with children and the uninitiated, in order not to be betrayed, they go masked. \

All sit in the order of their initiation at the tables; only those meritorious for the purposes of the society are promoted to higher rank. In the same order they possess power to do evil, honor and are honored. In Spain it was more the number twelve that ruled there; Pampelona was the main lodge, Barrabon its superior. There the initiates came with their masters from twelve Sabbaths in the round together, and threw themselves down before the grand master; on the homeward journey the air was entirely filled with the flying ones.

In the same principle the times were also divided, according to the order of the abominations to be practiced in them. On Sundays, according to some accounts, the orgies of unnatural lusts were held; on Thursday and Saturday those of bestiality and sodomy; on Wednesday and Friday those of blasphemy and the works for the satisfaction of revenge; Monday and Tuesday the Sabbaths of ordinary lusts. In nature the dominion expresses itself in the movement that it effects in the subjugated through the forces at its disposal. Thus the power of the sun can be recognized, in which she moves the wandering stars around herself. Among men one can easily discern the field commander's order of power in the tactical movements of the army; and the ancient war dances have turned the seriousness of these evolutions into aesthetic play; and the commanding word, spread out into song and music, directs all movements therein, interpreting them and circumscribing them with the rhythm.

Just so has the natural drive, in the relation of the sexes, by multiplying and regulating the movements, brought forth the moriscos, the fandango, the sarabands, and similar dances. The evil drive in man, when it has found its master and surrendered itself to his service, is now also driven by him in certain lines of movements, which, when brought into the form of a dance, symbolically represent the alternating relation of dominance and submissiveness. In these dances the Lord of the Sabbath will be the ring leader; around him as the center all the whirlings will move, and because the circle appears as the line of the strictest subordination, therefore they will most gladly be turned into roundness; but the center will enclose the formula and the word of all these circlings within itself. But because evil has no harmony in itself, therefore there will also be only dissonance in the music of this word; the song and the shouting, and the instrumental clamor will, according to the accounts of eyewitnesses, sound so repugnant and confused. One blows on a stick, as on a transverse flute; another treats a dead horse's skull like a zither; yet another strikes with a club against the oak tree, so that it sounds like drums and army kettledrums. A blind man, sitting on a two-branched tree, lets a tambourine resound; castanets are again handled by others; violins cut through the noise with sharp tones, and the spirits mix in their hoarse, hollow voices like muffled trumpets: Everything calls, rustles, roars, and howls wildly together; and the desolate clamor sounds like the charivari of the Sybarites at Athenaeus, when each one, unconcerned about the other, sings his own song. And after all the displeasure that those present may perhaps feel, they must still thank the spirit for the splendid music; and whoever resists wins only blows from it. \

The dance is in its kind just as much the reverse of the usual dance order, precisely because it is meant to express a fundamentally inverted relation. In the center sits the master, if he does not himself join in, seriously on his chair, from time to time humming inarticulate tones. The companions then in the round, naked or also in their shirts, turning their backsides to him; each with her demon at her side, all grasping each other with hands laid on their backs, and now under the most obscene movements always turning to the left.

According to the statements of the initiates, there are three kinds of these dances. One in the manner of the gypsies, who are frequently found in the Labourd, the borderland of France and Spain. The second is in the manner of the peasants with jumps; but just like the previous one going in a circle. In the third the dancers are lined up in a straight line, but man and woman turned with their backs to each other; and now, as they move toward each other and away from each other, colliding together in a brutal manner in certain cadences. Sometimes, however, they are also positioned in such a way that alternately one faces outward, the other toward the center, and they now thus begin the round dance.

One sees that, through the turning of the back, the usual order of the dimensions is reversed; because what was below has become above, the rear side is also declared to be the front; and thus the left must also count as the side of honor. The commissaries in the Basque country attributed the backward-bent posture of the girls there to their frequent attendance at the Sabbath. But Prieras lets himself be heard thus concerning those in northern Italy: "Often boys and girls of 8--10--14 years convert there, upon the exhortations and persuasions of the inquisitors; who then, on account of the strangeness of the matter, are sometimes even bidden to perform the dances as they are customary at the Sabbath.

They carry it out, and prove that they possess a superhuman art therein. These dances differ from human ones in that the girl holds herself behind the man's back, and jumps not forward, but backward while going backward. At the end, when a bow is made to the presiding demon, they incline---always turning their backs to him---the head not forward, but backward; and they bend the foot likewise not backward, but forward, lifting it high. But all this is executed with such grace and charm that it cannot possibly be learned in a short time and at a young age. Whoever doubts these statements can easily convince himself by ocular proof in the region of Como or Brescia; even here in Rome through the testimony of Brother J. B. de Biqueria, prior of Briren, and others. It would be desirable that one of the venerable cardinals might have 10--12 of these boys and girls brought to Rome; to give the city this spectacle, and to draw the veil of unbelief from the eyes of many."

This demonic St. Vitus dance is now called the pavana among those in Belgium; and the earth where it has been danced is struck with the curse that it shall no longer grow green henceforth. In its course, songs are sung in crude melodies and obscene content; from time to time interrupted with exclamations, such as, for example, those from Logny cried: Har! Har! Devil! Devil! Jump here, jump there! Play there, play here! while meanwhile the others in the chorus called Sabbath! Sabbath! So that everything may show itself in proper contrast to the usual course of the world, the lame, the limping, the old cripples and the infirm must likewise be present, who then display themselves in the dance with the greatest ease and nimbleness. \

The question arises: whether such a round dance, formed in the spirit of a distant community and submitted to its modulation, might also be seen by one who possesses the second sight? The following case, which Remy recounts, appears to decide the question affirmatively. When Nicolaa Laghernhard from the Garminger Mill went to Assencauria in August 1590, and was walking along the edge of a forest at bright midday, she saw in the adjacent field a circle of dancing men and women who, however, turned their backs to her. When she looked more closely, she noticed among the dancers some interspersed whose feet appeared to her shaped like goat feet. Half-dead with fright, she called out the name of Jesus and prayed that she might return safely and unharmed to her home. In an instant, all the dancers vanished, with one exception: Peter Grospetter by name, who also quickly ascended into the air, but in the ascent let fall a baker's brush, with which bakers are accustomed to clean the oven before inserting the bread. She herself was likewise seized by a violent gust of wind, so that she could scarcely draw breath; and when she arrived home, she lay sick in bed for three days. The talk spread quickly among the people from her relatives; and Peter, so as not to give the appearance of confirming the truth of the story through his silence, lodged a vehement complaint about it with the judge---but then let it drop, in order not to expose himself through the trial to greater prolixities and dangers. This increased the suspicion against him, as it was attributed to a bad conscience. The judge therefore inquired all the more earnestly into the life he led and his morals; and since he found sufficient cause, he had him arrested and brought him to a confession that was not entirely unwilling, as well as to the naming of those who had been with him. Among these were Barbel, the wife of Johann the stonemason from Dusa, and Mazetta, the wife of Lorenz from the same place, who in February and March 1591 confirmed his statements about the Sabbath and the spirits rubbed into the dance. To their testimony was now added another confirmation. Michael, the herdsman from Dusa, testified: he had been present at the affair as a piper, in that he had placed a round shepherd's staff to his mouth and fingered it around as if on a pipe. But when that Nicolaa, trembling, had called out "Jesus!" and thereby signed herself with the cross, he had fallen down from the high branch of the oak on which he had been sitting, and then been seized by the whirlwind and carried to the meadow where he had just before been tending the herd. For further confirmation of these statements, the place where the round dance had been performed was found trampled, as in a riding school where the horses go; but interspersed were traces of goat and cattle feet. These remained visible even when, in the following autumn, the plot was plowed under. Testimony was given by Nickel Klein, Desiderius Verner, and Gaspar the tailor, who were questioned about it by the judge. \

The visiting of the Sabbath becomes, for those who have once taken a liking to it, like opium-eating in the Orient, a passion of which they can scarcely gain mastery. Johanna Dibasson, aged 25 years, said: the Sabbath is a true paradise, and there are more joys there than can be expressed. All who visit it find the time so short amid sheer lust and pleasure that they part from it only with regret and always feel a longing within themselves to return to it. Maria de la Ralde, a very beautiful woman who otherwise had not visited it for five years, likewise spoke of the yearning that had driven her there; so that, when she had been called to it, it had felt to her as if she were to go to a wedding.

It was not due to the freedom and licentiousness enjoyed there, as she herself stated that she had never seen whoring or fornication there; but because the spirit binds her heart and will in such a way that it allows scarcely any other desire. Furthermore, the companions held the Sabbath to be a place where a hundred thousand wondrous and unheard-of things can be seen, and so many various, melody-rich instruments can be heard, that they believe themselves enchanted as if in an earthly paradise. 1)

At court they often questioned her: what attraction the Sabbath could possibly hold for her, since even merely hearing of its abominations and its filth makes the skin shudder? But she replied without concealment: they hear and see all these abominations with a wondrous lust and a raving desire to be present at them; the interval from day to night, when they could set out on the journey, seems to her all too long; the hours until then creep by for them with unbearable slowness, but there, in the enjoyment of so many delights, they pass with all too swift haste. All the abominations, all the terrors and shadows pass by so lightning-like quickly, and vanish so suddenly, that no displeasure or pain finds time to master their soul or body. Thus nothing remains behind but the feeling of astonishment at so much that is new pressing in upon them, satisfying their curiosity, and satiating all their desires, whether of amorous or vengeful kind. These are truly joys beyond human nature, and not of Jewish origin! 7

### Chapter 3. Personal States of the Spiritual Man in the Lord and in Sorcery

If Satan on the first stage has been host and steward, on the second king and unconditional ruler; then on the third he stands as God, whom they worship, opposite the companions, and these will form his church around him. Doubt has initiated the apostasy, sensuality has served as motive for the will; thus he has given his assent, and the perverted faith, which has taken root in the spirit in place of doubt, now holds him fast in the chosen decision. Once the demonic church of the night has thus first formed itself, through the free self-determination of its members; then it maintains and increases itself in the same way as the church of light, through the reception of the offspring of those who have joined. The children who are born in the bond, as well as others whom the companions seize, are offered to their God; so that he may receive them into his religion through a kind of baptism. \
