A certain rite is required for this, and definite formulas in which the reception takes place; and the judicial statements have by no means left us in the dark about this either. Those from Castile reported the following on the matter: When the assembly is together on the Prado del Cabron, the goat meadow; then the women offer these children to the Master while kneeling, with the words: Great mighty Lord! whom I worship, I bring you this new servant, who wishes to be your slave forever! The Master from his chair, as a sign of thanks and satisfaction, replies: Come closer to me! They now obeying, slide forward on their knees to him, and offer him the child, which he then takes on his arm and gives back to the one offering it, thanks her, and simultaneously admonishes her: Take care to nurture his youth, because his kingdom will thereby be increased. --- The mothers hasten more to offer their children on the Sabbath of reception than in the house of God; the time seems otherwise to depend on them, and mostly the second or third year is chosen. Until the ninth, they now guard the host of the Sabbath, and are only permitted to behold its wonders from afar.

Since the forcibly abducted can only be admitted with their free consent, there are arrangements there to extort this from them; deep abysses, for example, as in the trials of the Freemasons, into which they make as if to throw them if they resist denying God. Moreover, the women are beaten and scourged if they bring no children; that they, for the sake of peace, fetch them from other villages and regions; so that some in Mohra brought 15--16 children with them every night to the Sabbath. The children from Eüfdal knew much to say: of a white angel who forbade them to carry out what the devil had assigned them to do, and said thereby: the mischief shall not be overlooked much longer. On account of the base, dissolute life of the people, the matter had been tolerated hitherto; but now everything must be revealed. This angel had sometimes also placed himself in the doorway, between the malefactors and the children; and when they had come not far from Blokula, he had taken the children back, but the women had then gone in.

The Castilians now continue: "If the children, after they have reached the ninth year, unfortunately, without being compelled thereto by force from one of the companions, have surrendered themselves to the devil; then they throw themselves down before him on the earth. He, with fire flashing from his eyes, says to them: What do you desire, do you wish to become one of mine? He answers: Yes! Thereupon the other: Do you come with your full resolve of will? Answer again: Yes! Then will and do what I will and do! Thereupon the Queen of the Sabbath, who leads up the neophyte, says to him: Then speak after me with a loud voice: 'I deny God first, then Jesus Christ, his Son, the Holy Ghost, the Virgin, the Saints, the holy Cross, the Chrism, the Baptism and the faith that I have hitherto held, my godparents, and I deliver myself up in all things to your power, and into your hands; I acknowledge no other God, so that you are my God, and I your servant.'?" \

The demon on his side now promised him: by the power of his oath he should inflame all girls and women whom he wished to possess with love, if the breath reached their nose. Ordinary heat of desire in this world, and still greater joy in that life.

This happens, however, only after they have renewed the vassal oath: to remain forever faithful to their new lord, never to return to Christianity, to attend the Sabbath regularly, to offer worship there, and to increase and extend the kingdom and the church by bringing in others. To the newly admitted ones there is then also given, probably as a mockery of the Christian baptism, a new one, in a special font filled with filth, under various ridiculous ceremonies. Instead of the old godfathers, new ones are assigned to them, who serve as sureties for the new faith. Instead of the old name, a new one is bestowed upon them, taken from the places where they were born, or from other accidental circumstances. Thus Cuno of Rohren on the Moselle was called Barbicapa in this rebaptism, others again differently. They vow at the same time: never to go to the Eucharist; or, if they do so, only with the intention of approaching the sacrament in order to misuse it. They promise: to dishonor and revile Mary and all the saints, by word and by deed; to trample and spit upon their relics; to abstain from the sign of the cross, and, where it may perchance be found molded in plastic form, to break and destroy it; likewise to avoid all sacramentals of the holy water, of the consecrated salt, the candles; never to confess their sins; to cover their relation to the demon and the secret of the Sabbath with silence; and to dedicate all their powers and possessions to their new lord, who is ever present to them, alone fulfills all their desires, and after death can make them blessed. \

After all the threads have thus been severed by which those who have departed from the Church of Light remained connected to it, they have now passed over into that of Night; they are initiated into its mysteries, and put into practice what its statutes command. The banquets were, on the first level, boisterous orgies for indulgence, in which the initiates debauched with their initiators. On the second level, they have taken shape as symposia, where the entire retinue, united in league around its duke, gathers at the common table. Now, on the third level, they become sacrificial meals, where their god breaks the bread for his worshippers, and offers the cup to the confederates after pronouncing the curse over it; so that, having partaken in this supper of his substance, and now appropriating it to themselves, they may be transubstantiated into the same, and no longer permitted to depart from him.

This is already announced in the outward form and posture of these banquets. According to Del Rio, the meal was always opened with the formula that served as the prayer before the table: *En nom de Belzebub nostre grand maistre, souverain Commandeur et seigneur, noz viandes, boire et manger soyent garnis et munis pour noz refections, plaisirs et voluptez!* whereupon all chorused: *Ainst soit il!* When the banquet was ended, it was said: *De nostre refection salutaire prinse et veceue nostre Commandeur seigneur ei maistre Belzebub soit loué, gracié et remercié a son exaltation et commun bien!* whereupon the chorus again responded: *Ainsi soit il!*

In the ancient love-feast, it was the wine, from the vine of mildly radiant sun, distilled into the blood of the earth asceticized through cultivation; thus purified in the process of vegetation, and cleansed once more of all its dregs in the process of fermentation, and now gentle, enspiriting, and uplifting, it was held as the symbolic bearer of the higher life-spirit, who bleeds out in death for the race. But in these unlovely gatherings, it is the drink that makes one drunken and raging; sprung from that vine planted in volcanic soil, and in the ash of earthly Solfatara; and, in Egyptian intimation, the heart-blood of the giants, which, when they fell in wild combat, flowed onto the earth, was absorbed; and now it is the fitting expression of the evil that sprouts forth in the sun's blaze, from the earth impregnated with wickedness. \

This is therefore the potion that the woman on the beast offers to the peoples in the cup; from which the princes drink, and in which the peoples intoxicate themselves. As they now, instead of the mild food of earlier times---milk and honey---choose for their nourishment the milk of the euphorbias, and the honey that drove the Romans, who found it in the Caucasus, to madness: so is their bread not taken from pure, healthy wheat; but from such as has been struck by ergot, smut, and rust, and which therefore holds death and destruction enclosed within itself. Poison and death and putrefaction are thus the signature of the substances in which the Eucharist of Satan is consummated; and which, now taken up into the inner circle of life, unite and bind it with that in whose remembrance they are celebrated. But union on this side is separation on the other; and the Eucharist of Hell, first consummated in the Fall of Man, binds itself to the profanation of that other Eucharist, celebrated in the fruits of the Tree of Life. Hence the blasphemous abominations performed with it on the Sabbaths. A woman confessed in 1457, amid many tears and sighs, in a public avowal before a great multitude of people: how she, for thirty years in succession, had each time secretly removed from her mouth the host received in the Easter communion, and then trampled it underfoot. The same had a priest done with the host consecrated by him; and when he was now led to the stake, he demanded that a cross be erected at the place where he had done it, and along the path by which he was conducted.

Those who have partaken in the sacrificial meal of the Baalim, and thus unified their own life with theirs, have thereby also made themselves fit for spiritual adultery with them; and the whoredom practiced with the demons on the Sabbath is also a service of that gods' festival there. The offering of blood and of seed has the ancient Moloch demanded from his worshippers; both in the literal sense of a service at once bloody and dissolute; or in the offering of their own limbs and of the children who have proceeded from them or also in the natural order. The children of the flesh, following on a wild course the powers to which they have given themselves as prey; torn and rent asunder incurably within themselves by the ungovernable spirits that drag the life fallen to them in opposing directions, decomposed and disintegrated; become, like these spirits themselves, torn and divided in lust and pain, in madness and exhaustion, and again in lustful greed and thirsting blood-lust, in frenzy and deadly rigidity.

Whatever, therefore, the most dissolute madness in lust can devise; whatever a burning sensuality may drive up from its depths; whither unbridled passions, staggering, can lose themselves in delusion; the irremediable doom before which Nature herself recoils: all this is performed and practiced there as service to the new god. The wanton dances are therefore now sacrificial dances; in them death draws near to life, that he may court it; in ever narrower circles they swing around each other, and as the circles interweave themselves into a net, joy enkindles itself ragingly in pain. As tigers and leopards are wont to love, so do the frenzied ones tear each other to pieces in grim lust, and only in blood can the flames be quenched. \

Of such a kind is the pavana of the lords' feast, which the gypsies of the middle ages may well have brought from the Orient. That is the proper and common service of the magic church; but since this is built up in the midst of Christianity, another takes place in it as well, introduced for the mockery and scorn of the latter. On the Sabbath, the Devil has in fact built his sacristy onto the church's cathedral; and in this an apish cult is celebrated, of which the witches say that it is more solemn and beautiful than the churchly one. Such depictions in Weber's legends---and never an esteemed one---stood a church, comparable to their village church. Other testimonies of such witnesses who elsewhere had attended the Sabbath mass confirmed: that they had seen there a masonry church, and an altar in it, upon which a demon, the size of a twelve-year-old child, during the whole ceremony held himself motionless, and after the ending of the same disappeared with all the rest.

During the service one heard a music of instruments, intermixed with the ringing of bells, which sounded altogether lovely; without, however, either bells or instruments being visible. If crosses appeared, then their arms were broken; but if the sign of the cross was made, then it happened with mocking words in three languages: In nomine Patrico, aragueaco; Petrica, agora, agora Valentia; Jouanda goure gaitz goustia! accompanied. Holy water was present in a hollow of the wall, at the entrance of the church; it was the urine of the master, and the whole congregation was sprinkled with it. A hierarchy is also established, and just as a queen of the Sabbath makes her appearance, so too a bishop, distinguished by a tiara upon which he walks about; while at solemn masses deacons and subdeacons also come forth. \

The service usually begins with a proper confession; but in it the penitents do not accuse themselves of their evil deeds, but rather of their good ones; and beg the master, who hears this their confession, for absolution on that account. He then, raising the left arm, absolves them, and imposes on them as penance something like eating meat on Fridays or Saturdays in the fast, or on the eves of feast days, or otherwise whatever pleases him. After the confession the demon clothes himself in priestly garments, and reads mass. Confiteor and Alleluia are omitted; the rest is murmured from a book that he holds in the left hand. At the Offertory he sits down, whereupon the attendees come with black candles to adore; and after they have tremblingly kissed his left hand, they offer to him bread, eggs, and the like, which offerings the queen, at his side, receives in a bowl with his image upon it. Those from Logroño knew only of an altar erected under a tree or rock.

Money is also sacrificed, preferably quartilles, because these have no cross; if they are quarters marked with one, then he steps aside for a time. After the adoration follows the sermon, either delivered by himself in the form of a goat, or by a sorcerer. In the first case, he usually speaks of how he is their true God; and that those who seek another cannot bring about their salvation. An exhortation to persecute the Christians concludes the address, which in the other case mostly urges them to do evil, to accuse the innocent, to help the guilty escape, and to offer many children to the demon. Thereupon the mass continues. The demon raises a black host, with his image, horns beneath the words: This is my body! and the congregation prostrates itself with the words: Aquerra goity, aquerra beity! Goat above, goat below! The same is repeated with the chalice, which he empties. Then the attendees surround the altar in the form of a half-moon; he delivers a second sermon to them, and then communicates them with a part of the host, and a sip of a foul-smelling and abominably tasting drink; which brings them outwardly into a sweat, while bitter cold makes all their nerves and the marrow in their bones stiffen and freeze.

It is not always the demon himself, however, who conducts this ceremony; sometimes ordained priests step in his place. For the ordination itself does not protect against the Sabbath, as shown in the investigations in Labourt and elsewhere. The first in the Basque country in whom the matter came to light was the pastor of Ascain, an old man who confessed himself: how twenty years before he had attended the assembly, had renounced his Creator, and instead of his ordination had accepted that of Satan; and how, although he had often wanted to rid himself of the abomination, the devil had so beset him on that account that he had nearly lost his senses, yet had brought it about: that in all that time he had neither confessed his sin in the confessional, nor admonished others about it from the confessional chair. He named persons whom he had seen at the Sabbath; while two witnesses declared how they too had seen him there; he repeated his confession three times in writing before the judges and his bishop, and stood by it in death. \

Now accusations against the pastors poured in from all sides, and two of the most vehemently accused, Peter Bocal, 27 years old, and Migalena, 61 years old, were brought to trial. It was found that the first belonged to a family called by sorcery. Seventeen witnesses testified against him: how they had seen him at the Sabbath; indeed, according to these statements, in the night before he had celebrated his first mass, he had already held this one there with great pomp, and the sacrifice at the Sabbath had been more abundant than it later turned out in the church. Asked why he had read earlier at the Sabbath than in the church, he had replied: it had been done for practice, so that he might thereafter perform his office all the better. Twenty-four witnesses had also testified similarly against Migalena. Both were degraded and executed.

Similar statements also lay against others. One from St. Jean de Luz accused the priest Jean Sonhardibels: how at the place Cohandja, in such a mass, at the elevation he had positioned himself so that, with his head downward but his feet upward, he had floated in the air in such a way that the hands in which he held the black host had risen as high as is customary for priests in the church, and in this position he had remained for the duration of a Credo. According to others, the host on such occasions was not round, but triangular; and the congregation was accustomed at the elevation, instead of the prayer, to call out: Black raven, black raven!

According to others, the priest had directed his face not toward the altar, but toward the congregation; and after the elevation, he threw the host to the ground and trampled it underfoot. One must, in all these statements, on the one hand admire the consistency in their perversity; on the other hand, one sees that if, in the church for sanctification, a communal bond and rapport exists among all the members intermingled, in which they have grown together, which in the mystical states comes to consciousness, a similar relation returns in the church of corruption. However, no judgment can be passed on the degree of guilt of those accused, and from the numerous statements against them, this cannot by any means be measured with full certainty. For these statements rested on the vision, which, in order to be possible, certainly required rapports in which the witnesses were connected with the accused. But these must have been occasioned by some guilt, which could in any case be considered proven only for the spiritual realm, in which the testimony of the witnesses also held validity.

All these notes are taken from judicial statements, mostly from people of the lower classes, where so much acts disturbingly and confusingly; it might therefore seem desirable if we had before us the memoir of some personality written down in a calmer situation, who had been in such circumstances and, recalling these things in her memory, would be in a position to sketch for us a faithful picture of the impressions she had experienced. This wish is fulfilled for us by that Magdalena Bavent, who played the leading role in the notorious history of the possessed nuns of Louviers. She had been seduced by her own temperament and the influence of bad priests who served as confessors at her convent; she had taken part in all the horrors of the debaucheries there, and when the consequences of them erupted in that affair; then all the possessed had testified against her as the instigator; the episcopal authority had conducted the investigation, but the Parliament of Rouen had taken the judgment in the matter to itself and pronounced a death sentence; Bavent, however, who faced the same fate, was still held once more in her prison. In this situation, she had come to repentance over her licentious life, and her confessor, the priest of the Oratory of the Marais, had induced her to compose a short history of it, in the form of final and testamentary confessions. She based it on the last confession she had made when she had to prepare herself for the impending death; her confessor assisted and guided the pen; and thus these memoirs of the forty-year-old woman arose. Calmly, as it seems, they are written with all the signs of serious repentance; concealing nothing of what might redound to her shame, rejecting only what seemed exaggerated to her in the accusations; and thus, with all the faithfulness and reliability that can be expected of a human being in such circumstances, sketching a picture of her aberrations. Regarding the closed Sabbath of her fellow members of the order, she now lets herself be heard there, p. 23 and following, as follows:

During my imprisonment in this city, I have, on the basis of my earlier statements, been approached by many people for more detailed information about the Sabbath. Now, since I have permission to speak about it, I will give all necessary information on the matter; so that everyone may recognize the gravity of my terrible crimes, and learn to abhor the scene of them. It is for me in this to recount with sincerity what I believe I have seen; the readers will, according to their best judgment in my report, distinguish what they hold to be real from what seems to them illusion. --- I was never carried off otherwise than at nighttime, and after I had slept. Usually before Matins, which with us took place at midnight, it seemed to me once, twice, sometimes in longer indefinite intervals, as if I were called by a nun. I started up from sleep to answer; and when, rising, I came to the door of my cell, I felt myself led away from there, without being able to distinguish how or by whom; for I had lost all consciousness, until I arrived at the accursed place. My rising, as my confessor later observed, provided the occasion for the abduction; I myself, however, did not think of it at the time. Ointment or anything else I never used, but it happened through the power of Picard; of my own self, even if the greatest desire drove me to present myself there, I would not have been able to do it.

After an absence of one, or one and a half, two, or three hours, I found myself again in my cell, and lay down to bed. The place where the Sabbath was held, whether inside or outside the cloister, is unknown to me; I did not perceive the details with sufficient clarity to be able to make a description of it; I would therefore be deceiving the world if I were to sketch a drawing of it. I remember only that the place was rather narrow than spacious; there were no seats there on which to settle, but it was lighted, because of the lights that stood like torches on the altar. The company that appeared there was not numerous; only priests and nuns did I see there, laypeople seldom; perhaps it was not their Sabbath. The evil spirits were frequently present, in half-human, half-animal form, sometimes alone in the former; Picard, in whose presence I always found myself there, pointed them out to me expressly each time. I never saw them, as the nuns were accustomed to recount, in the form of a goat; their place was always near the altar; yet I never perceived any worship rendered to them.

When I speak of the altar, it is because there really was such a one, where the priests said Mass; and the evil spirits stood so near the altar because it was said in their praise; I, however, perhaps saw no worship, though it was, as my confessor said, the highest of all. The host was like ours, yet it always seemed reddish to me and without figure; of this I can judge, because there too one communed. One also performed the elevation, and I heard terrible blasphemies uttered during it. The Mass was said with the paper of blasphemies, which one read aloud in it as the canon, as well as at all consecrations and processions, and which contained the most frightful curses against the most holy Trinity, the holy altar sacrament, the other sacraments, and the ceremonies of the Church, and which was written in a language unknown to me. \

A priest once brought a host to the Sabbath to burn it; but this time the Savior himself appeared and struck the priest with his lightnings, so that nothing more of him could be found; the host, however, shot up into the air. The demons fled, all was in consternation; but this established example by no means put an end to the assemblies. I saw another priest carry a chalice with the blood of the Lord to the Sabbath. He thrust a knife into it, which became entirely bloody. A second did likewise, and the substance likewise turned to blood; and when a third repeated the act, it overflowed from the overfull chalice onto the earth. The Lord, in the company of the Holy Virgin and several saints, came thereunto and commanded the fleeing demons to remain. The priests were turned to ashes and seen no more; but the blood was collected with the earth and carried away. If these things thus occurred in reality---over which I leave the judgment to others---so are they great abominations, and alongside them great miracles; and my conviction of the real presence of the Savior in the holy sacrament has, through all these events wherein earth and hell have united in their rage against him, only been strengthened. \

That is all that has remained in my memory with certainty from the Sabbath, after I have carefully searched my conscience and been questioned about it very often. One must not believe that more can be asked of me than I told my confessor, as he prepared me for death. The judgment over the reality of these things I leave to the discernment of others; but I beseech the justice, if it takes regard to my testimony, only to pay attention to what I can say with certainty. As works of mercy are considered: to refuse food, drink, and clothing to the poor, not to take in the stranger, to abandon the weak and the imprisoned, to dig up the buried children for the Sabbath, to sow errors and heresies, to multiply doubts and scruples, to burden the afflicted with even greater affliction, to make those who have fallen into sin fall even deeper, not to pray for the deceased, to bear adversities with impatience. Mortal sins are held there to be: to live in humility, chastity, patience, moderation, compassion, and piety. For all virtues count as vices: extravagance stands in for chastity, gluttony for moderation, envy for neighborly love, avarice for generosity, pride for humility, impatience for long-suffering, and so too blasphemy for fortitude. Litanies are likewise held there, and in them, for example: *Ut Ecclesiam Catholicam apostolicam Romanam, per haereses turbare et destruere digneris, te rogamus audi nos*; *ut Ordines ac Religiones difformare et extirpare digneris*. --- *Ut congregationes nostras conservare in sanitate ab omni malo digneris*. --- *Ut rabiem nostram contra Deum et homines et Sanctos, qui sunt et futuri sunt, semper fovere digneris*. --- *Ut nos in cordis nostri duritie perpetuo retinere digneris*. --- *Ut nobis auxilium dones, ad resistendum semper spiritui sancto et divinis eius inspirationibus et admonitionibus, et quicquid saluti nostrae deseruire posset*. --- *Te rogamus audi nos*.

One sees that much from this ritual is still today useful for the secret service of many a doctrine that has purified the Sabbath, after cleansing it of all superstition and the ridiculous abstractions of the Middle Ages, and setting it upon tangibility, now holds it in broad daylight on the open market. Also a sermon that Beelzebub held on Trinity Sunday would be very useful; if one were to seat at the throne, instead of the obsolete three demons of the speaker, Leviathan's, and Asmodeus's, who sat there at that time --- their faces like a man's face, body, feet, and hands of a devil's feet, each with horns on the head, a golden tiara like the high priest --- three God-men: the God-philosopher, in whom pantheism has incarnated itself; the God-pleasure-seeker, husband of the exalted Lady Sophia of the Saint-Simonists; and the God-emperor of this world, in whom absolute liberal tyranny has become flesh.

The three could then speak from one mouth with the orator: My friends, today the great day of the most holy Trinity shines forth in humanity. We three are one in essence, but in substance completely equal to one another; almighty, because the three kings of the world; all-knowing, precisely because we ourselves are the All. In a word, we are able to bring forth everything, and again to transform it into nothing. *Filioli mei, vestrum est omni conamine sanctissimam trinitatem coeli contemnere: vestrum est, contemnentes dicere: Draco crudelissime, serpens venenose, Cerbere triceps!* Rejoice, my sons, that you have brought forth from your midst a God, threefold in person but one in full union; who in the first has freed you from all your superstition in the being of a supernatural God and his entire court; who in the second has overwhelmed you with all delights and blessed you with the liberation of the flesh; who in the third has freed you from all the needs of free will, and directed you to your true Lord, fate. At the close, the choir then sings the hymn: *Cerbere triceps, Draco crudelissime!*

Those who have turned themselves toward the nocturnal side of nature have there found the star of the night; and by setting themselves in rapport with it through their abdominal cerebrum, which is itself a moon in the organic body, they have become moonstruck from the side of nature, and the moon, moving them in ebbs and flows, has drawn them up to itself, but in truth down beneath itself. In this direction of nature, which has made them moon-women if they belong to the other sex; or such as conduct themselves in the manner of women if they were men who have turned aside to this side; the realm of death is unveiled to them in clear sleep, that realm which hides itself in the midst of the realm of life and encompasses within itself all the lower roots of being; and they now behold the rising and descending of the elements in the alternating intercourse of both realms. In this natural relation of such moon-wives, the mythical has been added in antiquity; in those nocturnal domains they have found Hecate, the terrible night-goddess, who, as the moon has three forms, so has a threefold countenance. She has been to them the guardian of all night-births, the ruler in the angle named after her, that great cave on the moon's disk where the departed obtain punishment for their wickednesses. She was to them the wrathful one who drives the night-wanderer along his paths; she has unlocked for them the underworld of the departed, which adjoins that realm of death; and thus the moon-women of antiquity have become necromantic sorceresses when they have turned to the evil side. In Christendom, where all relations of nature are spiritualized, and in this spiritualization the opposition of the religious-ethical good and evil is purely and sharply driven forth, those sorceresses, passing through the domain of nature and the psychic, have turned even more decisively to the final side. By taking the demonic as their center, and nourishing themselves physically with the shadows of substances, but spiritually satisfying themselves with the empty semblances of ideas, and working all this into somnambulistic illusory movements; they have likewise had to transpose themselves, formally transubstantiating themselves into the object of their choice, out of truth into the lie of a semblance-existence; which, however, in the concrete reality of evil, has nonetheless attained its negative reality as a contradiction against the positive of the good. But he who in spirit and will and in life has chosen a new center, gains, by appropriating it to himself in all these powers, new modalities of the thus remodeled faculties; in life, spirit, and will, new circles form for him, altered rapports, other ranges of his activities; and with changing intentions and purposes, altered modes of effect in differently positioned spheres of effect. We have therefore previously considered the subjective transformations that he experiences who enters into the domain of the new center of gravity, and the new polarities and tensions around it; then it remains for us now to assume also these differently modified repercussions of our mode of consideration. How has one who has become at home in those circles found his way in them? What new atmospheres have his powers drawn around themselves? What domain, what range and scope of force have they gained? What elective affinities have thrust themselves forth around them? How have their directions been modified? In short, how has the subjectively overturned human now also transformed himself in all his objective modes of effect, and what power has he attained in them? This investigation too we shall conduct, following the facts at hand, in such a way that we descend gradually from the height we reached in the previous one down to the depths.

There are two invisible churches on earth: that of the Lord, to which all good belongs that this earth holds within itself; and that of his adversary, in which all evil is enclosed that has spread itself within it. All those in whom the good dwells in an eminent degree; all who, in his possession, enjoy a highly elevated inner life; all mystical saints, are beholding, active members of the first of these two churches; they stand in immediate intercourse with their invisible center, which reveals itself to them nearer or more distant. But others are connected to it only by the bond of faith; they do not behold, in the measure in which they have remained strangers to the inner life, into the inner of the mysteries---only their outer side becomes manifest to them; there they traffic only actively insofar as they are called by grace. Both, however---the esoteric as well as the exoteric---are embraced by one and the same visible outer church, in which that invisible inner one dwells, which now reveals itself to different ones in different ways; but all are regulated and led to the goal by the common, universally valid norm revealed for this purpose.

In analogous manner is it also arranged with the other invisible church, in which is found the center that unites and cherishes all evil. It is the night-covered abyss in which it is built; the subterranean hearth where the evil flames drive the evil waters above themselves to the surface; where the poison dragon lies at the roots of the world tree and gnaws them. Also in human nature open wells that reach into this abyss; but the other church, hostile to it, has closed and sealed them. Whoever now tears open these seals; whoever presses into an inner life, not to elevate himself in it and drink from the source of the good water, but to question the abyss for its secrets and to make its powers allies to himself: he will indeed become an active and beholding member of this other church; he sees the guiding center of this realm and feels its influences. He knows henceforth what to do in all his doing; the evil does not proceed from him as if by chance, but it is sought with consciousness; for it has substantially incorporated itself into him. He therefore acts also in the whole inner power and might of this evil; while those who stand outside enjoy only the help that its outer bond offers them.

Because, however, things down here are calculated on the outer life, on the sober state of waking, this invisible church of evil also has the inner drive to embody itself in an outer, visible one and, in it, to transplant itself into the midst of the waking world. The invisible inner center therefore seeks outer and visible centers for itself, on which it lays from its spirit, and in which it can therefore now regulate itself in the outer world. Such are now the representatives and the mandataries of the center; they act in its full power and its might, and immediately begins the process of appropriation and organization around them. But all organic organization on earth is carried out through instincts. Thus it has been natural instincts, life instincts, in which the household---the common ground of all other association---has shaped itself; political instincts for protection and defense and for shielding personal freedom, and spiritual instincts to bring forth the best well-order, have then founded the state thereon. From just such instincts, only directed to a higher world order, inasmuch as they, ascending, meet the downward-directed effect of the spirit from above, was the Christian church, in the midst of heathendom, to the astonishment of the world-wise, built up. \

#### A. The Mystagogues of the Enchantment-Being

If someone has attained the consecration of the spirit of midnight, and the seven-parted ray of the darkness dwelling within him has come over him, then he becomes its vicar; the nights stream together in him, so that in the midst of their gloom he becomes a blacker, night-enveloped point that engulfs the light, and binds to himself all spirits that enter into the current, and henceforth appears as their central point and their leader and their master. Of such a kind was that succession of degenerate priests in Norman Louviers, of whom we have already made mention earlier: David, Picard, Boulle, who, by handing down their mandate---the canon of blasphemies---from one to the other on the deathbed as a hereditary bequest, transmitted their consecration to one another, and thus formed a whole lineage of such mystagogues.

They were Ophites, after the manner of that ancient Gnostic school, who, abusing the inexperience of the girls shut up in that convent in the most wicked way, endeavored to gradually divert their zeal for advancing on the path of the inner life into their own ways. They spoke to them of contemplation, inner light, ecstasies, transformations, self-annihilations, and of the hidden life in the spirit; they ceaselessly urged them on to rise to that spirituality which would lead them to the choirs of angels, and finally even into God himself. Then they would be exalted above the law, living only in love, comforted by the anointing of the Holy Spirit, and free in the freedom of the Lord, and established in this freedom, they need no longer heed the stirrings of the passions in the deeper regions; but mortifying all shame and timidity, they would find themselves empowered to give free rein to sensuality; because a spirit most intimately united with God could never sin.

Thus combining the highest spiritual tension with the deepest profligacy, they must gradually gain the greatest power over the spirit of those who had been incautiously surrendered to them; all the more so, since the seclusion and solitude of the conventual life at once furthered and concealed the designs of the seducers. This spiritual dominion soon manifested itself physically as well. One of the nuns testified later against Picard: that when he once unexpectedly touched her on the side with the tip of his finger, she immediately felt a violent pain at that spot, which thereafter persisted constantly, and intensified every time relics were brought near the place; moreover, since that moment a violent agitation had seized her whenever she went to communion or beheld the magician. \

Magdalena Bavent testified against him: how she had seen in his hands a register, consisting of three closely written sheets, into which he had inscribed the names of those whom he boasted of ruling, or who had assisted him helpfully in his misdeeds. All these had their intention directed toward him; he formed the center in which all these directions met, and mediated their connection with the root-like Evil. Just as in the Savior the highest ground, the supernatural moment, is present, while in the spiritually heightened nature of the Saints the natural element of all visions of the heights prevails; so likewise in the root-like Evil does the higher---or rather deeper---ground of all demonic visions lie, the Sabbath included; and in the central nature of such magical mystagogues, more closely bound up with it, the natural vinculum prevails, in which everything connects itself into a whole.

If now the outer waking life, in all earthly relations, has its logical categories, in which it comprehends all natural effects; then the inner life, whether in light-sleep or in dark-sleep, likewise has its own, in which it comprehends the inner impressions. The color and application of these categories, belonging to the subjective human being, will change with his nature and mood; while that other overarching moment, essentially always the same, takes the fleeting change in the visions---arising from subjectivity---and always directs it enduringly toward the same point, thereby fixing it. Thus will it also be arranged around the Sabbath. In its innermost essence built up around the core of Evil, it is among the peasants predominantly grasped in the character of the Venusberg and a raw debauchery; in the midst of a warlike knighthood it would have assumed the form of a wild hunt and a hellish Valhalla. Here around Picard, and with his retinue, under the enclosure of cloistered nuns, it has---as we have seen---taken the form of an abyssal monastery, in which every sort of blasphemy and desecration of the Holy is practiced. What in the novitiate partly occurred in reality has, in the vision, only been heightened. Especially with Bavent was the degenerate priest closely bound, and one sees clearly that both had concluded a demonic marriage with each other, and that the Sabbath was the foundation on which they built their house. Therefore it is he who, in his patriarchal power, always abducts her to the Sabbath according to his intention; she finds herself there, always inseparably at his side, just as others hold to others---the same persons always meet there together. But she beholds everything always in and through her leader. \

The Logos in the human being, when in the saints it binds itself more closely to the Logos in God, and in greater proximity to the light also greens forth in its own heightened vegetation and ramifies; has there---as we have noticed---formed its own mystical language. The same Logos, when in the underground shafts, in the proximity of the shadowing principle, torn asunder and cleft in sickly drive-force, will likewise acquire its own idiom. That we see returning here also in the relation of this marriage, concluded under a curse; an own language has formed among the companions, and this has formed its own secret script, which only the initiates understood how to read. The nuns said of her: she had given birth four times on the Sabbath; a testimony that she does not accept, probably because she did not grasp that it happened in the spirit. This marriage was concluded, moreover, for life and death; indeed, beyond death, she would have roused the audacity for it within herself. "In the night of the day on which Picard died," she herself recounts to us, "I was abducted to the barn of Mesnil-Jourdain, five quarter-hours from the monastery, to his corpse. He was at the edge of a grave, and the vicar Boulle raised him somewhat by the shoulders; many demons were gathered around the body."

He urged me thus: it was now time to fulfill my promise to share the same fate with him. I was ordered to seize him by the feet, which I found very cold. I was told to descend three steps into the pit toward him; but when I saw frightful flames therein, I quickly climbed back out, declaring that I had never promised to be damned with him, and that now, having come to my senses, I must take thought for my own salvation; whereupon I was led back to my cell. Twice more I was later brought to him, saw his corpse, and beside it a frightful beast.\" She had already earlier shared in the sufferings of the dying man, which appeared to her quite naturally in the form of demonic temptations; after the hour of death had passed, there came the admonitions to restore the rapport, beyond life, through the conclusion of a marriage. But now, frightened by the flames, she breaks loose from the bond, rends the tie asunder, and the Sabbath is henceforth sunk from her sight. What we have here shown by the example of Picard and of Bavent can likewise be traced into others; although, to our knowledge, in no second case do recorded reminiscences of one of the parties involved permit us deeper insights into the nature of the contracted relation. The Provençal Louis Goffredy of Beauvezer had, by his own confession, among other things received from his uncle a book on magic, which at first he had not esteemed, but whose spells he one day attempted. \

Then the invoked spirit appeared to him, talked him out of his scruples against a pact, and concluded such a one on the condition that, in return for the threefold surrender of his soul, his body, and all his actions, he would render him threefold service: to make him the most honored of all priests in Provence; to grant him 34 years of life without illness or other affliction; and to inflame in his name all women whom he breathed upon with love for him. He now goes to Marseille and obtains there, at the church of the Accoules, a benefice. The wife of the innkeeper Perrin was brought so far that a palpitating heart announced to her his approach from afar each time; another, named Bouchette, and a third, named Pintade, likewise became, one after another, victims of his lusts. But preeminently the three daughters of a nobleman, Mandals de la Pallus, and among them especially the then ten-year-old Magdalena, had aroused this lust of his, because his reputation had granted him free access to the house. Since the girl had taken him as her confessor, he had already in this relation allowed himself many liberties with her, and a deep melancholy had developed in her from such intercourse. She often lived on an estate near the city, and he too went there back and forth. He had previously told her: for her sake he had called upon all the demonic powers to his aid; and since he had now won everything in her, he wished to unite her in the bonds of marriage with the prince of the demons, so that she might find herself united with him and one another in him, with all the greater security, indissolubly. This was now concluded and carried out in this assembly. She was baptized with sulfur, salt, and urine; she now renounced, from her whole heart, from all her powers, and from her entire soul, her God and her faith, and signed the renunciation with the blood from the little finger of her right hand, which he had incised. Six or seven written vows followed this first one, to draw the already tied knot even tighter. She was then marked on her head, on her heart, and on various other places; and now all those present danced around her jubilantly, and in general acclamation they proclaimed the newly received one as the princess of the Sabbath; which she from then on regularly attended in this capacity. Goffredy himself had already belonged to it since his pact; they had appointed him there as prince of the synagogues of France, Spain, England, Teutschland, Turkey, thus of Europe and a part of Asia; and as such he had visited the Sabbaths of all these countries and presided over them.

Her master thereupon gave her the demon Asmodeus as her attendant, so that he might serve her, guard her for him, and preserve and increase in her the love for him. Things had thus proceeded for a time when the bizarre thought came to her: to enter the convent of the holy Ursula, which flourished under the care of the priests of the Christian Doctrine. Goffredy opposed this plan with the utmost vigor; but since he could not become master over it, he threatened to unleash the powers of hell against the convent. She remained three years with the Ursulines in considerable calm, only that on Wednesdays and Fridays, the critical days when the Sabbath was held, a black melancholy would take possession of her, which made her unbearable to herself and to all the world. She is now, after her reception, possessed by five demons, and beside her Louise Cappel by three; and the otherwise so peaceful convent becomes full of the noise and contortions of the possessed, so that terror and horror seize the superiors.

Here too it is visibly apparent: that a somnambulistic predisposition lay at the foundation, which a bad priest had turned toward the demonic, and finally heightened to possession. The means he first employed was the breath, that aura in which so many natural connections are forged; in the ecclesiastical so often the conductor of the spirit from above and of his gifts, therefore also in the anti-ecclesiastical of the spirit from below and of his curse. The melancholy in early youth marks the first stage of the evil. This is heightened with persistently maintained sensuality, until the demonic witches' sleep with the entire scenery of the Sabbath has developed itself, and the second stage is now fully formed. Now the incipient partial possession emerges, and with it the third stage, where Asmodeus has taken possession of those organs to which the actions of sensuality are also directed. Finally the fourth stage has begun, when, in an impulse of return, those earlier melancholic attacks, still chained to the Sabbath time, have likewise returned, and now at last the full fivefold possession with all its manifestations sets in. \

#### B. The Spiritual Magic Means in the Misuse of the Sacraments and Sacramentals

If now such a hierophant has been found for the formation of a branch of the underworld Church, and has begun the work of appropriation around him; then this work will be powerfully advanced if such binding means stand at his disposal: those which on the one hand permanently bind to him all who already stand in community with him; on the other hand, working outward, help to draw others across into the same through sensuality, terror, fear, despair. Such binding means are now the maleficia of a twofold kind: such as aim merely at temptation, and others that bind more closely in possession. We have already found the like in the earliest times among the demonic sects; and tradition has known how to report to us concerning the irresistibility of their effects, once the assent of the will has joined in. Through the more recent times the evil has propagated itself, and the magic books are full of praise for their efficacy.

Like the sacraments of the Church, a material enters into their composition, mostly of obscene kind and bordering on putrefaction and decay. As form, the holy then unites itself with that which thus in abhorrence outrages nature; and thus one of the sacramentals in the lower degrees, higher up a sacrament, in the deepest sense the Eucharist; and the gray or black powder that has now arisen is sprinkled about, or taken in food, and now does its never-failing work. As alkahest and actual spiritual death-tincture, there prevails in this realm that olla podrida which, according to the account of Ma ria of Sains, Goffredy first brewed. It consisted of consecrated hosts, specially desecrated beforehand, of the blood consecrated by him on the Sabbath, mixed with bones from the goat, the powder of skulls of murdered children, the seed of the men and women present, blood, hairs, nails, and all uncleanness.

Three times had the demons held council over the new invention, the inventor and his confidants had pronounced the words of consecration over it, and they had then sent it to the prince of the demons, and he had imparted to it the effective power, infallibly to bring forth possession. The Sabbath brought him in thanks there for many boy-sacrifices; but the inventor of the new poison-means was on that account elevated to the highest principality over the magic realms. We let the truth or falsehood of these specific statements rest here for themselves, and investigate here only what truth there is in the whole matter. The sacraments and sacramentals are in their inmost essence withdrawn from the natural region of things, and belong to a higher order of the same. Their effect is therefore also, in the ordinary course of things, directed toward this order of salvation, and spreads itself only exceptionally down to the lower natural orders, since these by no means entirely close themselves to them. \

For there is also a natural side to them, in which their higher being dwells; and they are now received into the double order of man, affecting the higher order preferentially through their essential nature, but in the deeper order finding the paths of transition mediated through their matter; only that in the current circumstances of life this their influence hides itself behind the plasticity of the envelope. But if this envelope has become more easily penetrable in the saints, and more opened in transparency and permeability; then also this their action will become perceptible in the more mobile medium, and we have seen in the second volume of this book many examples of that hagioscopic susceptibility for such influences.

Sister Margaretha of the Holy Sacrament was thus, in her twelfth year, overtaken by violent convulsions, followed by a twelve-day state of half-sleep. Then a frightful condition came over her, from which only the laying on of a scapular freed her. Soon there followed such a heaviness in all her limbs that she could no longer hold herself on her feet, and, lying on the bed, could not move any of her leaden-heavy limbs; so that for seven to eight days she could scarcely take any food to herself. Then again, since all the doctors' remedies proved ineffective, violent convulsions followed. In this state one heard her call out with the accent of an enraptured soul: Let me regain my strength before the most holy Sacrament! The sisters resolved, upon her repeated cry, to carry the sick one into the choir; but when they tried to take the suppliant into their arms, none was able to lift her alone; only the strongest among them could at last, with unspeakable effort, bring her to the place. As soon as she had arrived at the door of the choir, there came, like a shining cloud from the tabernacle, which enveloped her and drove out the spirits. The cloud not only restored strength to her body, but made it so agile that she was sometimes carried from the choir door, at other times even from the cloister gate, as far as the altar railing. A wonderful peace descended upon her, and she, who through her illness had also lost the use of her sight, yet saw the object of her longing when it was exposed.

Once the efficacy of the remedy was known, they brought her from time to time into the choir and let her remain there for 3--4 hours; when she then returned to the sickroom, all her sufferings immediately returned. The doctors attributed her ills to a congestion of evil humors in the brain, and applied cupping to her head against it; she endured everything with the greatest resignation, although she well recognized the uselessness of the procedure. They then wanted to provide an outlet for the fluids between the skull and the brain membrane through trepanation. It was done, but no fluid nor vapor could be seen: everything was perfectly sound and healthy. This determined the superior, a wise and virtuous woman, to make a trial with obedience. In the convent was preserved the little cloak of the saintly Cardinal de Bérulle; this she laid upon her with the words: My sister, be healthy out of obedience to our most revered father! Immediately her convulsions ceased, which upon its return happened several times with the same success. At last the superior spoke the words: Be completely healthy in obedience, without convulsions, ravings, and blindness, and eat unhindered like the others. Immediately she was freed from all her ills, and henceforth ate without discomfort, as the doctors attested with official certificates. \

Thus, the sacraments, on the good side, in properly attuned dispositions, produce such physical changes; then, toward the left side as well, this influence will not fail, provided that in the organs there exists that easily movable mobility. Such a mobility-attuned excitability is never lacking here, where the true virtuosity is at hand; only is it arranged, according to its kind, for infernal stimuli. Such a nature will now, as we have already seen in many examples, spasmodically close itself entirely to the higher, sacramental stimulus, and reject it as hostile. If it is therefore to enter into her, something homogeneous to the repelling element must mediate the transition, and that can be nothing other than the profaning, blaspheming element, which, by veiling the inner indestructible form, now becomes a means of appropriation between opposing natures. The same personal guilt that enwraps the dominated will in the malicious one has now also embraced the sacrament with its abomination; and as it reaches over with this congenial atmosphere into the circle of life, its direct direction is turned into the perverted one prevailing there; and with the same energy with which it otherwise acts elevatingly, we now see it exert a depressing effect, one physically perceptible as well.

Thus the efficacy of this kind of magical means is understood, which, deflecting from healthy life, by no means lead it over into the morbid state; but upon that already inwardly diseased, they exert their full influence, and in the case of a certain attunement, draw it deeper and deeper down into confusion. In all reports on sorcery, frequent mention is made of these means; the belief in their power is rooted most deeply in this entire domain, just as much as the belief in the power of medicines in the natural domain; and there must have lain in this conviction a truth, but one of a magical nature, to be sure. The entire practice rested on the principle of the Manicheans: below in the depths is the dwelling of the Prince of Night, who, surrounded there by his people at the borders of darkness, ceaselessly labors to capture away the rays of the uncreated light, and to lay the words of God in fetters. The simple consequence was now that for these emanations of the divinity, which had fallen into the captivity of the powers of darkness, a food and a drink for preservation and strengthening had to be prepared; and that was that magical repast, prepared from the sacraments and sacramentals; just as those rays of light are captured into the material night, so into the horror and the abhorrence and the putrefaction, the frothing of sin.

Very instructive and significant is what occurred in the convent of Louviers regarding such things. As a result of the errors and confusions there, many nuns had become possessed; they were exorcised, and from the statements of their spirits it emerged that Picard had applied six different kinds of magic within the convent. One was composed to keep the nuns in constant discord; another, to awaken in their hearts a disordered inclination toward Picard and la Bavent; the third, to shake their chastity; the fourth, to awaken in them an inner aversion to faith, hope, and love, and to provoke blasphemies against God in them; the fifth, to arouse in them a desire for the Sabbath and all magic; the sixth, to produce in them a contempt and abhorrence toward all sacraments. They now continued the exorcisms to compel them to indicate the places where they were hidden, and to bring them to light. \

In all these things deception lay very near, and it is obvious that all these results are utterly worthless, if one did not employ all prudence to exclude the possibility of fraud. Let us see how it was handled in this regard. The next suspicion that had to arise was naturally: that the possessed, who descended into the pit to bring the hidden thing to light, had themselves carried it down with them. The appeal to their simplicity, education, and conscientiousness could here give no sure guarantee; because all that became invalid in the paroxysm. Therefore, before they descended into the pit, for greater security, they were most strictly searched by other sensible, prudent nuns of good judgment, and moreover unmolested by the spirits. With them other thoughtful persons, clerics and doctors, descended into the trench, who kept them sharply under watch, and never permitted them to come near the place where the amulets were hidden. One was accustomed to give the searchers a pole with a hook into their hand; and all had to remain at a distance from the spot as far as the pole reached, and to bring the magic to light from there with the point of the hook.

More than that, the edge of the trench was lined with other people who paid very close attention to the hands and all the movements of the possessed woman, and who would not easily have missed any practiced deception. It was advantageous that the time of discovery always fell at night; for now many torches were lit, which, properly distributed, mutually dispelled all shadows on the walls of the pit; so that everything stood in full light, which would not have been achievable by day. The Bishop of Embrun, who was present everywhere, moreover had the Most Blessed Sacrament held over the heads of the exorcised possessed woman in the pit at the decisive moment; in order to strike down any deceit also through the terrors of sacrilege. Despite all this caution, the result was always the same: the possessed woman dug up the earth at the indicated spot with her lance; the paper in which the charm was wrapped then became visible in its whiteness through a kind of glow; but it immediately clouded when touched by the air, and became dirty, moldy, and unsightly. But the possessed woman, in the instant when she perceived the hidden thing, was cast backward as if struck by a thunderbolt, uttered a terrible scream, and the spirits howled and roared out of her like wolves and tigers. \

Since all these precautionary measures that had been taken still did not fully dispel every doubt, as long as the nuns descended into the pit; the method of procedure was also changed in this respect when searching for the last three talismans. The one buried under the choir door was exhumed on 15 December 1645, and two others in the Loreto chapel on 3 January; so that the possessed woman, kept far from the edge of the trench, indicated the spot from outside with a 15-foot-long pole, where the buried item was then found, without the finder ever approaching it. The last one was likewise indicated by the possessed woman from outside the trench, with her face turned away; as she thrust the pole into the earth at one spot, and then ordered them to dig further. From time to time she then called out: One moment more! At last she made a violent thrust, always with her face turned away; and immediately the little package came to light, two finger-breadths from the tip of her pole. Skepticism now had to yield to the evidence of the facts, and the commissioners, sent on behalf of the queen and the council of state, with the Archbishop of Toulouse at their head, issued an authentic testimony as to with what caution and deliberation the proceedings had been conducted in their presence; how they had placed the searching nun between them, and how the paper, white and intact at the first finding, had become moldy, dissolved, and dirty under their eyes.

And yet, despite all this praiseworthy caution, deceptions may have slipped in among them; not exactly such as were consciously devised and carried out by the girls, but begun in the paroxysm under the impulsion of the power possessing them, and completed with the skill that then entered in. The voices called out from the possessed women several times during the whole search: I will play a trick on you! I assure you, you are being fooled! In the case of one who had thus called out, the outcome seemed indeed to confirm the warning. She had indicated a spot with her 12-foot rod; they searched and could find nothing. They therefore emptied a portion of the earth at the bishop's feet to examine it; the bishop held the hands of the possessed woman in his own. She claimed that the sought-after item was in this earth, and threw herself upon it; now, after she had searched for some time, some of those present saw the charm under the little fingers of her hands, and thought that she had rather trickily carried it into the pile.

One sees truth and lies border in these realms so closely upon one another that they falsify and mingle with each other mutually, and a hair-sharp separation of the two becomes nearly impossible. What, however, emerges in all these attempts is a result that, given all that has gone before, can by no means surprise us. As natural stimulants pass unnoticed over life tuned to the middle average temperature, but touch the more tender resonating part most strongly; so too will it be arranged in like manner with the stimulants of a higher kind, and their relation to the higher spirituality. As the rhabdomancer thus feels out the metals and salts in the bosom of the earth; so too does the possessed one harbor the same excitability for the magic stimulants to which precisely his condition appears tied; and this will make all the narrated events fully explainable to us.

The curse that rests upon the head of the favored ones in the nocturnal regions acts like the rigid, staring gaze of the serpent upon the mobile nature of the birds; fettering, bewitching, banishing, and then drawing into itself. It thus forms a whirl around itself, and whoever falls into this whirlpool is driven about and swallowed down like the ship in the maw of the sea; whereby those artificial magic stimulants act subsidiarily, like magnets, to strengthen and heighten the pull. The consequence of being bound in this magic circle is now the state of obsession, in which the tightly held grasp of the relations binds all the entangled ones into a real community of fellowship. This state usually leads in gradually through a whole series of visions, apparitions, and ghostly occurrences, in many intermediate stages; which, increasing gradually, finally bring about the height of the enchantment. This gradual increase was quite strikingly noticeable in the convent of Louviers. It began with the Sister Barbe de St. Michael beholding, several times at night, in her cell a great number of lights kindled, and soon she herself could not take three steps without her knee being violently struck against the ground, until at last she fell to the earth.

When she and some others, who afterward came into the same state with her, went to Communion; then they saw the grating toward the church illuminated with torches, but pursued by all sorts of phantoms, which, after frightening them greatly, flew off through the chimney. At the same time one saw bowls and pots falling in the kitchen without anyone touching them. To Sister Maria de St. Nicolas came a phantom in the form of Picard, at about the time of sunrise, sat upon her bed, and spoke to her; while at another time, amid great noise, all sorts of utensils were overturned around her. Upon the Sister of St. Laurent it came from the heel, and made her fall often; but soon it climbed up to the head, so that henceforth severe headache alternated with the ailment in the foot. Still more strongly was Sister Anna de la Nativité disturbed. She saw a phantom in terrible forms that stood motionless before her the whole night in her cell; if she went anywhere, it hurried ahead of her; in the choir it performed all sorts of juggling tricks before her to amuse her; and threatened her fiercely when she discovered the matter to the superior, who advised her to treat all the spook with contempt. At the time when she performed any act of humility and renunciation, the form fled; but upon returning, made what had happened ridiculous. During Mass it gaped its maw against the assembled, and threatened to devour them; set naked people before her, and sometimes struck them hard as well. Once during the Preface there appeared to her a crucifix, from which a voice declared itself to be her husband, promised her his protection, freed an arm to embrace her, and recommended to her only to keep their relationship secret. \

Since she did not answer at all, the apparition finally vanished amid great noise. Against these temptations she held a nine-day prayer before the Holy Virgin. Then an exceedingly bright-shining sun appeared before her, and the voice brought forth the same language from her, gave her sweet words of love, and urged her to union with the eternal light. Since she did not consent, the voice first fell silent; then later the glow also went out, when she made the sign of the cross against the illusion. The apparition soon returned in the form of other sisters and the superior; during the fast she saw meat dishes in abundance, smelled the odor of flesh everywhere, and men were there who urged her to seize them. Then followed violent convulsions and rigidities that pressed her hard; and the superior found her several times lying on the ground, stiff as wood.

During a service in the choir, her breviary was thrown from her four or five times without her moving her arm, and during the prayer she herself was thrust forward. When she once came out of herself, her sandals were tied without her moving; her rule was torn from her sleeve and thrown away, sometimes all the way over the altar; and the same happened with her rosary. Another time, in the presence of the superior, this rule was hurled into the middle of the fire; the superior quickly pulled it out again, and found it not damaged, although it had lain in the flames long enough. Another time, her relics were torn from her neck; the superior fastened them with three knots in the name of the Trinity, and the confessor forbade them to be torn away any further. It did not happen anymore; but from then on she was more often strangled at the girdle. When she sang with the others in the choir, she was often lifted a cubit high; and when others, to prevent this, placed their feet on hers, they felt these themselves lifted. Finally the spirit came in the form of the Holy Virgin, confirming all earlier apparitions as if they had come from her Son, and repeatedly demanding silence from her. \

She had to overcome some reluctance, also to disclose this to her superiors; and on account of her fear, two sisters were assigned to her at night with a burning lamp. But the lights were repeatedly blown out, the utensils thrown into disorder, and the beds shaken for so long until the light was relit. With Sister Maria of the Holy Spirit it was done in the same way, the same noise and throwing and falling surrounded her; three nights in a row circles were made before her, and she heard the words: When we are finished, then we have you at the right point! When she knelt at Christmas before the exposed Sacrament, reflected on her life, and offered herself to the Lord, suddenly a horror in the spirit came over her; blasphemous ideas rose up in her, and she no longer dared to look up at the Sacrament; for she saw there things that the human mind cannot bear. In the following night she felt a heaviness that laid itself three times upon her head; then she lost her senses, and could neither speak nor move herself. Thereupon two phantoms appeared to her, one large, which seated itself in a chair; the other dwarfish, only a cubit high, which settled on her stomach; both spoke with each other as if the whole convent, and she herself also, belonged to them. Meanwhile she lay under her alp unconscious, and could not bring forth her usual saying: Et verbum caro factum est! although the two constantly mocked her to do so. But what was most remarkable of all on this occasion was what happened with Sister Maria of the Holy Sacrament, and what she herself recorded. The event began with that touch at the pit of the heart, which her Picard, as we have mentioned earlier, had made.

When I had gone to bed in the evening after nine o'clock, she recounts, three strong fire sparks fell from the ceiling onto the bedcover, such that I had great fear on account of it. When I once imposed the discipline upon myself, the scourge was snatched from my hand and thrown into my face; a light was blown out for me in the attic, and I was seized by the girdle and thrown down the stairs. Another time a heavy mass was laid upon my shoulders, such that I thought I would suffocate; when I dragged myself with difficulty to the worthy Mother, I felt how the mass tumbled down onto a step of the stairs with a great crash; but I was thrown down at the same time, such that blood gushed forth from my mouth and nose. I was to ask fearlessly, if it returned: Who are you, what do you want here, and why do you turn to me?

When therefore I again one night around 11 o'clock heard a confused noise, I spoke the words. A terrible voice said: My sister, I have a secret to entrust to you! I cried out in horror; people came running, and still heard the sound of a blow that I received. The following night the spirit came in the form of a deceased convent sister, begging for certain prayers for the comfort of her soul, which however the confessor forbade in the prescribed form, allowing me some other devotional exercises. After some days a voice came, as if from a flash of lightning, thanking me for what I had done; I took it for the voice of the soul that I had freed, and formed a good opinion of myself. \

Several apparitions in various forms followed, some very frightful; and I was plagued in every way. Once my signature was tricked from me for a paper that was supposed to be a creed; in truth however, as it was later read to me, it contained all imaginable blasphemies. Again it came to me in the form of a convent sister who was my friend, who now brought me roses and carnations; then again struck, bit, and scratched me. One night I saw a young, naked man standing before me; I made the sign of the cross against it, and sprinkled holy water; but the form only mocked me. I, holding it for a ghost, then went toward it; but when I noticed that it did not vanish, I cried out with all my strength. The worthy Mother came running, asked what was the matter with me; but I only kept crying, holding fast to the form, which dragged me to the chimney, and in doing so lifted me two feet high. I feared being dragged out of the convent thereby, let go on that account, and now fell to the ground; where they found me, my hands full of black, reddish-glinting, stinking ointment.

They cleansed me of the filth, and then threw the cloth into the fire. The confessor now ordered that one of the older sisters go to me from time to time, to see how I was each time. But if this one omitted it once, then the demon came in her form, flattered itself into my trust; and as I gradually placed some faith in the deceiving words, and confided my perplexity amid the many apparitions to the seeming figure, this one advised me: no longer to entrust myself to people, nor to appear before my superiors, confessor, and directors; God would lead me by his own ways, to him alone must I turn my whole trust. In later meetings the form then let itself be drawn into various teachings, which amounted to this: all flesh is like hay; the Lord had therefore taken it upon himself, not to honor it, but to make it contemptible to us through the assumption of so many mistreatments. For that reason he had also reproved his apostles that through too great attachment to his humanity they had become unreceptive to the spirit.

For his true worshippers worship God in spirit and in truth; only the carnal ones have made the body into a sacrament for themselves, which they now adore; whereas the divine Majesty abhors flesh and blood. She then declared herself with equal definiteness against another life; hell is an invention of men, who knew no other way to maintain order here below. The true hell is rather on earth in the midst of men, and there also paradise is to be found; it is therefore a great folly to give up a present good for a fantastical hope that will never be fulfilled; for the soul must die with the body, otherwise God would have spoken untruth when he said: Thou shalt surely die. \

I became wholly confused, and at last told it to my confessor; and now the apparition sought, in my opinion, to ruin this one too, by appearing one morning in his form in my cell, and making me a formal declaration of love. Amidst my horror at this, doubts yet arose in me again, and I drove him away with the sign of the cross. The apparition came likewise another time in his form to the speaking grille, until the arrival of the real one drove it away. The spirit then made me believe that the confessor handed me a magic potion in the host of the sacrament every time; as a sign of this I should pay attention, and I would find it marked red every time. I now looked more closely indeed, and beheld on it as he had told me. Another time the hosts appeared to me half-blackened, and only the firm conviction of the confessor's spotless virtue could destroy this illusion for me.

Now the matter took another turn. One day in the early morning, a glow like that of a summer dawn illuminated my cell; and a beautiful youth of fifteen or sixteen years appeared to me in it, who greeted me graciously, saying: he was sent to me for my protection, because I had found grace before God, who had been pleased with what I had done hitherto. But he wanted now to lead me further on his ways, and had sent him to me for that purpose. For this, it was first of all necessary that I trust in him alone; for men, since their fall, have taken ignorance, mortality, and bestiality into themselves, and now one blind man would lead another. Silence and secrecy is therefore the first thing he demands of thee; for thou canst not serve two masters, and where God's Majesty is active, the reason of man must stand aside. Say therefore, like the mother of the Savior: Behold the handmaid of the Lord; be it unto me according to thy word! and henceforth ask no more at the high priest of the law.

The conversation lasted three hours; I had weighed everything carefully, and found nothing suspicious; he truly seemed to me to be my guardian angel, and I thanked God in full joy, for that day I felt no temptation. On the following day his discourse turned to the predestination of God; how he chooses his brides, and leads them on unusual paths, and allows them not the smallest thought of infidelity, which I therefore must combat even as it arises. Then for three days in succession it was spoken of the essence of God, and of the nature of men, who were created in the image of the angels---who themselves are images of God---but have defiled this image, and now wrongly call themselves fathers, masters, and doctors, and true Christians; whereas God, as Christ has said, should alone be called Father. In the sixth conference it was set forth how God created the angels from his essence, who, being of like nature with him, are also bound in perfect union with his substance. The two conferences next following spread themselves over the diversity of opinions and the disunity among men; for which God therefore sent his own Son, to bring them back to obedience. \
