Gabriel was there the bringer of the commandments of the Most High, and since he found her willing, he entered into her, and incarnated himself in her body; therefore he is the one whom men call the Redeemer of the world. I too should arm myself with prayer to receive the approaching Bridegroom. At the now following return, he asked me: whether I was now resolved to serve God in utmost perfection and renunciation. I replied: how I had therefore left the world to serve God; body and soul stood without reservation at his service. He praised me for it, and I felt such comfort and longing to be pleasing to God that I could scarcely bear it. He said now: Permit me to touch your heart, to strengthen it, and to fix it in this love.

At these words a kind of fear came over me, and I laid my hands on my breast: Know that before my confessor I have made a resolution to permit no one, whoever it may be, any touching! He said: he had done it only for my testing; but I replied: If it is God's will, then do it, otherwise I can never will it! I saw his countenance change, he seemed angry, yet without his splendor being diminished. He touched me, and said: that I was wrong to doubt him. For the tenth time he came shining brighter than ever before, to cleanse me, as he said, from my imperfections. He touched my heart, but in all chastity, and no evil thought arose in me, only a longing to love God; and I truly held him to be my good angel.

At his eleventh visit he asked me what I had, because I showed some unrest; I confessed to him at last that I had been in temptation the whole day to disclose the matter to my confessor. He reproved me for it, and said: Give me your tongue, that I may touch it and strengthen it. I could not help telling him: that all these touchings of his highly displeased me; because they seemed to me unsuitable for a spirit. He replied: You must mortify your own judgment even more strongly, for you will only your own will, and not that of the Lord! So do then, I replied, what pleases God's Majesty; he touched, however, only after a long speech on submission to God's will, my tongue. In the morning he came earlier than usual, in the full splendor of his beauty, and spoke so movingly of the glory of the blessed that my heart was ravished; and he, after touching my heart and eyes, had to keep his hand on the former to give me strength. They found me as if out of my senses, the whole day I could scarcely hold myself; and since I reproached myself for it: as if I sought only my own comfort in the All, and therefore grasped the nettles, and gave myself a hard discipline; he fully approved at evening what I had done. \

He returned in the morning, an exceedingly beautiful rose in his hand, which he offered me. But I covered my face, beseeching him: that he might moderate his all too great splendor, because I could not bear it. He touched my eyes and heart, I took the rose and kissed it; but he spoke to me of the immortality of the soul, and how only one man had been immortal, because without sin; since sin makes the spirit mortal, as the body is. I rejoiced over all these speeches, and my better knowledge before other men, and attributed it to my unceasing zeal to serve God. In the evening I had withdrawn to my cell, and prayed to God: that he, if the form was my good angel, might let it appear to me now for my comfort; but not permit that I be deceitfully led astray. He was immediately present, and after some exchanges of words I said to him: O you who are so good, and will the peace of souls, disclose yet to my confessor or to one of my superiors the relation that exists between us, so that I may find full peace!

He replied: the most beautiful gift that he could bestow upon me was my complete seclusion from all fellowship with men. In doing so, he touched my heart: "See," he said, "this is the seat of the passions; but you feel none at the touch, for I purify and sanctify all that approaches me in simplicity and faithfulness of heart." In the fourteenth meeting, he spoke to me of God and the fall of the angels, which had occurred only because, through lack of steadfastness and trust in their will, they had moved unstably; and thereby stepped out of their union with God, the highest bliss, to which they, as intelligences whom God had not called forth from nothing but from his own essence, had been predestined. All this was said so beautifully and compellingly that I cannot reproduce it, yet some apprehension always lingered in the background for me; so that when he demanded a pledge of fidelity from me, I always replied: "If God so wills!" or: "I have placed God in full possession of my heart!"

The next day, after Communion, a great dryness had come over me, and I complained of it to him. He said: he had imposed it upon me for my testing, and to draw me away from all earthly things; and then he asked me three times in succession, with a sweet voice: "My daughter! my beloved! do you love me?" Each time I lost the use of my senses; he had to bring me back to myself by touching me, and then he vanished with the words: "Three more days, and you shall be forever established in my grace." After the next Communion, the same sadness and aridity returned, and I withdrew quickly into my cell. My spirit soon visited me again and reproached me for my weakness in bearing my trial; nothing on this earth is won without effort. Finally, on the last day, when he came and inquired about the state of my inner self, I said to him: nothing troubles me at present, for I have come to full resignation in God's will; although, whatever I may undertake, I cannot master a certain fear of possible deception. Yet I promise, if nothing contrary to God arises in me, deep silence. He approved of all this, and spoke to me ravishingly of the joys that awaited me. \

In the evening, the confessor had me summoned to the speaking grille; I went with reluctance. When I appeared, he asked me: how things stood with me, and what was passing within me? I answered: things stood well, and only good passed within me! He, in turn: "So something is indeed passing in you, and I want to know what it is!" "Jesus! my father," I said, "if something were passing between God and me, I would be bound to disclose it! For the left hand should know nothing of the good that the right hand does." He now commanded me, upon holy obedience, to tell him what I wished to conceal; and I said: nothing except that I had come to a full indifference toward all creatures. He found this well done, but warned me to be on my guard; lest under the pretext of the good I be led into evil. "But," I said, "my father! is there something in my behavior that perhaps arouses suspicion?" "I have no suspicion," was the reply, "but rather fear of deception; your fainting spells after holy Communion, the sadness on your face, your silence about the state of your conscience for fifteen days or three weeks, make me believe that something is the matter with you." "Truly!" I replied, "for some time now I have been withdrawing from men, because true consolation is only with God; from men, however, only hindrance comes." "Well!" he said, "I believe you, my daughter, and I pray to God that he may let you recognize the truth, so that you may not be deceived, and that all may end to his glory!"

I looked at him without saying a word, for I did not know what I should do; but I thought to myself: this is a temptation, for I have today pledged fidelity and silence. He, noticing my uncertainty, said: I see well that you do have something to share with me after all! No, I replied, I am only pondering the words I have heard, and at the same time I rose to leave. When I was in the middle of the parlor, I stopped to consider what I should do. He called me back: My daughter! I beg you, tell me the truth---that was his address; do you perhaps have some fear? I fear no one but God, was my answer. Then go on your way, I believe you! When I was near the door, I turned toward him and said: Farewell, my father! He in turn: Farewell, my daughter! I kept looking at him, and said once more: Farewell, my father! I am going now. He called me back yet again: My daughter! one more little word; come closer, I will tell it to you softly. I approached the speaking grille, and he gently took hold of the cord with which I was girded, and said to me: I see clearly that you have something to share with me; I will not let you go now until you have spoken the word to me, even if I should not depart from here until tomorrow! \

I was greatly astonished, and said: It is true, my father! something extraordinary is taking place between me and my good angel. God imparts many graces to me through him; but I cannot speak of all this, because I have pledged fidelity and silence, and I fear otherwise to lose the consolation of his visits. The confessor replied to these words: In truth, my daughter! this angel is the devil himself! An immense trembling seized my whole body, my teeth chattered against each other so that I could not speak. The confessor spoke prayers and exorcisms over me, and in the end had to summon the worthy mother to my assistance. The trembling lasted perhaps half an hour; when it had passed, the father wanted me to abjure all the words of agreement and affection that I might have spoken. I replied: as I renounce everything that I might have said contrary to God's will. But he would not be satisfied with that; I was to renounce the angel entirely and regard him as a devil; I, however, refused to proceed further that day, saying that one must first see what the matter truly was. I promised him in this that I would faithfully report the further outcome. He handed me over to the sister with the charge: not to leave me until she had brought me to bed.

I, when I was alone, spoke words of courage to myself, and when all in the convent had become quiet, he came in his clarity; but with an expression of such raging anger as if he wished to destroy me. He reproached me as unfaithful, ungrateful, wretched; I knew not what misfortune awaited me; only repentance and a solemn vow of greater fidelity for the future could save me. He looked at me with a piercing, loving gaze: Promise me, he cried, only better fidelity for the future, and I will forgive your weakness! I felt a great tenderness toward him, but at the same time a fear of giving my consent, and without answering, I turned to the other side. But he immediately turned me back, and said: What is this, my daughter? How changed you are! Do you not wish me to take possession of your heart? I replied: This heart belongs to God alone; I do not regret what I did earlier in the confessional. If you are from God, then it will also be pleasing to you; but if you wish to remove all suspicion from me, appear before the confessor at the speaking grille in your full clarity, and reveal to him what you have undertaken for my guidance. If he approves everything and declares you to be an angel of God, then I promise you unwavering fidelity; if not, then leave off from me, unworthy as I am. \

With every word that I spoke, the expression on his face changed; at last he became furious, and losing all composure, he said: Wretch! Is this the fulfillment of your promise from yesterday? What have you noticed in me since then that is hateful to God? I see, I have shown you too much love, you have turned the medicine into poison; once more, do not force me, after so much mildness, to turn to severity against you! I was so moved that it was a close thing---I would have agreed. But I said: Even if I promise you fidelity, I cannot keep it; the confessor will question me, and for all the world I will not deceive him. Give me only your heart, he said, and I will manage it somehow. My heart belongs to God, I cried out; I renounce you, wretched deceiver! Now I see, you are not from God, and I despise your flattering words and threats. Ha, unhappy one! With this word I deliver you to your enemy, as punishment for you! With that he vanished. That was on April 4, 1642; splendor and glory were gone, and from then on he returned to her armed only with all terrors.

Nächtliche cross and zigzag wanderings, one will say, of a nun dancing about in the garden of love, who by day, through cloister and rule, saw herself excluded from entering the enchanted gardens, and now in the silence of the night recovered from her harm. The confessor was the lord and master of the waking world that surrounded her; and in her prose, her asceticism, her penances and her constraints he kept her enclosed. But when she had sunk into the arms of sleep in her solitary cell, then the poetess awoke within her; the alleged angel was the lord of the new dream world; he touched her creative imagination with a glowing finger, and this then gave birth to the extravagant images in which she reveled, entirely forgetting the troubles of waking states. But soon a strife arose between the two realms, for the master of prose and the master of poetry could not in the long run get along under one roof. The mother of the nun had cried out, at that time when the goddess-mother Isis had tried to burn out the daughter, purifying her in her flames.

The master of prose was crude; by her girdle he drew the reluctant one down into his phlegm. In the sinking down, her inner being was transformed; the genius of gentle beauty turned for her, in frightful fashion, into a terrible demon; the idyllic drama, since the tragic element had veered into the comic, was translated into a baroque parody of itself---that is, she became possessed as punishment for her fall; with a different outcome, the monk would have become a Philistine, just as the peasants who had blasphemed Latona were transformed into frogs. --- \

All this sounds round and witty; but it fits only poorly with the dubious barter between the two regions. This alleged dream world finds itself, below and to the side, built around and framed by the waking world; and of the arabesques that traverse it, a part does indeed take root, in its plant-like half, in sobriety, and only the winged spirits in the flower calyces grow over into the enclosed realm. For just as the strong, encroaching color in the eye awakens its complementary color; so one may assume that the imagination complements the prose of life with poetry awakened from within, in contrast. But these poetic dreams and foams have at other times entered very tangibly into life; and one cannot deny that the plant-like then took root in the dream world, but the marvelous, which had blossomed above, was carried out into the waking world. When the possessions broke out in the cloister, and the Bishop of Evreux Picard, proceeding thither in a six-horse carriage; the possessed nuns came, who knew how to run swiftly like the wind over the roofs and the walls, and who walked over the waters without sinking, nimbly towards him, threw themselves between the horses, and it succeeded for them more than once to halt the carriage.

Was that perhaps also a dream which the horses had dreamed? When in the choir the breviaries and order rules of the tormented flew about, desks and utensils were overturned at their approach; when their sandals hung on their veils; when at dead of night a murmur of many voices arose around them; when the dreaming Marie herself was thrown down the stairs: were all these wondrous things perhaps dreams that had escaped from the dream-world into the waking world? When the same Marie once, in the presence of witnesses, ran with impetuosity up a mulberry tree to its outermost tender summit branches, and now from branch to branch circled and flew around the tree like a bird; did the tree that had borne this wondrous fruit stand in the open cloister garden, or in the nun's cell behind the dream portal? Thus the truth that has fallen from waking into the alleged world of illusion stands opposed by another, which has stepped forth from this world of illusion into the real; each of the two thus has a root of truth within itself, and they are therefore placed on equal footing with one another. \

This equal validity of both spheres, and the complete parallelism in their effects, utterly inexplicable under the presupposition that the one is merely the negation of the other; explains itself readily if one lays beneath them a double ground of truth, an inner and an outer. Then arises a state which takes its first origin from certain mediating personalities, here that of Picard. Its genesis, and the gradual development of the symptoms in both directions, we have seen pass before us in what has gone before. If on this path it has reached its height, then it ends at last in that possession which calls forth voices from the inner realm, named the spiritual obsession. Sixteen or eighteen nuns of the convent were in this state. They were, shaken by the most violent convulsions, rolled into balls, twisted in the strangest contortions; but the doctors were astonished to find them, amid all this, in perfect health, and after three to four hours of paroxysms of the most violent kind their pulse was mostly unmoved and calm. They declared unanimously: it is impossible to explain such violent, prolonged, frequently recurring attacks, which leave no trace after their passing, by mere natural forces. For four to five years the thus affected ones were tormented day and night; for two years during the exorcisms they were for many hours at a stretch in raging, howling, screaming, and convulsions; moreover they felt the movement of their spirits often, so that they were for 6--8 hours of the day in the most terrifying excitement: but when the attack or the exorcism ceased, and the stole had scarcely been removed; then they went away dancing and laughing, without a sign of fatigue, and without after-effects.

### Chapter 2. Psychic Reports

The spiritual reports connect the personalities with one another in their midpoints, and with the center of the radical evil; the psychic ones continue the begun work then in the middle man. The psyche, which with a spiritual one gives itself to the spirit, with a vital one to vitality, has, although both moments properly belong to it, yet in them tinged itself with the color and manner of the two regions into which it has thus inserted itself, and which have given themselves to it through it.

But she herself entirely, in her specific particularity, is she only in her middle moment, in that wherein she reveals herself outwardly, in every kind of voluntary movement. Where, therefore, a short and compact intuition is in question, this movement can be taken as her most proper expression, and as the medium in which her essence and her manner inscribes itself in the purest and most compact form, and from which her properties and inner relations can again be derived. In the movement expresses itself the higher will, within a certain, precisely psychical limitation; and its inhibitions and morbidities make themselves felt in it, just as one feels in the pulse the disturbances of physical life. This thus regulating will stands now, first, in a determinate relation to itself, and then in another to the surrounding nature and its forces, divides itself therefore into a subjective and an objective. \

Since now the movement is the expression of the in- dwelling inner, so will it also divide itself into a purely voluntary one, and one of mixed kind, a so-called in- voluntary; and from the natural relations of both kinds will the power and freedom of the total will in this domain be dependent. The relation adequate to the ordinary conditions of life can now be disturbed: either by the one subjective moment, in that this once claims too much for itself, and seeks to emancipate itself entirely from all involuntary movement; or in that it surrenders itself too much to the other, so that the involuntary, overflowing its banks, threatens to master the whole. There then arises a possession of this will immediately through nature, or mediately through itself; which will appear as a work of guilt, and thus as an obsession. Or the natural relation is disturbed by the other involuntary moment: which either, overwhelmed by positive natural forces, breaks over into the domain of voluntary movements; or, yielding itself too much to the negative, calls forth the irruption of these movements. In both cases it is a natural possession, which, as a work of contagion, is a misfortune and a disease. To this belong therefore the rigid spasms, the St. Vitus' dances, and the over- tensions of the movement-systems in all kinds of manias, which are mostly at the same time connected with deeper natural intuitions, in the activities pointing toward the purpose.

With such intuitions, however, the view into the otherwise closed spirit-realm is also opened, and there a second relation of the psychical will-forces to the powers native there makes itself known. This relation, however, forms itself now either in the involuntary will-forces: those powers master these forces, and pave their way through them to the other order of subjectively voluntary forces, which they, binding to unfree ones, to evil purposes immediately or in the back-effect of the loosed, press toward. Then the demonic ob- session will emerge as disease; whereas conversely, if the outset comes from the voluntary will-forces, and these smooth the paths for the evil, and prepare the ways for it, that demonic obsession enters, which as guilt intervenes more deeply.

The first kind of obsession, if it finds many individuals in similar situations, in determinate rapports toward one another, and toward the contagious demonic miasma placed, can therefore spread itself epidemically over all; and the same power will seize it in those rapports and bind it to its center. They all will therefore, infected by the same possession, form around it a group of their own; and a demonic epidemic, spread more narrowly or more widely, will then emerge. The other kind of obsession likewise, when it arises either in an individual of superior powers, who knows how to draw strongly to himself, through his relations, as the center of an entire sphere, those belonging to it whom he has won over by means of these relations; or when it otherwise arises simultaneously in several individual personalities who are capable of forming such a nucleus; will likewise become epidemic, and thus can bring forth an entire circle, not without the complicity of the possessed. This epidemic of obsession, intermingled in the personal contagion of the afflicted, will thus form the second object of our consideration. To the third will then be subordinated the cases of mixed kind and doubtful nature.

Such evils will, as is easily recognized, occur for the most part there where many persons, under similar influences, in similar circumstances of life, live in close contact with one another; most of all, when they are individuals of the female sex, who already in themselves stand in a closer natural union with the men. Female convents will thus first be the scenes of such occurrences, and indeed there is no lack of examples where such things have taken place in such conventual associations. Among these cases there is especially one that was exactly and sharply observed by four bishops and four doctors of the Sorbonne; which they then likewise sharply weighed and discussed in its various circumstances; and concerning which, after they had confirmed the individual facts through repeated experiments, excluded the doubtful, and retained only what was evidently certain, they then drew up the following clear and luminous report, which dispels all suspicion of fraud and deception, and presents the matter roundly and plainly.

It reads, however, as follows: We, the undersigned, after having heard the report made to us by His Episcopal Grace of Châlons-sur-Saône concerning the occurrences that took place in his presence among many persons, some ecclesiastical, some secular, who seemed to be plagued and seized by the evil spirit, in Auxonne; at that time when, by order of the King and on the commission of His Highness the Archbishop of Besançon, he conducted the exorcisms on the spot for fourteen days; after he had called in several priests chosen by him, all persons of great piety and great merit, and moreover assigned to them Mr. Morel, formerly the city physician of Châlons, known for his science and experience; who all agreed in the same judgment concerning the matter, which the aforesaid Lord Bishop presented to us under the following points of view:

First, that all those virgins in their entirety, 18 in number, some secular, some ecclesiastical, and without excepting even one, appeared to him to have the gift of tongues; inasmuch as they always answered correctly to the Latin with which the exorcists addressed them, not from the ritual, and still less by prior agreement. Often they also expressed themselves in Latin, sometimes in whole periods, once or twice through formal speeches. One among them, Anne des Ecolos, called of the Purification, when one of the exorcists spoke Irish to her, testified that she understood him very well, and explained what was said to him several times in the French language. Secondly, that all or nearly all showed that they possessed a knowledge of the interior, and of the secret of thoughts when these were directed toward them; which showed itself especially in the inner commands that the exorcists gave them on many occasions, to which they in general obeyed very exactly, without these commands being translated into words or any external sign; concerning which the Lord Bishop himself made various experiments. \

The other clergymen who had been present there, according to his report, since the same thing occurred with them every day, had adopted it as the manner of making them obey, into their practice.

Thirdly, that they on various occasions had foretold future things, especially in regard to the maleficia and sorceries which one must find; not only at various places in the convent, where they were indeed really found; but also in the bodies of other sisters, with whom they had not previously spoken, and who then vomited them forth and expelled them from themselves exactly at the hour which those had determined for them. At times they had told the Holy Bishop, and some of his clergymen, very secret particulars in regard to their household affairs, and the time of his journey to Paris, which he himself had not even known; which things then turned out in truth just as stated, but could neither be guessed nor combined from the circumstances. This lasted sometimes half an hour, more or less; but when at last the received particle was swallowed, then she who had taken it remained immediately calm, and without remembrance of what had occurred. That further they had felt the most extraordinary aversions and fits of rage, at the approach of the relics of the saints, which they often recognized and named by name, before they had seen them, and without knowing anything of them. That furthermore nearly all, when the holy Bishop several times secretly laid hands on them, and without their being able to know it, had given to understand how they felt it; as they cried out: this hand is unbearable to them, it presses heavily, they would be burned by it! To all this added the testimony of Mr. Morel, the physician, who was present at everything, and who assures that all these things surpass the bounds of nature, and can only proceed from the demon; so we believe, having weighed everything well, that all these extraordinary facts in those virgins go beyond the powers of human nature, and can only be wrought by the demon, who possesses and besets their bodies. That is our opinion. Given in Paris on the 20th of January 1662.

One sees with what circumspection these men proceeded, examining and weighing everything carefully; and we shall see who will have the forehead to contradict their testimony, and to declare respectable men as deceivers, or as deceived by the juggling tricks of the companions of a convent and its conniving spiritual directors, continued for more than ten years, whose good reputation is secured by the testimony of an entire city. But assuming the event to be true, since no one was found upon whom any suspicion of bewitchment rested, the evil must therefore have arisen within the convent itself through immediate communication, either simultaneously in all, or also in one or more, and then passed from one to the other through epidemic contagion; until finally the entire community was seized. Since they drew it upon themselves on the Sabbath, it has been a true obsession that overtook them; but since none among them was found from whom one could truly have suspected that she had first given occasion to the evil through her own fault; it has therefore come upon them as a judgment, and it has been an obsession that yet again emerged in all the forms of a possession; which therefore here proceeded from a source of contagion lying entirely outside the circle of the human realm. \

Such obsessions differ, except for the Sabbath, in none of the other phenomena from those which the possessions exhibit; but they are at the same time, except for goal and intention, otherwise in all things equal to the symptoms of higher ecstasies. The gift of languages, the beholding of another's thoughts, the hearing of the commands of the exorcist from afar, the knowledge of holy things, of the sacraments, of relics and consecrations, here expressing itself as loathing and horror, the power of the will over the unfree ganglionic life, invulnerability to fire, painlessness and closure of the senses, the stopping and flowing of the blood at will, the drawing in of the whole body into the form of a circle, or successively into the forms of two half-circles divided from one another and turned toward each other: all of this we have already seen mutatis mutandis in the saints just as well. That circle which the one formed would, had the exorcist so willed, have rolled itself just as much in the circular streaming of the forces, toward any arbitrary point on the radial line; as the holy Peter of Alcántara did it voluntarily in his ecstasies toward the Most Holy Sacrament.

These events are proven in the saints by the most unimpeachable testimonies; they are proven here now in the possessed by equally unimpeachable witnesses; the facts confirm one another just as much, and here as always the devil, so far as it lies in his power, must against his will bear witness for the higher truth. All of this is in nature, for it is executed with natural forces; but it is also above nature, for the ground to which these forces attach themselves lies beyond the region of ordinary life. Next to this, the casting forth of objects designated by certain names seems still to point to jugglery and deception. So much is certainly true: these things did not write themselves, the devil did not write them either; therefore it was the nuns who did it. But they did not do it in waking senses, with the intention of deception, but rather as they were beside themselves, in the properly negative demonic ecstasy; in it they also swallowed the written things, which alone would have been possible in such a state. \

The same one, when she was once confronted with Bavent, stood with one foot stretched out three shoe-lengths high against the speaking grating; her face pale, emaciated, parched, her eyes sunk deep in her head like those of a death's-head, for fully a quarter of an hour in an unchanged position, staring fixedly at Bavent with rage. Once she lay senseless for half an hour in the refectory, and when the bishop commanded her spirit to depart from her, it threw her into strange contortions. Suddenly she shot away like a flash of lightning into a fairly strong fire; her face and one hand were thrust into the glowing coals, and when people ran to pull her out, no burn damage was found on her; only some blackness and a little ash lay on the part of the face that the heat had touched, which could easily be blown away. She was thrown violently backward onto her head in the cloister courtyard, without it harming her; she climbed up a ten-foot-high wall on an old piece of wood, and ran along it to a spot where no ladder could be placed. The nuns begged her to go back to where she could be brought down. One of the exorcists adjured her spirit and began to pray on his knees. Dagon cried out: If you do not stop, I will hurl the carcass down! And indeed, he threw her the ten feet down onto stones and bricks, without her being injured in the slightest. Sister Anna of St. Augustine was to go to confession, but her spirit Gonzag would not allow it for two hours. Her confessor Bosroger, weary of his obstinacy, finally commanded him in the Latin tongue to enclose himself in the left foot of the possessed one and to set her spirit free for the task. He resisted most violently for an hour, but finally had to obey; and he gave the sign of obedience imposed upon him by striking the floor in rhythm with that foot. The nun now confessed without disturbance and then also went to the Lord's table; but as she did not know what had actually occurred, she limped on the left foot and finally fell to that side, so that she had to be led. Later Gonzag would not come out of his hiding place and had to be forced once more to free the foot.

The same Marie of the Holy Spirit was likewise to go to communion at the time of examination; for four hours her Dagon resisted, driving her through the crowd into all corners of the church; and finally he jumped with her onto the high altar, where he blasphemed God and demanded adoration from those present. The exorcists now called out to him: *Illa superbia quae te de coelo praecipitavit, deturbet te de altari.* Immediately, as if struck by a thunderbolt, he fell to the ground against the railing, four or five steps from the altar. They also banished him into a foot, which stiffness immediately seized, so that she might complete the communion in peace.

All the obsessed ones in general were, after their attacks---in which the head was bent backward against the heels---brought into the bow form. Sister of St. Lawrence, allegedly possessed by Behemoth, was during one hour bent two or three times into this form; similarly the one of the Redeemer, so perfectly that the head lay down to the mouth at the feet, while the belly formed a complete arch. Once she was as if broken in two, the head and face hanging backward to below the middle of the feet near the heels; like a handkerchief laid over the finger, so that the ends hung down on both sides. Sister Louise of the Ascension, terribly plagued for a whole year with every sort of nervous ailment, was several times placed in such a position that she touched the earth only with a flank of the left side or of the belly, in a breadth of about four inches. \

The mobility of the spirits in the obsession, or if one prefers, the interchange among the obsessed, is easily recognized in the following occurrences, which testify to a migration of the evil. Putiphar, who directed the Sister of the Holy Sacrament, said in the inner choir to Eneitif, who had his dwelling in Sister Barbel of St. Michael: Shall I not come into the lair that you possess? The one asked replied: Yes, I will. In an instant, Putiphar had entered the other; the Sister of the Holy Sacrament was meanwhile entirely free of her demon, threw herself immediately before the altar, and quietly prayed her breviary up to the Lauds. Sister Barbel, who meanwhile had both demons, was near the door as if nailed to the earth; the arms stretched out like two iron bars, likewise the right foot, on which no heel was any longer visible; the head of unspeakable weight, so that it could not be raised from the earth with any exertion, not even so high that the tips of the fingers could have been placed between them; and thus she remained lying for half an hour. Meanwhile the other had made her confession to the bishop, but when she too went to communion, and the holy Host had just been placed on her tongue, Putiphar came back like a flash of lightning, and cried: To the devil, I will not endure that! While I am absent, they deceive me, and let the bitch receive communion. \

In the moment when he thus cried out, the other one began to twitch; and she started to howl and scream, as her demon was accustomed to do. Since the doctor, for whom they had sent, arrived too late, the bishop believed he must compel Puttiphar, through the power of the Church, to make restitution. He refused; but after they had shouted at him: "Si sit voluntas Dei, fiat!" he finally obeyed on the fourth call, and the one became free again, while the other was doubly possessed. This lasted a quarter of an hour, until they brought the holy Sacrament to the stomach of the latter, who lay stiff and heavy upon the ground. When they had progressed from the words "O salutaris hostia!" to the others "Da robur, fer auxilium!", she began to stir and move. In the same instant, the sister of the holy Sacrament collapsed in convulsions at the other end of the choir; as swiftly as a shot wild animal in the flash of the gun. The same transfer repeated itself several times in the presence of many people, among whom were also doctors, who wrote down their report on it, and noted therein how the actions and sufferings had been separated by sufficient intervals from the general tetanus. Often the demon, in such a transfusion---after the stiffness and heaviness---produced a great pliancy and incomparable lightness; as we indeed found several times the head of one such person, who had two demons, as light as a ball of wool, but the neck as flexible as a piece of old linen cloth, and as if it had no sinews. The demon himself attributed the heaviness of the head to the strife between the two for the upper position in the head.

After these events, which occurred among crowds of nuns, it will not be surprising if we see similar symptoms break out in whole masses of the people. When, in July 1214, the Church of the Apostles in Liège was consecrated, whole crowds of a wondrous sect came from Upper Germany, from the Rhine and the Meuse, first to Aachen, then to Utrecht, and finally to Liège, whose manner was as follows. Men and women, possessed by the demon, half-naked, with wreaths on their heads, went along; and, holding each other by the hands, they performed dances before the spectators on the streets, in the churches, and in the houses, without the least shame. They jumped high in the air during this, and in the songs that they sang, they named demons such as Friskus and the like, which had never been heard before. When the dances were finished, they were plagued by the most violent chest cramps; so that, if their friends did not gird them around the navel region with linen cloths and draw the girdle tight, they would rage that they must die. \

These hordes swelled from September to October to many thousands; for more and more dancers kept coming from Germany, and in Liège and the neighboring provinces many healthy people, and such as were completely in their right minds, were suddenly seized by the demon; and, extending their hands to the dancers, they immediately joined their choruses. Sensible people saw the cause of this phenomenon in the ignorance that prevailed in those times concerning the faith and the commandments of God. The people, however, sought the cause in the priests who kept concubines, who had not baptized the people properly; and they prepared themselves, especially in Liège, to rise up against the clergy, to strangle the culprits, and to plunder their goods. But God wished to demonstrate to men that baptism, whether administered by good or bad hands, was all the same to Him; therefore He gave to the secular priests of Liège the gift of healing such possessed persons through the laying on of hands and exorcism, which He refused to other priests.

In the Kreuzkirche there, a man who had been assigned to carry the censer around the choir during the divine service suddenly began to swing it about in a playful manner, to dance around with it, and to sing numerous songs in unknown words; and since he did not cease from all this despite reminders, people came to believe that he belonged to that sect. A priest called upon him to recite the Lord's Prayer and then the Creed; he refused to do both, and said: he believed in the devil. The priest therefore placed the stole around his neck, spoke the usual exorcisms over him, and immediately freed him; so that he recited the Creed and Pater Noster with great devotion. Around All Saints' Day, the dancers in Heristall, scarcely half a mile from Liège, had gathered in large numbers, and had resolved among themselves to go to Liège and murder the entire clergy there. But their resolution came to nothing; for when they arrived in the city, they were led by pious people to the priests, who did not harm them, but from whom they received healing. Some were brought to the Marian chapel in the St. Lambert's Church, where the priest L. Lones freed the first one, and then nine others, with the stole and the Gospel: "In the beginning was the Word." The rumor soon spread, and now they came in droves, and were freed in the same manner. Others were led to other churches, where the same was accomplished with them by good and bad priests alike, without distinction.

They made use of that same Gospel for this, and subsidiarily of others as well; especially where Christ healed the demonic, such as "to the eleven as they reclined" and "Jesus sent" and the like. In cases where the freeing was more difficult, the priests either placed the Sacrament of the Eucharist on the head, or gave the blessing with it before them. To some, consecrated or exorcised water was given to drink, or, if they refused, poured into them; also the consecrated fingers were placed in the mouth under the words: "Depart, unclean spirit!" and so forth. Words were spoken into their ears, and breath blown into their faces, to break the power of the enemy. \

In the St. Bartholomew's Church, a demon said to the priest: he should just stop, he would depart of his own accord. One had already gone out because of the torment, and they would never again enter a Christian person. If the exorcisms had not been performed, they would have gone from the poor into the rich and powerful, in order to drive out the clerics. A girl, treated fruitlessly by several priests, had gone to Aachen; and the cleric named Symon had dressed her there in alb and stole, and immersed her in a vessel of exorcised water up to her mouth. On the question of how long he had been in the girl? The answer was: Two years! Where he had been when she went to Easter Communion? In the toe joints. When conjured, he wanted to enter the nearby castle of Schremborg and guard it against thieves. Asked if he could blow the horn? He began to blow it with great noise before all those present. Since they also would not let him enter the Bath of Charlemagne, he finally departed, after the girl had expelled a coal from herself. When it did not succeed for a priest to free a possessed person, he added prayers and fasting to the exorcisms, and he immediately became master of it. Thus the rush to Liège was great over the course of a year; but it gradually diminished, and around three thousand were healed, lightly or severely, and they said: during the entire course of the affliction, it had seemed to them that they were immersed in a stream of blood, and that was why they had jumped so high. Even after three or four years, individuals came sporadically, and were easily freed by the clerics.

So the matter was settled to the satisfaction of the people and to the glory of the Liège clergy; since the evil, which particular dispensations had imposed, was also removed again through the intervention of higher powers. As a byproduct, the teaching of the Church was thereby strikingly confirmed, that grace is not defiled by the impure vessel, and thus that all tangible reformation is foolishness. The occasion from the natural side was probably a kind of St. Vitus' dance, which had taken its seat in the abdominal ganglia, and now discharging itself against the pulmonary ganglia, excited those dances; but in the reaction, the spasmodic affliction toward the diaphragm, which could only be alleviated by the constriction of the epigastric region. The depolarization had proceeded downward, from where a sloping inclination toward the demonic sets in; the people had therefore directed their solicited intention thither, and it had taken on the character of obsession for the evil; and the dances, to the foreign-sounding Sabbath songs with the demon names, became a pavane. But this turn had now also made it possible to attack the evil from the ecclesiastical side, and it had succeeded happily thereby. In our times, less fuss would have been made; the police would have dispersed the dancers as lunatics, and in any case beaten those who resisted; the compliant ones would have been shunted back to their homes, and there might have made their peace with their friskiness or withered away. Enlightenment would have triumphed over darkness, and the applause of all friends of the victor would have fallen to the expedition.

#### B. The Psychic Contagion in the Obsession

\

The ease of transmission in this and the preceding case brings us close to the fact that there must be a contagion, which, as it were, atmospherically envelops the inner core, carrying the effect from one to another. Whoever enters into the demonic circles experiences there a transmutation of his entire being, through all organic regions; thus in the fluid as in the solid, in the nervous as in that which envelops the nerves; hence also in the aura, which surrounds the human being and every single organ in him from afar. But the demonization now communicates itself, just as electrification, magnetization, heating, and the like do on physical bodies; and the demonized corporeality becomes a ferment, a yeast and mother of vinegar, which is capable of producing again in others, even in still healthy personalities, and thus all the more easily in those already inclined toward the pathological, the same process from which it itself has emerged in this manner. The most suitable medium in which this communication occurs at a distance will therefore be precisely that aura which surrounds the entire fermenting corporeality; which participates in its conditions in its own way, and carrying it over into the foreign, thereby awakens the like in the encompassed personalities. This aura, like that around the sun which mediates the reciprocal intercourse to its world bodies, will have different regions, propagating itself to farther or nearer distances through the higher or deeper; but the processes on this side and that, above and below the mediating, will always relate to each other as archetype and copy. \

If, therefore, in the midst of a fellowship anyone has been found who has attained virtuosity in these domains; if the demonic has not merely, as in ordinary life, operated through distribution and in a mere aggregate state; but if it has struck and ignited within him, so that he has now become an independent source of the wild fire: then such a one, acting as deputy for evil, kindling it himself, can bring the conflagration into the surrounding bonds; and all those who, even if spatially distant from him, yet stand inwardly connected to him in sympathy, will be seized by him; unintentionally, where the transmission still belongs to the previous category, but also intentionally and with premeditation, where the practice then falls to its own \[category\]. If these are indeed spiritually, morally, and physically healthy natures, at the height of their vital force, then he will indeed accomplish little. But if it is an age less guarded against external impressions, a youthful stage that comes in his path; or a disposition disarmed by illness, or otherwise already inclined by temperament that draws near to him; if above all a spiritual, especially a moral, means of appropriation is already present: then he strikes swiftly, draws such personalities, appropriating them to himself, into his circle; and armed with them, he lords and rules in this sphere of action at his pleasure.

As for the children, in the Basque country some two thousand of them had been found, who, according to their statements, had been to the Sabbath. They had all confessed: if a sorceress wanted to lead them there, she would merely pass her hand over their face or head; immediately thereafter they would find themselves wholly confused, and as if out of themselves; but they did not say that the hands had been anointed. Sometimes, they protested, the women would give them an apple to eat, or a piece of black millet bread; after they had eaten it, they would become entirely defenseless, and then it would not fail---they would come the following night to fetch them. Even if they were then held fast in the arms of their elders and siblings, no one could awaken them. Such was the unanimous testimony of 2--300 children who were examined on the matter.

Johanna du Hard, 56 years old, had testified: when she had gone out of the church with a professed sorceress named Chorrozique, the latter had touched her arm, and she had immediately become as if dead. Corneille Brolu, 12 years old, deposed: that once, in 1608 during the fast at St. Jean de Luz, the sorceress Marie Martin had passed her hand over his head; and thereafter, in the following night, in the form of a cat, had taken him from his bed, out from the midst of two other boys; and had led him to Lecohanda, that is, to the great lake, where the Sabbath was held. Since that woman had died, he had not gone there for a month; until another took charge of him and led him there again. Since then he had been disenchanted, in that the woman whom they had summoned to justify herself---because she had not white but, like all her kind, red blood---had had some drops of it drawn, and with it a belt had been smeared. In the Swedish Elfdale as well, the children were awakened from sleep and taken there, with or against their will. If they betrayed it to anyone, they were harshly beaten at the following Sabbath; signs of this, however, were seldom to be discovered. Upon their return, the children usually looked quite weak, pale, and battered, and could scarcely recover the next day. They therefore often sought to save themselves before being led away, and when it began to come upon them, they would lie in the arms of their elders. These would sit by them and watch over them whole nights through; and as soon as they noticed an unusual pallor in them, they would shake them violently, but it helped nothing.

They also noticed that their breast became entirely cold; they also stuck a burning light into their hair, but it did not ignite. Their state of being away from themselves lasted sometimes half an hour, a full hour, or even two hours; and when the children came back to themselves, they lamented and wept most piteously, and begged forgiveness to the utmost of their ability, as much as they could. This was solemnly declared on oath before the court by two old men, who wished to call all the residents of the village as witnesses; for their children had mostly all experienced the same thing. Those grips of the witches were magnetic grips, which transferred the state of the one grasping into the one grasped. The state was, from the natural side, a magnetism; an inner awakening of the ganglia of the lower body, connected with the closure of the senses, the concentration of life in that region, and thus a cooling of the lung system; as it all showed itself in those Nordic children. But since the magnetism was at the same time of a demonic nature, the Sabbath had necessarily to be evoked in the circle of visions. \

Such a communication of the evil also manifests itself in manifold other ways. The father of a Swiss woman in Bayonne wanted to buy apples in 1605 from two notorious women, Galanta and Mandiburo. While haggling, his daughter bit into one of the apples that was offered to her; and she was immediately seized by a nervous disorder that returned at once every time she caught sight of the two women. It consisted in such a violent movement of one arm that the whole body was shaken by it and thrown to the ground; whereby her fingers moved with such rapidity that no virtuoso on any instrument could have matched her in agility. This repeated itself every time she sighted the woman, and with such violence that when de Lancre, who at first took it for simulation, together with two others tried to hold the arm fast and prevent its movement, they found it impossible; and instead, all three were most violently shaken by it. No other means remained to calm the half-dead one again than to remove the women; whereupon she, as was shown by the threefold repetition of the experiment, immediately came back to herself. \

Since then, when the same de Lancre was instructing at the Parliament of Bordeaux the trial of a sorcerer and of four witches from Amou near Eaux, these confessed how they transmitted two kinds of such diseases: once the falling sickness in full fury, more violent than the natural kind; and then the evil called Layra. This evil showed itself from time to time in the church of that place; where, as often as a witch entered who had given it to one or more in the assembly, sometimes forty or more persons began to bark like dogs in the full-moon nights. But sometimes the barking also occurred at a distance from the witch-women, because these could evoke it at their pleasure even from afar; then the afflicted did not cease calling them by name. One had already become so accustomed to it that if someone in their house felt an attack of the evil, their household immediately ran out into the street; and if they then found the called one there, this served them as testimony that often confirmed the confession. The court in Bordeaux, which had found these circumstances in the instruction of the judge from Amou, wanted to assure itself of the matter; and therefore dispatched two commissioners, Moneins and de Lancre, to take the thus bewitched into closer examination. The wife of a captain, who had suffered from the Layra for two years, was brought into the hall of the Tour de la Lanterne to the commission. She walked calmly about in it, viewing some pictures hanging there.

As soon as the gentlemen, against whom she had testified, without her being able to know it, were brought near her, she began at the very moment when they entered the staircase to bark most violently; so that it resounded through the entire house. The women were made to go back down the stairs, and the sick woman was spoken to reassuringly; she replied that she had no fear; and indeed, large as she was, she had a brave, manly appearance; but she could not overcome the abhorrence of coming into the nearness of these women. The malady had been done to her, as she believed, during a childbirth, since which she had remained barren; and while telling this, she stood there, arms akimbo, and stroking toward the womb for about a quarter of an hour, after which she became calm again. The commission repeated the experiment two more times with the same result; as the women, named Four and Fezendin, came near, the malady manifested itself both times so violently that the gentlemen came running together from all the rooms, and all became witnesses themselves of the trial. The screaming was so piercing that she had to be completely removed from the building. 1) It was also sometimes found that the sorceresses had passed the malady on to one another, in order to remain beyond suspicion. Thus the Violone of St. Jehan was accused by the Françoise Broqueiro of having been at the Sabbath in a conspiracy, where the same evil was inflicted upon her. \

But she replied: she was innocent, and had suffered the evil like herself. And in fact, she had such a severe attack on the witness stand that she had to be carried away. The same woman always named nine different people who had collaborated in it, among them Jean de la Lanne; and every time she was brought to the torture after him, she had a new attack. The same Broqueiron also confessed: how she had given a powder to the liver of a woman, which however only stayed with her for two days. That the transfer could also be done to animals, even to plants themselves, she affirmed; on the one hand, she stated how she had made birds fall down like epileptics; on the other hand, she recounted: all the witches of the diocese of Amiens, who were known, were obliged every year on the same day, at the same hour, to wither an elder tree (Ulmus); by circling it three times, and laying some salt on its most vigorously growing branch.

The latter can be left to rest until closer examination; but what was told before is remarkable, because it strikingly shows: that one who, in a tense mood, has drawn a far-reaching aura around herself, can evoke an analogous mood in a circle of such predisposed persons. A case in which all circumstances, well considered, and the confessions of those involved taken into aid, hardly offers any other explanation than through conscious transfer, is the story of Renata Sänger, who at the end of the first half of the previous century ascended the stake. She was, according to the intelligently written report that the Premonstratensian Oswald Loschert, abbot of the monastery of Oberzell, as an eyewitness wrote down immediately after her death, and sent to Empress Maria Theresa, born around 1680 in Munich, and without the knowledge of her parents already in early youth in contact with suspicious people, and thus initiated into various traditional magical arts circulating among them.

Taught by an old woman, she had already begun these studies in her seventh year; a rider had then continued the begun work in her ninth; and in the eleventh and thirteenth, two officers, a maid, and a noble lady had successively joined. From them she had received various magical herbs, especially a root of great power, and a little black man, which however soon disappeared again, probably a mandrake; various talismans with numbers and letters and incantations of all kinds, and learned many arts: to make people sick at will by her blowing upon them, by fixed gazing, accompanied by reciting certain formulas, by needle pricks into specifically shaped figures, by placing the herbs under the door threshold, or by communicating falsified foods, to drive them out of their senses, or to plunge them into demonic relations. Here one sees the aftereffect of the Thirty Years' War, whose terrible dissolution, barbarization, and despair had recently brought forth all these traditions of malice from earlier centuries, further developed them, and spread them among all classes, especially the lower ones and the wild soldiery. In the practice of these arts she soon became visionary; she heard, gazing into the distance, what was secretly spoken of her here and there; she saw herself at the Sabbath, with the change of her name to Emma Renata, entered into the black book, and received seventy years of life promised in exchange for her renunciation. All this was now a poor preparatory school for the monastic life that she, compelled by her parents who were unable to do otherwise, around 1699 entered in the monastery of Unterzell, which was highly esteemed for its discipline and strictness. \

Had she been endowed with a less resolute character, and possessed less mastery over herself than was truly the case; then this disproportion would have had to lead to a swifter outbreak. But resolute as she was, once she had taken her side, she went her ways in silence, without letting anything outwardly be noticed. She submitted herself to all the rigor of discipline; was careful in the fulfillment of her order's duties, and even knew how to spread around herself an appearance of piety; so that many held her in high esteem, and her convent sisters appointed her subprioress; indeed, they would have elected her prioress, if not a frequent dissatisfaction with her state, often rushing into it, a persistent aversion against her superiors, and a continuing restlessness on account of inner concerns, which she only hinted at with half words and would confide to no one, had held her back from it. This uncanny quality in her being, combined with the dark seclusion in which she set herself apart from all, also brought it about that for many years she came into no closer intercourse or more intimate association with any of her fellow sisters; which in turn preserved these from contagion by her arts, which she ceaselessly practiced for herself, drawing the herbs in the convent garden, and procuring from outside whatever else she lacked. Meanwhile it could not fail to happen that her heart must have embittered itself in this isolation; the compulsion to outward hypocrisy, alongside the secret practice of wicked arts, must have, ever increasing the tornness of her nature, filled her with resentment and hatred. This was greatly augmented still further by outward circumstances that arose; such as when in the year 1738 the provost of the convent removed the many cats with which she surrounded herself---already characteristic of her disposition, even if they did not, as she later confessed, hang together with her sorcery---on account of the great unrest they caused. Her mind, it seems, was thereby embittered to the depths, and from then on she began to direct her arts against those who had drawn her hatred upon themselves. From this moment onward peace and quiet had fled from the community of sisters; and the convent became the scene of the strangest events. Nightly there arose tumult and unrest within and without the cells; now it seemed to the sisters as if coaches and wagons were driving through the dormitory; now they heard in the garden, beneath the windows of the same, an unusual clamor. When they lay in their beds, then they were pressed, struck, pinched, and strangled; so that in the morning they could scarcely stir, and more than once bore blue marks from it; the locking of the cell, the sprinkling with holy water, and the blessing helped for a time, but never in the long run. Once when one of the convent women, on such an occasion, struck about her with her scourge, and the tormenting spirit fled from her after she seemed to have hit it hard, there was seen early in the morning on Renata's eye a bloody mark; which indeed awakened some suspicion against her, but naturally led to no certainty. But soon others fell gravely ill, and it was noticed that it was always the best, and those most useful to the convent, who in this manner were suddenly, and as if struck by evil sorcery, afflicted with burdensome and painful illnesses. This fate befell four in succession within the convent walls; and it was soon observed that the evil also spread outside of them, in a striking manner, to the male and female relatives of the provost. In five other sisters there soon appeared symptoms of another kind. \

They retired to rest, then they came---without really sleeping---out of themselves; and in this state, having become clairvoyant, they now saw various persons standing before them, among these also Renata; who tormented them in every conceivable manner and way, without their being able to stir themselves, to defend, or even to cry out. On the whole following day they were then tormented by inner anxieties, which especially multiplied in the church; from which they were often driven out against their will, as by an irresistible force. When they went to choir, their voice was alternately taken away and restored, and their singing in between transformed into a hideous howling; whereby the throat sometimes swelled high, and then fell together again. All this was connected with trembling, head-shaking, striking of hands and breast, and various convulsive movements; accompanied by the feeling as if an animal moved in their body; great despondency and despairing thoughts joined themselves likewise to these evils.

All who had been seized by this state were, according to the testimony of the doctors, previously of good bodily constitution; their mental powers were unimpaired, their conduct showed itself blameless. Thus neither in a natural cause nor in a sinful play of lies could the ground of those hitherto unheard-of effects be sought; but no one thought of possession and sorcery. Among the sick was also Cäcilia Pistorini from Amberg, and from this one the spirit had begun to speak in 1745, named his name, and predicted much of the future; but since she did not speak in foreign languages and nothing very remarkable, one still took offense at advising possession. Moreover, one was not sure of her as one who had only recently been in the convent; and that had brought her many humiliations and hard trials from the side of the superior. Renata had been very active in this; she persecuted the afflicted one, on whom she had cast a hatred, to the utmost; and since on account of her age and understanding she stood in some esteem with many, she took all pains to teach those in the convent: there are neither witches nor possessed, and what showed itself in Cäcilia was a pretended thing, mixed with many punishable disorders. In the meantime, however, no one could see what the unfortunate one drove to such a play; one had previously, when her states began to show themselves, given her leave to leave the convent; with tears in her eyes she had begged for her admission, to all trials she had willingly submitted with humility and obedience.

She herself, when her mouth in her attacks spoke terrible blasphemies, or to her shame blurted out the secrets of her heart, and the most terrible convulsions shook her; then she nevertheless never wanted to be persuaded that she was really possessed; she held herself only for one who on account of her sins had been abandoned and rejected by God. In the meantime, however, one had at last decided on the application of exorcism on her, this had not missed its effect; but the states had always returned again, and one had then each time noticed: that Renata had come close to her shortly before, breathed on her, murmured some words to her, or made some gestures; and it had then each time been to her as if a fireball passed through her body, whereupon the convulsions immediately set in again. That must of course awaken suspicion; all the more, since also one of the sick convent women, who on account of her spirit and her exceptional piety stood in great veneration in the convent, on her deathbed had repeatedly testified against Renata. \

But they still took scruple at allowing themselves to be prompted by this to any measure against her; and instead ordered a general church prayer in the convent: to implore from above help in the heavy distress, and light in the dark matter. The devotion had been continued for about three days; when the mouths of two more among the five opened, whose spirits had hitherto been mute; and amid the most violent convulsions it cried forth from them: Alas, our time has come, we may no longer conceal ourselves; whereby they, as ones compelled thereto by higher power, testified against Renata as the originator of all the evils. When one immediately applied the exorcism against them, they confirmed what had earlier been said voluntarily.

A few weeks later the remaining three also began to speak, and all six now unanimously attested the same; so that, as at the same time the torments and plagues of the afflicted were raised to the highest pitch, and no one could any longer doubt a real possession, general mourning arose in the convent, from which even Renata did not outwardly withdraw herself. The spirits, however, did not cease to testify against her; they gave the year, day and hour, place and occasion with the utmost exactness, where she there four or six, there ten and eleven years before had wrought evil; so that finally the long-spun net over the unfortunate one had to draw itself together. Her superiors had, in praiseworthy calm and moderation, still taken scruple at doing her any harm; until finally the provost of the convent found it advisable to carry out that upon which Renata herself, out of hatred against Cäcilia, had pressed for a year and a day; by requesting the abbot of Oberzell to institute a formal investigation of the matter. This one came over, examined the convent sisters under oath, and found Renata so multiply implicated through their statements, that he could not refrain from separating her for the time being from the rest of the convent.

She herself, when questioned about the accusations, had steadfastly maintained her innocence; and when the abbot pronounced the separation against her, she had begged to be allowed to go once more to her cell beforehand, in order to take with her some writings containing matters of conscience and confession; which was naturally not permitted to her, and now in the investigation the ointment box, various magic herbs, a yellow robe and the like were found. When, at her imprisonment, the possessed were quickly brought near, it began to howl and lament miserably from them, and it cried forth from some: O ye accursed hounds! why will ye destroy our nest? O little love---thus they called Renata---do not forsake us! The confessor of the convent now gave himself all effort to bring the unfortunate one to a sincere confession and to a conversion of life; and it seemed to him in so far to succeed, that she not only to him outside of confession, but also to the superiors of the convent quite voluntarily laid the confession: that she was a sorceress, had learned sorcery outside the convent, and had brought the six possessed into the state in which they found themselves; and that indeed with all the circumstances as the voices from them had earlier spoken. \

There was now no exercise of repentance, no renunciation and abjuration, which Renata did not repeat after the priests with all outward signs of contrition; thereby showing such composure of mind as if she had never committed any evil. When she was alone in solitude, then one saw her lying on her knees before the crucifix, or reciting the rosary; so that, to judge thereby, a complete change seemed to have taken place in her. But the nightly torments of the possessed continued as before and after, and Renata was always visible to them therein as a helper; although meanwhile a lay sister did not let her out of her sight in her room.

The voices only mocked with their pretended conversion, and in doing so revealed blasphemies that they had committed during their confinement without the presence of a single human being; so that one again began to doubt the sincerity of their improvement; doubts which were later justified by her own confession.

Up to this point, the whole matter had been kept secret and confined within the cloister walls, and in accordance with the manner of ecclesiastical procedure in such cases, in the hope that a way might be found to settle the affair quietly, every public step and summoning of witnesses had been avoided. But the cries and howls of the demons from the possessed became so noisy that they resounded throughout the entire region around the cloister; from one of them they had betrayed to the visiting elders the condition of their daughter, and accused Renata as the originator; so that soon the rumor of what was happening spread all around. They now first resorted to a new confessor; Father Maurus from the Scottish monastery in Würzburg was summoned, in the hope that he might perhaps succeed in moving her heart. Her confessions, tears, and contrition at first made him believe that he had succeeded; but new events in the cloister, and the continuing accusations of the possessed, soon led him to doubt his opinion again.

The confrontation with her accusers brought her to new confessions of ongoing misdeeds, and to repeated vows of improvement; on which occasion she, among other things, declared: how she would no longer be able to do harm if she were taken to another place. One doubted the truth of this statement; for in the meantime the nightly unrest would not subside, and indeed several voices were heard speaking with Renata at night on more than one occasion, and then, at a horn call, she rose up from them like a light cloud; moreover, since the voices of the possessed threatened her with death, and once even suddenly hacked in the outermost door of the place of her confinement with an axe that happened to be seized, it was believed necessary to agree to her removal from the cloister. The matter was therefore reported to the Prince-Bishop, and a request was made for the dispatch of a commission, so that this commission might examine Renata, and, according to the findings, order her safekeeping in Marienberg Castle. \

She alone stood obstinate; she did indeed confess the misdeeds that the spirits charged her with, but at the same time asserted: her time was not yet up; and when once all the possessed unanimously pressed in upon her to compel her to renounce the pact and hand over the magic root, she did deliver some herbs and men's hairs that she had managed to keep even in her dungeon; but at the same time, suspicious events were reported again.

Finally, the spirits had granted her, as the last period of grace, three more days; when these had passed, Renata suddenly collapsed in the presence of the possessed, as if struck by lightning, at the feet of the confessor---so that he thought her dead, and the spirits howled triumphantly. She came to herself again, however, and was now, while the possessed were handed over to medical care in Würzburg, brought in secular clothes to Castle Marienberg, and her trial immediately instituted. They disregarded it and did not stop. She was still seen at night, as she with others inflicted these torments; the hands and faces of the maltreated showed traces in the morning, and various objects were found in the beds, which had been dragged from other places in the monastery for this purpose. The possessed were alternately freed through the exorcisms and newly afflicted again; and the spirits continuously testified from them against Renata. She was therefore interrogated repeatedly, and since she persisted in her previous confessions and continuously admitted herself guilty of sorcery, she was finally declared forfeit of all spiritual privileges and immediately handed over to the secular courts: which, after a newly conducted investigation, condemned her according to the laws on sorcery to the fire; which the highest authority mitigated to the effect that she should first be executed with the sword. The judgment was executed on the sixth of February 1629; both at the announcement and at the execution, Renata remained calm and composed, and the external signs of repentance continued as before; but the spirits of the possessed interpreted this calm differently, and predicted certain circumstances of the execution.

That is the course of this wondrous story, as the most credible witnesses have communicated it. Many writings of the time have sharply criticized the severity of the judgment; but one could not help granting full justice to the calm, impartiality, and humanity with which the investigation was conducted from all sides. Every attempt at an interpretation that would exclude all demonic influences involves completely insoluble difficulties. The most immediate thing that offers itself to such an interpretation---the assumption of an unintentional self-deception among all involved---will least lead to the goal. Were all the possessed, the sick, Renata, the superiors, and the judges---the former insane, the latter accomplices---then scarcely any mark would remain by which one could then securely recognize the state of unaltered health. Renata and the possessed were obviously in opposite states; they are in self-contradicting tensions; and yet the one, when pressed into a corner, always confirms the statement of the others; they mutually respond to each other and complement each other in a certain alternating manner. Thus there is a kind of established harmony between their spheres, and it by no means suffices to assume a simple madness or a general delusion; but a world of madness must be assumed, which in the midst of denying its being yet affirms itself in its members; and in the most thorough dissonance yet, as it were against its will, remains subject to the law of harmony. The assumption of a fraud that crept in must drive into even greater confusions. Judges and superiors are beyond such an assumption, and among the other participants, suspicion and doubt do not know where to settle.

The only possibility might point to that Cäcilia who had stood as a special object of Renata's hatred; but precisely in this case the spirit does not testify against Renata as the immediate author of the evil that she had to endure; and the testimony that her superiors give regarding her disposition and conduct is incompatible with such a presupposition. But, even if allowed, it further demands, in order to become serviceable for explanation, the assumption of a continued understanding over many years with the other possessed, the sick and even the remaining convent sisters. All that raging, all those convulsions were either fabricated, and the physicians and other witnesses blind; or they were truly grounded in reality. \
