The events in the convent of Nazareth, where the incubus assumed the form of a definite person from whom the evil had originally proceeded, lead over into a realm where the drive makes use of artificial means to bind the lust to definite persons, or to make it impossible for others to practice the same. In ordinary life, where every personality stands round and closed and bounded, and repels everything that might thrust itself upon it by force, there are no other means of the kind than those in which the instincts to mutual sympathy are aroused; where then, in the play of spiritual and bodily elective affinities, the mutual process of appropriation is accomplished. But this drive, like the life that pours itself into it, is not of simple nature; it has indeed a simple element within it, but also a manifold one, and from the relation of the two depends its tension or its slackening in degree. It also dwells, like life itself, in an organic bearer, and this too is grasped in a much-divided unity and graded stepwise; this indwelling vital force manifests itself outward, and translates its intensity into the extensive.

The entire life complex thus has an outer bodily side, in which the entire vitality collects itself toward this side; and \[it has\] toward the outside a limited, extensive sphere of action, and an inner \[side\], through which the living element in it is connected with the soul-related, derives its power from it, and exerts a determinate, inwardly psychic effect. If all this, according to the measure of ordinary life, works together in an ordered sequence; then the inner act also reflects itself, in each of the sexes, in the outer \[relations\] between them, and the process runs its course in the usual, orderly track. But this order can be disturbed in a twofold manner: either through disordered influences that disturb the equilibrium in the organically bodily, so that it becomes protrusive in more or less degree; or through such \[influences\] that throw themselves more upon the inner spiritual side, and assign to it the preponderance. Both kinds will find their consideration in turn.

The way of building, through physical \[means\], thus also through those acting directly upon the bodily, a bridge to a foreign personality, has naturally been the first one upon which men hit. There it was soon found that there are substances which in such a way act specifically stimulating upon those organs, the aphrodisiacs; and others again which possess a depressing effect, thus appearing opposed to those. In the first case the life flame burns more strongly in the organ, its inner gradated strength increases, and its sphere of action expands. But the direction of the thus strengthened drive goes in general; there is no means to give it a determinate direction toward a particular person, if this one does not throw itself in its way.

In the other case the life breaking forth toward this side is held down, and its manifestations are dammed up, again against all and every one; so that thus the intended personality also finds itself only incidentally hit. Since now on the one hand it is aimed at the gaining, on the other hand at the denial of the coarser pleasure; since through the immoderate heightening of the drive that which is irresistible, which lies in the matter itself, is heightened almost to irresistibility, and the satisfaction in the positive case can only take place at the cost of life, but the paralysis in the other does not redound to its benefit; so the inevitable consequences of the use of these means are exhaustion, madness, and the drying up of all life sources. \

The physicians have made manifold experiences concerning these consequences, and Heer has one such, which we will here only mention in passing. To a fourteen-year-old youth, exhausted and thirsting through walking, a girl known to him had put such a philtrum into the beer; as, she said, above all suitable to lift the fatigue. The youth had drunk with greed, thereupon slept deeply the whole night; but found himself in the morning assailed by great weariness, so that he could scarcely drag himself home. A hemorrhage, through mouth and anus and urine, in superabundant quantity, occurred; ligatures were not able to staunch it. Only sympathetic means could staunch the blood flow, which however returned upon their abandonment; so that the tears which he wept were blood, and blood secreted itself in the ears. The former means indeed stilled the blood, but the young man became more and more enfeebled; so that at last he was held for dead, and as a corpse, sewn into a cloth, laid aside.

He came to himself, however, fell into excessive sweat, and finally a thumb-thick crust formed over his entire body, which compelled him to stand for six days and nights on a pole until the rash had dried up, and life, at such a price, had expelled the intruded harmfulness once more.

Kircher tells: A youth noticed that, whenever he visited a spot in his garden, distinguished equally by its greenery as by the freshness of its shade, he was each time moved by a violent impulse to lust; so that it seemed as if he had been seized by satyriasis. It happened once, however, that he confided this strange matter to the apothecary Heinrich Corvinus in intimate conversation. The latter, having formed a suspicion about the cause of the affair, had himself led to the spot; and found it entirely overgrown with satyrium, belonging to a particular species. After this discovery, it was easy for him to explain the cause of the violent symptom; since the plant excites many merely when they carry it in their hands.

We have seen above, from the confessions of the Bavent, how the same thing happened to her: when she came near the place on the churchyard where Picard, making use of her finger, had buried drops of her menstruation caught in the host. One may make every allowance for her imagination in this, but the event undeniably shows that the buried thing had acted just like the satyrium above, and that this effect could not be a direct physical one: that here too her nature had inverted itself, and that, in her inner being turning outward, she had acquired excitability for stimuli which otherwise pass unnoticed by the ordinary person. She had entered a realm where sympathy and attraction do not stand in inverse proportion to the distances; but where spirits and things draw toward or flee from one another, without regard to remoteness, solely according to the relation of their inner gradated tensions. As here the spatial dimensions are without significance, so too do the physical qualities in themselves lose their own, and count only as signs of inner spiritual qualities.

The same occurs in the deeper circle, where the sympathetic cures find their place; a region which, despite much superstition that has mingled in it, yet likewise has a foundation of undeniable truth within itself. All philtres in this circle are therefore of a symbolic kind; so that nature provides only the outer shell, while the truly inner effective part forms the higher core of the matter. The enjoyment to which these symbolic entwinements lead can therefore likewise be only of a symbolic kind. It occurs therefore only in the vision, which, from its originally merely potential meaning, completes itself in the radically evil, and realizes itself as a demonic one. \

What the poetic legend knows to tell of the green candle, which, when lit, leads the beloved through night and fog to the lover---that can never happen in ordinary life in flesh and bone; but rather in the spirit, in visionary phantasmagoria, or in demonic reality. All those vincula directed against the drive therefore draw, in their ultimate effect, toward the Sabbath; directly connecting a relation with its Lord, they lead into the harem of the Grand Master of all incubi and succubi. Indirectly, however, only uniting the sexes, either crosswise in the dissimilar or even straight across in the similar, and seeking the union then only in the radically evil---from this proceeds the mingling of sorcerers and sorceresses in the synagogue,³ where those philtres are applied on both sides, and therefore also appear doubled in their efficacy.

The ordinary Incubus and Succubus is merely the domestic Sabbath, and the private worship; just as the pharmacy of those symbolic philters is only the orgies of this common Sabbath, under the protection of the Penates, in the house-sanctuary of the demon, celebrated privately. Already Jerome tells us in the Life of the holy. A connection, which, by the way, is not viewed there with too favorable an eye; for when Brognoli questioned that Manichaean sorcerer, of whom we spoke much earlier, he blushed: the demons sought to prevent it. But to mix with demons is the greatest merit, a distinguished virtue, and a work most worthy of all praise, since they themselves are angelic spirits, by nature most noble and most illustrious.

Hilarion tells of such a case: where a lover, on the advice of the priests of Asclepius, made use of such a bond, and the girl became raving mad with love over it. Another case, reported by Brognoli, gives us insight into the progress of the evil, once it has taken root. In Venice, the seventeen-year-old daughter of a merchant was greatly loved by her father's servant, who, in order to gain possession of her, resorted to a sorcerer, who struck her with the maleficium of love. She suddenly began to scream one night: "I will die if I cannot sleep with this one." The elders ran to her, and were astonished at the girl's words, who otherwise was distinguished by modesty. But the demon, who possessed her maid, betrayed the perpetrator, who immediately fled.

The next morning I was called, and questioned the girl: whether she had spoken those words with full intent? She replied: how suddenly she had found her heart inflamed with love toward the servant; fantasy and imagination had been clouded, the understanding beclouded, the will urged on by repeated and pressing demands. At the same time, she had been inwardly, by a violent impulse of lust toward coitus, also against her will, driven; so that she could not refrain from crying out those words. She was healed by the use of spiritual means.

The above-indicated origin of the whole condition gives us insight: why with its development, related symptoms of demonic possession often emerge as well. For example, the aversion to all things spiritual, as it showed itself in that Johann Hilpat, the servant of a nobleman. He had received and eaten from his master's maid or cook cakes, into which such a philter had been baked. For four days he felt nothing, but on the fifth he began to delirious, to rage, to speak all manner of absurd things; suffered from persistent insomnia; imagined that he was in the power of the devil, and could not endure the presence of the local pastor, at whose sight he broke out in sweat from fear. \

Likewise, in the neighboring domains of these realms, the magical emissions often occur. In the year 1589, there lived in Genoa a youth, who was otherwise well-formed, who suddenly burned with such fierce love toward a woman that he forgot God, and devoted himself only to this his passion. For three months, secret meetings and love letters were exchanged back and forth, until finally the youth fell ill with a violent sickness. Then it was astonishing, what and how manifold filth he spewed from himself in the presence of many witnesses: women's hair, egg shells, cotton, hair and straight pins, nail clippings and bone fragments, various iron scraps in no small number, all mixed with blood. One of the clerics, a Jesuit, exhorted him: that he should no longer allow himself to be bound by such a pernicious love affair; and finally questioned him, whether he perhaps possessed any belongings or letters from her? He confessed: that he had indeed received letters, but had torn them up.

The clergyman gave no credence to this assertion, and advised his own people to make search in his cabinets; and if they should find anything relating to the love affair, to take it away. As this matter became known to the patient through a secret voice, he demanded the key of the cabinet with terrible outcry: and when he had obtained it, he brought the same, at the exhortation of that same voice, to his mouth, to swallow it, if he had not been prevented therefrom. He then laid it under his pillow, and now lost the light of his eyes. The mother exhorted him that he, now made wise by experience, should give back the key. He therefore sought after it; but as he could not find it, he believed that it had been stolen from him; and he now began to scream and lament even more violently, as he searched the whole bed for it. Meanwhile, the cabinet had been broken open by force, and as two love letters were found in it, they were consigned to the flames; whereupon he immediately recovered the use of his sight, and saw the key lying before his eyes with astonishment. He now began to heal, both in body and soul, and was soon entirely restored as before.

A case of this kind, of a poisoning turned inward through a philtre, which obtained a judicial investigation, is that which befell Maria Elisabeth de Ranfain, the daughter of a respectable house, of great beauty and even greater holiness, around the year 1622. Her parents had forced her into marriage, but after a few years her husband had died; a physician, Poiret, had now cast a violent passion upon her, and had given her such a philtre. She had felt its effect, but had suppressed it with prayers, tears, and vows. Poiret had now managed to administer a second one to her; various ills had thereupon afflicted her, and her parents had compelled her to send for Poiret; but as she distrusted him, she had dismissed him again. \

This drove the physician out of his senses with rage; but Elisabeth soon fell into unnatural states. One half of her body showed itself stiffened in frost, and without sensation; while the other was in such violent agitations that, notwithstanding the delicacy of her constitution, four of the strongest persons could scarcely hold her. Now one saw her head (in the sutures of the skull) open itself, then close again to the astonishment of those present; while at another time it swelled up in a monstrous manner. The matter caused a sensation; the physician and his adherents spread about that it was all natural effects; consequences of the patient's cunning and confused imagination. Her bishop therefore had her brought to Nancy; six of the most renowned physicians of the city were called in; they examined the matter thoroughly, and at last gave their unanimous testimony to this effect: among the various symptoms of this illness there were some which could only take their origin in a principle foreign to nature.

The most insightful clergymen were now consulted by the bishop, and several respected bishops took part when the exorcism was applied. All declared unanimously: the patient was possessed by evil spirits, and only audacity could deny this truth. In fact, she was hurled into the heights with such violence that six persons could scarcely hold her down. She climbed in the trees, from branch to branch, with the ease of the nimblest animals. One saw her, entirely lifted into the air, turning herself about in a wondrous manner.

She fulfilled everything that was commanded unto her in the Italian, German, Latin, Greek, and Hebrew tongues, as we have already heard elsewhere; she read a sealed Latin letter, and pointed out the error of an omitted letter. Countless witnesses were present at all these proceedings. The clamor roundabout grew ever greater, the spirits of the sick testified continually against Poiret; this man at last made preparations for flight, whereupon Heinrich II of Lorraine, otherwise a mild regent, caused him to be arrested, and his trial to be instituted. The greatest caution and circumspection were observed in the matter. Magistrates, whom he had requested from France, joined with the natives to form a tribunal of ninety-four judges.

The accused found defenders; a doctor of theology wrote a book in his favor; a princess expended great sums for his liberation, and the Infanta of the Netherlands wrote on his account unto the Duke. The woman was not spared: she was accused of a hypocrisy at which the most shrewd wits would come to shame; whereupon her two daughters were also arrested, and she herself shut up on water and bread. All who took her part were slandered. A prince of Lorraine, who was a bishop, was to feed her secretly in his palace with dainties. What she did and said was twisted to the worst sense, she herself overwhelmed with every sort of indignity; her letters were broken open, and men wrote at their pleasure whatsoever they would into them; unknown persons pursued her with loaded pistols, but were disarmed in the decisive moment by a secret terror. In the morning rope ladders were found at her window, and footprints in the sand, and she was poisoned several times; a reward of a thousand pistoles, it was said, had been promised to whoever would kill her. \

She therefore had to be guarded by watches. The prosecution meanwhile watched over her; the slanderous writings that were spread against her were refuted by the most thorough investigation of every action of her life; the exorcisms that the Duchess had instituted were at last continued at the instigation of the Bishop. The trial proceeded quietly on its course, and after the investigation had reached its goal, the 24 judges unanimously agreed upon the death sentence for Poiret. His friends managed to prevent the execution; the Sovereign ordered a new revision, with the same result; the judgment had to be carried out on April 1, 1622, and he died without showing any sign of remorse. After his death, God willed, for the justification of the judges, that Anna Bouley, the companion in all his crimes, should be arrested in Paris with all her magical documents and brought to Nancy. In the remorse that seized her, she confessed her crimes and gave all testimonies of her sorceries.

The judges, on their side, not relying on her statement alone, conducted all necessary inquiries; and finally condemned her to death, which was just as edifying as Poiret's had been terrible. Several who had engaged in the same wicked practices were deterred by these events; some apostates returned to the bosom of the Church, and the court and nobility visibly improved their morals.¹ How the folk legend, however, takes the matter, shows itself in an amusing way in the following tale. My lecturer, P. Syn. Lupus, author of the Commentary on the reserved cases of Bergamo, and on the Edict of St. Ing., told me how he had known three men from Bergamo, followers of the priest Simon, who was notorious throughout Lombardy as a magician, and who had agreed among themselves: to demand from the demon a thousand gold pieces for each, and in addition, for all in common, the enjoyment of a beautiful girl.

Accordingly, they invoked the demon, who appeared to them and promised to perform everything if they would surrender their souls to him. They were, however, first to procure some hairs from the girl and lay them on an altar in the forest, near the girl's house; where they were then to sacrifice them to him with incense and worship him as God. They pledged their souls to the demon and then went to the girl's house to ask her for some of her hairs. She refused for a time; but then pretended to consent and cut some hairs from the cow in the stable, which she handed over to them as her own. Immediately they built the altar, put on mass vestments, lit coals in the censer, and invoked the demon, who soon appeared and laid the thousand gold pieces for each upon the altar. But now the cow suddenly broke out of the stable, rushed into the forest; and attacking the magicians with horns and teeth, and leaping upon them with her legs, wounded one after the other, destroyed the altar, and overturned the candlesticks and everything. The people came running up, found the magicians thus badly beaten, and brought them before the Inquisitor; who had them seized, investigated their case, and sent them to the galleys. \

As for knot-tying at last, Bodin reports the following on that subject. When I was in 1567 at Poitiers, serving as substitute for the royal prosecutor at the great assizes, it happened that several gentlemen were accused before me. When I had now returned home and explained to my landlady the lawsuit in question, just as it had actually occurred---she being a respectable and well-regarded woman---she in turn recounted, as a highly experienced woman in matters of such arts, in the presence of the secretary Jakob von Beauvais, the following. First, that there were fully fifty kinds and manners of nestelknüpfen; one, by which one could bind a husband alone. The other, by which one could prevent begetting alone.

There would also be another kind whereby one loved the other, to be sure, but nothing was forbidden to it in the utmost degree; and another whereby they loved one another most fervently, but when they were to see one another, they would horribly scratch and strike each other. Of such a story it had been told in Toulouse concerning a couple who thus stood together for three years, then without having begotten children with one another. Moreover, the woman said that one could most easily hold back the man with it; indeed, one could hold him bound in impotence for a day, for a year, for all his lifetime, at least so long as the nestel remained entwined.

There would be people who could be entwined only for begetting, not for mingling; some for whom it would be impossible to effect the entwinement; others who would be susceptible to the matter only before marriage, not after it. She also recounted that one could knot people's urine, which she called nailing shut, from which many of them would then have to die. The aforementioned landlady of ours also told us all the particular sayings and words that belonged to each entwinement; which knotting spells were yet so indistinct and incomprehensibly twisted that neither a Greek, a Hebrew, a Latinist, nor anyone of the more recent nations could have understood them.

Piraitins in his eighth eclogue claims that one should make nine knots; she, however, knew only of one, and indicated of what leather and what color the knotting nestel must be. And since such things had become very ingrained and common in the land of Poitou, in the year 1560 the criminal judge at Niort, on the mere accusation of a young bride who for that reason sued her neighbor that she had knotted her bridegroom, threw the same into a dark tower and threatened her that he would not release her from this prison for her whole life unless she unbound the knotted man. Thereupon the prisoner, two days later, had summoned the young married couple to try it again. As soon as the judge had learned that the entwined ones were rid of the magic bond, he had released the binder and loosener freely again. \

It lies on the hand that all the nonsense of formulas and manipulations which those fifty different kinds of nestelknüpfen possessed could do the least bit over a healthy, sound, unharmed nature. On the other hand, the time was not so unbelievably stupid and foolish that it would have employed all its wit on the devising of so many different methods if nothing at all corresponding to the intent had come out of it; and not fearful enough to fill the courts with its complaints if these had had no ground at all. One must therefore presuppose that the evil in that time, which had not yet long seen the syphilitic ills arise, had been epidemic; on which the circumstance in that narrative also points: that many showed themselves not at all susceptible, or only under certain conditions, to the entwinement. Those were the healthy ones, and therefore the untouchables; the unhealthy ones, far more frequent than perhaps now, provided a multitude of variations in which chance found a rich field to play its game.

If the evil was then of a nervous kind, it formed connections with other natures, perhaps of an opposite nature; those, once recognized and incorporated into a secret practice, made this side easily vulnerable: so that the evil, through transmission and transference, could easily propagate itself, and this partial possession appeared only as a part of the likewise transmissible general one.

##### iii. The Demonic Bloodlust

Closely akin to the lust of generation, and forming its reverse side, stands the lust of murder opposite it; both awaken a blood-rage, which in the one passes only from the lifeless into life, in the other from life into death. Both can thus cut into the human being in like manner as corrosive forces; both, driven to an extreme, will be capable of polarizing him inwardly; and as now the drives, thus crowded together toward certain poles, grow in their swiftness and energy, they will fight more and more against the dominion of the will; and finally, when the corrosion has advanced to the core, they will entirely withdraw themselves from its power; and as they, in their irresistibility, now drive their body-servant from horror to horror, they at last also bring about the obsession.

What the sexual fury can accomplish in this way, we have just seen; we still have to consider what cruelty can achieve; and after the deeds of Asmodeus have passed before us, we must also turn our attention to him who, among the erotes, called himself Behemoth. Facts that mark the stations of this path lie in abundance in the records of the courts of justice; they are too well known for us to need to enter into them more closely. When in the carriage era a young beautiful woman of good birth, the Countess of Brinvilliers, is seized by such a fury; and now, without any ground of hatred, poisons relatives, friends, and the household staff, and even visits the hospitals to poison the sick: then that otherwise sealed wellspring has opened in her depths; and she has now begun, with that cold, unstoppable fury that seizes the marten when it strangles everything living around it, to murder. \

The deep physical ground underlying this raging also reveals itself in this: that this evil, once it has emerged decisively in an individual, becomes easily infectious and seizes the masses; as everyone recalls from Roman history, when that epidemic raged among the Roman women; the berserker fury of the North took no other origin. People nowadays are accustomed to classify such things uniformly under the great rubric of madness and derangement; and it cannot be denied that, insofar as every extreme can only arise from a derangement of the usual relations, a derangement indeed lies at its base. But the actions that proceed from such a displacement are not empty deliriums; they are recognized as punishable because they are carried out with full consciousness, leading over into an objective world of their own, to which they belong; a world which, like the one in which they arise, is indeed likewise an extreme one, but which also, like the actors themselves, connects itself with the usual one. Reaching over into the evil order, they also take up influences from it; and as they appear in themselves, through the direction and aim of their activity, to be of a demonic nature; so do they lead from step to step deeper into the demonic world; so that what was at the beginning only an overpowering by the affect becomes at the end an overpowering by the demon. That this is so can already be proven by the case where the attacks, directed against a saint, were led to their goal most swiftly through retribution.

So slays Leopardus the hermit Ehoarn in Brittany in 1024, and is forthwith seized by the evil spirit. For twenty years thereafter he wanders about, naked in winter as in summer. If someone gives him a garment, he does not budge from the spot until he has torn it to shreds. Wool or linen he unravels, fur he tears into small pieces. In this case what happens suddenly and as punishment, hurling him out of his course, in others unfolds gradually; and the raving natural instinct, the natural evil, passes without discernible transition into the ethically demonic evil.

A striking example of this kind of progression, on a path leading swiftly downward, is Gilles de Laval, called de Rais, Marshal of France; who, of noble descent---from the houses of Laval, Roncy, Montmorency, Rais, and Craon---inherited vast estates; increased these still further through marriage with Catherine of Thouars; and thus became one of the richest landowners in the land, distinguishing himself not a little in the wars against the English at that time. At twenty years of age he had succeeded his father, and forthwith began a senseless extravagance. He maintained a guard of 200 men on horseback; a chapel of 25--30 persons; choirboys, musicians, chaplains had to follow him, along with a great number of other servants, everywhere on horseback, and for them, as for others, he always kept open table. Rich silver vessels, costly garments of gold brocade belonged to this chapel; a portable organ had to accompany the procession everywhere; his chaplains were called, as at cathedrals, deans, singers, archdeacons, scholasters, and one among them bore the title of bishop. \

They were clothed in scarlet with ermine, had rich stipends, and he had several times petitioned the Pope for miters for them. At the same time he had mystery plays performed at great expense, or rather mysteries, as they were called then. He soon found those who fostered and encouraged his lusts in every way; besides many of lower rank, especially Gilles de Sillé and Roger de Briqueville. To cover his enormous expenditures, he naturally had to squander his estates below their value; and not one would have remained to him had not his relatives taken the matter in hand, procuring a royal prohibition against selling any further possession, and a prohibition from Parliament against anyone purchasing any. In this predicament he sought help from chemistry, which was to provide him the philosophers' stone; adepts soon appeared to him: quicksilver had already been fixed, but the philosophical egg broke before it could be hatched. He now sought help from the one reputed to be the possessor of all hidden treasures.

Trusted agents of this master also came to him; a physician from Poitou drew his circles in the forest; the Black One, as he said, had passed by him in the shape of a leopard; that he had remained silent was due to a fault in his preparations. He wished to return home to investigate more thoroughly; richly rewarded, he departed and did not return. A Florentine, Francesco Prelati, great alchemist and magician, took his place; and made use of a book from the Marshal's library. Later in prison he confessed how he had several times seen the demon in the shape of a young man of twenty years, who called himself Baron; how once he had given him a black powder with the command to carry it to the Marshal; and how on another occasion he had shown him a quantity of gold bars, which afterward proved to be merely a heap of sand and a yellowish earth. The Marshal on his side had made a contract in his own blood, in which he promised to give the demon everything he demanded of him, except his life and his soul.

He had worshiped him for this purpose, offering him sacrifices, incense, alms, and a feast arranged in his honor; and he sealed all this by immediately offering him, as a token of allegiance, the heart, the hand, the eyes, and the blood of a child. Now an old woman was noticed, who roamed about the country and the heathens, approaching the little children who tended the livestock or ran about begging, and flattering them, while always keeping her face half covered with a heavy cloth. She thus lured them to the castle of Raiz, where they then vanished without a trace. At first it was only peasant children and homeless ones who thus perished; but soon, with growing boldness, the city children too came in turn, even as far as Nantes.

Bodin recounts on p. 249, probably from the records: after the werewolf had in this manner slaughtered eight children for the devil, he at last also promised the ninth, his own, and indeed while still in its mother's womb, to kill it for him as a pleasing sacrifice by opening the same. Yet he did not attain to familiar intercourse with him face to face, and he was wont to say: the Unknown must be a common fellow, that he should shrink from associating with persons of rank. This speech of his, now, the sign of the cross that he perhaps made upon entering the circle; or the prayer that he always spoke, especially his Alma Redemptoris Mater; his attachment to the chapel that surrounded him; the secret resolve that he cherished, to atone in the end by a crusade---these were the reasons that his entourage adduced for why no such relation would come about. \

Raiz meanwhile surrendered himself to the most shameful lusts that the imagination can possibly conceive; and so had the bloodthirst in him united itself with this lust, that the unhappy victims of his brutality acquired a true charm for him only in the moment of their death, and out of grim lust he continued what he had begun in despair. He himself killed his unhappy victims with his own hand; their cries, their rattling, their convulsions delighted him, as he strove to increase and prolong them, and to enjoy this lust all the more closely, he would seat himself upon the dying ones. In the tower of Chantocé a whole barrel full of calcined bones of children was found, whose number was estimated at forty, all of whom this Moloch had burned in his glowing arms. According to his own confession, the number of those whom he had thus sacrificed there and in the castle of Machecoul amounted to a hundred; others were found in the privies of Suze, likewise in Nantes, Vannes; so that the total number was estimated at 150.

They were all sacrificed to the demons Barron, Orient, Beelzebub, Satan, and Belial, while the office of Easter Day was sung to them. Soon after Easter, when he had anew vowed a journey to the Holy Land, but immediately thereafter in Nantes had again defiled himself with the same abominations; he was at last, on the order of the Duke, together with Prelat and some others, arrested. The accusation was brought by the procurator of the Duke, and the promoter of the Bishop of Nantes; six or seven family fathers, whose children had gone to the Marshal and not returned, were likewise complainants. The trial was conducted in the new tower of Nantes, before the Chancellor of Brittany, the Bishop of the place, and the Inquisitor of the kingdom, Jean Merri, on charges of heresy, sorcery, sodomy, and so forth; but before Peter of l'Hôpital, the President, in regard to all that pertained to his competence. He was at first very bold in confronting these; he said: he would rather be hanged by his neck than give account to the clergy, who were all stained with simony and shameful deeds. He knew the faith as well as they, and he wondered that the President should allow them to meddle in such processes.

He became, however, soon more pliable, and the censors of the church made him confess a part of his shameful deeds; the fear of torture accomplished the rest. He was confronted with Prelati, and the confessions proved Marshal, under tears and sobs, to him: Farewell, Franz, my friend! We shall never see each other again in this world. I beseech God that He may grant you patience and understanding. Be assured that, if you have good patience and hope in God, we shall see each other again in the great joys of Paradise. Pray to God for me, I shall pray for you! On the following day he confessed in public audience all his crimes, and how he had committed an uncountable multitude of other horrors; but he attributed everything to the bad guidance he had received in his youth, which had known no rule but his will and his pleasure.

On the 25th of October 1440 his judgment was read to him, he was thereupon handed over to the confessor; a procession was held for him, that God might grant him patience, and he was then delivered to the flames on the Magdalene meadow; yet, on account of his repentance, he was buried after his death in consecrated ground. \

Similar horrors have also occurred elsewhere, and especially children have become the victims of such abominations. In Nider's time the rumor went around in the Bernese region that 13 children had disappeared there in a short space of time. The justice authorities therefore became attentive, and one woman, who had been taken into custody on account of her suspiciousness, confessed: how she especially stole unbaptized children, then boiled them until the flesh became like a jelly; from their firmer parts she then prepared her ointments, while the more fluid part served at the initiations, and made those who were received immediately clairvoyant. One man, named Stadelin, from Boltingen, in the territory of Lausanne, confessed: how he had seen children in a house even killed in their mother's womb, so that it always came to abortion.

A woman from Thann, in Alsace, made the following confession to the Sprenger: she had, as a midwife, brought many children into the light of day, then, lifting them into the air, had offered them to the demon; but thereupon had immediately pressed a large needle into their head, from which they then died without the wound bleeding. If the dead ones had then been buried, she had dug them up again at night-time, had them roasted in the oven, thereupon had eaten the flesh, but had preserved the fat for other uses. Her confession amounted to forty children whom she had thus killed. Another one, who once, going out of the city gate, accidentally lost the arm of a child, was thereby discovered; and now confessed that she had murdered children without number in a similar manner.

Joh. Müller of Wellferdingen had, as Remy relates, a one-year-old child, his only joy and consolation. Three women, Agathina of Pittelingen, Anna of Melzingen, and Mageta of Hochit, stole this darling of his from the cradle; brought him to a neighboring high mountain, called the Gyse, kindled a fire there, laid the child on the embers, and burned it to powder. They now gathered the ashes with all diligence, moistened them with the dew from the grass and the ears of grain, and made a dough from it, which they afterwards sprinkled over the vines and fruit trees to destroy them. Bernhard's wife killed, chopped up, and roasted the fruit of her own body, and in the same way other corpses were also burned to ashes; and from the powder a drink was then prepared, which, on account of its bad taste, was still mixed with other plant remedies. Whoever drank of it was doomed to death.

One sees in this procedure that from the burned animal substance a Prussian blue acid developed, which then combined with the potash of the ash, and in the drink, released by additions, immediately acted deadly. In the form of an ointment, the same substance could then also probably become deadly already through mere touch. Thus it had been observed in Gazal in Piedmont that wherever a certain Androgina had entered other people's houses, the inhabitants of the same immediately died. \

She was arrested, and confessed: how forty of them in number had concluded a conspiracy, and now anointed the door handles to make the inhabitants die. This happened in the year 1536; in Genoa the same occurred in the year 1562. The convent in Yssel in the Netherlands, in which Marie von Sains lived, was full of obsessions and maleficia, but no suspicion had fallen on her; for one held her to be a saint without equal, until she, driven by a secret power, declared herself to be a sorceress, and was now arrested by the official of Tournay. But it still took another year and a half until she finally, in the year 1613, made the more detailed confessions about her misdeeds, which first of all ran thus: that all the maleficia of the convent had really been instigated by her. Then she also made confessions about her murders. She confessed: how she had murdered many children, or disemboweled them alive, in order to sacrifice them to the devil. Others she had strangled, the still-beating hearts of still others she had crushed and eaten with her teeth, especially those born of Christian parents. Many of these children, she said, I have secretly strangled in this city and the neighboring places, and then exhumed the buried ones, and carried them to our nocturnal gatherings. To many I have thus given death, or removed them from the way with poison that the demons supplied to me; others I have pulled the hair from, still others I have pierced the heart or the temple with a needle; which were thrown into the fire oven, others drowned, still others roasted on a spit, boiled in pots, thrown into the latrines, laid on burning pyres, thrown to lions, snakes, and other wild animals for food. Some were hanged by the feet, with the arms or by the neck, others also by the genitals; to some I have smashed the skull against the wall, flayed them and cut them up as if for salting; still others I have placed under presses, tied them to dogs, and thus let them be torn apart; or I have hanged them on the cross to the shame of the Savior, and to all this I then made use of these words: In mockery of the Creator I bring you, Lucifer and Beelzebub, and the whole assembly of demons, the body and soul and every limb of this child as an offering. The Archbishop of Mecheln, who was present at these confessions, declared: In the seventy years of my life I have seen and heard much, since I began to reflect; but nothing have I ever heard or understood that could compare to this; the crimes and abominations of this girl, Maria von Sains, seem to me to go beyond everything that is conceivable.

Before we share in this astonishment, we must first establish the viewpoint under which we have to take up these events; their visible exaggeration gives the closer consideration the invitation. One must assume that the interrogators had the human understanding to have a part of these alleged victims named to them, and then inquired whether they had really died at that time; because otherwise they would have been most grossly deceived by a web of fantastical imaginings. A number of these children had thus been snatched away; the sorceress had taken the instigation to their death upon herself, and the question is, what share in it can really be ascribed to her? \

Her cloister had the enclosure, and she could reach the deathbeds and graves of these children only through remote action in ecstasy. She had thrown a part of the stolen ones, as she said, to the lions, snakes, and other beasts. But her cloister maintained no menagerie; these beasts therefore belonged to the Sabbath's collection of animals; there, where the toads also go to pasture. There, too, the crosses had been erected, the pyres piled high, and the ovens heated, which formed the apparatus of her atrocities; and there she had blasphemed the Lord, His mother, and other saints who appeared to her to lead her back to a better path, had pelted them with filth, struck them, and even wounded herself.

All this, therefore, had occurred in the vision; she stood then as the members of the Sabbath are wont to do, her back turned to the demon, her head inverted downward; and since the logical order of her concepts had now been turned upside down, her will too must have been entirely perverted; and as the demonic influences entered into this perversion, those monstrous forms were called forth within her. Her will had become bestialized, and now brooded shapes similar to those that a tiger, locked behind iron bars, might behold in its dreams. It was punishable before the inner judge, because it had consented fully to these deeds; and it itself, whatever fate and blind impulse had been at work in the matter, had previously assumed them with good conscience. The deed by which she alone fell to the worldly court was otherwise constituted. To remote action is also added remote vision; and she recognized the nearness to death in the state of those whom she had chosen for her sacrificial victims.

Against them she had directed the intention of her will, in order thereby to wrest the inevitable death---the work of an organic necessity---over into the realm of freedom, and to make it there her own work. Although such influences and intentions, especially in the moment of death when everyone becomes clairvoyant, and thus a corresponding receptivity is joined to them, are by no means entirely indifferent; yet it is in no way to be believed that it succeeded for her according to her intent. For even without taking the ecclesiastical into account, a protection against such attacks must already lie in nature itself; and she will know how to preserve her law against the intrusion of such brazen caprice. She was therefore a criminal in the realm of the spirit, but the visible deed did not fully correspond to the intent; because the power does not expand evenly with the wicked willing, and the execution must therefore always lag behind the design. Not the depth and the extent of the most atrocious doing can therefore claim our wonder here; but rather the frenzy, to which the demonic ecstasy raises and sharpens the slumbering murderous drive in man, will rightly lay claim to our astonishment.

#### C. The Palingenesis of the Demonized Life Toward the Outside

The life that has fallen into those downward-drawing whirlpools experiences changes that it perceives from within, or that also become bodily visible outward. It further enters into a different relation to the life-circles near to it; insofar as it acts upon them destructively, or, according to circumstances, apparently healingly. Finally, new relations also tie themselves between it and certain natural powers, upon which we must cast a glance, just as upon those other transformations.

##### i. The Demonic Metamorphosis

In a life, disrupted in the manner set forth, through demonic influences, a change in the general feeling of life corresponding to the assault it has undergone must also necessarily enter; because it is in the self. \

It seizes it every time as it finds it. But it finds itself through that influence, among others, also degraded, and brought down from the higher stage which it had previously occupied to a lower one. But man, originally the lord of the animal creation, has, through the Fall, drawn closer to it, become its tyrant; and every further descent will thus take place on this well-trodden path, first into these natural realms standing closest to him, and the sinking man will find himself more and more resembling the natural productions there. But most rapidly and thoroughly, however, is this sinking brought about through those demonic connections; with equal rapidity and in an equally deep plunge will this assimilation also follow; and the common sense, finding the imprinted form within itself, will bring it to intuition. Thus the metamorphosis into animal form, which we encounter in the natural domain as a disease, in the wake of a similar disruption wrought by the forces of nature, will also return here in the demonic realm; as one of the forms in which the demonic influence manifests itself.

To now obtain the distinguishing characteristics of this new form, we must first place before our eyes the facts that pertain to it. Passing over the manifold hearsay, of which there is plenty here as everywhere, and setting aside all impure reports; we hold to two main facts, both of which, but especially the second in sequence, clearly and purely ascertained, are fully sufficient to orient us as to what we should think of the whole matter.

The first factual report is contained in the confession that Peter Bourgot, called the great Peter, and Michael Verdung, made before the inquisitor and the prior Bom in Poligny, in the diocese of Besançon, and before many witnesses in the year 1521, when he was accused of maleficia; which Wier has communicated in extract from the original. Peter testified as follows: how, nineteen years before, at the time of the fair in Poligny, the most violent downpour had so scattered the herd he was tending that he did not know how he should find them again; and how, while searching for the cattle, he met and saw three black riders. The last among these, on being asked what drove him, after he had complained of his distress to him, bade him be of good courage, and promised him: if he would give himself over to him, he would give him a master who would assist him so that henceforth he would suffer no damage to his herd from wolf or any other beast, or from any other source. In confirmation of what was said, he promised him the recovery of all the cattle now lost, and in addition money.

He had accepted the condition, and had said he would present himself at the same place in 4--5 days. Since the cattle had indeed been found, he had also returned to his rider on the third day, who asked him whether he really wished to surrender himself to him. On the question from his side, who then he might be, he had replied: The servant of the great prince of hell; but fear not on that account! They had now concluded an agreement together, renouncing the Christian faith; whereupon he had offered him his left, black, and cold hand to kiss; but he had now knelt before him, and had greeted him---who later called himself Moyse, and forbade him all church attendance---as his lord. \

One day, while they were again with the herd, a wild animal had thrown itself upon her, seizing her by her clothing at the right hip and tearing it; whereupon she had struck at it with her stick. The animal had been thicker and smaller than a wolf, had also had a smaller head, along with brown hair and a small tail. The third witness, Jeanne Gaboriant, 18 years old, reported on various things he had said. He was somewhat dull-witted, yet not so much that he would have been senseless on that account, and he carried out quickly what the good Carmelites, who had taken charge of him with love, commanded him. He showed little spirit, and struggled with things that required only plain human understanding; like one who had always spent his time with the herds, and seen nothing of the world. He made no secret of the fact that he had been a werewolf, and that he had run across the land on the command of the forest lord; and he only said that this was not shameful to him, since he had ceased to be such. But he also confessed without concealment: that he still felt a great lust within himself to eat the flesh of children; especially that of young girls was a delicacy.

To the question: whether he would perhaps still eat such things, if he were allowed? he answered honestly: Yes. Also the clergy told how they, in the beginning of his stay in the monastery, had sometimes seen him secretly devour the removed entrails of fish. He also once had a wondrous skill in going on all fours, and jumping over ditches like the animals. De Lancre remembered thereby another boy from Saint Pa, who had run as fast as a fleeing dog; knew how to turn around so swiftly that one scarcely noticed it, and sprang over the ditches like a gust of wind. Grenier also assured him: how he had had a wolf skin, which the lord had given him in the forest of Droilha, in the marquisate of FronSac, and which he had hidden on the roof of a barn in his village; yet he had not always brought it to him when he had let him run. His father had likewise made use of it, and on that account, and because he had let him grow up so badly, he expressed great aversion toward him; he also never wanted to see him, although he came to the monastery several times. In contrast, he had a quite special pleasure in seeing wolves, and this affection might well be mutual; since in his interrogations he had often testified: how he had always left the greater part of the prey to the accompanying wolves. His forest lord, moreover, he abhorred and cursed at that time, and said of him: how he had visited him still twice at the beginning of his stay in the monastery, which had frightened him greatly. He had promised him much money if he would serve him again; yet he had soon departed again, because he had more often made the sign of the cross against him; which he also still did now and then, so that he would not return. He died, moreover, still in the same year 1610, at the beginning of November, in a Christian manner under the care of the monastery clergy.

It is here two natures neglected from youth onward, and in shepherd life utterly feralized, who had become werewolves. In the one, and probably also in the other, the wolf nature already lies hidden; the black-bilious temperament inclined toward cruelty, the restriction of all higher mental faculties extending to blunt stupidity, the wild eye, the lust for human flesh, the sympathy with the wolves, and the skill in going on all fours, all point decisively to the predominance of a wildly rampaging, animal disposition; which required only a slight external impulse to turn into the werewolf. But this impulse came, and in that the physicians in the second case were by no means mistaken, not from nature, but from the will; for it is the Lord of the Forest who first brought about the condition. \

It has arisen from the homage paid to the demon within him; and the one paying homage is turned toward him in servitude through the kiss, which in the first case is given by him, in the other received, and is designated to him as a symbol with the mark. The demon now stands, as the object of his animal seeing, with necessity in his field of vision, and indeed in the form of the black ruler, who sends his herd of werewolves into the land, and whom the one sees unwaveringly before him as long as he remains in the condition; while the other rediscovers him when he has resumed his previous form. As in this way there is a rapport in the senses, so is the werewolf now also, as the servant of the Lord of the Forest, who grooms his horse for him, submissive and bound in will to his own; and he drives him forth to murder, ruin, and child-devouring. But life and life are also placed in rapport with one another in that cold kiss, and thereby it has become possible for the Lord of the Forest to arouse the wolf nature in the servant at any arbitrary time; so that it rises up against human nature, and holds it down during the duration of the condition.

It is thus a demonic, deliberately provoked intercourse that has here opened itself between the two; without thereby excluding the sickly condition that enters simultaneously, in which this state indeed roots physically and vitally. This dual nature of the affection shows itself precisely in this: that while the running, on the one hand as a lunar sickness, occurs in the waning moon and is bound to the time of day; on the other hand, in its demonic nature directed against the ecclesiastical, it also occurs on the eves of festivals and on the festivals themselves. The anointing too, in its effect, conditioned on the one hand by the powers of the substances entering into it, on the other hand by the resolve of the will, shows such a double nature, and thereby links the sickness with malice.

The ointment is twofold: the use of the one unleashes the wolf nature with all its drives, and the anointed one appears to himself in wolf form; the run begins with wild force, other wolves, driven by instinct, join the runner, and share the prey with him. The other binds again the unleashed beast, and the restored human finds himself weary and faint, with bloody extremities once more. But the community with the Lord of the Forest, and the use of the ointment, is a traditional matter. There already exists a fellowship into which the novice is received; an earlier member of it initiates him into it, one in whom the condition has already become habitual, and who therefore scarcely needs the ointment. But they also strangle these werewolves, and there arises the question: whether merely in appearance, or in reality? In the first case, the coincidence of their running with the stranglings has not been legally ascertained; in the second, however, it has been done with care, and the result speaks decisively for this concurrence, which has returned too often for it to be attributed to chance. \

Grenier ran thus truly, not merely in imagination; this is proven by the black, claw-like nails, the filed-down teeth, the appetite for human flesh even seven years thereafter, when he had long since ceased to run. He also truly attacked the designated children in wolf form; this is attested by the statements of those attacked, and even more by those who came running up, and whom one must assume knew how to distinguish a wolf from a human. The other question will thus be: how to explain the undeniable matter? And here the remote seeing connected with remote acting might offer itself as the nearest explanation; an explanation, however, which is neither justified nor refuted by the records. For to ground it factually, an observation would have to be at hand: where one sees him enter the state, and remaining present as a human in the same place, but at the same time seen elsewhere as a werewolf; such an experience is, however, in no way given here.

It will thus be safer for the present to assume the wolf skin, of which he constantly spoke up to the end, as cooperating therein, even though it was not found. He was of small stature as a youth, and as a boy in his stuntedness probably even more dwarfish; and with his ability to run on all fours, a donned wolf skin might easily have given him the appearance of a wolf; all the more so, since the fury of the attack and the terror of those attacked did not permit too sharp an observation. The manner of this attack, less with the paws than with the teeth; and the shedding of the clothes, which fell off without the undressed ones knowing how it happened to them, do not deny the human who makes use of his hands. There also appear in the process of another werewolf testimonies that one believed to recognize hands and feet, after human fashion, on him.

Corresponding to the outer form was then the inner wolf nature aroused to fury, and it was the demon who made use of this ecstatic raging one, as his instrument for working evil. Thus the acceptance of the facts and the sharp looking here, as everywhere, leads to the track of the true truth; while the unconditional denying deceives itself about it, and the all too great credulity gains only one falsified by error. There lie, however, also other examples at hand, in which the wolf running again coincides with the Sabbath vision. A woman rabid for wolves anoints herself with her ointment on head, neck, armpits, and other limbs, in the presence of the magistrate of her place, who had promised her life if she would perform a proof of her art before him. She falls down, and is seized by a deep sleep. After three hours she awakens suddenly again, stands up, and asks: where she has been in the meantime? She replies: how she, transformed into a wolf, near a city several miles distant from there, first tore apart a sheep and then a cow. Lerchheimer on his side recounts: I once went with a church servant, my good friend, to the house of a land bailiff, who held a werewolf captive, as such people are called. He had him brought for us, so that we might converse with him and inquire what sort of business it was with these people. The man behaved like a madman, laughed, hopped about, as if he came not from a tower but from a life of ease. Besides much other devilish deception and specter, he confessed: that on Easter night he had been at home with his household in wolf form; which place was more than twenty miles away, and a river between, twice as wide as the Rhine at Cologne. We asked: How did you get over the water? I flew over it. How did you get out of the prison? I pulled my feet out of the stocks, and flew out the window. What didst thou among thine own? I went about and beheld how they lay and slept. Why didst thou return to the prison? I had to, my master would have it so. He praised his master greatly thereafter. When we told him: that was an evil master, he said: Can ye give me a better one, that will I accept. He knew of God as much as a wolf. It was a pitiable thing to behold and hear the man. We begged and obtained it, that he was released; else had he had to burn. God better such courts.

So is it ordered with this distortion of human nature, which in the aforementioned examples is already abominable enough, but reaches the peak of hideousness in that Peter Stumpf, who toward the end of the sixteenth century was executed in Bedburg, in the diocese of Cologne. According to the records, he had consorted with a succubus for more than sixteen years, and from her received as a gift a broad belt, which, when he girded it on, had the effect that he seemed to himself and others to be a wolf. In this shape he had strangled fifteen boys one after another and devoured their brains; moreover, two of his daughters-in-law were attacked by him, that he might make them his prey; while he had taken his own stepmother and daughter as bedfellows. We have just seen, and Boguet confirms it, how examples have also occurred of women who ran as she-wolves; nevertheless it is easily understood that the disposition in the more timorous sex by no means inclines toward that side; and that it therefore prefers animal forms more suited to its nature for its metamorphosis. There the cat first offers itself, this shy, timid, malicious species, which, with glowing eye prowling through the night, from time to time rends the imagination with its hellish song and howls it through; and thus we need not wonder if we encounter this animal form so frequently in witchcraft. \

Thus at Remy many of those arrested for sorcery unanimously confessed: that, when they had faithfully served the demon for several years, he gave them the power to slip in the shape of cats or also of mice, locusts, etc., through narrow holes into another's house. Arrived there, they then resumed their shape, and carried out what they had purposed; to which also belong deadly assaults, but here exercised on adults by poison, and only on children by open violence; as indeed Barbelina Ragel confessed that in cat shape she had killed a child, seizing it between her paws. Assuming the truth of the fact, there can be as little question here of a real transformation of the body as with the werewolves; the cat nature, which has become dominant in life, also rules in the senses and in self-feeling, so that they see themselves as cats, and accordingly act as cats; but both in seeing and acting, because heightened toward the negative side, they overreach into the distance of space, or also perform the deed only in intention.

So it is, according to the diversity of the need, that other animal forms also come into play, into which the demonized and thereby inwardly depressed human being transports himself: a kind of transmigration of souls, in which the degraded self-consciousness, descending step by step, traverses all the moments of animal creation, which the human being, as lord of this creation, binds and conceals within himself; and which all mingle together, when he, instead of ruling them, allows himself to be ruled by them, awaken in him, and then, reshaping him into their kind, take command within him. The human being can thus, descending in spirit, traverse all these various animal larvae at different times. The bodily aspect will of course remain steadfast in its fixed dominion thereby; but it will, mastered and driven by the animal drive peculiar to the larva, for that very reason also imprint the ruling physiognomy of the same upon itself.

A human being who, in such a manner, has Proteus-like run through all these forms, and mimicked them outwardly, has thereby unbound in them his personality, which was bound in unity downward, so that it has fallen apart into its elements; and thus he himself has become a kind of animal Sabbath, spread out in time, in which all these shapes, held together enduringly in the unity of the personality, press successively upon one another, and pronounce his name in animal hieroglyphs. This visionary metamorphosis remains, in its essence, enclosed within the inner circle of life, because no real metempsychosis, through all animal bodies, exists for the human being. Only individual effusions of the transformed reproductive power sometimes reach the region of the bodily, and now also make themselves known outwardly through unusual, plastic formations. We have seen earlier how certain saints, by a mystical path, have called forth such formations in the heart and elsewhere; here on the dark side the same must occur under certain circumstances. Something of the kind has shown itself, for example, among the possessed of the convent of St. Ursula in Loudun. \

One of the four spirits of the prioress there had been compelled on 5 November 1635 by Father Surin to throw himself down before the Sacrament and adore it. He then cast her down at the feet of the exorcist; she rolled about there terribly, and clasped his knees several times, while the Magnificat was being sung in the church. Suddenly she stretched out her arms, which then stiffened together at the hands; and thrown upon the altar step, and leaning her head against the feet of the one performing the exorcism, she turned the profile of the latter toward the window for some of those present; and these now saw the figure of a cross upon the forehead, incised into the first and second skin, from which fresh and red blood welled forth. Since the Protestants present said that she could have imprinted this mark upon herself in her convulsions with a concealed iron in the form of a cross, which nevertheless seemed impossible given the stiffening of her arms; a repetition of the act followed later, shaping itself slowly before the eyes of the spectators. For it is stated in the verbal process, recorded on the spot:

On 29 November 1625, when I, J. Deniau, royal councillor at the presidium of La Flèche, and procurator of the commission, attached to the lord state councillor F. Laubardemont in the matter of the exorcisms in the Ursuline church of Loudun, went there with J. Nozat, secretary of that commission; where Father Surin,---whom the most holy Archbishop of Tours had urged in a letter to conduct the exorcism in such a way that it would lead to an edifying result for the English lord Montagu,---earnestly exorcised the prioress of this convent, in the presence of that lord Montagu, and of the lords Killegren and Seandrel, both English gentlemen, as well as several other respected persons. \

When he now pronounced the exorcism over the kneeling woman, she leaned backward onto her heels; and as she held her left arm, in the sight of all those present, up in the air, we, along with other bystanders---namely, Monsieur de Morans, vicegerent of Monsieur de Poitiers, the Fathers Anginot and Bachelerie of the Society of Jesus, Father Luc, a Capuchin, that English gentleman, Monsieur du Fresne, a citizen of Loudun, and Father Surin---saw, on the upper part of the hand of the aforementioned prioress, bloody letters forming themselves, which combined to form the name Joseph. Therefore, we, the aforementioned procurator of the king, have written down this our verbal process and signed it, and had it signed by those present as testimony to the truth, after the court clerk had read it aloud. Signed: Deniau, J. J. Surin of the Society of Jesus; de Montagu as eyewitness, that he saw the letters of the name Joseph impressed upon the hand; Thomas Killegren. Under the seal is written in English by Monsieur de Montagu: I saw the hand as white as my collar; but suddenly, along the whole vein, the color changed and became red; immediately afterward a clear word appeared, and the word was Joseph.

Montagu soon afterward went to Rome, told the Pope there what he had seen in Loudun and heard from others; then returned to the Church, took holy orders, and from then on lived in France, where he had the reputation of a man of spirit.

The natural side of these appearances emerges purely, it seems, in the case observed by B. Haan. An innocent, pious, twenty-two-year-old woman, of melancholic temperament, was seized in the evening of November 8, 1684, with shortness of breath, and in the night with sleepiness; and in the morning, upon rising, she saw two blue spots in both hands, and from the wrist to the bend of the elbow the arm marked with various cracks; over the elbow, however, inscribed with letters, especially N B, and interspersed with the sign of the cross. The next morning, after she had been at a wedding, she found the number of crosses---longer and shorter, deeper or shallower incised---increased by new ones on the neck, the breast, down to the abdomen; and within seven days the entire skin from the head to the heel was covered with them, and rough to the touch.

The face had at first remained untouched, but in the end it too was marked, though only lightly. On November 11, she had moaned in her sleep and wrung her hands; she had therefore been awakened, and needles were found thrust into both hands; which later played a role in various visions, along with an old woman who demanded them from her and struck her. Later, other needles had to be pulled from the soles of her feet, and on November 16 she was found outside her bed under a bench. In between, then, in the third, fourth, sixth, and tenth nights, new crosses were impressed upon her, then the signs of the planets, their aspects, and those of the simplest chemical preparations, all of which she knew well and with which she was accustomed to occupy herself for her instruction. The affliction diminished gradually until January 21, 1635; only that, as she was sewing at her neighbor's on that day, on the right a cloverleaf, on the left a trefoil, with the year 1635 lightly but clearly depicted, appeared. On both, the year showed a heart pierced with arrows, and beside it the image of a fool, with the inscription: Fool! On February 9 she had another violent but short-lived crisis, and then recovered completely. \

Although people attributed the evil to an old sorceress, to whom they had given a dress, without, however, seeing any sufficient grounds for the suspicion; yet if nature is capable of so much, then one must not be surprised if something similar happens in the highest crisis of the obsession, at the departure of the spirits.

##### ii. The Demonized Life as Poison and Antidote Torment

Just as in the times of earlier paganism all belief was naturalistic, so too was all mysticism a natural mysticism and magic. Just as one did not know how to separate the concrete and yet universal deity from her work, and to reconnect it again in the right way; so too did one not know how to separate natural evil from ethical evil with all sharpness; rather, corroding the one through the other, one accepted both in the same way as natural products. Thereby the opposition of good and evil was again thrown into confusion and obscurity, and instead of attaching it as such to God and the fallen creature, one rather divided it halfway under God and the nature mingled with him.

Thus one had to regard the good and the evil affection as alternating states of one and the same being; and by letting them, say, in periodic alternation, emerge at different times from it, the gods of antiquity were alternately good and evil, mild and wild, appeased and enraged, striking and raising up, killing and enlivening, confusing and clarifying. Those who now in a mystical way held themselves in the nearness of these gods, the retinue of Odin for example, and of Hulda, were imitations, formed after the manner of the model; it was the wild host and the mild; riding through the air, it now disturbed the cheerfulness of the sky into wild storm, and calmed the uproar again, so that serene stillness returned; it struck down the harvests and withered the vine, and made them green again, fed and watered with the harvest blessing; it sent the arrows of plagues into the lands, and healed again helpfully the damage to the land.

This lasted a long time over into the times of Christianity, until it succeeded in correcting the ideas of the masses. Therefore, for a long time still, in those who deviated from the paths of ordinary life, this intermittent character of their state was acknowledged; those sorceresses, into whom the old Feyen, Allrunen, and Drudens had passed over, are called, depending on whether they turn one side or the other forward, now Huldas, now the Unholdas, now good mothers, but again rascal wives. Only with the progress of time, as the good separates itself more sharply from the evil, is this intermittence also abolished; as the one orders itself exclusively upward, but the evil falls to the depths. Now at last the concept of the Unholdas becomes the prevailing one for these, as such who hold no one dear, but are hostile and born enemies of God, of men, and of all God's creatures; and they now become, in the full sense of the word, harlots and harlot-masters, black artists, poison brewers, cloak riders, goat riders, weather makers, night hoses and night wanderers; and again night women, mist bears, specter women, shimmer birds, devil's concubines, human thieves, etc., all in the far prevailing character of the evil side.

Meanwhile nature enters into all these states, and nature does not depart from its kind. But this kind is always, because in it all extremes touch each other, giving forward and returning, oscillating back and forth from one extreme to the other. Continuously through the whole duration of the evil, those who were seized by it have, precisely because it unbound unusual natural forces in them, felt compelled, according to circumstances sometimes to make a salutary use of them. Remy tells of a remarkable example thereof. \

When the child of one of his friends, the rentmaster Blankenstein of Dampmartin, had run away from his mother in the church and was passing the time with play; an old woman passed by him, stroked his head caressingly with her hand, wishing him all good things, and then went on her way. At once the child lowered his head, and his piteous weeping showed how it fared with him. As the weakness of the little one, whom they had carried home, kept increasing, the people judged that it came from the old woman, who had long stood in ill repute. The neighbors therefore pressed upon her that she should go and make the child healthy again. She was willing, and as soon as she came into his vicinity, she began to fall ill in the same manner as he himself. Her mouth turned blue, and a foam appeared before it; so that those present were horrified by it, and believed nothing else than that she would become rabid.

Since night had fallen in the meantime, she insisted absolutely on remaining in bed with the child; once she laid her outstretched arms upon it, held her mouth to his, as if she wished to drive back the faltering breath. The women who had kept watch at the bed through the night reported: how a humming like that of a hornet had been heard around the child for a while. The boy, whom they had given up for lost, was fresh and healthy the next morning; but most of the livestock in the house fell ill in his stead.

That the illness had begun with the woman's touch, that it had then passed back from the child onto her, and that the child had found himself healthy after some magnetic manipulations, are three facts whose coincidence can scarcely be ascribed to chance. She was thus, like an old Allrune, a night-woman and hunt-woman at once; like that one in Blois, who, in order to heal an enchanted person, had a mass of the Holy Ghost read at midnight in Notre Dame des Arbres; then laid herself full length upon the sick one, and murmured some words thereto, whereupon the sick one became healthy at once.² In all these healings there appears a natural force at work, which strengthens itself through mystical addition; but sometimes also, when present in rich endowment, reaches development on the mere path of nature; and then forms that class of doctors called by birth, who from time to time arise, and, after they have practiced a doing bordering on the miraculous, are either suppressed by the guild-members and the police, or, with waning power, gradually sink back into obscurity.

Of this sort was, for example, that Valentine Greatrakes, who, born around 1628, from a respectable house in Ireland, served for a time in the army; but around the year 1662 heard a voice in an inner admonition which told him: that he too could heal scrofula by his touch, like the Queen of England. At first he was laughed at by those to whom he communicated this summons; yet he boldly attempted the thing, and it succeeded. For a time he confined himself to this ailment; but soon the voice admonished him: to try himself also on the ague, which then raged epidemically. \
