When he now laid his hand upon a woman and added a formula, the fever departed at once, and the woman recovered. Now he expanded the circle of his practice, countless testimonies of the efficacy of his laying on of hands spread his fame. People began to call him the Antichrist of the doctors; sick persons of every kind spared no expense to reach him; while he, contenting himself with fulfilling the duties of human love, turned away every other reward from his hand. Besides the healing of scrofula, leprosy, and fevers, he restored sight and hearing, and gave paralyzed limbs back their vital force.

He laid his hands on the epileptic, and their convulsions immediately ceased; the movements of the fever stopped at once; sensation and activity were restored, and the illness was forever lifted. On a single day, the hands were laid upon as many as sixty persons at once. An eyewitness reports: several among these sick ones had been afflicted with the falling sickness, and some among these, seized by their ailment, had lain in the same room; he had been called to their aid, and he, leaving other patients, had hastened to them. While the afflicted ones now lay foaming at the mouth and rolling on the ground, he had struck them on the chest with his hand, and immediately their attack had ceased, and they had risen, saying that they felt very well. His procedure was very simple: at times he rubbed the afflicted limb, at times he spat upon it; he placed his fingers in the ear of the deaf, and they became hearing.

At times he also made use of repulsive means for the restoration. But, unlike his superstitious contemporaries, he employed no magical remedies or special words; rather, he spoke only a sort of short ejaculatory prayer before the manipulation, and once the healing had occurred, he then reminded the patient to give glory to God. His warmest admirers attributed the miraculous power to a peculiar temperament of his organism, from which a sort of beneficent influence streamed forth. He himself, especially in the consciousness of the time when he had acquired the gift and of the effects that followed, sought it in a power that dwelt in his hands.

Before he possessed it, he had namely noticed that, when he had severe headaches, the laying on of hands was utterly ineffective; afterward, when he had gained the power, he needed only to bring his hand to his head, and he was healed. Of other patients he was wont to say: their ailment jumped and fled from place to place, just as he changed the position of his hands, until it was finally driven out. Even the laying on of his gloves was not ineffective, though by no means so with other items of his clothing.

Countless testimonies from the healed, from physicians and persons of higher rank, attested to this healing power of his; but he experienced what all earlier and later ones have experienced: envy and jealousy arose against the man who would perform miracles, after---as they said---the time of miracles had long passed; the tongue denied the eye, the rubbing had been the sole effective palliative. Others took up his defense; men argued and grew heated, controversial writings flew back and forth; the death of the miracle-worker finally put an end to the dispute, and the customary care was taken that he should be forgotten as soon as possible. \

If now such a disposition is present in those who have turned to the reverse side, or if it is called forth by magical practice, then the healing effect will appear only as the counterpart of the harmful one, which steps forth as the dominant force, and the other subordinates itself only to its service. For the healing of a sick person out of mere goodwill is entirely contrary to the principle of the work. Therefore, according to judicial statements, it is the rule that no one is healed without a more severe illness having been transferred to another; so that in the end there may always remain a gain for evil. This transfer must thereby take place each time to the better and the more important: from the woman to the man, from the older to a younger one, from the body to the soul; if the magician wishes to proceed otherwise, then he himself comes into danger.

All this can hardly have always held true in the practice of ignorant people; but it is the simple consequence of the principle: that, while God permits one evil in order that a great good may be attained, evil, on the other hand, removes a small evil in order to bring about a greater one. Therefore, it is also regarded as a law in this sphere: that only an illness inflicted by magic can likewise be lifted by magic, and indeed by the one who wrought it.

Around the year 1208, it was customary in Scotland for such afflicted persons to send for Elspeth Rule in order to seek healing from her. When she once refused to come, the sick man begged his kin to compel her by force. When she finally came and prayed to the Lord that He might restore health to the invalid, he nevertheless died on that same day, though only after he had laid the blame for his death at her head. Another had sent for his sister-in-law several times without success; he now went to her himself, declaring that he would have her burned if he did not regain his health.

From that point on, he took a turn for the worse day by day, through her devilry, in his recovery; so great was the trust in these, albeit uncanny, healing powers, which, moreover, were exercised, as with Greatrakes, through the gaze, through laying on of hands and touching, through spitting, water and salt, and so forth. Sometimes the illnesses were merely suspended and, as it were, lulled to sleep, only to be awakened again at another time; but in transferring them, the evil would sometimes wander through an entire sequence of animals and people until it was extinguished.

Thus could poisons, in popular belief, sometimes become heroically potent medicines; but their proper nature was to bring sickness and death, not healing and life. The sorcerer and the sorceress were like the Bohon Upas; whoever came within the tree's reach, or whom sleep overtook in its shadow, had breathed in death and ruin. This was the general belief throughout earlier times across all of Europe. Beigis Tod's death, the Scottish records relate, cast a severe and unknown illness upon Alexander Fairlie, who forthwith wasted away in violent sweats and an unceasing burning around his heart. \

This illness lasted fully two months, so that despair took hold regarding his life. Nightly, Beigis appeared to him in her own form, whereupon he would cry out for help each time; by day, however, she came to him in the shape of a dog and drove him out of his senses. A woman had threatened an English soldier quartered with her: that evil would befall him; he fell ill at once and sweated himself to death in one or two days. While Margareth Craigie was recovering, Christian Marwik passed her hand over the woman's breast, and she died that same night. Madness in particular was transmitted in this manner. Jean Craig laid the evil upon Beatrix Sandilands, and she became mad and sleepless, and through this madness of hers was ultimately robbed of her life. Christian Wilson had threatened: a certain man should never again haul stones, and he forthwith fell into madness and rage, took to his bed, and never rose again, but died in a few days. During his illness, he cried out incessantly: that Christian stood ever before him in the form of a gray cat.

Similar things occur in great numbers in the witch trials of all countries, and one stands amazed at them: that locally and temporally in the peoples the most excitable moods have arisen, that individuals have frequently been made irritable to stimuli which otherwise would pass by without visible effect; and that the general belief in the overwhelming power of magic has served here as the medium through which it has struck into the diseased personality. The malice of those individuals who dispense the diseases then armed their own inner corruption with the externality of the elaborates of the poison cloths; those which on the Sabbath cultivated the spiritual side of that poison brewing, whose natural side is carried on in earthly apothecaries.

The idea underlying this has expressed itself in the most pregnant form in those confessions where it is said: when the Sabbath comes to an end, the demon throws himself into a flame that blazes there, burns to ash in it, and this forms the main constituent of the poisons that come from there. The principle is: the natural poison is only the physical semblance-shell of the ethically evil; the ash of the body which this has assumed will therefore be the poison mother, which is penetrated by its inner essence just as the relics of the saints glow in the aftershine of their higher spirituality. In another way, it is the toads of the Sabbath that have to supply this primal poison. They are whipped, seized between the teeth and lacerated, with spiders and snakes, and according to the statement of the Necato, with the seed, marrow, and bark of the bush called Suhandurra in Basque, in Gascony also Herenbaum, and given with the father-murderers when drowning them in the sack, combined, now stamped and also perhaps burned, where then the most potently effective magical poison forms itself, which in the incineration attaches itself to the blood-acid then developed as its carrier. One kind is thick like a salve, the other liquid.

The first is used for the ruin of hated persons, the other is sprinkled over plants and grain. A green water is likewise prepared there, which brings death already at the mere touch, and therefore makes necessary from the side of those who use it an antidote for hand-washing.¹ Another armament of the evil will one has believed to find in the magical plastic. An image is formed of wax or another substance, baptized in the name of Beelzebub, and now pierced with needles or roasted in the fire; everything done to it shall then propagate itself to the archetype. \

That is already ancient practice, the legend of the death of Meleager rests upon it, and Ovid in the verses on Medea *Devovet absentes, simulacraque cerea fingit,* *Et miserum tenues in jecur urget acus,* has described the whole procedure. One knows what Boethius in the XIth book of his Scottish history tells of King Duffo and his sorceress wives; especially, however, at the time of the popes in Avignon the thing went very much in vogue, and John XXII, who believed that this plastic was directed against his person, issued his well-known bull against it.

From this time and connected with it is therefore also an act of the Inquisition of Carcassonne from the year 1328, in which in the process of the Carmelite Petrus Recordi the judgment states: Because thou at different times successively hast made and uttered many and manifold invocations and callings upon the demon; because thou hast fashioned images and mixed manifold poisons into them, also drawn the blood of a toad in a fearful and terrible manner, poured it into them, and now hast thrown thyself down before a table, covered with a cloth or carpet, sprinkling their belly with blood from thy nose mixed with spittle, in the intention of thereby bringing an offering to the devil.

Because you buried those images, wrought in such a manner and in other ways not to be mentioned here, secretly under the door-sill of certain women whom you sought to gain for unchastity, as indeed succeeded with three among them, and would likewise have succeeded with two others if your order had not transferred you to another place. Because, after you had known these women and indulged in lust with them, you again removed the aforementioned images and threw them into the river; and then offered to the devil as a sacrifice a papillon (a gold coin of that time, according to Du Cange), and sensed its nearness through a wind or in some other manner; believing that the images had the power to compel the aforementioned women to your love, or, if they would not consent, to torment them through the demons. Because, after you once struck one of these images on the belly, blood flowed, etc.

One sees that this is a matter here of a love-spell that was to be tied to these images, and whose reversal then turns into a death-spell. Especially the Byzantine history is rich in precedents of this sort, and the French history also knows some to recount, particularly in the time of the religious wars. The exorcists cite similar ones; Sprenger has recorded some,¹ likewise the physician Zacutus.² All these cases, however, are not so purely investigated, and presented roundly and clearly with the exclusion of all deception, that one could found upon them any reliable judgment whatsoever. The image is to be a kind of mirror that collects the malevolent intention as in a focal point, and then directs it upon the object represented itself in full perniciousness and conveys it over. The fundamental idea is thus that of an apparatus in which the demonic influences unite; something like how the magnetic baquet was supposed to concentrate and further conduct the somnambulistic influences. But as this led on a well-trodden path to all sorts of charlatanry, so too was the way paved through these demonic condensers to every kind of fraud and self-deception.

##### iii. Relations of Magically Aroused Life to the Natural Forces

\

Witchcraft has at all times claimed a dominion over the powers of nature, and we have already seen within what limitations these its pretensions find justification. The natural sphere, governed by physical law, and the spiritual sphere, standing under the psychical, are separated from one another, and both find mediation only through the organic. Within this mediation, the energy of the spiritual grants to the natural only a limited influence, which in turn, on its side, is secured against the all-too-disturbing encroachments of the spiritual through its massiveness; the measure of reciprocal influence is thus bounded by the mediating organic. In the meantime, it has been believed, especially that the air-sphere, this earth-encompassing ocean of a volatile, mobile element open to all impressions and equalizing all, yields itself most readily to such influences from the spiritual side; and thus at all times has ascribed to magically heightened life a disturbing influence upon the atmosphere.

This belief came particularly to light at the end of the sixteenth century in a process that became famous; at that time, when the insipidly pedantic James of Scotland had been drawn, by a band of ecstatic women under the leadership of a schoolmaster, into a heroic drama in the enchanted forest, and now personally conducted the investigation of this wondrous affair himself. In a fit of romance, he had sailed across to Norway in the year 1590 with a fleet to fetch his queen himself.

On the homeward voyage, while the whole fleet sailed along in favorable winds, his ship alone encountered headwinds, so that it made only laborious progress forward; moreover, a boat carrying jewels for the queen went under in the storm between Leith and Kinghorn. This was now all the work of those women, as was discovered after the king's return. Geillis Duncan, who served at Bailie Seaton's, had for some time been performing various healings that aroused her master's suspicion, until at last he had the thumbscrews applied to her, whereupon she confessed that the cures had been accomplished by the devil's help, and now named many others as accomplices and witches. Thus: Agnes Sampson, the eldest of them all; Agnes Thompson of Edinburgh, the wife of George Mott; Barbara Napier; and Euphemia MacCalzean, the daughter of the Lord of Cliftonhall, one of the members of the justice college; many other women were likewise named by her, and also men, among them especially Doctor Fian, otherwise called John Cunningham, schoolmaster of Saltpans in Lothian, who among the others was regarded as the devil's secretary.

All were arrested, but Agnes Sampson was first brought before the king in Holyrood House. She denied everything at the outset, but was tortured, and now confessed such strange and wondrous things that James himself declared her a liar. She replied, however, that it would not be good if His Majesty did not believe her words; she therefore offered to communicate things to him that would dispel every doubt in him. She now took the king a little aside and told him all the words that had passed between him and the queen in their wedding night in Oslo in Norway, with all the answers that one had made to the other; so that His Majesty was highly astonished, and swore by the living God that all the devils in hell could not have invented the like, so deeply was it grounded in truth; from then on he believed her statements. \

She now related how the whole fellowship had resolved to raise a destructive storm on the sea against the king on that voyage. Satan had first wanted to let a fog arise, so that his ship would strand on the English coast; but since that did not seem sure to succeed, Fian, the schoolmaster, wrote to Marion Linkup, a famous witch, and to the others of the sisterhood, and summoned them all to meet at sea with their master within five days, in order to destroy the king in common. On the eve of All Saints' Day they assembled, some four hundred persons strong, at the appointed place, and each embarked in a sieve, merry and in good spirits. After some cruising about, Satan appeared and gave a cat to Robert Grierson; with the cry "Hola!" it was to be thrown into the sea, and the desired storm would then follow. Even earlier, six witches had bought such a cat in the weaver's house; two had seized the iron hook of the hearth, the animal had then been pulled three times through the ring of the hook, and driven three times under the hearth. To its four legs had then been bound main limbs of men, and when it was thrown into the sea after midnight, the storm had come there too, which had swallowed that boat.

When the sieve-farers had completed their business, they landed at the church of North Berwick in Lothian, first drank wine from their sieves, and then, more than a hundred in number, went two by two to the church to observe the Sabbath. Geillis Duncan danced ahead and sang to the harp the lay:

> Commer, goe ye before, Commer, goe fe\
> Cit she will not goe before, Commer, lei me.

Fian acted as master of ceremonies in the church, opened the doors and lit the lights, while Gray Meill served as doorkeeper. The demon appeared as preacher; his body was hard as iron, as it seemed to those who touched him; his face terrible, his nose like the beak of an eagle, claws on hands and feet like a griffin, his eyes gray and burning, his voice hollow. He delivered an exhortation to those present to henceforth carry out all evil, after which the homage followed in the usual manner.

The king had Geillis Duncan brought forward; her testimony agreed most perfectly with what Sampson had said, whom Spottiswoode describes as a worthy and truthful matron in her statements. She had to play that lay on the harp for him; the king, who was present at all the interrogations, marveled at the agreement of the testimonies, which also remained consistent in the confessions of Fian and all those who were present; and even now sets all English reviewers in wonder, that they declare it the most insoluble problem in the philosophy of Scottish history (sic). One sees that a conspiracy against the king had taken place; he, it seems, of whom Bothwell, later himself accused of witchcraft, was not entirely unconnected. But it was a mystical conspiracy, carried out in the magical manner of the cult, and the demon was to play the principal role in it as weather-maker. \

The drama therefore played itself out in vision, and the bond in which the conspirators were united gave their testimonies that agreement in the circumstances; while their clairvoyance knew of the king's doings. But the visions, moving in the spiritual realm, and the baptized cat had broken against the sluggishness of the elementary sphere; the king's ship, it seems, had sailed into a local wind current, and the whole undertaking was thwarted. The courts had turned the entire heavy apparatus of the tangibly real realm against the ideal world of the mystical conspiracy; and that they sought to grasp the airy shadows with tongs and levers brings precisely the baroque, ironically mocking strangeness into this affair. They had, moreover, just as much ground and no-ground to hold the matter for true as the earlier inquisitors; for that the Protestant liturgy had been inserted into the visions could change little. Their judgment pronounced: Fian should be strangled and burned, the same fate was assigned to Agnes Sampson. Euphemia Maccalzean, a woman of great resolve and ungovernable passion, who was accused of manifold poisonings, like the Brinvilliers in France, was likewise bound to a stake and burned to ashes.

In Remy's Praxis in Lorraine, such complaints of storm-raising and weather-making likewise occurred frequently; but mostly the damage inflicted reduced itself to a few tiles thrown down from the roof; whereby it never lacked excuses why it did not come to greater mischief. Yet there also occur testimonies in him that lead on the track of how it went with that weather-making. More than two hundred persons confessed judicially, namely, how at certain times the witches gathered in hordes at a body of water or lake, preferably where one lies in a desolate and unvisited place.

Having now arrived there, they struck for so long with rods, which they received from the spirit, into the water, until a thick vapor and mist rose up from it. In this they then led themselves upward into the heights; where immediately the vapor condensed into black clouds, in which they rode back and forth with the spirits, and finally came down again with hail and under claps of thunder. J. Carmé of Gerbeweil and Jana Oberta testified: that it had not been a dream to them, but that they had seen it with their own eyes: how an incredible number from their coven rode back and forth in such conjured clouds, faster than the storm wind, as when sparks shoot in thick smoke, and came down again and they vanished. Meanwhile, it had thundered around them and crackled terribly. Aleria said: how she had shot over J. Vehrt as he was tending the horses, and the spirit, at her urging, from the heights above, had struck two of his steeds dead with lightning. In the mountains, especially those of primary formation, lakes of a peculiar kind are no rarity; not of great extent, but of unfathomable depth, hence dark-colored from the water.

They must be fissures that fill them, which have been rent through the mountains deep into the interior of the earth. The interplay of the subterranean forces in the abyss, and of the atmospheric ones above in the heights, is thus mediated through the body of water contained in them; so that the fountains of the deep still stand in connection here with the cataracts of the heavens. Such localities must therefore be nodal points of atmospheric changes, which develop from here out of the counterplay of the forces; the local weather will appear tied to them, and in summertime the mountain storms will most gladly brew themselves in the mists of these lakes. The folk sense has long recognized this, and its legend ties much to such localities. \

One knows what Pausanias reports of the well on the Lykaeus, which was the weather lake for Arcadia. "In the diocese of Girona," recounts Gervase of Tilbury already in the year 1212, "rises the mountain Cavogum, today called Canigou; its peak is steep, and toward many sides unclimbable. Upon it stands a lake with blackish water, unfathomable. There, according to the legend, is the house of the demons, a vast palace with closed doors, yet castle and inhabitants are alike invisible. If someone throws a stone or some other solid thing into the lake, there arises, in the anger of these demons, immediately a storm. It is certain that in these mountains there is eternal turmoil of warring winds, and seldom or never stillness and calm." The same legend goes of the Mummelsee in the Black Forest; if one throws one or more stones into it, the clearest sky clouds over, and a thunderstorm arises, with hailstones and storm winds. The same is reported of many other such lakes, and they are therefore probably also called Nixie wells by the folk. One now comprehends what significance they have in witchcraft, in which the natural forces active around them prove themselves of particular influence.

These women have, like all the sick, especially those in the nervous system, the calendar in their limbs, which makes them particularly excitable to every change, especially electrical ones, in the air. Their intentions are in any case directed toward those lordly heights; if now a storm should brew over those lakes, then an electrical local nexus forms above them, from which and to which all the electrical currents of the surrounding area flow. The intentions, already aroused, therefore find in them the paths laid open, upon which they, drawn concentrically to that same center, begin the journey that leads them to the hearth of the incipient atmospheric change. The Sabbath is thus now a weather Sabbath, and is held over those lakes. With rising electrical tension, the lords rise in the fog that is lifting itself; as the lightnings shoot and zigzag through one another, so do they traverse the thickening clouds; and finally, at the slackening of the tension, they return to earth in the weather-ray and the thunderbolts: All in vision, but laid into the natural uprising itself. As weather prophets, they have sensed the impending evil in the realm of the meteors beforehand: their sympathy has risen and fallen with its development; it is no wonder that they have the full conviction that they have brought it about and caused it.

The difference of the sexes, which, in all occurrences of ordinary life, has its pervasive significance down to the deepest root, is in the upward-directed mysticism, in relation to God, entirely without meaning. The ray of His grace shines over mountains as into valleys, and no distinction is to be noted other than the one He Himself makes in His choice. But the inner human relation is by no means thereby destroyed and annulled; it continues to exist in everything that belongs to the human in that relation, thus in the preparation for the reception of that ray, in its inner processing, and in the emission of the received into life. In all this, the difference of the sexes shows itself: in that the man therein acts more as the self-standing unity, the woman as the nurturing, nourishing multiplicity; the former thus in a kind of imitative substitution as the deputy, the appropriator, and the re-emitter of the received grace, and hence again as the steward, householder, leader, and enlightener in the earthly household; but the latter more as the nurse taken up by the ray of the instilled, also in the emitting forever clothing it; thus, therefore, opposite the first, appearing as the preserver, collector, and light-sucker. \

It will be otherwise in the downward-directed mysticism, where creature stands opposite creature; and thus there is no talk of any incommensurable relation between incomparable magnitudes. There the night can deceitfully clothe itself in the light of day; the relation that exists between the sexes can thus also be transferred to the relation that exists between the demon and them; and this transfer expresses itself in a physical formula, that one can as incubus or as succubus offer itself to the one near it. Here, therefore, a relation of the man to evil is conceivable, in which he is permitted as the lord, but this as the ruled subordinates itself to him; whereas the woman everywhere is permitted to community only in the relation of subordination. The man, set in such wise in a positive relation to the demon, is it even so much more in relation to the woman; he is its representative against it, and therefore consistently steps forth in the role of the seducer in the midst of the seduced. For precisely as such a one he gives forth from his unity what this one, seemingly imparting, yet in truth receives from the first unity of all evil.

Also, emanating from him, it can affect many receivers, who thus peripherally, as seduced ones, surround him, their center. Hence the circumstance that, like the incubi more frequent than the Succubi; so also more sorceresses are to be found than sorcerers, and that therefore the title of the *Hexenprozeß* \[Witch Trial\] can fittingly encompass the entire method of interrogation of the witch courts. The phenomenon of sorcery, as we have now come to know it in its extent, considered as a doctrine, is without the slightest doubt the most abominable false teaching into which the human spirit can lose itself.

This spirit, which, just as the body of nature feels itself beneath itself, above itself, around itself, and within itself, so perceives the Divinity at the beginning, at the end, at all its boundaries, and in its entire substance, and just as it has come to self-consciousness from Him, so too can it preserve itself only in Him alone, in such a way that the mere thinking away of Him in it arouses the vertigo of death; this spirit, therefore, grounded and dependent, here enters not merely with its purely personal basis, but with the absolute basis of all that has become, into the most sacrilegious contradiction. It does not fortify itself, by holding onto its inner vital breath, in that dizzying, suicidal thinking away of its inmost vital basis; since in atheism, by turning its spiritual freedom against God, it in truth turns it against itself, and through its doubt does not seek to abolish Him in itself; but rather, as much as possible, denies itself in Him, and thus withdraws itself from His service. \

It does not, like one form of pantheism, allow God to dissolve in His work, thus perhaps in boundless pride in itself; nor does it resolve, like the other, to dissolve itself in Him, in order in equal pride to find itself in Him as God, and thus by its own power to transubstantiate the created substance into the uncreated, or vice versa. Rather, it allows God to subsist in His essence, and now rises up in its own, which it owes to Him alone, in a senseless revolt against Him. For this purpose, it now arms everything within itself that entered into it in the times of that first, hoary rebellion, and that, damped and built over by later formations, boils beneath in the depths; and it devotes its higher and better nature to ignominious servitude to this. Well aware of the impotence and powerlessness with which this pact is concluded,

it looks around for other allies in the invisible realms; and now allies itself with the even older revolt that shook the first-created spirit realms; seeking, by breaking through the bounds of nature, to raise up the scum that these rebellious realms, in consequence of the igniting conflict, have cast out into its dark abodes; not in order to participate in the, albeit insane, hopes of a still undecided battle, but in the despair of defeat. And if such a teaching were still to confine itself to the purely theoretical domains, one could regard it as a spiritual eclipse, through an overwhelming stiffening power, as a kind of intellectual tetanus. But now it also breaks into the ethical domains, and in them too, in the same reversal, turning the highest to the lowest down to their deepest basis.

Through artificial precipitation, the implanted center of gravity is detached from its natural basis and bound to those unnatural ones; and all morality loses in this turning its original validity. It sets itself in the most decided contradiction to the divine order, and seeks, through the death of all life, not to thrust itself out into nothingness in an opposing act of creation, as in atheism; but to force itself into a negative existence which in everything is the counterpart of the positive; and just as the latter bears the absolute positing in its bosom, so this encloses the absolute abolition of the posited, and a positing of the unposited and the unlawful within itself. \

Therefore, every virtue in it is transformed into its opposite vice, not merely disguised, but thoroughly metamorphosed from within; and the entire will, with full impetus, is not directed toward its goal, but strives away from it toward its antithesis. Hence all its movements become hostile toward the spiritual world-law, crossing it, erring and confusing it, and filling its entire sphere of action with uproar and hatred. Hence the grim bloodlust, which ignites itself with enmity against all that lives, yet in the blood again intoxicates itself in boundless lust, and begins a new fantastical creation in this rapture; which it then endeavors, in the daemonic counterforce, to activate from its mere potentiality, to integrate from its impotence, and to realize enduringly from its shadowy non-existence. Finally, the evil is a plague, overturning all the foundations of life, and inverting everything that rests upon this foundation; shaking and disrupting all bodily existence, perverting the forces in constant excess, boiling all milder secretions into poison, and expelling what is thus prepared in a vaporous sphere, which then envelops far and wide the wellspring from which it has arisen, entwines everything that approaches it, and draws it over into the same perdition. Such is the nature of this evil, which in its full perniciousness has arisen in the midst of civil and religious society, and soon challenges the entire vital force within them to counteraction. Order has thus armed itself against this lethal disturbance; let us see how it has held in the struggle, and first consider how it has equipped itself for the conflict.

### Chapter 1. The Preconditions of Judicial Investigation.

#### A. Historical Foundation of Legal Procedure

The great ethical influence, as we have seen in the history of its development, has not been lacking in any age; but it enters history, as is the case with all cosmic diseases, as the great secular epidemic, whose generation occurred in the first Fall, and whose stages of age are measured by those century-long recurrences. In more recent times it has ignited, especially in the frictions that arose between Orient and Occident in the Crusades; and from then on we see it, in the escort of great epidemics of the spirit that have likewise assumed the form of secular heresies, and in the train of organic pestilences that march ahead as lictors and executioners and form the rearguard, traversing Europe.

The Manichaeism that flared up almost simultaneously with mighty power was destined to become the medium in which it could take root and communicate itself to the masses. If this doctrine, which spread quickly over the South and had already begun to migrate northward with rapidity, had carried off the victory; then its hierarchy would easily have provided the external framework in which the spiritual, esoteric hierarchy of magic could have united itself around the secret service. But Providence then awakened in Innocent III, and in the two great founders of orders, Francis and Dominic, the men who possessed the strength to withstand the dangers of the time. The false doctrine was attacked and defeated in the Albigensian Wars in its great arsenal, and the two orders were destined to cultivate and guard the field won from it. The right of the priest to be judge in matters of faith---a right that attaches itself to that great judicial act which, after the Fall, God Himself held with the guilty, and which from the beginning the Church has exercised in the individual case for itself, and in the general case in councils---was now delegated to special courts of inquisition, and entrusted to the two orders, chiefly to the one founded by the holy Dominic. \

As the theocracy already had its own knighthood in the Templars for the war against the Mohammedans; so now, from the Holy See, a so-called Militia of Christ was established for it against the heretics, marked with the cross, and enjoying the same indulgences; laying aside the vows of obedience, of poverty, and of conjugal chastity, equally ready for the spiritual as for the knightly strife at their own expense; in the latter placing themselves at the disposal of the Inquisition, and thereby forming, as it were, its armed family, just as the actual familiars formed its ministerial retainers; but later, when disarmed, with an altered constitution, they were joined to the Order of Preachers in the order of the Tertiaries.

The institution spread from France to the Spanish and Italian peninsula, thus to the entire Romance South, to East and West India, and in individual ramifications also to the Germanic North. Through it the terrible heresy was utterly eradicated, which, had it, through the mediation of the Spanish Jews, allied itself with the African Mohammedans (as it has already been accused of attempting such a thing), would have seized mastery over the entire part of the world; and after the victory achieved, it immediately expelled the Jews and the remnants of the Moors from Spain. From then on it watched over the preservation of the purity of the doctrine; hence the tribunal in matters of witchcraft also belonged to it, and for France a parliamentary act of the year 1282, drawn up at the instigation of the Archbishop of Paris, decided: the cognizance in matters of witchcraft should remain with the clergy, to the exclusion of the laity.

At the end of the thirteenth century, the Christian theocracy, shielded by German emperors and having ruled Europe for half a millennium, was overthrown, because the popes could no longer agree with their protector lords. Its great outer fortress against the East, the well-formed fiefdom in the Holy Land, was lost in the great battle that devoured the flower of the two knightly orders, around the middle of the century; until the beginning of the fourteenth, all the bulwarks of this fortress were lost except for Cyprus. The disgrace was deeply felt throughout Christendom, the prestige of the popes was severely damaged, the attack on Boniface VIII became possible, and the high priests had to wander over into the eighty-year captivity of their new protector lord France, for their share in the guilt of all. Their knighthood, the Templars, were the companions of their misfortune.

The order, in contact with all the vices of the Orient, was eaten away to the core by the plague. As bankers and moneychangers between East and West, and entangled in the administration of all lands, it had itself become exceedingly rich through constant contact with gold, but had also thereby degenerated in many ways. Thus as priests it was hateful to the emancipating powers, and at the same time, in its degeneration, to all the more serious confessors of the old doctrine; as a powerful, war-hardened nobility, closely bound to its retainers, it was a stumbling block and a terror to the encroaching princely power; as a guild of rich bankers, an object of envy to the emerging financiers of the modern age, and, on the presupposition of overly vast treasures, also of greed. To them, therefore, was chiefly ascribed the cause of the bitter loss, and the general indignation discharged itself chiefly upon their heads. \

Nogaret, the instigator of the attack in Anagni, and Marigny, the finance minister of Philip the Fair, took over the prosecution; the trial was conducted before the Inquisition of the Dominicans and other monastic orders: for it concerned apostasy and sorcery, and for the first time the world beheld the tragic spectacle of such a process carried out on a grand scale. The indictment was specified more closely: the renunciation of Christianity through thrice spitting on the crucifix during the initiations; the worship of Baphomet with the glowing eyes; the homage paid to him by the initiates entirely in the forms of the Sabbath; the vow of sodomy and the mutual surrender of the brethren pledged to one another: all standing types of witchcraft.

Torture extracted uniform confessions: of the appearance of the speaking cat, to which worship was rendered; of the demons who presented themselves in female form, and of whom always one would join with a brother; of child-eating and the like. That a trial against the Order could be founded on such accusations rested on the general opinion that existed of its corruption. The confessions, wrung out under torture, will serve as proof to no reasonable person. The proceedings at the reception may have been based on ancient symbols whose key the Order itself no longer possessed. On the other hand, we must accept the conscience of the judges, of the Pope, and of the Council of Vienne as the guarantee: that the matter was by no means entirely without foundation, and that such things were practiced by individual members of the Order, perhaps by individual lodges.

The Grand Master and those who died with him by fire recanted in the decisive moment what they had earlier confessed; and we cannot deny belief to them also for their persons. They died, therefore, innocent enough with regard to themselves, but in that solidary liability from which the members of every great corporation cannot escape. What had been violent in the conduct of the affair was punished in the interpretation of the chorus in history, in public opinion, by this: that Pope and King, on the summons of the Grand Master, had to appear within forty days and one year before the higher judgment seat; but of the subordinate instruments, Marigny and other finance officials, accused of the same vice, had to atone for their crimes on the gallows of Montfaucon. \

The entire act, however, with all its forms and appurtenances, and in all these influences and aftereffects, is a portent and a prototype of by far the most subsequent witchcraft trials. The theocracy was now broken, the federal relationship in which all European peoples had stood was dissolved; those who had previously been partial members rose to full independence, and the territorial power worked its way forth in the midst of the nations to full sovereignty. In the transition from the abandoned form into the new one there now arose a time of wild struggles, of unbound forces wrestling with one another, which in France mark the rule of the Valois. Sorcery played its role therein as an instrument in the hands of the powerful, and Robert of Artois sought to destroy Philip VI and his queen thereby. Since in such a manner the heads of states found themselves entangled in the affair, it could not please them in the new order of things that those involved should seek their right before an ecclesiastical court. Thus the administration of justice in such matters, which an earlier parliamentary decree had assigned to these courts, was by another in the year 1390 taken from them again and granted to the secular courts; whereby the king's procurator was made it his duty to conduct the inquiries. Thus jurisdiction was given into the hands of the jurists, who from then on exercised it, to be sure with subsidiary involvement of the clergy.

The matter itself now took its course; Charles VI considered himself bewitched; it became the custom at the courts to keep necromancers, like dwarfs and court jesters; to whom, in turn, when the lord could no longer protect them, process was made. The Maid of Orleans had to pay with her life to the English for the undertaking of having saved her fatherland; because pride could not convince itself that she had done it by any other path than that of sorcery.

When the Duke of Guyenne, the brother of Louis XI, had been poisoned, not without his knowledge; the Duke of Burgundy accused the king of fratricide by poison, malefice, loose laying, and invocations of the devil in an open manifesto. An ordinance of 1490 now sharpens for all justice officials the judicial pursuit of all kinds of sorcery; assigns to the accuser the fourth part of the punishment, and commands: to hand over the clergy who might be implicated in the accusation to the court of the bishop. In England the same course of things. Queen Joan is arrested in 1417 for sorcery.

The Duchess of Gloucester, accused of sorcery against Henry VI, must do penance, but her accused agents are hanged. Richard III complains in his council that the queen has made his arm entirely withered. In the war of the houses of York and Lancaster the two parties mutually accuse each other of sorcery. Soon Pope Innocent VIII issues his bull (1484), in which he gives the inquisitors Sprenger and Institoris power, in the whole Rhine region, to proceed against sorcerers and witches, to convict them, and then to punish them. For a time thereby, in those regions and higher northward, the investigation came into the hands of the clergy; but the soon-breaking-out Protestantism brought it back, more or less exclusively, into the hands of secular authorities, and the process form soon established itself in fixed manner.

It is a grave matter to set oneself up as judge in God's place, and to pass judgment over human beings accused of a crime that in part withdraws from visibility, and reaches deeply into an invisible world. The eye of the judge does not look into the past, as does the eye of God; the roots of the crimes go back into that night which envelops the human horizon, while all their branches grow through the real world, and threaten society in its innermost being. As therefore the deeds to be judged belong to two worlds, so also will their investigation go twofold in two directions; and it will be indispensable to fulfill relevant preliminary conditions thereto, before it begins its work with a good conscience.

Thereon therefore we must first expatiate. The evil is, as we have seen, first of all a plague, a holy or rather unholy disease in its higher root; in its bodily extension, however, a pathological affection, running its course in determinate stages, and developing itself in its crises. It must therefore first of all be considered from this viewpoint, and that will be the affair of the physicians. Every disease has its symptoms, and these are, insofar as everything deviating from the ordinary course of nature appears something wondrous, in themselves wondrous; a character which, in this evil that stands on the boundary of two worlds and stirs both together, necessarily stands out sharply. The first question therefore arises: to what extent can such transcendental symptoms count as proofs for the intervention of higher powers? To answer this question, therefore, nature would have to be sharply circumscribed within its boundaries, and this boundary-determination of it brought to clear intuition.

Even the organic life, and even more so the deeper spiritual life, are set at the boundary of this world and the beyond; it is in any case the medium of passage for all higher marvels; what now does it add of its own? What does it contribute from its altered relation to the surrounding and indwelling nature? The limitation must therefore not be merely in general, but specifically determined against the two natures; so that the thus liberated, fully rounded and self-enclosed conscious being, would be in a position to precisely determine its relations to the two spheres; in order, after it has also separated out its own contribution, to determine the measure of daemonic influences.

It is indeed true that the concrete manifestation of all spiritual substances makes such a determination not impossible; but what progress have we made in the six centuries in which such investigations were urgently demanded? How could one have expected the physicians of earlier times to undertake the solution of such a task? A further question, demanded by its resolution, was: what kind of organic disease lies at the foundation here? Of possession one knew: a power stronger than that of man has taken hold of him; from its objective side it has enmeshed him, and now holds him, as if woven about with a web, captive in its net; so that he, an object of the highest pity, has claim upon the help of his fellow men. It must now above all be determined: does not the incubus rest in its natural ground likewise upon such a natural evil, which only later passes over into the ethical realm? Has not perhaps that evil, which possession has exchanged, and among the organic realms and the forces active in them, merely chosen another hearth for itself? \

Possession is a disease that does not shrink from stepping forth into the bright light of day; the sleeplessness invariably connected with it even keeps the shadowing of organic night far from it. Could not the incubus, most frequently seizing women, be a nocturnal disease, bound to sleep in the same way as the former to wakefulness? Could not man under certain circumstances free himself from the envelopment of this sleep, and now seeing in the darkness, illuminate it with his own eye-light, as the beasts of the night, breaking through the natural sleep, swarm through the darkness like living natural dreams? The state in which those women who rode to the Sabbath found themselves was very well known to the physicians; they knew that a deep, stone-hard sleep held them fast, and that it lay upon the sleepers like an incubus. How now, were not the occurrences of the Sabbath perhaps the deliria of this ephialtic evil, and was the damage to the land that went forth from the sick perhaps the effect of the insalubrious atmosphere that surrounded them? Such considerations would without doubt have led to the precise knowledge and sharp distinction of animal magnetism, and vindicated for nature a great part of the domain which, owing to ignorance of its power and to the incomprehensible ambiguity of the phenomena, theology had to occupy.

But great discoveries are, in the course of things hitherto, not the matter of deliberate reflection; but favors of a higher power sparingly granted to different times. They were not granted to the physicians in those times, and so the confusion remained for the spirits. The wondrous phantasmagoria that characterized all the births of evil had to pass over immediately to the imagination, and designate this as one of the hearths in which it had firmly seated itself. This investigation too was the affair of the physicians and naturalists.

Was not a pathological condition conceivable, which seized the afflicted, like the corresponding drives in nymphomania, and now poured itself out into a luxuriant plastic form, which, drawing all higher drives down to itself, transformed the inner man without their own doing; much like in certain illnesses through exanthema and secondary formations the organism undergoes a transformation? This must then lead over to the investigation of the role that the imagination assumes in human affairs. It is the mythical faculty in man; myth, in the ordinary sense, grasped as the living plastic of the spirit.

This power had already prevailed in earlier times before the Christian era; the blocks which it had then shaped lay openly in the folk belief everywhere. Whole chunks were visibly mingled also in the witchcraft belief; a part of them indeed hung together with the theological element of this belief; but a part was also visibly agglomerated through that imagination of the plastic masses. Above all, therefore, thought must be given to the separation of these elements, so that here too the legend in man might be separated from history; and not, by rashly misconstruing, punish as wicked malice what belongs solely to the poetry in man. \

But scarcely anyone has thought of such a distinction; very comprehensible, because all these domains still lay confusedly intermingled, and one had in general become too accustomed to identifying the rogue in man straightaway with the demon, and to attributing to this latter all too often, without distinction, the earlier bold extravagance. So innocent were the first inquisitors of Germany, Sprenger and Institoris, that they took the mocking folk legend of the phallus nest in full earnest, and recount it with a concerned expression in the Malleus. If what is truly characteristic of the evil is held to be the voluntary assumption, so that it thereby falls under culpability and responsibility. It is the business of the jurists and of those who occupy themselves with the ethical nature of man to ascertain the measure of this culpability, and to weigh the punishment accordingly.

But the measure of guilt will be all the less, the more of the illness there is in the evil, and vice versa. One does not deny, although one by no means holds it to be absolutely necessary, that a culpability preceded the ordinary possession; and yet one regards this itself as a misfortune which by no means falls under punishment. Could it not be, just as here the illness in certain cases followed upon the guilt as a punishment, that conversely in witchcraft the evil often first came in the train of the illness? All crimes that are committed at the sabbath follow upon the sleep-like condition, in which the vision of the sabbath itself first dawns. If so, then the investigators must say to themselves: must not the first of these visions also have arisen from a similar state of stupor, so that here too the night was first, out of whose darkness their light then first developed.

In waking, our I hovers freely over its will, and exercises its arbitrariness according to its well-being; full responsibility therefore weighs upon us for all our actions. In sleep this will rests, like a bow that has been unstrung; but he who should string it can scarcely recollect himself. Would it now be the nature of illness that lower organic powers, or natural powers, or even spiritual ones within it gained the upper hand, and now entered vicariously, and from below upward, imitating, strung the slackened sinew; would in such a case a responsibility be imputable to man? The will is in ordinary life well guarded, so that with sound senses such an abuse cannot be perpetrated with it.

But how the likewise well-preserved spirit may yet come to madness; so it also seems impossible that a sleepwalker, in his unconscious nighttime activity of reality, should ever commit a murder: would one be justified in demanding the spilled blood from his hands? The actual crime that ought to be punished in these monsters is this: that they have gathered around the demon, and entering into his service, have thereby surrendered themselves to him as organs through which he can break into the natural reality of things, which would otherwise remain closed to him. But the actual culprit of the first order will then be the leader of these instruments; the courts, however, cannot reach him; they must therefore hold to the instruments themselves, the culprits of the second order. \

The manner in which the demon has come to these organs may now, however, be a varied one. They may have surrendered themselves to him with full consciousness, in all sobriety; that will, according to the nature of the matter, occur as the rarest case; and those who find themselves in it will without doubt be the most punishable, and the full severity of the law strikes them with complete justification. But the master may also have seduced them to himself through cunning, he may have pressed and stolen them; he may have bought them into his serfdom, or taken them over as an inheritance from conscienceless ancestors. That establishes certain degrees of guilt, which one must also allow to stand where one has recognized them; but who would want to distinguish and bring them to light in all cases? The slave-works that are produced in this factory are now again of varied kinds. Some are entirely of an idealistic nature, and confine themselves within the mystical circle that the fellowship fills. Their investigation and punishment then belongs before the forum of the inner judge; and God above all has judgment to hold over them. Or they have broken forth beyond this circle, and have paved their way to reality.

Then, however, they have either again remained confined within the domain of the human will, and with the best intention of carrying out their purpose, the power to do so has yet been lacking for the willing. Then those who have thus been inclined and willed evil, without actually being evildoers, belong before the judgment seat of the church. Or the mystically arisen, in the will carried evil, has also been born into the light in its execution; then it is indeed the tribunal of the state to which the jurisdiction belongs. The decision will be subject to no difficulty: if the physical has been injured with physical means, as in actual poison-brewings. But otherwise, if the means of execution show a metaphysical character; if not the enveloping, but the invisible enveloped has actively worked.

If free confession occurs, then after due investigation of the fact the decision is again without difficulty. But if denial enters in, then the civil judge finds himself at once driven into a domain in which he is utterly blind and without path or guidance, helplessly lost. Every fact is as it were a living creature, equipped with body and soul; and the soul is as in rapture, and stands in no speech with him; it only points mutely to a world in which he is a stranger, and his mandate extinguished. As the crimes root in the darkness of the secret, so witnesses, means of proof, and everything alike vanish into the transcendent; the procedure at once loses all firm ground; in the unknown world the litigator no longer knows his way, and falls into helpless confusion. The question of the forum was therefore likewise above all to be investigated in full sharpness by the jurists. Further, a knowledge of the statistics and history of crimes on a grand scale was to be expected of them. \

Whole centuries were oppressed by the fear of the general spread of this greatest of all crimes; and if this fear indeed abated at intervals, and the light-hearted blood sought to vent itself through mockery, then the panic terror emerged with increased intensity now here and then again at another place, and oppressed the minds all the more strongly. But now crimes, although it is their peculiar nature to recognize no law, yet have a law of necessity to which they cannot but submit. All such crimes, as country plagues, have certain carriers and focal points to which they attach themselves; in which they first, as it were, embodied themselves, and through which they broke into society, and now in it again seek to propagate and sustain themselves in gangs.

The number of such carriers is for each crime measured, weighed, and counted, and this measure is conditioned by the state of health of society; the intensity of the evil in its initial impact and its agglomerating effect is likewise determined thereby. This constant figure is of course, according to times and places, capable of increase and decrease; but given the constitution of human nature, oscillating between malignancy and benignity, yet in its changes confined within certain limits. The magistrates and courts are now placed at a point where they can recognize these figures and limits, if only approximately.

If therefore crimes in the common opinion multiply beyond all measure outward, they will not easily lend credence to the startled anxiety, and allow themselves to be biased in their judgment thereby. But if the number has truly and undeniably increased, then they will recognize in the evil the character of an endemic or epidemic social disease; and will be more inclined to derive the overrunning of the contagion from the increasing contagiousness and disposition of the infected, than from the augmented number of the contagiously actually culpable. Then, however, the office of the judge divides into a twofold: one conclusive, directed against the herd of the contagion, and one protective and preservative for those exposed to the contagion; which then leads us over to these, since it may not easily be accomplished without the clergy. For it has namely fallen to the theologians, above all, to instruct the judges and the physicians concerning the degree of influence that the demon can gain over human nature.

What power does he possess by nature, what has he acquired for himself in addition, and on what can he, over against the Christian church, lay claim? These are questions whose discussion must precede every accusation of alliance with him. The first witchcraft trial is, after the first Fall, brought and decided before the judgment seat of God. The first-created tribal heads of the race had passed by the well of the water of life, and had drunk from the magic well. The dragon had beguiled them with cunning, and they had concluded the alliance of servitude with him.

The woman had first believed him: that, where she ate, she would become clairvoyant, and like the Elohim in discerning good and evil; powerful over both, and therefore by no means obligated to death. Thus, in eating at the table of the Sabbath of its fruit, she had committed an outrage against the Lord, and brought the husband to the same deed through partaking with her. Now God, the all-discerner, sits in judgment, and the inquisition begins. The accused are summoned; they are themselves the witnesses of their guilt, for since they have become clairvoyant, their fear and their shame must loudly proclaim that they have now taken evil into themselves. \

The man shifts the blame onto the woman, this one onto the dragon; to him, as the first instigator, the judgment is therefore pronounced first of all. The curse strikes him amid all the animals; he shall not stand upright, but shall wallow on his belly and eat dust all the days of his life. To the bond that he has knotted with the woman, the enmity between his seed and hers shall set itself in opposition. The heel, the outermost part of the one, is given over to him; but she, in return, shall trample his innermost and highest. To the woman is imposed the toil and the pain of childbirth, and she is given into subjection to the man; to this one, however, a toilsome life on the earth made thorny for him, until he returns to her from whom he was taken.

Thus was the judgment held, as only God could hold it, with complete insight into the matter at hand; the punishments, however, not like ones casually alighting on the individual, but springing from the offense itself; hence also not confining themselves to the individual, but inhering in the whole race. It had wholly fallen prey to death, which was awarded in common to all the condemned; and indeed it was not merely the bodily death, but also the spiritual one that was consigned to it; namely, the fall and the reprobation, of which the former is only a sign full of meaning. After the times had run their course, a second judgment was held. Because to the seducing spirit, in a contemplative beholding of the present, there also belongs a will that is similarly firm, constant, and unchangeable; thus the fall and reprobation were irrevocably fixed for him. But because to the seduced ones, united in body and soul, there inhabits a discursive mode of thinking, and thus also a will that is mobile in like manner; therefore history was allotted to them for expiation, under favorable assistance. In its unfolding, the enmity set between the seed of the woman and the seed of the dragon worked its effect; the blood purified itself in the one race to the degree that it poisoned itself in the other; for this separation was the task of the ancient time.

The chosen people had therefore separated itself from the other peoples; in it, pride and hypocrisy again drove to the left, just as humility and piety tended to the right. With the latter stood God; the other side was the dragon's side; but they believed in him more than in God, because they took his illusory image for the image of God. When at last the opposites had come to their simplest expression, when on the one side God had hidden himself in the Incarnation, on the other the dragon had disguised himself in possession; then the hour of judgment had arrived. But this time it appeared as if not the true God were going to judge over the evil one and his followers, but the reverse; the evil one had summoned the tribunal, his followers sat on the judges' seats, and it seemed as though the reprobate were to pronounce judgment over the one who reproved. The blind ones judged: it was not they, but He who had allied himself with Beelzebub, and, as a sorcerer, had wrought signs and wonders through his power. \

They therefore condemned him to death, and thus the auto-da-fé was held on Golgotha. Hell rejoiced; the gray bonds of the left had triumphed over the fellowship of the covenant on the right; the ancient prophecy had been brought to shame: for the seed of the dragon had crushed the head of the seed of the woman, since the slayer of the serpent had himself been entwined and slain by the serpent's own coils. Then the wonders of providence suddenly became manifest. Sin, brought forth through the misuse of freedom and stepping in between God and the creature, had also split soul and body apart within it, and thus carried death into them.

The restoration could only take place by God, through union with the creature preserved in the same temptation, casting out the divisive sin, and that creature now going with freedom into death, thereby atoning for and expelling the sin that had intruded between body and soul. The moment of death, which Hell in its judgment pronounced over the victim, was therefore the instant of its defeat; the wounded heel had only brought about the physical death, but the resurrection shattered the dragon's head; the prophecy was fulfilled, the spiritual death was averted for all who held to the Victor. But the act was also exemplary, enclosing within itself the whole history and its future; therefore in this resurrection was also prefigured the destruction of physical death at the end of the atoning history and the restoration of all things.

The serpent-treader thus stands ever since upon the head of the dragon; the stone upon which his church is built has been rolled away from him; the center and core of his power has been taken from him, only the outwardly deeper, as it were the animal element, has remained to him; and he still convulsively entwines with the coils of this broken nature the stone, in order to help complete the historical expiation. This the theologians above all must now consider: that the Inquisition, in which human judgment sat as deputy for God to pass sentence upon attempts at the restoration of ancient covenant fellowship, imaged forth the judgment of God in the beginning; and not that in which the children of the world under their prince pronounced their sentence over the leader of the children of God. The demon no longer has the power as formerly to entangle an entire race, so that only a flood could wipe out the magnitude of the corruption. He no longer has the might to infect entire peoples, so that other peoples must be mustered against them to ward off the pestilence. For the church with all its institutions of salvation stands opposed to him, as protection and shield for its own; it is stronger than he, and his host is bound by its own.

Only those who renounce it; individuals who venture beyond its gentle boundary, can henceforth become his covenant allies. Thus the talk of the witchcraft companions, who had grown in their hordes like the sand by the sea, must have been exaggerated; and the tales of countless child-murders they had committed must rest upon illusion or falsehood. Trois Echelles, who long played the jester at the court of Charles IX but was executed in 1571 on the Greveplatz, had made his confessions before the king, his marshals, and Admiral Coligny concerning the Sabbath, his dances, his poison kitchen, and his unchastity, and how he performed his arts with the help of a spirit. \

To gain pardon, he had named his accomplices and the signs by which they might be recognized. In the investigation many of those thus designated were found. Some said there had been 1,200 of them; others reported 3,000 were discovered; still others claimed the companions numbered 20,000, more than 100,000, even 300,000. The negligence of the judges, it was complained, had so multiplied the number into the immeasurable, that a greater multitude---then whores and whoremongers---filled the Christian world. One sees how the panic terror, rising from stage to stage, heaped these figures of unchristian fears one upon another.

If we consider the arrangement of the household in the physical nature, then we see there an analogue of the demonic in the bewildering, harmony-disturbing, immoderate-acting, violent forces that from time to time, perhaps under foreign influence, arise and seem to break loose from the laws of nature, and now produce great anomalies in the otherwise tranquil course of nature.

But immediately the healing power of nature also steps forth; it overspins the disturbing forces, levels and smooths out the inequalities, and the old harmony is soon restored again. This proves, first, the superiority of the preserving forces, and that those which are from evil appear subordinated to them; for which reason the lawlessness of the disorderly is dominated by the law of order, and thereby likewise acquires its legality. It is no different with the moral world, where the freedom of spirits complicates the relations; but where the rage of the disturbing forces, in the long run, can accomplish nothing against the quiet resistance of the good, and still less against its active manifestation.

In both worlds, therefore, the masses of forces on both sides are unequally distributed, and those of the preserving necessarily preponderate; precisely because the world appears set upon continuance. Should it now be otherwise in the realm of grace, since the antediluvian times that have passed away? Should God in them be weaker than the demon? Should the gift from above find in the good that lies in man a less willing reception, than the seduction that wells up from below finds prepared for itself in evil? To drive evil up to its outermost peak of negation, as it is found among the initiates of the magical realm, there is required a genius in perversity, such as belongs to all good things in order to form a mystical saint; for the mere allowing free play to the wicked or to the good nature in them will by no means lead to the goal.

But genius of every kind is the affair only of the few; and it stands not to be believed that the black outweighs the white, and that there are incomparably more devil-worshippers and possessed than friends of God and saints; the middle between both will then be filled with the ordinary crowd, bad and good alike. Men have felt this at all times, and have explained the mass of increasing evil to themselves through the approach of the last times; where the impending downfall must be ushered in through such an increase. But this opinion has proved itself premature after the passage of so many centuries; and the judges were not authorized to proceed upon this presupposition. Finally, as the mystical life of the saints rests upon the foundation of the simple moral, plain good conduct in ordinary life, and what emerges here is only repeated upon a higher stage; so will this demonic abomination likewise present itself, only as a deeper stage of depravity, of the region of a vicious life, within the bounds of the commonplace. \

For he who wills the true freedom of his will seeks it either in the source-like freedom, which has also originally granted its own to the personal will, and thereby unites him with this his source in God. Or he seeks it, in contradiction to it, in his self-will; and now inclines, in necessary gravity, toward the source-point of all negation, toward the demon. Already in ordinary life, therefore, there enters a continuity of the earthly good with the heavenly and superheavenly, and a correspondence of all the bad with the subearthly and the infernal; and to the covenant that is lived with God, there lives another opposed to it with the demon.

Now in this twofold covenant there is a double manner of execution: either the union takes place preferentially in the theoretical will, or in the practical, outwardly effective one. In the first case, the union with God goes toward the purification of the individual in itself, that with the demon toward the strengthening of the false self-will in its negation. In the other, it is the active, outwardly effective will that on the one side experiences purification and strengthening toward the good, on the other side defilement and energy toward the evil.

In the latter case, his actions are the affair of the political society, which experiences their influence in their consequences, and honors them through recognition if they tend toward the good, or wards them off through repression if they are directed toward evil. In the other case, what he has accomplished within the confines of his earthly home is not the affair of the political society, which by no means has the power to intrude into this his fortress; but solely that of the church, which on the negative side exercises its jurisdiction in the confessional. Now, if there exists a state in man, the mystical one, in which these pacts close more tightly because he is placed in a relation, as it were between death and life, and can intervene more deeply into the super- and sub-sensual; then these distinctions will persist in him.

The mystic who has turned himself toward God will, above all, have strengthened, purified, and expanded his inner contemplative life, and through this then also his outer, active one, under the conditions of that first; but the opposite will occur in those who have directed themselves toward the other side. Here too, therefore, the distinction between the esoteric and the exoteric must above all be sharply maintained; only the latter modalities belong before the tribunal of the state, which must leave the others to the church. Over the sabbath and all its abominations, therefore, the criminal courts have no judgments to pronounce; no more than they accept divorce suits on the basis of incubus and succubus. Such things belong to the sphere of action of the church, which on its part by no means interrogates its confessional mirror with the torture. \

To it also belongs, insofar as it is feasible, the decision: whether the evil lying in man, in the given case, suffices to explain the fact; or whether an explicit pact with the objective evil was required for it. In these matters, one has truly not failed to make inquiries; but we do not see that in the course of the occurrences the full importance of these preliminary questions and investigations was recognized, and that one came to a clear resolution through their answers. One must, however, remember that we, who have surveyed the incidents and experiences of so many centuries, stand in an entirely different relation to the question than those who, at the beginning devoid of all this practical insight, suddenly saw a work, as if rising and growing forth from the ground of hell, before them. The world seemed threatened by this birth of the abyss; it was as if a chasm had opened in the midst of society, which, by vomiting forth the glowing lava of a horror-covered, subterranean depth, threatened to grow into a volcano that would undermine the whole society and draw it down to itself.

To ward off the evil, if there was still time, the courts were dispatched; they could not preface their protective work with those investigations which, so it seemed, had to emerge as results from their own inquiries. It was easy to speak of the improbability that so many were involved in the affair as deliberate criminals; since the memory of the Manichaean heresy still lived in everyone's recollection. At that time, one could also deem it improbable that many people would confess to such fundamentally perverse, absurd doctrines; and yet hundreds of thousands had adhered to them, and it had nearly come to pass that they gained the upper hand. One had countless voluntary confessions, not extorted by torments, and these revealed the great spread of the evil. That certainly pointed to a pestilential contagion; but rabies is likewise a disease---should one therefore allow it to spread and spare the dogs because they are not guilty of their misfortune?

This dissemination, which, as has been found, did not merely encompass many individuals in their spatial coexistence; but also extended itself hereditarily from generation to generation, was so deeply rooted in the general folk belief: that entire places were found whose inhabitants, having become of one mind, abandoned their dwellings and betook themselves elsewhere; for no other reason than because the authorities could not bring themselves to engage with this kind of crime. The people also considered themselves entitled to self-help in such cases, as indeed in Laon two such accused persons, whom the court had condemned to be swept to dust, were stoned; allegedly to avert the wrath of God from themselves.

This imposed upon the judges the obligation to attend to the matter with all seriousness, and to combat the ruin in its germ; lest it burst into flames over the entire ancient order. Lambert Danäus relates: in some regions, probably Savoyard, the audacity and fury had gone so far that several of the accused openly and without concealment before all the world proclaimed that, if they could once obtain a great man as their leader, they would then be numerous and strong enough that, assembled around him, they might venture an open war against any king, and that they might hope, with the aid of their art, to carry off victory over him as easily as the Huns once did over Sigebert the Frankish king through sorcery, as may be found in Gregory of Tours. :) This probably spoke the despair from them over the persecution they endured; but one sees how they felt themselves, and how the courts stood toward them in the battle line, and had no time to make great reflections on the nature of their task.

#### C. The Witch Trials in Sorcery

\
