One would grievously err against the courts, namely those which judged in the better times, and among the greater corporations, where religion, morality, conscience, righteousness, equity, and humanity still counted for something, if one believes: that throughout judgments in this matter had been rendered with levity, inhumanity, and conscienceless harshness. The good judges recognized at all times the uncertain, treacherous ground on which they had to walk. Directed everywhere toward the visible, the tangible, they found themselves here in a world of phantoms, where the knowable seemed only the mask behind which the actual object of the investigation hid itself unrecognizably.

As with the angels in old paintings, so with all the facts a face was indeed visible, but the body vanished into a floating garment, eluding every firm grasp; and everything that according to the claims of the law should have been worked out in solid form dissolved for them into an airy indeterminacy. Even in the very best case, where an unreserved, clear, entirely voluntary confession of the penitent criminal occurred, the doubt did not therefore recede; for he himself was not certain of his cause, and often wavered between the suspicion of deception and the belief in the reality. Only one thing stood indubitably firm and graspable and naked and clear: the flames that the sentence had kindled had neither fantastical nor ideal tongues; they licked and consumed what was offered to them, without leaving a trace behind. Therefore we see at the French parlements the foremost legal experts of the time taking up investigations of this kind, and frequently conducting them to the end with great conscientiousness and mastery.

One clearly recognizes in this process how, there in the progression, a certain practice forms half through instinct, half through deliberation; how the reluctance to enter these regions hostile to the law, and to extend the investigation beyond a certain point, continually increases; how a salutary vigilance establishes itself against the excesses of the lower courts, and how finally other cases are not readily admitted than those which, through their complication with palpable other crimes, provide the investigation with a firm foundation.

There is no cause, where ecclesiastical high courts conducted the investigation, to presuppose that they proceeded with less conscientiousness, although the difficulties for them were still considerably greater, because they had to enter into the inner essence of things, which the secular courts avoided as much as possible; whereby, of course, false views concerning the inner connection of the matter, such as the educational level of the time brought with it, exerted their disadvantageous influence. All these judges, ecclesiastical as well as secular, always directed their strained attention to this connection, and inquired, precisely to calm their conscience, after all means and ways that led into this inner realm, or upon which it emerged toward them, and could now be grasped and mastered. Since theoretical inquiries were of no use to them, they busied themselves mainly with practical means that led to this end, and from which they believed that with their help they would discover the truth. \

Let us subject the principal of these means, which they gradually adopted, to closer examination. One of the three evident proofs, even in the sorcery trials, was the unanimous testimony of unimpeachable witnesses. The witness must be of unblemished character, and have the presumption in his favor that the good, guarded by conscience, prevails in him; so that he may swear and be sworn to speak the truth. But such witnesses are to be found only in crimes that have come to light in the outer world; in those, however, that belong to the inner world, at the Sabbath, only accomplices can be taken. Thus, in the beginning, it must have provided the judges with a reassuring conviction when they learned that the same event which had occurred at the synagogue found its confirmation in the mouth of ten witnesses; who, when arrested, had no communication with one another, or who, living miles apart, simultaneously made the same unprompted confession.

It seemed a complete proof of the truth of the whole abomination; all the witnesses could not have known what was testified unless they had been present; they had then beheld the incident, and their concordant testimony raised the narrative to complete certainty. But one forgot thereby that all the bystanders must necessarily also have been accomplices; that they all had chosen the demon as their chief, and placed themselves in his service. Now, however, the demon, in his own person, could not be valid before any court as an accusing witness. For concerning the spirits, the theologians rightly predicate that they are confirmed in the choice they made at the test of freedom, and undergo no change.

Those on the good side are thus confirmed in the good, and therefore can utter no lie. But of those on the evil side it is said: they are murderers from the beginning, and have not stood in the truth, for the truth is not in them; when they speak lies, they speak of their own, for they are liars and the fathers of lies. The demon can thus well bear witness to the truth, against his will, through contradiction; but he cannot himself utter it without abandoning his nature; God, however, governs and limits his power indeed, but refrains from doing violence to his spiritual freedom.

But the witch, however, has---under that presupposition---concluded a pact between her own will and his, that he enter into hers with this one, and strengthen him for all evil. Her will is thus his own, and when she gives testimony, then he has begotten it in her. But he cannot give true testimony; rather, his accusation must result in acquittal, and only his testimony, set upon acquittal, lead to condemnation. It changes nothing that the one who is by nature mendacious confirms his statement even under torture; for torture may not, as one has often believed, cleanse the dishonorable one of his guilt and overpower the foreign will ruling in him.

Only the truly pure and genuinely reconciled with God could, as the theologian Tanner rightly remarks, be admitted to such testimony before death. But even if such perfectly valid testimonies were present, nothing more would follow from them than what the testifiers themselves can prove; since they themselves by no means have full conviction whether that which they have seen was reality or illusion, they also cannot prove the former with certainty. The agreement of many who have not previously agreed upon it proves nothing here; for according to the laws of rapport---which were indeed unknown in those times---this concurrence only proves that they have been in spiritual community with one another, and thus ordered around one center, in which they have seen the same vision. Since one felt, with greater or lesser clarity, the inadequacy in this kind of proof, one looked around for others. \

He who has been bitten by the tarantula doubtless often beholds her image in the vision; because through his condition he remains connected with her. Thus one had also often observed that, when those suspected of causing an obsession approached the maleficiated one, all symptoms of his affliction worsened; and that they, once risen above the horizon of his vision, remained there as the actual tormentors and malefactors. Here it was not the infamous criminals who testified mutually against one another; rather, it was the victims of their infamies who, through the manner in which they were struck by them, had come to clairvoyance in the realm of darkness; and now with sharpened eyes tracked down their enemies in their very hiding places.

This kind of witness-proof was not subject to the objection that made the previous one entirely unusable, and it seemed there was nothing substantial to object against it. We shall consult experience on this, and we choose an event that took place far away across seas, in a Protestant land, among entirely unprepared people. In the year 1602, in New England, in Salem and Dover and the region around Boston, a series of events occurred that cost many people their lives. Two years earlier, in the house of a resident there, Goodwin, a young girl, otherwise of good character, had fallen into obsession; Cotton Mather had taken her into his house and made a report about it known. She had stated that, when her paroxysm approached, someone brought her an invisible horse. She then jumped onto a chair, positioned herself in the posture of a rider, and began to kick and stamp and gallop. She spoke with invisible company that wandered about with her, and listened to their answers. After two or three minutes, she seemed to imagine that she was at a distant place with the witches at an assembly; after which she later, on her invisible horse, returned again, and soon thereafter came back to herself, and told all sorts of things about the Sabbath and the people who had been there.

One sees: it was a demonized somnambulist who had directed her intentions toward the Sabbath and executed them; Mather had experimented with her in various ways, and many eyewitnesses had been present for it. Now it happened that at the end of February 1692, various young persons belonging to the family of the preacher Parris in Salem, and still several others in the neighborhood, began to behave in a strange and unusual manner. They crawled into holes and under chairs and benches, made strange and distorted gestures, spoke wondrous things, and fell into paroxysms of various kinds.

A day of fasting was held on their account, and now the thus afflicted named various persons who, as they said, hovered before their eyes in their paroxysms, and who were the ones inflicting the torments. An Indian woman in the house, who had previously baked a cake to discover the witches, was the most severely blamed; she was beaten and threatened, and now confessed that she was a witch, and that the Devil wanted to force her to sign a book which, according to other testimony, was red, of considerable thickness, and a cubit in length. Meanwhile the number of sufferers had risen to ten; but the number of the accused was far greater still. \

Testimony was given against one named Cory: that her spectral shape brought them a book to sign, and that she bit, pinched, and strangled them. In the examination she confessed that she had a yellow bird, and that a black man whispered something in her ear. A child of about five years was accused: that all were tormented upon whom it only cast its eyes; it bit the tormented ones in the process, who showed the marks of its little teeth on their arms. On April 11 there was a public examination before six magistrates and some clergymen. The afflicted complained against many, with terrible screaming and gnashing of teeth. Especially against one, Mistress Proctor, the screaming was most vehement; and when her husband came to assist her, screaming was raised against him as well. The afflicted usually fell down upon seeing the accused, and they were then made to recite the Lord's Prayer, and searches were also made for witch-marks, as one was believed to have been found on a certain Bishop.

The accused were always to sign the book, and then they would receive relief; one of them had allowed herself to be induced to sign through her pains, and her affliction had abated. But now she, the former afflicted one, became a tormentor; for her specter appeared to another person and pressed for a signing. One of those thus haunted by her once pointed to a spot where she stood; another who was present, though he saw no one, struck there with a rapier, and now the afflicted cried out: You have given her a thrust in the eye! The struck one soon confessed thereafter: that she had become a witch through the book, and now tormented the maid; but in the process had received two wounds, one in the eye, and a larger one on the side, of which the scar was found upon examination. On May 14, 1692, Sir William took over the government; the matter took a more serious turn, and the witches were put in irons; whereupon it was said that the afflicted felt better and were freed from their torment.

A month later Bridget Bishop was executed, who always maintained her innocence. On July 19 five others followed her in death. Rebecca Nurse, one among them, had at first received a verdict of not guilty from the jury; at this, first all the accusers in the courtroom, and then all the afflicted except her, raised such a terrible screaming that all those present were horrified by it. The jury now assembled for more mature deliberation, the result of which was then guilty. All five defended their innocence to their last breath. On August 10 five more were executed, all of whom steadfastly denied their guilt.

Among them was a clergyman, Mr. Burroughs, who delivered such a moving speech from the ladder, in testimony of his innocence, that many could not restrain their tears. But the accusers said: the black man dictated to him what he should say. John Willard was another of their number, who had earlier arrested many others; but because he became unwilling to seize ever more others, they cried out against him as well. He fled forty miles from Salem, but was recaptured, and those in the paroxysm knew exactly the time, and said: Now Willard is captured. \

In September Giles Corey gave himself death, because he observed that the jury freed no one. Soon after that, when eight others were executed, the cart at the hill would not move properly; the afflicted said: the devil was holding it back. Captain Alden sat fifteen weeks in prison, and then escaped; likewise Philip English and his wife; their property was confiscated. In October some of the accusers, who boasted of seeing spirits, were summoned by J. Ballard to Andover, to tell him who was tormenting his wife. The people fell into convulsions after their fashion; then they named the persons whom they saw sitting at the head, and others at the feet of the afflicted.

Gradually more than fifty persons were also accused there. Some of those examined confessed their guilt, and added circumstances that authenticated their statements. They agreed therein with the accusations of the afflicted and with one another; they gave the time of their covenant with Satan, and their motives for it; they confessed how they had flown through the air on poles to the Sabbath, how they had mocked the sacraments there, and signed themselves into the book; and they even showed the wounds from which the blood had been taken for it.

They spoke therein of the toads that they had suckled, and showed the sores here as well; a turn of events that, as we have seen, is peculiar to the English school of witchcraft. The confusion grew ever greater; many elders believed their children were witches, many men held their wives to be such. The spirit-seers became more numerous, and they said: they saw the spirits of the murdered hovering over those who had killed them. Thus they spoke of Justice Bradstreet, who himself had committed thirty or forty suspects to prison, that he had murdered nine of them; he saved himself by flight. A dog was soon afflicted; the seers said: the brother of the fugitive was riding it. This one took flight, and the dog was killed. Another dog met the same fate, because they were seized by paroxysm when he looked at them.

Meanwhile, among the accused were also many of the very best reputation, whose Christian disposition no one could doubt; and the number of the accused in general became so great that one could not imagine them all to be guilty. Also the protestations of the nineteen executed had had their effect. Thus one came to consider whether the whole thing might not be Satan's work, who thus deluded the afflicted? The clergy, at the request of the authorities, held a meeting, and here, among other things, the question was put to them: whether Satan could not appear both in the form of innocent and godly persons, as well as in that of guilty and godless ones, in order to deceive those whom he had afflicted? and they answered that he might do so. Now one began to reflect; to be sure, in January 1693 twenty-six were still examined, but only three were convicted, and none more executed. Soon the convicted obtained a reprieve; on April 25 one confessed himself guilty, and yet the jury pronounced him not guilty. \

And now, after the storm had lasted sixteen months, nineteen at the gallows, one voluntarily deceased, over fifty had confessed to witchcraft, over 150 still sat in the prisons, and more than 200 were yet under accusation; after the judges, like the best of the people, had been reviled, they finally desisted. The accused were set free in all the prisons, the fugitives returned, and peace was restored. With it now came the reactions as well. Since everything had proceeded from the house of the clergyman Parris, and he himself had been a strong zealot in the matter, many withdrew from his congregation and submitted a petition against him: that he had given credence to the accusations of the devil. He acknowledged his error, to be sure, but the accusers did not rest until he was removed.

A day of fasting and repentance was proclaimed, to atone for the congregation. On it, one of the judges stood up in their midst and publicly confessed: that in the recently occurred events he might have erred in many points, and he humbly begged forgiveness. Six of the accused women, who had confessed their guilt, signed a document in which they, among other things, recounted: We were brought to the afflicted persons, who, as they said, fell into their paroxysms upon our arrival. Mr. Barnard then prayed, and our hands were laid upon them, and the seized ones now said: it would become better for them again, and we were guilty of their torments; whereupon we were immediately seized and sent as prisoners to Salem.

We, however, who knew ourselves to be entirely innocent of all that, were exceedingly dismayed, astonished, and confused on account of the sudden assault; so that we almost lost our reason. Since our best friends, beholding us in such a state, believed there was no other means to save our lives, they persuaded us, out of love and pity, to confess that what those others said of us was true. But those were only confessions that were suggested to some of us by others, who said: we were witches, and they knew it, and we knew it likewise; and they knew that we knew it. Since we had now almost lost all understanding, all reason, and all mental faculties, we were not able to judge of our condition; and the most that we said was only an assent to what they chattered to us beforehand.

When we were afterward a little composed again, and they told us what we had confessed; then we certainly said again that we were innocent, and that we knew nothing at all of such things. --- One cannot depict more touchingly and emphatically the state of mind of countless ones who stood in court in such accusations, nor more aptly portray how people, often without malice, impose their delusions upon one another. The twelve jurors likewise signed a document in which they declared: "how they had not been able to comprehend or withstand the mysterious deceptions of the powers of darkness; and how they therefore feared, along with others, though unwittingly and unintentionally, to have loaded upon themselves and the congregation the guilt of blood.

They therefore pleaded with God that He would not impute this guilt to anyone; but all whom they had unjustly offended, they humbly begged forgiveness." That was now good and praiseworthy; but the executed were not thereby brought back to life. The entire narrative vividly illustrates how the good folk had entered the enchanted forest, and became all the more entangled in it the further they advanced. If we consider in this the view that was taken during the investigation: that the demon had caused the confusion; then one sees that he made use therein of two kinds of people as his instruments. \

The first group consists of the afflicted: their actions were driven by malice, or at the very least, no suspicion had ever been cast upon them; they were clairvoyant, experienced their paroxysms, were struck down by them upon seeing the others, and their numbers grew through the ever-wider spread of the affliction.

The others were the tormentors. On their side the evil, probably with the Indian woman in the same house as Parris, had taken its beginning. Mather writes later, in his history of New England, the whole confusion to the Indian pawwaws or sorcerers, who had sent their spirits among the Europeans. That woman, who wandered about in the kitchen, formed according to him then the transition; and from her the evil passed in pursuit to the ever increasing number of the others. The allegedly acting and the suffering formed two rows; but in their midst stood deciding the red book in between. Who signed belonged to the first, who refused to the others; and if one of these decided upon the signature, he, like that woman, immediately entered the other row, and became spectral.

The evil also passes over to children, even spreads among the domestic animals; one of the two dogs places itself on the side of the afflicted, the other joins the tormentors. Now the question arises: Can one of the two rows give legally valid testimony against the other, without accusing itself? The left could only, if seriously repentant, direct its testimony against itself. The right, the afflicted, are possessed according to the presupposition; but there is no infallible sign by which one could distinguish the possession through immediate incursion of Satan from the obsession through mediation of a third. But if the first were the case, then the thus possessed could not testify against the others that they had obtained Satan through their mediation; these could rather with greater probability give testimony against them that they, the first-possessed, had transferred the devil onto them. But if even an obsession had taken place, two cases are possible.

The left had indeed sent Satan to the right; but this would have been received with conscious consent on the part of the possessed. The ones would then be possessed like the others, there would be only the difference of giving and taking, like that of incubus and succubus in possession; the movements in the neighborhood arose from the community of both, and one would have had the equal right to strike both dead, as was done to the two dogs.

Or the taking possession happened without foreknowledge of the seized; then the accused could reply: You see the devil in you only in our shape, your faith is thus deception, and your testimony false. In all these cases therefore no reliance could be placed on these statements; all advantage was however on the side of the evil, in whose interest the two lines, as the third, that of the judges, worked. For what concerns the first, the more were arrested, the so much greater number became afflicted; and the attacked always complained of new ones who frightened them, and with the number of the confessing the multitude of the defamed increased without end; the judges however were drawn ever deeper into the blood-guilt.

First the magnitude of the evil awakened the healthy understanding to counteraction, and the entanglement became now evident. The circumstance that the animals were drawn into complicity reveals: that a demonic disease in two forms here raged; and it is from what lies before us not to be ascertained how the relation of guilt to misfortune in that evil had been. But that is certain, that the gallows does not belong to the *materia medica* of such plagues. \

Another test should be provided by the witch marks, which were imprinted during the initiation on the Sabbath. The left side predominated in this. As a rule, it was pricked into the left eye under pain; applied to a cheek, it was sometimes also struck onto the left shoulder, given to the left elbow, bitten into the left side, thrust into the left thigh with the goat's foot, applied through a stab at the left knee, nailed to the same shinbone until it bled, and marked onto the left foot.

Sometimes, however, rarely, the right eye, arm, knee, or the same thigh and foot were also chosen; the mark sometimes bitten into the lower lip, sometimes also painfully set upon the heart, or also according to the Buhler Protocols of 1628: the blood taken at the shame, where the marked one received her witch mark. If one now found this mark, and had it examined by experts in the art with the probe, whether the spot bled, and all sensitivity to pain was lost; then one believed to have an infallible means of getting to the bottom of the matter.

We have previously, in these cases, seen the reverse analogy of the painful bleeding of the stigmatization over the whole body, or at individual places, and explained the phenomena in their opposition, from the contrariety of both states. Thus one mark can indeed bear witness to the reality of a demonic affection, just as the other attests to one of a higher ecstatic state. But the bodily mark is only the outer shell of something inwardly soul-like that has prevailed here, and has sought in it an expression and a body. But into the soul, however, the opposition that produces the contradiction in this body can enter in entirely different spheres.

It can first of all be the religious one, and there, certainly, the holy and the demonic will correspond to the different marks. But already here there is no guarantee that the protruding and the receding mark are altogether necessarily connected with the like inner modality. For just as one has found a stigmatization on the demonic, so the possibility also lies open: that this bloodless, partial insensitivity may also show itself on the holy; since with them too the dryness alternates with the elevation. But just as well the two states can alternate in the personal ethical sphere, in the will, in the imagination, in the domain of the affects.

In all these powers there are impulses of advance and retreat; and if these concentrate themselves bodily at any particular place, then a transgression of the same or a paralysis can occur there. But especially in the domain of life can such an organic outburst, and the revulsion opposed to it, easily take place. For if this life is driven from within outward, by upward- or downward-driving vital or also higher forces, or from without inward through sharply incising natural potencies, into ebb and flood; then the bodily, with all that is movable in it, will take part in this oscillation. If now they are spring tides that have entered, then the organically movable will overflow its usual bounds; it will break out at places that appear determined by the configuration of the fixed, and the undulations and the law of the vibrations of the fluid; and the surface will cover itself with extravasations or eruptions.

But if the spring tide is followed by a neap ebb, or if it occurs exclusively after the animation of the vital force; then the mobile element will follow the backflowing motion, just as in the sea vortex the water yields to the intruding force; and at all nodal points such vortices of the influx will then lie; partial ebbs, a disseminated vacuum; places that are bloodless and insensible, and either exist alone for themselves, or periodically alternate with those outbursts. \

This will occur all the more easily in all those inwardly magnetic states, where the mobile element on the one hand gains in mobility, the resistance of the fixed element diminishes, and the will and the imagination obtain greater influence. Here it can very easily happen that what occurs nightly in the vision comes forth in bodily and plastic form during the day. Above all, it will be the eye, the microcosmic repetition of the entire organism, in which these fleeting inner affections become fixed and enduring. The iris in particular is, in its movements, as it were, the life pulse of this organ; the opening and closing are recession and advance, and the toad's feet and other formations observed on it are the external signs of a peculiar nervous disposition, which in the own piercing ghostly gaze of such eyes shows itself still more clearly.

This will therefore also extend to all other functions of this organ; a mere cramp will, for example, inhibit the secretion of tears, which in old women is not frequent anyway; and the inability to weep will be, in equal measure, a deceptive and invalid sign for witchcraft, just as are the tremors. That more than 3000 designated persons were found in Labourt, who were almost all children, who testified that they had been at the Sabbath; this proved only in general the cramp-like disposition of the visionary people, who had taken that demonic direction, and were therefore easily susceptible to all those impressions. The judges had found a girl who, according to her statement, wanted to recognize the sorcerers at first glance.

All from Biarritz, she testified, had the toad's foot on the left eye; which those brought in from there also admitted. But the matter could not be verified, as de Lancre says; for she could not clearly demonstrate the signs as she perceived them for herself.¹ The reason was that she herself had been clairvoyant, which now made her testimony useless for the judges; because it applied only in a region into which they could not penetrate; so that for them it could only count as a matter of faith.

Another test for witches was that of cold water. The persons to be tested were thrown into the water three times, with the thumb of the right hand bound to the big toe of the left foot, and the left thumb to the right toe; but in such a way that two men held them loose by a rope. If they were guilty, they floated; whereas sinking was supposed to indicate their innocence. Around the middle of the sixteenth century, this method of testing was first tried again in Westphalia; for, as it seems, this ancient manner of ordeal, which the Franks, Lombards, Normans, and other peoples had already known, was recently brought forth again and applied to the case.

But it was by no means confined to Saxony, but was also customary elsewhere. In the Netherlands, on the Rhine, in Lorraine and Champagne, it occurs everywhere; either under the authority of the courts, or also without it carried out. A notarial act from the year 1696 attests: how five named persons, who had been under suspicion of witchcraft, offered themselves before the notary to undergo the test in the river Seine, not far from Auxerre. It happened in the presence of more than 600 people. \

They, mostly lean people, swam all, no matter what they did; only two sank, one once, and the other twice. All who had swum were now held to be sorcerers; but the judges gave no further heed to the matter, and the accused departed into exile.¹ In England it was likewise frequently applied; until at the assize held in 1712 at Brentwood, a woman drowned; whereupon Parker, the Lord Chief Justice, forbade it henceforth, because those who practiced it made themselves guilty of willful murder. The belief in the infallibility of the test was so widespread that those who underwent it, as a rule, made their confession when the outcome testified against them.

In the Amt of Linn, in the lower diocese of Cologne, an old woman saw how two women, subjected to the water ordeal, floated on top. She ran at once to the bailiff and did not cease begging him and the assembled judges to subject her also to the test; because she too was under suspicion of sorcery, and now wished to prove it false before the whole world. They finally gave her a hearing; thrown into the water, however, she floated on top, however much she struggled to dive under. Asked why she had been so hostile to her own body? she said: the demon had advised her to undergo the test, he would free her. The unfortunate woman would have paid with her life, had she not taken it herself in the dungeon.

Such confessions must necessarily have strengthened the judges and the people in their opinion of the infallibility of the method. Therefore, elsewhere in Holland, a scale had also been set up, where the suspects were weighed; and if their weight reached a minimum of 18--15 pounds, they were deemed too light and accused of witchcraft. Flying through the air had probably awakened the idea of great specific light- ness, and thus the matter was attributed by many to the demon.

When Scribonius of Marburg was present at such a test in Lemgo in the year 1582, he wrote a letter to the local magistrate interpreting the phenomenon, in which he says: the Satan, specifically light like the air, united with the substance of those bound to him, imparts to them his negative gravity, and keeps them floating on the water.³ But for one thing, witches were in general not possessed by him; from the demon, moreover, the physical properties of weight and lightness cannot be predicated; and the judges, through the test---which in any case was forbidden to Catholics in the canons and decretals as superstitious and tempting God---made themselves guilty of demonic arts.

Therefore the same interpreter later derived the matter from a hatred of the water against witches, which King James also incorporated into his Demonology: because such persons had received baptism in the water, and later renounced it; for which reason the water in turn refused to receive them later. Others maintained again: it was God who directly to the judges, or through the spirits presiding over the elements, allowed his aid to come to them in their office; yet just one step further could have spared them their efforts: namely, if those who had been swimming for a time had been pulled down and drowned. \

The phenomenon itself was, on the whole, well-founded; the ancients already knew it, according to Philochorus, among the inhabitants of an island in the Pontus who were suspected of sorcery, and the executioners stated, according to their experience, that those whom they had carried bound to the water often distinguished themselves by their extraordinary lightness. One knows how little it takes to prepare a person who already swims on his back by nature, so that he does not sink in any position; and the enforced hunger and need, the asceticism of old women, could only too easily bring about this preparation. If they were driven by this into a more inward region of somnambulism, then they were partly absolved from the law of gravity; as one observes this manifoldly in this state.

Those who had fully penetrated through nature into the realm of grace or of the curse were also exposed to the floodings and ebbings that prevail there; they had become birds of heaven or of the abyss, and while those flew toward the light and the divine as birds of the day, the others directed their flight against the evil and its darknesses. Those who, in poverty already before their death, had returned to nature a part of what they had borrowed from her; those who, in vital magnetism, had already partly unchained themselves from their fetters; those who, clinging to God, had flown upward beyond the earthly, or downward, binding themselves to the evil, had plunged beneath it; the saints and the monsters are found guilty in the same way in this test.

It is therefore entirely deceptive, and experience has long since found it so: that those who had floated high in it could not be brought to confession by any means, and had to be released like the others. Since, therefore, all these tests proved themselves insufficient, would the torture perhaps have supplemented this inadequacy and wrested the carefully guarded secret from its concealer? This infallible means, for the discovery of buried treasures of truth, was taken over from the Romans, who, in their inhuman contempt for slaves, applied it only to this class of men; but to the shame of Christendom, upon its adoption it has been applied to every class.

It seeks to arm pain against reticence, and heightens the torment until it has overcome the strongest stubbornness. The result is: the tormented one is torn asunder, rent, dislocated, and crippled; but with regard to the truth, the uncertainty remains as it was before. For if it is still conducted with some fairness, then the confession as well as the denial, uttered in the midst of its pains, is taken with indifferent sense as incontrovertible truth. But it has nothing of this character of apodictic certainty, but rather leaves the judgment entirely undecided between opposing probabilities. For the tortured one has been innocent or guilty. In the first case, he resists with the feeling of his innocence, with the dread of death and shame, and in earlier times with the terror of the threatened damnation if he should speak lies in the decisive moment, against the pains pressing upon him, overcomes them, and persists in denial; if, namely, he possesses the superhuman steadfastness to endure the superhuman.

In the other case it is the feeling of his guilt, in order to escape death and shame, which with stubbornness seals his mouth; he likewise remains victor in that struggle, and denies like the first one. Torture has extorted two negative confessions, one of which is truth, the other lie; there is no sign by which one might recognize each in its kind; both must be taken as true, and everything is as it was before the torture, when both simply denied their guilt. Or conversely: both succumb in their strife, they are overpowered by the unbearableness of the sharpened pains and confess. \

Thus two affirmative confessions have been wrung from them, one of which was false, the other true; but they again, in their truth and falsity, cannot be recognized by any external sign, and therefore, taken as proofs, will ground one just and one unjust judgment. 549 All probabilities will even speak in favor of the fact that the guilty one, to whom in the rule rather the extraordinary strength that belongs to the successful struggle stands ready, covers his guilt through denial; while the innocent one, taken at random from the common heap of men, is unable to muster that power, and through confession will ruin himself. There is thus no guarantee for what is extorted; the fear of death can give no such, for it, as the more remote, will be far outweighed by the presence of the pain.

The nature of human nature can guarantee such still less; for it is placed in a situation that lies beyond all lawfulness and obligation, and where nothing but the law of self-preservation holds.

This whole matter Augustine has already expressed in these words with striking aptness: "If someone is tortured on accusation, and, to find out whether he is guilty, tormented; then the harshest punishments are inflicted on the innocent one, for the sake of a crime not committed, not because it is discovered that he committed them, but because it is not known that he did not commit them. Therefore the judge's not-knowing is in the rule the misfortune of the guiltless one. And what is still more unbearable, and still more to be lamented, and to be wept over with inexhaustible tears: since the judge therefore tortures the accused, so that, not instructed by the truth, he may not kill the innocent one; it comes about through the misery of not-knowing that he kills the tortured one and the innocent one, whom he tortured in order not to kill the innocent one. For if he prefers to give up life rather than endure these pains any longer; then he will confess that he committed what he really did not commit. If he is now condemned and executed, then the judge still does not know whether he has killed the guilty one or the innocent one; whom he nevertheless tortured in order to prevent the killing of the guiltless one, so that he tortured the innocent one in order to gain insight; and, remaining without that insight, killed him."

Had one only weighed these words through so many centuries, one would not have defiled and stained oneself with the practice of this brutal method of penetrating into the secrets of guilt and innocence.

### Chapter 2. The Errors, the Good Observance, and the Inhumanities of the Usual Procedure

The preconditions were not fulfilled, and in part also not fulfillable; the means, the proofs, and the tests were ambiguous, uncertain; departing from the firm ground of human reality, on which above all the law must maintain itself, into unsafe, pathless, often fantastical regions where only the divine ordinance holds, and the civil legal determination often finds no application. \

One can easily imagine oneself in the position of conscientious and religious judges who, on the one hand, had to pass judgment on a crime that was, as it were, principled and enormous, one that enclosed within itself the seeds of all other crimes; but who, as soon as they undertook their duty in this matter, immediately plunged into a trackless, boundless, confused, and confusing wilderness, where things had faces that faded into gray, but no bodies that could be grasped in any way; where one thing continually passed into another in playful transformation; where falsehood clothed itself in a thousand forms of truth, which danced around them with will-o'-the-wisp-like shapes, mocked their seriousness, and took every pains to turn the intended court into a witches' sabbath. One sees: their power of judgment was in no way equal to even the most frequently occurring cases of ordinary criminality.

Whoever had once mounted the airy steed in this fork-riding, had completely withdrawn himself from the jurisdiction of earthly judges; he had literally risen above the law; whatever he might do, practice, and effect, whatever crimes he might heap up, all these criminal deeds, as long as they remained in this airy realm, were like gusts of wind; and even if a spark from them struck downward, the invisible origin could not be traced; the scales of justice had only foam and dream to weigh; a burden for which no system of measure and weight had yet been found, not even a balance. The judges, therefore, had to count themselves fortunate if a simple case, still within the scope of their jurisdiction, was brought before them; if tangible and weighable crimes had emanated from this transcendent source, and if an unforced, voluntary confession confirmed this origin. Such a case then undoubtedly fell under their court's authority, and it was probably the only combination in which they could exercise it with the best conscience and with success.

They then had only to ascertain the crimes themselves in their practical aspect; with regard to their origin, to establish the imputability and mental presence of the accused; and then confidently to pronounce the judgment in accordance with the laws. If these conditions are fulfilled with conscientiousness, attention, and insight, then in these matters the good observance is formed.

#### A. The Good and Secure Practice

There is no lack, neither in ecclesiastical nor in secular courts, of examples of the most blameless administration of justice in such cases. We select from them only one, the case of del Vaulx in Stablo, because of its rounded completeness, and because the judge himself recounts it from the records. Chapeauville, canon in Liège, reports the following about this legal proceeding. In the year 1595, Johannes del Vaulx, a member of the old and famous monastery of Stablo, had been imprisoned by his prior on suspicion of poisoning and other crimes; which, when it came to the knowledge of the abbot and administrator of the monastery, prompted him to send me there.

I saw the man, who by God's grace had grown weary of the demon's tyranny, and who, in the first conversation with me and the prior, opened up his entire life to us with many tears. For when he had tended the herds of his elders, and his boyhood had already been stained with abominable crimes, after his fifteenth year had arrived, he had seen an old man in long and seemingly clerical garb walking through the forest, who asked him: whether he would serve him and obey him? He would, as a reward, bring him to high honors in the state that he himself chose, to which he had then boldly agreed at once. \

Afterwards, he appeared to him in other and ever other monstrous forms, and also pressed into his shoulders two marks, which we examined; then carried him to the nocturnal assemblies, over many places, and provided him with poisons, with which he killed the cattle of the elders and of others, and also, in addition, human beings; and then accompanied him on his studies to Trier. On his advice, he then took the habit and immediately the orders of the priesthood; and removed the prior along with other order clerics, in order to gain the priory, by poison. But he had still many participants in his crimes and malefactions.

When I reported this to the prelate, he resolved: to have the case judged in the legal manner. He therefore sent the reverend Mr. A. Stregnart, suffragan, and me with a notary once more to Stablo; we interrogated him on all individual articles, and recorded his statements in writing. Since we noticed during the interrogation that the demon had taught him many pagan and heretical errors; we instructed him in the doctrine of the one and triune God, of the good and evil spirits, of immortality, of the future life, as well as in some other fundamental doctrines of our faith. The prelate wanted: that a thorough examination be conducted with him, so that, if he were brought to true repentance and stood by his statements --- but he accused more than 500 accomplices ---, these testimonies might have all the greater credence.

After weighing the confession and the accusations made, the prelate dispatched a commission to his principality of Stablo; whereby he transferred to his suffragan A. Stregnart, to me his general vicar, then to Father Oranus, pro-chancellor of his council and assessor of Liège, as well as to Mr. Molempeter, advocate of the fisc, all authority: to judge over the whole matter, to pass sentence, to execute the judgment; and if necessary, to call in the ordinary and feudal judges, knowledgeable in the laws and customs. In consequence thereof, we set out at the beginning of 1500 for Stablo, in a carriage which broke in two in the middle on the way; so that we had to cover the rest of the journey on horseback. We arrived still in the evening at the monastery, and visited the prisoner, who, upon our greeting, without returning it, at once brought forward excuses regarding the incident with the broken wagon.

Not his demon, he said, who had never done him any harm, had caused it; but another evil-minded one had committed it. At the break of the following day, he was examined and interrogated on the articles fixed by the fisc, and he persisted steadfastly in his first confession, not only naming his accomplices, but also specifying precisely: to which sodality they belonged; whither he had been nocturnally abducted with them; what criminal acts had been practiced there, what had been done in honor of the presiding demon; in what order the banquets had been held, the minglings had taken place, and the enchantments of humans, cattle, and fruits had been performed. \

The names, status, and circumstances of the accused persons were thereby determined with the utmost precision. But we, in order to test the consistency of his words, and to close the mouth of slander, waited some days before visiting him again; then reminded him of his salvation, and warned him that on this account he should beware of falsely accusing anyone. Thereupon we read to him his statements and accusations again, but in reverse and confused order; so that we placed those whom he had put in the first row, say, under the second and third, and vice versa. But he then insisted: that he had not said so, that the words had not been correctly recorded; that the matters stood thus, whereupon he repeated his earlier statements in their order.

We held it thus more often, for he had accused both clergy and laymen. Thus he said: that he had often visited the Trier assembly, where D. Vlaet, electoral councilor, who was burned there as a sorcerer, had presided; and that he had also had at this place a beautiful and charming girl, a fisherwoman, as his beloved, who after every assembly presented him with fish. After we had heard all this most wondrous from him, we nevertheless interrogated him still more often in formal sessions, treating him mildly and inquiring of him in every way the truth about his life and his deeds; but we found him in all things so steadfast and consistent with himself that we dismissed all suspicion of madness in his mind.

Oranus, who now, as I write this (1616), lives at 76 years of age in great vigor, and I myself, we visited him out of Christian love moreover still often in the room wherein he lived; we questioned him often about everything that we had learned in part from writings, in part from his confessions. But he always adduced weighty reasons that proved that what he had confessed had not occurred through deceitful demonic impressions, merely in the imagination, as we suggested and as it seemed probable to us; but rather truly, really, hypostatically and personally encountered him, and he indicated certain signs by which he could recognize when he had actually attended the assemblies and committed this or that, and when merely in the imagination.

When we had communicated the records to the prelate, and he recognized more and more the importance of the matter, he commanded us: to open the instruction of the process against the accused, both clergy and laymen; which then throughout the course of this year, up to the tenth of January of the following, was done with equal diligence and equal attention. It had been impressed upon us: not merely to lay hands on old women and men from the common folk, but also against the notables of the place, the mayor named Kannerlink, the judges and the pastor, as well as some religious persons distinguished by age, spirit, learning, and judgment. On the 10th of January 1597, after an advocate and syndicus had been assigned to the prisoner, the articles of accusation of the fiscal were read to him before the assembled court, along with the responses that he had made and maintained thereto thereafter; whereupon he clearly, frankly, and persistently declared and confessed: that he could make no change in the admitted sorceries, nor in the accused persons, or render any retraction, without placing the salvation of his soul in danger. \

Since the fiscal now urgently pressed for the pronouncement of judgment against the confessing accused, the terms set for the verdict were prorogued nine times on account of the importance of the matter; and just as often the guilty one was reminded of the peril of his previous life under the dominion of the devil, and how he had mocked the almighty God, his service, and his religion; he should therefore take care not to rob himself of all hope of salvation through empty and fabricated confessions, or false and slanderous accusations. He said again and repeated himself ever: that he could change nothing in what he had previously confessed, or retract anything whatsoever without lying and perjury. He hoped only for a merciful judgment; and that was his sole, fervent desire, that after renouncing the devil, reconciled once more to the almighty and merciful God, he might obtain his grace. The syndicus, dissatisfied with this, demanded that the clergy of Stablo, who, infected by the poison and still lying sick, be interrogated thereon. Aegidius Harsetanus, the prior, Mauritius of Offl, Quirin of Generet, Cornelius Neufforge, and Paschasius Lymburg were thereupon examined, all of whom testified: how they indeed considered themselves harmed by the poison that their fellow brother Del Baulr, or his companions, had placed in various places in the monastery.

The syndic now proposed: to proceed according to the records, and to condemn the guilty to be interrogated under torture; so that the confession regarding his accomplices might thereby be proven, and gain greater evidentiary force. This exhortation was made in the presence of the accused, who merely implored the mercy of the Almighty God. Accordingly, the following resolution was adopted: In the matter of J. Vilars, syndic of the Abbey of Stablo, plaintiff, against H. J. Del Vaulr, a member of that monastery, accused of sorcery, which matter remains pending before us, J. Chapeauville, commissioner specially appointed by His Highness; upon the counsel of those learned in divine and human law, to whom the state of the case has been communicated, it is resolved and pronounced: The aforesaid accused shall, before proceeding to the full resolution of his case, be rigorously questioned, and further interrogated under torture. Given on the 19th of March 1597.

When this decree became known, amid the bitterness of many of those accused of sorcery, the rumor spread: that we had been dealing with a deranged and senseless man. In order to dispel this rumor, we summoned the lords Ludwig von Viset, prior of Malmedy, a man of proven and tested truthfulness; Hubert von Verlemont; Gabriel Neufforge, steward of Stablo; Remigius Ultrapontanus; Wilhelm Rane, podestà of Malmedy; Adolph von Rahier, the schultheiss of Bodeur; P. von Noirfalli, schultheiss of Chenron; as well as other clerics, noble and esteemed men, officials and magistrates, among whom some were also suspected of sorcery. In their collective presence, J. Del Vaulr was now repeatedly questioned anew regarding the confessions and accusations. He always responded undauntedly, steadfastly, and aptly to everything put before him; so that he corrected all the errors and perverse narratives that we had intentionally fabricated, as well as the objections of the suspects, who made them vehemently against him; and, providing good reasons from all sides, he entirely refuted the opinion of his mental derangement.

Yet with this, his adversaries were still not pacified, but rather spread about: how, during the time of his imprisonment, he had written letters to the lords de la Bourlotte and de Goberville, as well as to D. de Wils, in which matters were contained that pointed to madness: in that he called them his nephews; and therein promised to do away with all enemies of the Catholic king through his arts and his secrets, and more of the like. \

When earnestly questioned, he replied firmly and calmly: that at that time he had played the fool and the delirious, pretending kinship, and spoken of the fall of the king's enemies, so that he might be released from prison on the grounds of madness; on this statement he persisted during three and four interrogations. After all this was concluded in judicial and customary manner, he said, when the acts were repeated from the beginning and translated into the language of the country for those ignorant of Latin, repeatedly: all confessions and accusations written down here are entirely true; and everything he stated therein about persons was truly done and committed. Then he was confronted with J. von Frounille, the pastor of Stablo, whom he accused of sorcery. When D. Oran, extremely experienced in these legal matters, wondered at the categorical denials of the pastor, Del Vaulr removed all his wonder in my presence by explaining to him the secret of silence among sorcerers. A solemn oath is repeated annually over this in all gatherings, and it had not long been taken in that of Stablo; at which he had been present and had recognized the said Frounille very well.

Now the syndic of the court demanded: that all his statements and references, and the confessions of the accused, be read out again, and then the latter, under invocation of God, be questioned on oath and under threat of eternal damnation: whether he persists in his oft-repeated confession, or has anything contrary to testify. The accused, after the punishment for perjury had been solemnly explained to him, answered firmly: all his confessions and accusations are entirely true, and he can and will retract nothing of them. With this testimony the syndic would not be satisfied, but now moved for the application of the rack, not to elicit further confession, but to confirm the one already given; so that the guilty of the crime might have no cause to complain. The accused, when all his testimony was read out to him again, insisted upon it, calling God to witness under oath.

Proceedings now advanced to the rack; the accused testified under torture, as the articles of the fiscal were presented to him one by one, at peril of his salvation and damnation: that all and every one he had named had been accomplices in the sorcery; that he had seen and recognized them in the assemblies, and had committed and carried out with them everything he had stated. Earnestly reminded again to consider maturely all that he had said and confessed, and to accuse no one guiltlessly; after prayers and exorcisms had also not been omitted over him, he confessed openly and firmly: everything said and confessed is the pure truth, and no one is slandered or unjustly accused; this he testified on the mercy of God Almighty, to which he, after revoking the vows made to the demon, betook his refuge, and awaited forgiveness for his poor soul, which had hitherto been in a state of despair. Finally, the improbability of so great a number of accomplices and confederates was set before him; which we did to test his reliability, but he nonetheless stood by his word. After common prayers and new exorcisms, he was again urged to say nothing against the truth; under repetition of the solemn oath he remained by his testimonies and accusations, and avowed: that he would hold to them until the end of his life. \

After all those present had unanimously reminded him once more of the consequences of perjury and the dangers of false accusation, and he had sworn for the second and third time that he had said nothing against the accused persons except what he himself had seen and heard; he was released from the torture and led to the hearth, unharmed in his limbs, for the torture had been only mild. We had also seen the marks on his shoulders at that time, and tested them with a needle, which we drove deep into them without his feeling any pain from it. Since all this had now thus taken place, the fiscal requested a legally valid transcript of what had occurred, and declared, after receiving it, that he would and must make use of it not only against the accused but also against every other person, as testimony and foundation for every investigation. He further moved that the defendant be summoned for the seventh hour of the second of April, in order to hear his judgment in proper form from the mouth of the commissioner and judge D. \[something\] v. Chapeauville. The notification of this summons was thereupon attested by Henricus Harsetanus, the cleric, with his own handwritten signature.

The judgment read as follows:

Whereas thou, F. Del Baulr, priest and abbot in Stablo, art convicted not only by many reports, witness testimonies, and public rumor, but also by thy oft-repeated confession, of having denied the faith and religion to which thou didst profess thyself at baptism, not merely with thy mouth but also in thy heart and soul, and in opposition thereto of having dedicated thyself to the demon, the enemy of the human race; whereas thou hast worshipped him at the nocturnal assemblies repeatedly; hast also concluded a pact and vow with him in order to commit maleficia, to obtain honors, pleasures, riches, and other earthly goods besides; and, to confirm the pact, hast obtained his marks on thy shoulders; whereas thou hast caused the death of several fellows of the abbey of Stablo, namely the lords Antonius von Salm, the prior of this monastery, Perpetuus, Aegidius Warsegnius, Anton Harsetanus, Heinrich de Rahier, Leonard Fronduille, Corbelius Neufforge, and others of the lay estate, namely Nicolaa, the widow left behind of Heinrich von Houfalize, the wife of the foreman of the same place, and J. v. Morimon, citizen of Stablo, by means of poison which the demon gave thee; and furthermore hast committed many other abominable crimes with demonic succubi, as well as with married and unmarried women; for which thou deserves not only to be deposed from all offices and degrees, but truly degraded and handed over to the secular arm, according to the ordinance of the holy canons.

We, therefore, in order that such crimes, under the pretext of thy priestly order and monastic vows, may not remain unpunished, but that thou in this life shalt undergo a punishment to some satisfaction for thy sins and vices, for the reparation of the scandal, as an example and terror to the wicked, and for the edification of the pious: do hereby decree by this our final judgment that thou be stripped of all office and every dignity, declared worthy of actual deposition, and handed over to the secular arm; as we now in fact do strip thee of thy offices and dignities, degrade thee, and hand thee over to the secular arm; while however beseeching the judges and officers of the secular jurisdiction that they, insofar as the law permits, may abstain from bloodshed.

In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost. Amen.

Given on the 2nd of April 150; in the morning at 8 o'clock. \

After the reading of this judgment, the degraded and stripped of his dignity was handed over to Prochancellor Oranus and Fiscal Advocate Molempeter, whom the most worthy Suffragan had appointed for this purpose; who now, with the involvement of some notables, wise assessors, and honored persons, after reviewing and carefully weighing the records, decided: J. Del Baulr should be executed with the sword, but then buried in consecrated ground in the churchyard of the monastery. The reason for the mitigated punishment was: because he had been in a state of accusation for five years, and during this time had been confined in a dark dungeon, living on bread and water; and what is more, had proven through his tears and sighs that he felt remorse over the past.

When his judgment was read to him, as he knelt dissolving in tears, he thanked them for the mitigated punishment; and asked the Prior that the ration, which according to custom was distributed to the poor for forty days after the death of every monastic cleric, should not be withheld in his case either; so that the poor might pray to God for the forgiveness of his grave crimes. One must say, such a careful, patient, thorough, prudent, zealous, and yet merciful procedure, while it does the court all honor, must entirely disarm every doubt about the justice tempered by love in its entire proceeding and its definitive judgment. No reasonable doubt could find place regarding the thoroughness of his remorse; the state of his mental faculties had been found completely satisfactory in every thorough investigation. One must therefore lend full credence to his statements about himself and the innermost ground of his actions.

This was demonic, because he had made the demon the principle of these actions, which as usual had led to murder and manslaughter. One might say that these latter did not appear to have been properly investigated; but given the insight and thoroughness with which the entire process was conducted, one must believe that this too was not lacking there, and that the compressed brevity of the presentation prevents further elaboration; just as it does not allow use to be made of the interrogations of the other accused. The judges could thus only apply the existing laws, and their conscience might fully rest at ease with the pronounced judgment.

#### B. The Errors in the Course of the Judicial Procedure Before the Ecclesiastical authority

With God, in all cases, good and sincere justice is to be found; because He, justice itself, looks into the inner and whole of the one to be judged. If something approximately similar is to become possible at a human court, then the accused must open his closed inner self before the judges without reserve; so that these, recognizing the invisible as well as the visible, may assign to each his exact right. So it was in the case just recounted: Del Vaulr has withheld no secret from his own; they have tested his sincerity with care; they have devoted equal attention to the investigation of the state of his mental faculties, and have found everything well ordered and proven; and thus nothing remained for them but the application of the law. But the same one who here, as the only valid witness over the state of his inner self, has given good account, has at the same time also made accusations against others whose inner selves were entangled with his, and who thereby took part in his crime.

His statements were examined with the same conscientiousness; the state of remorse and contrition in which he found himself provided an opportunity to probe the basis of it; and the swift, as it were unconscious, restoration of their inner coherence, whenever he was fleetingly confused, testified to the reality of the representations that otherwise would have flowed into one another like fading dreams. \

It was evident: he himself had the same conviction of the truth of these facts as of those that concerned himself; the same reasons that spoke for the evidence of the one also made themselves felt for that of the other; it seemed beyond doubt, these statements were fully as authentic as the others; if any could be used as testimonies of an eyewitness and earwitness for judicial proofs, and to proceed further on that basis. Yet it is not so, and precisely here begins the possible error that can creep into these procedures. Del Vaulr had gazed into the distance, and seen the accident with the approaching judges' carriage, and communicated his vision, before anyone informed him of what had occurred. He was thus clairvoyant, all his statements therefore rested on visions that had come to him; whereas what he reported about the state of his own inner being referred predominantly to clear, lucid intuitions. His soberly reflecting self stood in an entirely different relation to his mystically beholding self than the latter did to the equated spheres of other personalities; and the inner spiritual activities followed entirely different laws in their effects.

Had the visions all been realities, then to be sure these differences would have balanced out again in the general lawfulness of nature, and the unity of the whole human being would have absorbed the differences within itself. He himself regarded them as a rule to be real, and in translating them into the language of ordinary life had noted certain signs by which he believed he could distinguish the truly real from those that were only apparently so. But these signs were not infallible, not even for him himself; as Oran related to his friend and Delrio: he was nevertheless sometimes uncertain whether everything had not altogether merely transpired in the vision.

Thus in this daemonic vision, with the conviction of its ideality or reality, it is precisely the same as in the higher mystical one regarding the insight into its relation to truth and deception; whose uncertainty we learn from Maria of Agreda, who despite the long years of apprenticeship and the most earnest discipline in which she held herself on the path of her progress, yet sometimes became doubtful whether deception had not beset her. If in this kind of visions nothing at all blameworthy has shown itself, if all signs have declared themselves for their authenticity; if they have been indubitably accompanied by the infused higher light that awakens and sharpens the inner higher instinct, the discerning spiritual conscience, so that it separates deception from truth with all certainty; then, as we have seen above, the Church gives its assent: in such a way, however, that it holds the seer himself obligated to ascribe belief to the content of his vision, according to the measure of his conviction; but by no means compels others to the same agreement, as it demands such for its doctrines, but rather recommends them only as credible, as subsidiary support of the faith, for acceptance; leaving the measure of assent to each, and only rejecting unconditional repudiation. Should it now be otherwise with the daemonic vision? Del Vaulr had, with all the certainty that can enter in this domain, the conviction of the reality and truth of his own; and the court had to allow this conviction to stand, insofar as it concerned himself. \

But otherwise it was constituted with regard to that part of them in which other actual human beings were drawn into the circle that she enclosed. Here his conviction, against the denial of these people, could not make itself valid; because they were not obliged to accept his visions as infallible truths. The court, therefore, could grant to the accusations from this source---however well they might be judicially confirmed---no other validity, especially in questions where life and death were at stake, than a mere subsidiary one, which could indeed support an accusation but by no means establish it. In truth, what are visions other than beholdings into the interior of things, which now represent themselves symbolically; because the hitherto seen exterior is now only a shell and expression for the newly attained and emerging interior. One could easily imagine that a magnetic somnambulist might have the visions of summer and of winter.

The center of the first would be the sun at the summer solstice. From this center she would see the streams of light and those of warmth descending toward the earth; these would set the electric currents in motion in her vicinity, which, now conjoined with the propelling ones, would quicken the three lower elements---air, water, and earth---so that they in turn would awaken the hidden germs of life, which now would burst forth at all the nodal points of the earth. As all those outer movements now arouse corresponding inner ones, and unfold themselves in the now flowing streams, the earth would then cover itself with green before her eyes, and in the midst of the thus unfolding vegetation the animal kingdom too would soon develop itself to her, each according to its time.

That would be a wild swelling, flowing, surging, waving, weaving, flaming and blazing and radiant life; to behold it from its outermost extension to the innermost fountainhead in closest proximity, but in all its members, all plant and animal genera, all natural forces and faculties, expressed only in symbols. The center of the second vision would be the winter pole of the earth, which, in the remoteness of the sun, has selfishly enclosed itself. From this center the binding, congealing forces of darkness and cold would take their origin; they would, if dealing with freedom, murderously destroy all animal and plant extensions down to their germs, and then, burying these germs in the congealed earth, frost them over with rime, pelt them with hail, and cover them with snow; even the element of air would, wingless and bound, lay itself down around the rigid waters for winter's sleep: for everywhere the magnetic force would only rule, and the ancient night would at last enclose everything in her gloom.

The one would be the summer dream of life of the earth, summed up in one intuition; the other her stony and iron winter sleep, felt in the innermost root of death. To these natural visions there must correspond two others, beheld in the interior of the spiritual realm. For the seer might behold the daylight side of humanity in general, or of a society friendly to him in particular, that is turned toward the sun of eternity, how it, connected with this its center, receives into itself its vivifying effluences; how the forces and faculties, touched by them, according to their orders and hierarchies, become ensouled and exalted in the warming ray, flowing: so that all spiritual pulses beat more strongly, all energies tense themselves more powerfully, all virtues, purified and transfigured, express themselves in their effects with joyfulness. That would be the vision of a superterrestrial Sabbath, held on the bright heights of the earth, and bringing before intuition the inner connection of all good on earth, and its deepest origin from the primal source of all blessing. \

What, then, can the vision of the Sabbath mean, which is held upon the midnight-dark heights, other than a sight of the inner spiritual intercourse that exists between the night-side of the conjoined ones and the root-like evil, which through its influences demonizes all the forces of this side; so that, while all the self-willed passions of the most radical ones are bound together, these operate in every one through the power of all. That such a connection exists, given the continuity that prevails through all realms of being, is beyond doubt; here only what hides itself in invisibility in ordinary life is brought to light for contemplation; so that the entire web of attracting and repelling forces comes to the fore.

The form of the entire vision is also here a symbolic one; all vices appear, according to their kinds and species, in great images; all their connecting threads with the heart, which beats in them all, are concrete, demonic personalities; all the accessories have their own peculiar significance, and the inversion of all the distorted, mirror-reflecting forms is the ruling law. The interpretation of these symbols is, like that of the images in the second vision, a matter that demands great insight and experience. That the crimes which appear in the vision have concretely and really taken place is by no means a necessary condition: for just as the seer himself throughout appears personally withdrawn from the realm of action; so too do his images throughout express only in a general manner how the orders to which this or that person belongs, in their present disposition and position, find themselves driven to act in relation to the conditioning world-powers, and under certain circumstances actually do act.

Only the earthly birth of things, just as in the vision ascending upward the super-earthly one, is here indicated: but for this to become earthly, the accession of a third, likewise earthly, moment is required, which first activates the matter into a particular deed; which, if it is of evil root, alone belongs before the courts, which, if they disregard it, immediately lose themselves in apocalyptic interpretations. How seductive, therefore, his statements had been in the matter of de Vaulx, one sees nowhere that use was made of them. And one did well thereby, and thereby averted the danger of shedding innocent blood. That in other similar cases, where even such an outwardly well-secured foundation was lacking, equal prudence was not shown; but rather, incautiously carried away by an unbridled zeal, has already in earlier times wrought much mischief.

We select from among them the trial in Arras, which began in the year 1459, in that we here share in extract the account that is preserved in the chronicles of Du Clercq. The reports are admittedly not from the records, but at least, without hatred and without love, written down from the events of the day on the spot. In the city of Langres, in Burgundy, Robinet de Baulx from Artois, who had passed himself off as a hermit, had expiated the charges against him with death by fire, and his statements had run as follows: many men and women were his companions in the Waldensianism, the local name at that time for heretical being. Among others, he had accused a prostitute from Douai named Deniselle, and J. la Vitte, called Abbé de Pessens, thereof. The inquisitor in Arras, Peter le Brousart, had learned of this, and first had Deniselle arrested, and then also la Vitte, after he had learned of his residence in Abbeville, and had them locked up in the episcopal prisons. \

The vicars of the bishop, P. du Hamel, J. Thieubault, J. Pochon, and M. du Hamel, to whom J. du Bois also joined himself, had interrogated the first one several times on the rack; where she then confessed her participation, as well as that she had seen the others take part. This one, while arrested, had attempted to cut out his tongue, but it had not succeeded for him; however, he was laid on the rack, even though at first he could not speak, where he then had to write down his confessions. He testified again against others whom he had seen at the Sabbath: two men and four women, among whom again three joy-girls. These were immediately arrested; but since the matter, through the multitude of the accused, seemed to be spreading far and wide, most of the investigators were of the opinion to give it no further pursuit and to release the prisoners.

But Master J. du Bois, dean of Our Lady in Arras, opposed this proposal, and the suffragan of the bishop, Brother Johann, joined his view. They went to the Count of Estampes at Peronne, who immediately came over to Arras and commanded the vicars to do their duty; otherwise they would have to answer to him for the consequences. Accordingly, the arrested ones were now again laid on the rack and otherwise questioned, and their confessions were sent by the vicars to Cambrai; where the doctor of theology, Gilles Carlier, a seventy-year-old man, one of the most eminent clerics of the Christendom of that time, as dean of the main church, as well as M. Nicolai as canon, resided; these were consulted for their advice in this matter. Their opinion is said to have been that, if the arrested ones recanted, they should not be subjected to the death penalty the first time; unless they had committed murders or abused the body of our Lord.

But Master Johann and the dean du Bois were of the opinion: All who had taken part in the Waldensian rite must die the death; also all who would be accused by them, if, in case of their not confessing, they were convicted by rack or in other ways, with witnesses. They gave themselves all effort to make this their opinion prevail, and I have heard the dean himself say: the third part and more of Christendom is infected by the Waldensians: he knows much of it, which he cannot say, and if he were permitted to speak it out, one would be horrified by it. All who had been accused thereon were real participants, and those who were not could not be accused. If objections were made against this view, whether by clerics or laymen, those who did so were called: such must be immediately taken into custody as suspected of Waldensianism. \
