The same also said: if it came to pass that some of the guilty were led to the stake, then it was not to be doubted how the devil would tempt them to that, that in the hour of death they would retract everything they had confessed and admitted, so that they would immediately be damned to hell. In all this he was supported by M. Jehan, bishop of Varut, who had been grand penitentiary in Rome in the year 1450; for which reason one also believed that much had become known to him. He also had such an imagination that, if he only looked at people, he judged and declared whether they had been in the Waldensians or not. For this reason he also held: bishops and even cardinals had been in it; and there were so many of them that, if they could draw a king or eminent prince into their interest, they would be powerful enough to rise up against those who did not belong to theirs, and to do them all injury and shame.

Both said also: as soon as anyone should be accused of this crime, no one might take his part; no one, be it father, mother, brother, sister, or whatever relative, under penalty of being himself regarded as an accomplice; moreover, those belonging to the Waldenses, if they learned of their accusation, might not escape the investigation by flight. Accordingly, they arrested yet another new accused person, and had the vicars once more admonished by the Count of Estampes to hasten the process. The vicars therefore assembled all the esteemed clergy of the city, together with the most skilled advocates, laid before them the records with all the depositions from the seven accused, and then proceeded, after the assembly had been heard on the matter, to the execution.

All the condemned were brought to the scaffold, save one who had hanged himself in the dungeon, and the mitre with the figure of the devil was placed upon them; Father le Brousart delivered a sermon to the kneeling ones, and thereupon set forth to them what they had done and perpetrated. They had, he said, anointed a very slender rod and the palm of the hand with the ointment, and had then flown over cities and forests to their meeting place. There they had found richly laden tables, there the demon in the form of a goat, a dog, a monkey, sometimes a man; they had worshipped him, and dedicated to him either their soul or a part of their body; and with burning lights in their hands, had kissed his behind. They had immediately spat upon the crucifix and trodden upon it, and the abbé de la Biche had been the guide of all the newly received.

They had at the same time pointed their behinds at the heavens and the firmament, in mockery of God. And after they had eaten and drunk their fill, carnal mingling had followed, in which the demon had taken part in the form of man and woman: sodomy and bestiality and all the stinking vices that the speaker would not name had been committed therein. Toads, fed with the consecrated host, then burned, mixed with the bone-ash of hanged men, moistened with the blood of children, and compounded with herbs and other things by the abbé, had formed the ointment. The Church had been forbidden to them; they had been permitted to take holy water only with the words: May it not displease our master! \

content:
[Page 374]

The demon preached to them: there is no other life than the present one; for they have no soul. After he had thus reproached them and more, he asked each one in turn whether all this had not indeed come to pass so? All, even the abbé, affirmed it. Thereupon they were severed from the Church as infected members, and handed over to the secular court; and their property was confiscated for the sovereign, their movable goods however for the bishop. The four women were sentenced to death by fire in Arras; but when they heard the sentence, they cried out like desperate ones to Master Gilles Flameng, who was just then present: Ha, false traitor! thou toldest us we should only confess what was dictated to us; we should then be let go, and have no other penance to perform than perhaps a pilgrimage six or twelve hours distant.

Thou knowest, abominable one! that thou hast deceived us. They said moreover: they had never been in the Waldensian sect; what they had confessed had been extorted from them by torture, or lured from them by the promises of that M. Gilles and others, and much more besides. But that availed them nothing; they were led to the stake. They prepared themselves Christianly for death, but maintained to their last breath that they knew not what the Waldenses were; which words gave the people much to think and talk about. The same happened with the demoiselle in Douay, where she was executed.

Even the abbot of Depuysens held the same speeches, and said: he died without guilt; but his last words were: *Jesus autem transiens per medium illorum ibat*. He was 60--70 years old, was a painter, well regarded in many places because he was a singer and a poet. He had also composed ballads in honor of the most holy Virgin, and thus had become valuable to many. But whenever he had sung a holy song, he had always doffed his little cap at the end and said: With the permission of my Lord. Some had attested to this; I do not know what there was to it. Six men, among them Knight Robert le Fosne, governor of Arras, and seven women, among whom again several joy-girls, were immediately arrested in Arras. But the matter now soon spread elsewhere as well.

In Amiens, on the basis of the statements in Arras, several were likewise taken into custody; but the bishop let them go, and said: he would do the same with all of them; for he did not believe that they did or could do what they said. In Tournai, likewise, 3--4 persons had been locked up; Master Jehan Taincture, doctor of theology, wrote on this occasion a good treatise on the Waldensians, which I, however, have not seen. The prisoners were released after some imprisonment. In Arras, meanwhile, proceedings had continued; two of the richest men of the city had had to wander into the bishop's prisons; finally, Payen de Beaufort, a noble knight, one of the old bannerets of Artois, about 72 years old, was also seized. He had been warned earlier, but he had answered: and even if he were a thousand leagues away, he would come to answer for himself; he feared nothing on that account. \

content:

He had come to Arras; his kin had adjured him, if he knew himself guilty, to withdraw. But he had sworn the most solemn oath, and consigned his soul to damnation if he knew what Waldensianism was, and had taken part in it. Yet he was arrested on that same day, and wished to be led to the Count of Estampes; but the latter refused to hear him, and had him taken to the episcopal prisons. Jacques Guillemeau, his brother-in-law, who was accustomed to heal fevers with incantations, when he visited him there, was likewise detained as an accused. Meanwhile, the trial of three men and double that number of women had been completed; on the scaffold their deeds were likewise recounted to them, which this time consisted in practiced lust with the demon.

All questioned, they confessed the truth of these accusations, except for one of the women, who denied everything. Two, who had steadfastly persisted in their initial confession without wavering, were sentenced to imprisonment; all the others, led to the stake, died---as much as one could see---in Christian composure, but persistently denying all participation. Again, A. Sacquespée, one of the richest citizens and aldermen of Arras, and two others were brought in. Martin Cornille, receiver of the county, and Willaume Le Febvre, a rich man, fled, and were pursued by the count as far as Paris. M. Anton had earlier replied to the urging of his friends to flee in the same way as the knight of Beaufort. The count, for the interrogation of the new prisoners, had further strengthened the commission by adding new members; among them was Philipp H. von Savinses, a strict man in these matters; also the Duke of Burgundy had attached his confessor, the Bishop of Salins, an eighty-year-old man, and Baldwin, knight of Nogent-lès, governor of Péronne. Two others were now taken into custody, and Arras thereby became so notorious in all of France and elsewhere that the merchants lost their credit, and no one would receive travelers from there in the inns.

No person dared to leave the city either, out of fear of being seized as a Waldensian; indeed, the people, as soon as anyone so much as stirred, immediately accused him of Waldensianism. The Vicars therefore made it known: no one should have fear, for no one would be arrested who had not been seen by 8--10 witnesses; although it was later learned that it had indeed happened on the testimony of 2--3. The Vicars now invited the fugitives to present themselves in person and to give account and answer to the charges laid against them.

Thereupon appeared Wilhelm Le Febore, the son of one of them, with a notary from Paris, early in the morning before Jean Pochon, one of the same, in the church, and appealed against them in the name of his father. After the protestation had been made, both mounted up and rode to Paris; where his father surrendered himself into custody in order to answer the charges of the Vicars. But they were overtaken by the men of the Vicars and brought into custody; a fate that many of their friends shared with them, those who had known of their intention. They were first released only after they had renounced their appeal, but the fugitives were excommunicated as Waldensians.

Messengers had been sent to Amiens for more clerics and their counsel on behalf of the Lord of Beaufort and Master Anton; but no one came except Master Martin and the Inquisitor of Tournay; the others excused themselves on account of their age and other circumstances. \

But it was said: the matter, hitherto unheard of, seemed to them grave and weighty; for out of 100 people, in and outside Arras, not one, it was said, believed that the accused had taken part in the Waldensian rites and actually carried out what they had confessed. The Vicars therefore turned, in accordance with the request of the prisoners, to Philip, Duke of Burgundy, in Brussels, for counsel on what they should do in the matter. He summoned from the University of Louvain the most eminent and renowned teachers, as well as from all over the land.

To them were laid out the processes of both those who had confessed and those who had not; for there were some who did not confess, no matter what was done to them. What they judged, I have not seen; but it was said: they had been very much at odds. Some had opined: the Waldensian rites were not real; others had held them to be a pure illusion, and judged that the people believed they were doing what they did not in fact accomplish. Others said in turn: it was all reality; they entered into it body and soul, and whoever once surrendered himself to the enemy permitted him all power over himself.

The Vicars now took their leave of the Duke, who gave them with him Toison d'Or, his chief herald, in whom he placed all his trust, to be present at the interrogations. For although those from Paris and elsewhere said: he was having the rich people arrested in order to seize their possessions; he nevertheless wanted to know exactly what the truth of the matter was, in order to decree what was necessary.

On 14 August 1460 they returned to Arras; and whatever the counsel of the legal experts may have been, from that time on no one was arrested any longer on the charge of Waldensianism, although countless people were still accused; the prisoners were also treated better, and up to September only 4 processes were decided, and laid before the Duke and his legal experts in Brussels.

In the meantime, papal bulls, procured through the fugitive Martin Cornille, were brought in; by which Pope Pius transferred to the Dean Carlier of Cambrai, Gregory Nicolat, canon and official there, and the two Vicars of Arras, Pierre du Hamel and Master Jehan Thienbaut, the right to pass judgment in such matters.

About that time in Mantes, Noel Ferre from Amiens was burned, who had testified much against those of Arras; and how he had been at the assembly where the burning of the town of Pernes had been resolved.

On 12 October the delegates from Brussels returned, with them Master Adrian Collin, president of the chamber of the Duke of Burgundy in Douai; before whom the prisoners were interrogated once more.

The vicars now assembled many clerics and laymen, laid the records before them, and on the following day pronounced the judgment over Beauffort, Tacquet, Cariens, and Aubry. Before an innumerable crowd that had gathered from a radius of ten hours' journey, the accused appeared with the mitre on the scaffold. The Inquisitor of Cambrai now first charged Beauffort: how he, persuaded by evil women from the fellowship, had himself carried on the anointed staff to the Waldensians; how he had paid homage to the demon there, but instead of his soul had given him only four hairs from his head; how he had then kissed the paw of the ape, and recognized an unnamed woman. He had been twice more in the assembly, and had heard the devil preach: how men had no other souls than the beasts, and when they died, all was dead; and how he had let himself be forbidden by him the church and all churchly things. \


Keywords: the, and, in, of, had

content:

He then asked the defendant: whether it was not all so? To which this one loudly and clearly said, "Fa!" and begged for mercy. Since Beauffort was without mitre, the speaker thereupon explained to the people: he owed it to the circumstance that he had confessed everything without torture, and never recanted. Tacquet, as he then continued, had taken part more than ten times, had consigned his soul, had promised never to betray one from the sect, and if he did so, driven by torture, to recant it before death. Cariens had moreover killed four children, from whom the salve had been prepared, and the harmful powders. Asked: whether it was not all true? he had replied: everything he had just spoken was nothing; as for what he had confessed, he had been forced to it by torture.

Hugnet, the fourth in the row, had nine witnesses against him; but whatever torture had been inflicted on him, he had always denied it, and even now, when grace was offered him if he confessed, he had replied: he knew nothing, and recognized nothing. He had, as it was said, been put to the torture more than fifteen times, sometimes twice in one day; he had been led to a nearby castle, and told: he should be forthwith beheaded if he did not confess; he had only repeated what had already been said. Once at nighttime he had attempted to flee from the prison, but had been recaptured; and that was counted against him as guilt.

Beauffort was now declared a heretic, apostate, and idolater, and sentenced accordingly to seven years' imprisonment; however, he was to be publicly scourged on the shoulders with rods while clothed. He was further to pay 5,000 gold thalers, of which 76 made a fine mark, into the alms box at Mechelen for the war, and smaller sums to named hospitals and church foundations. Tacquet was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment, to scourging, and to smaller fines. Cariens, who had already earlier been under investigation for the faith, and in whom no sign of repentance had become visible, was handed over to the secular sword. Huguet, who heard his judgment kneeling and weeping, was condemned to twenty years' confinement on water and bread.

Yet the rumor ran: he had, as a former servant of the bishop, been much favored by the vicars. Many said: there were so many Waldensians in the church, at the courts of the powerful, and elsewhere, that it was a wonder. It was also believed that the Antichrist had already been born; he would soon rule, and all Waldensians would form his following. Yet in Paris, Amiens, Tournai many had been arrested, men and women, but released again without harm being done to them. Cariens was burned, but beforehand declared all innocent upon whom he had testified. The vicars now set free all those who had not been brought to confession by torture, twelve in number.

Against all of them witnesses had testified; they were interrogated under torture, some so often and severely that they were crippled; but they had persistently denied. They had to, before being released, swear their innocence on the Gospels; and for this, bring forward 4---5---7 honorable witnesses who likewise swore to their belief in the accused's innocence. They then still had to pay the court costs, and were mostly banished from the county. Only the Inquisitor P. le Broussart and the vicars of the bishop handled these releases; none of the others who were present at the interrogations took part in them, or were called upon to do so. \

Martin Cornille, who had fled but now sat in the prisons of the Archbishop of Besançon, was now absolved by them from the excommunication that they had issued against him. A song that was found on the streets now harshly assailed the authors of the persecution. But on the following 16th of January 1402, a court messenger of the Parliament of Paris appeared in Arras to inquire into the injustice that had been done to the lord of Beaufort, as he had entered a complaint; as indeed Tacquet and others had also submitted complaints on this account; and also to make inquiry into the appeal that Beaufort had lodged with the Parliament before his interrogation.

Philip, his son, had brought the messenger there; both now went, along with the other three brothers and 30 friends, well armed to the vicars; and since these out of fear did not show themselves, the court messenger demanded the keys to the dungeon; and since the jailer refused them, he took them by force, freed the lord of Beaufort, and summoned the vicars to the 25th of February as the day on which they would have to stand to right before the Parliament in the matter of the appellant, whom he took with him to Paris. On the 1st, the vicars de Hamel and Thiebault betook themselves to Paris; but the matter was postponed, and they returned home. There they received letters from their bishop in Rome, who ordered: to set Huguet Aubry at liberty, which was accordingly done. Martin Cornille also returned, whom the Archbishop of Besançon, after some investigations, had set at liberty.

In June the matter of Beaufort was finally heard before the Parliament, and on this occasion M. J. de Popincourt, parliamentary advocate and legal counsel to the plaintiff, said in open session among other things: how, as often as a prisoner was brought in on account of Waldensianism, he was told: if he did not confess what was said to him, he would be burned; only in the case of an open confession would he be let off with a small pilgrimage. If he then refused this, he was put to the torture until he confessed whatever one wanted. He said further: when the lord of Beaufort was brought in, and had sworn against Dean du Bois that he had not been in the Waldensianism; the dean had knelt before him and most urgently begged him: to confess, otherwise no one could save him from death by fire and the confiscation of his property.

Pity for his children alone moved him to this urgent plea, the fulfillment of which would procure him his freedom again within four days. When he replied that he would then have sworn falsely, the dean countered: he would give him absolution. By this and by more he had then been induced to make his confessions. Later he had also been compelled to pay considerable sums to the Duke, the Count of Estampes, the Bailiff of Amiens and his lieutenant, without having been sentenced to do so. The Parliament pronounced the plaintiff free from the prison sentence imposed upon him, had the three still under arrest in Arras brought before its bar, and set them likewise at liberty.

Because of a fourth \[accused\], Le Febvre, witnesses were examined, and after he had cleared himself before the Archbishop of Reims and the Bishop of Paris, he too was likewise set at liberty. The same happened with the last of the imprisoned, Hotin Longs. Before this had taken place, the Dean of Arras, M. J. du Bois, while on a journey to Corbie, had been seized by a mental illness, and he had been brought to Paris as if out of his senses. He stood in the reputation of a good cleric, was still young, and many lamented him. \

Others said again: it was God's punishment, because it had happened on his instigation that inquiry was made into the Waldensians, and some burned; he had also taken the most pains to prove the reality of the matter. Those who said this did not believe in the air-flight in this Waldensianism. Although he came to his senses again, there was yet no security in it, and he had to keep himself always in his chamber. Finally he became bedridden, and then his body opened in many wounds, and he had much to suffer. Some said in this connection: he had been poisoned or bewitched by the Waldensians. In February 1461 he died in full possession of his faculties, and certainly made a good end.

Meanwhile, in Burgundy, M. de Jehan, the Bishop of Barut, had been arrested in his birthplace, in order to learn from him what had actually determined him to stir up the matter with the Waldensianism in Arras. But soon he fled from this prison, and was, as he himself said, saved in a wonderful manner. He went to St. James in Galicia, and on the return from there he remained behind in France as confessor to the wife of Charles the Seventh. M. Paille, who had likewise taken part in the affair, withdrew from Arras to Paris; similarly Gilles Flameng to Douai; and it was said: it had been because they were all not gladly seen in Arras.

The process between the appellants, the heirs of the sixth of Beaufort and all those prosecuted on account of Waldensianism, and the defendants, the Duke of Burgundy and his ecclesiastical and secular judicial authorities, before the Parliament, meanwhile went its course. In the eighth year of King Charles VII, in the year 1491, the judgment was finally pronounced, which decided: that the said appellees had acted badly and abusively, had spoken, imprisoned, fined, proceeded, sentenced, and executed; and that the said appellants had rightly appealed. It then cassates all these processes, as well those conducted in the ecclesiastical as in the secular courts; the acts shall be torn up and destroyed, all made confiscations annulled and rendered void, the defendants personally condemned to make compensation, to the costs of the process, and moreover to a fine of 6500 Paris livres; of which 1500 francs shall be taken to establish a daily mass in perpetuity, for the souls' peace of the executed, in the cathedral of Arras; also a stone cross with an inscription shall be erected on the place of execution. The ecclesiastical courts of Arras were forbidden, in future processes, to make use of any extraordinary executions and cruel tortures. The sentence was solemnly proclaimed on the place of execution, a sermon held upon it, and on that day all work in the city had to be suspended.

One sees, this affair is just as instructive through its errors and blunders as the previous one was through justice, prudence, and thoroughness. Moreover, in order to pass a just and not hasty judgment upon it, we must first transport ourselves into the time in which it occurred. It was the middle of the fifteenth century, whose beginning had seen three popes at once on the chair and three emperors on the throne; only the outward expression for the weakening which the unity in church and state, amid the increasing power of multiplicity, had suffered in the wake of the earlier struggles between the two powers. \

The Witch Persecutions in Trier

content:

The ecclesiastical unity had fallen in Avignon into the power of French politics; that of the state in the emperor into that of the ever-increasing estates of the realm through constant encroachments; the consequence was a dissolution of the entire common and ecclesiastical order throughout all the European realms. In the church, therefore, the beginning of the newer heresies with Wycliffe and with Huss, and in their wake the Hussite wars. In the hierarchy, the disruption of the inner wholeness and cohesion, the rebellion of the members against one another and against the unity; at the councils of Constance and of Basel, the prelates and the lower priestly orders in strife. After the restoration of the see in Rome, constant struggles of its occupant with the unruly territorial nobility.

In the state, a similar dissolution of the old enclosed feudal state into its elements; the territorial lordship in conflict upward and downward, armed brotherhoods of equals against those higher and lower in rank, the struggle of feudal law with the public peace, of the old manner of warfare with the new, the gradual complete dissolution of the central authority. Between England and France in particular the great, centuries-long struggles over the succession, and in their train the great civil wars in both feudal states, that of the white and the red rose in England, Burgundy and the overlord in France; in both realms at last the unity, with the Tudors and Louis XI, triumphing everywhere; the world traversed by condottieri, Armagnacs, Landsknechts, black mercenaries; brazen outrage, violence, the impotence of the administration of justice prevailing throughout all Christendom.

In the wake of this fermenting dissolution of all elements of civil order and the prevailing savagery, then the greatest immorality; Venus the wandering strumpet dug out as the first among all the gods of heathendom; all cities filled with courtesans, even at the church assembly of Constance an incredible number of them, in the city where it had taken its seat; as Nider relates, on account of the presence of the many princes and their retinues, as well as the numerous craftsmen. In all this, France-ravaged Italy, standing closest to the contagion from the East in any case, going ahead with a good example; and out of the midst of this loathsome corruption, as the scourge of avenging Nemesis, the venereal disease developing itself. Added to this now the fall of the Greek emperorship, which had occurred beyond the straits.

Behind the storming Ottomans then at last Gog and Magog unleashed in Timur and the Mongols; Europe, and the sink of all vices in it, threatened with an inundation from the East, and these floods already breaking on the borders of Bavaria. Such was the state of European society at that time. Was it surprising, in this hopeless state of affairs, if serious minds came to the opinion: the world, now grown hoary with age and decrepit, was hastening toward imminent dissolution; the time was approaching that had been foretold by earlier prophets who had foreseen their agony in visions, and now it was inclining toward the end.

Had Christianity visibly lost its power, while the power of evil had strengthened itself everywhere; then the time of the Antichrist had arrived, to whom dominion was given for two times and half a time, and who should unite and assemble all his own under his sign. He was already born, this adversary; all signs seemed to proclaim his nearness, and the people believed, as we have seen, in his presence. What the coming times should behold in the light of day must now prepare itself in the veil of night; there he must recognize his own, enter them in his registers, and exercise them in all villainy. \

At the courts he had begun this work of his; from there he had proceeded to the aristocracy; what de Rais had practiced in Brittany, what Lady Fowlis had practiced in Scotland, had not remained unknown; what had occurred in Avignon in the vicinity of the Prince of the Church, what doctrines had gained entry into the College of Cardinals, and what morals had arisen from them, which had later even raised Alexander VI to the throne: all of this had remained no secret; Master Jehan, Bishop of Barut, had seen it all quite close at hand as Grand Penitentiary. It was no wonder, then, that what had earlier circulated concerning immediate pacts of men with the demon, what had haunted here and there in the licentiousness of the age that recoiled before no crime, that it, heaped up and multiplied, should suddenly coalesce in anxious minds into the dread image of the Waldensians or Vauderie.

To the Bishop of Barut was joined the dean, M. Jacques du Bois, at that time a man of twenty-four years, of good repute, of whom that threatening song itself spoke: "Chascun cuidoit que iu keusses prophète, --- Sage comme un Salomon ou Sibille; --- Mais si du sens quy oneq feust en ta leste, --- tu a voulu semer une tempeste, --- tu beueras ton brassin ei brouct; --- Er sy seras des premiers à la feste. --- Folie fait quy folie com met."

Both, studying the Apocalypse in the course of the world at that time, may long since have arrived at the suspicion of a secret connection between a part of it and the demon; the ever-increasing audacity in crime of the century must have confirmed them in it more and more. Now had come the deposition of Robinet de Vaulx, born in Artois, who had testified against the Demoiselle and the Abbé la Vitte, the former a Sister of Joy, the latter---as it appears---a brother more than merely merry; and the word Vauderie, which at the surprising confusion immediately brought to their minds the Manichaeans, the worshippers of the demon, had been acknowledged by the Demoiselle at her arrest. Now they had found the trail, which they needed only to follow in order to find their view confirmed all too fully.

That the hermit had probably made his deposition under torture could, given the reverence that this faithless instrument---which the ecclesiastical courts should never have accepted---enjoyed at that time, by no means lead them astray. It was applied against the two prisoners as well; the gate of the secret had been burst open, and the mystery of iniquity now lay exposed before them. That a woman of the Vauderie, as the reporter says of her, and a frivolous cleric and wandering singer, designated by popular wit with the mocking name "de peu de sens," were little suited to serve, in a matter of such weight involving life and death, as foundational witnesses, had not occurred to them. If doubts arose in them, the torture, applied also against other arrested persons, immediately dispersed them. \

If suspicion fell upon the instrument, then voluntary confessions appeared, either tricked out by promises, or also---since the matter lay in the intentions of many at that time and surely lacked not all foundation---here and there called forth by remorse, or also brought about by the simplicity of the afflicted in order to save themselves, coming in to pacify; and they found support again in the general belief around them. The surprise on account of the discovery made was, it seemed, so great that immediately the spectral image of the pact with all its terrors stood before them: how it possessed a third of the human race, how bishops and cardinals belonged to it, princes without doubt as well, and how only the Mighty One was still lacking to it, in order at its head to carry out all the plans of the abyss.

Since the poor testimony given by the Veltnerin was joined by that of the witnesses brought forward by her, who had been in Waldensia---a testimony which, even if given voluntarily, could only ground a suspicion of innocence---; the error thereby increased, and it was firmly established: All must die who had been denounced by four such witnesses. Whoever spoke against the system thereby rendered himself suspect of the vice; and it was soon likewise considered proven that no one could be accused unless he had truly made himself guilty of it; for which reason the contradiction to an earlier confession, made in the face of the flames, must also be invalid, because the demon had driven him to it.

Thus there developed a system of terror, before which nothing could stand once it had come within its scope; and this reached its height in the delusion of M. Jehan, who believed he could already recognize guilt or innocence from the physiognomy. No age may deem itself entirely secure from the possibility of falling prey to such errors; and should the present one, in the consciousness of its enlightenment, harbor such presumption; then one might remind it only of that twofold doubled attack of the disease which has befallen it in our days. The first at that time, when the Jesuits were supposed to be regicides from bloodlust, corrupters of morals and custom through their discipline, state-endangering conspirators from habit, accumulators of wealth from insatiable greed.

The order knows how to recount how the fixed idea of the delirious patient played its tricks on it; and since the attack, the specific smell will not yet depart from the nose of the Jesuit-sniffers. For the second and third, the attack has returned in the Revolution, once in the heads of the terrorists, who have armed their political virtue-logic with the guillotine, and subsidiarily assigned fire and water as helpers to it; and on the other side in the opposite siren idea of their battle-victims and the higher estates: that all this had already long ago been prepared for them by the dying Templars, and carried forward through secret societies, come to outbreak only in our days. And when finally, fourthly, the demagogic machinations emerged, how far, one believes, might this mania also have led, which could by no means lack defensible grounds, if torture had been at the disposal of those seized by it? All these examples show how dangerous it is for men, most dangerous for those who are of good will in it, to engage in such treasure-hunting in the depths of the human world of thought, in which God alone knows the way. \

In the present matter of the Waldenses, it was the preserving instinct which, in the opposition of the vicars against this terroristic doctrine, first made itself felt; but the strict observance then still overcame the mildness. That emerged again in the opposition of the chapter lords of Cambrai and several bishops, but could likewise not make itself felt against the first zeal. Only the council of the prudhommes of Duke Philip of Burgundy in Brussels brought about a turning point. That the investigators had been sincere was proven by the circumstance: that they extended the investigation, without distinction, to the poor as well as to the rich and powerful; but that also brought about a swift conclusion to the matter. The Parliament of Paris took an interest in the affair.

The thirty years which the process lasted are filled, to a great part, with the perfidious, violent, but snake-cunning government of Louis XI and the fall of the House of Burgundy, and the death of Charles of Lorraine; circumstances which, as can scarcely be doubted, exerted their influence on the course of the legal proceedings. But as it has ever been in such matters, the Parliament has judged rightly, and Nemesis has not neglected to collect the debt fallen due to her.

For however little the age may have esteemed blood in its feuds and struggles, the shed blood cries out to heaven and demands its atonement. Not the mercy that leads man in good disposition toward a good end justifies him alone; if he does not cooperate in right strength, held in right measure: then he remains bound to it, and must atone for its neglect as for its excess, as du Bois has paid the debt with the darkening of his spirit. 1) Du Clercq relates among other things on p. 201: Robert le Bougre, who had been Bailiff of Amiens, during his term of office had 1900 and more either beheaded or drowned. It was the time of the Burgundian-French wars, and it sufficed already that one called the individual an Armagnac, in order to bring about his death.

#### C. The Witch Trials in and after the Time of the Reformation.

Amid such uncertain groping about after the truth and what was rightful in this matter, the Malleus maleficarum had also emerged; a book pure and blameless in its intentions, but composed on an insufficient basis of actual experience; not always carried out with sharpened judgment, and therefore often incautiously tipping over to the sharp side. The book had, however, scarcely had time to penetrate into the mass of ideas, when the sixteenth century broke in, and the Germanic fury brought about a new catastrophe and an ecclesiastical uprising.

The mass of democratic forces and opinions had for a long time already accumulated excessively in Germany, and while the old faith, against which they had risen with might, found its support in the unity of the Empire and the spiritual princes; the uprising one had spread itself in the worldly princes, in the aristocracies, in the burgher estate of the imperial cities, and in the peasant estate striving after emancipation, in the corruption of the clergy and the critique of the humanists. The still weak and unfortified one had, in the confusions of the great war between Charles V and Francis I over Italy, in which all Europe had taken part, found its protection; the other princes' wars, nobles' wars, cities' wars, and peasants' wars had episodically inserted themselves into the great European conflict; until at last in the Religious Peace the middle power, between the higher unity and the lower democratic tendencies crossing through it, carried off all the advantage alone, and divided the territorial sovereignty of the Emperor's simple crown and the Pope's threefold crown between itself. \

In England the whole movement had been incited by the despotism of the Tudors, also entirely exploited in its interest, and in the laying aside of the oath of supremacy the worldly power had taken over the homage of the spiritual; as in the North a new dynasty had bought itself in with the sacrifice of the Church. In France likewise it is the directions fighting against unity that, mastering the spiritual movement, find their heads in the court parties of the Bourbons and the Valois, their leaders in the nobility, their fighters in the cities, and now set the municipal league of the Huguenots against the League of the Guises, and thus nearly fill the last half of the century with a civil war that finally there also ends with the victory of unity in the return of the leader of the Bourbons to the Church; while simultaneously the struggles in the wake of the revolt of the Netherlands are fought out, which lead to the victory of unity on the one side and to that of the opposition in the other half. As the result of the secular strife, therefore, everywhere the worldly power victorious, and indeed in the form of territorial sovereignty, and even in the two peninsulas of Italy and Spain, where the movement had remained nearly entirely without effect, this only achieved through the earlier gained predominance of this power.

Protestantism declared the old church, as it stood opposed to it, a work of the devil, and its head the Antichrist, but Rome the beast with the seven heads. Satan was thus indispensable to the new doctrine, indeed his power, which has proven itself so victoriously in the greatest part of modern history, had increased considerably in splendor and reputation; for he had also gained territorial sovereignty in the south of Europe. Had it followed the opinion of the founders of the doctrine, then the new age would have followed the example of the older one. At that time, when the divine race of Zeus followed that of the Uranions around Cronus in rule; then Cronus with the Titans was locked in Tartarus, so that the defeated old time in its horror might hold its death-sleep.

The church triumphing in the saints would then have become such a Christian Tartarus; but the militant church, gathered around its head, a Sabbath celebrated in broad daylight on the seven hills and in the choir of every church. But the power that directs the fates of the times was not in agreement with this doctrine of the zealots, the heaven of the saints was not banished into the shadows of the underworld; the church maintained itself in the daylight, and in the north only a counter-church was built upon bodily discipline.

Thus the members of this counter-church had to content themselves with explaining all higher mysticism in the other as a deception of the demon, and thus to him, who before and after remained in possession of all areas of possession and sorcery, now also to concede all the higher mystical regions previously kept pure from him. Hence there could be no question of stopping the heresy process in Protestant Europe; rather it received a new impetus, and began to spread in proliferating drive. The world, which emerged victoriously from the struggle of the century, as it has handed everything over to territorial sovereignty, had also completely secularized this process; and as it took away from the church the instruction in matters of heresies for easily comprehensible reasons, so also the magic matters were entirely referred to the secular courts. \

Hence now the parliamentary acts of Henry VIII against conjuration, heresy, and sorcery from the year 1541; of Elizabeth from the years 1559 and 1562, sharpened at the beginning of the following century. The last act of the ninth parliament of Queen Mary of Scotland imposes the death penalty on sorcery and those consulted for advice; and now there too the legal disputes, which had previously been very rare, arise in multitude; and it shows that thereby the practitioners of lower standing appear placed in a relation of clientele and patronage to the powerful ones. So the Protestants in the north; the Catholics in the south, among whom likewise the state has more or less triumphed, gradually followed the given example, and the secularization of the whole process occurred also among them gradually everywhere.

The Bamberg criminal court ordinance of the year 1510 already sharply distinguishes between what in these mixed matters belongs to the spiritual and the secular court; and in the 121st article it ordains: the sorcerers who have harmed others to be burned like heretics, but over all others to bring in the jurists; since the vice of sorcery in general belongs before the secular judge. Since the Carolina followed this ordinance, it has remained so in it; and it has only wisely added the prohibition of the inquisition based on the statements of the sorcerers.

Since in such a way the jurisdiction has entirely fallen to the secular authorities, we must not wonder to see them personally take part in the investigations, especially when the magic has turned against themselves. That was especially the case with James I in the year 1591.

At that strange witches' conspiracy which had formed against him, he took great pleasure in being personally present at all the investigations and proceedings. The main figure in the whole affair was Cunningham, usually called Dr. Fian in the records, a schoolmaster near Tranent; as it appears, a dissolute man, but, as emerged, one of great strength of soul and firm nerves. The knotted cord was first placed around his head, and he confessed nothing; gentle persuasion led equally little to the goal; finally the Spanish boots were applied to him, and when, after three tightenings, pressure was brought to bear for a confession, his tongue failed him. Later he signed a confession in which he admitted guilt for directing witchcraft against the king and uncovered the scandals of his life. But in the following night the apparently penitent man attempted to escape, was indeed recaptured, but now sought to deny everything previously confessed.

James, in view of his stubborn obstinacy, devised a new torture himself: the nails were torn from him with pincers, and under each two needles were driven in up to their heads. But amid these pains he did not flinch, and confessed nothing; the boots were applied to him again, and drawn so tightly that the legs burst and blood and marrow spurted out, so that they were crippled forever. However it may have gone with his confession, it agreed in all circumstances with that of Agnes Sampson, whom Spottiswoode describes as a worthy, truthful matron in her statements, and who had declared herself a witch. From Janet Bowman's pyre in the year 1572 to the end of James's reign, another 35 witch trials up to 1625 are recorded in the records of the court, and Archbishop Spotswood relates that the greater part of the winter was always spent on the instruction of these processes. \

Even Knox had been accused of such arts, which allegedly made his secretary delirious. The Lord Chief Justice of Scotland, Sir Lewis Bellenden, had died of fright from an appearance of the conjured demon; and on account of this James in 1597 had taken occasion, in a parliamentary act, to regulate the forms of the witch trial. In the preface to his Daemonologie he says: his conscience had compelled him to write the book against the Sadducees Scot and Wier from the devil's school. He rejects, however, the possibility of witches slipping through narrow openings, because this is connected with the transubstantiation of the papists. But in the second book, chapter 7, he says: there had indeed been more ghosts in popery (probably on account of purgatory), of which nothing more was known after the Reformation; but in compensation the devilish power of witches had become far more manifest, which he could prove by experience in Great Britain. In fact, these processes now also increased in England with rushing speed. Thus the demonic conspiracy against Elizabeth in the year 1570, the Countess of Lennox's case, the trial of Alice in 1575; that of the Windsor witches, the 17 or 18 who were condemned to the fire at St. Osyth in Essex; that of Mother Style, the other at Cambridge, those of the Warboys witches, and others.

On the continent meanwhile the courts had not been idle either. At the beginning of the century the blind man from the Quinze-Vingts in Paris was hanged with several others for sorcery, and testified to 150 accomplices. Trial of the three werewolves in Besançon 1521. In the year 1556 four hundred burned in Toulouse according to Petrus Tholosanus; as it seems, as a prelude to the civil religious wars that broke out a few years later and filled the rest of the century.

Now ever-increasing multiplication of witchcraft. In the year 1571, the death of Trois-Echelles on the Grèveplatz, and his confessions regarding the number of initiates in the presence of Admiral Coligny. The werewolf Garnier at the court of Dole. After the death of Charles IX, the proceedings sharpened. Trial of J. Harvilliers. 1582, trial of de la Rue for witch's knots. Decrees of the councils thereon and against all sorcery. 1584, the 14 accused thereof by the Parliament of Paris, then in Tours, acquitted on the report of the physicians!).

In Bosdau, who voluntarily, and without any torture, before the court of Bordeaux confessed the Sabbath and his participation therein. Around this time, toward the end of the civil wars, Florimond de Rémond, councilor of parliament at this court, says that the vice of sorcery had become so common in these wretched times that the parliamentary prisons could not hold all the prisoners, nor did the judges have time enough to interrogate them. Their judges' benches were daily stained with blood, and they left the court always with sorrow and dismay over the terrible and horrifying things that the statements of the witches revealed.

The book of Bodin, De la Démonomanie des sorciers, 1570, contains a part of the results of these and the earlier investigations. At the same time, Remy in Lorraine executed from 1580--1595, thus within fifteen years, 900; and his three books De Daemonolatreia give account of what he learned at their interrogations. A few years later comes the mission of de Lancre to Labourd in the Basque country, where many thousands were found afflicted with the evil. These were the consequences of the desolation of a century, in its first half filled by the ambition of its kings in foreign wars, and in its other by the religious disputes with a chain of eight civil wars, raging longer than 30 years. \

Christian Rome had, and by no means without its own complicity, in the first of these wars, experienced a plundering by the descendants of the same peoples who formerly carried out the judgment of God against the earlier world tyranny; the Blood Wedding had marked the middle of the second. With the Catholicism of strict observance, as the League knew it, the Calvinism of the Huguenots had contended in all its harshness, and had opposed to it the denial of all mysteries, and in their place the doctrine of predestination; and all the poison that had developed in the black bands and their hangers-on had attached itself to this strife, which must shake every conviction to its deepest foundations.

The people, terrified, plundered by the lawless robbers, in constant distress, became astray in their faith, and turned rather to him who seemed to be the lord and master of these wild times. Many of the Basque witches confessed to de Lancre: they had always believed that the worship of the devil was the best religion; for the mass was read at the Sabbath with greater pomp than on the day, and there was nothing evil in attending them. Moreover, Satan had made them believe: that he was the true God, but the Sabbath his paradise; and the joy one enjoyed there only a foretaste of the higher joy in that world!). One sees, they had fled only from the misery of the actual present into the pleasure of this perverted ecstasy; without thinking more closely about the consequences of this flight. Thus the evil that the wantonness of the higher classes had spread, carried about by the wild soldiery, had become epidemic in the misery of the people, and thus the judges encountered it in their investigations. In Germany meanwhile the events led to the same results. On the Lower Rhine the revolt of the Netherlands against Spanish rule had broken out.

Protestantism had fled from France, now seeking from there to spread upstream through the ecclesiastical electorates, and for this purpose had found in Gebhard of Cologne a suitable instrument. All the lands round about, where the war raged, suffered most terribly under the plundering lust of the warring armies; not only the Dutch filled everything they could with robbery and arson; the Spaniards too, amid the dissolution of all discipline, plundered the Eifel and the neighborhood; the people nearly succumbed to misery and need, and grew savage in the most frightful manner.

The nineteen years of the reign of Elector Johann VI of Trier were, moreover---excepting only the years 1584 and 1590---years of unfruitfulness, of high prices, and of hunger; countless refugees increased the distress still further, and the plague soon made its appearance to clear things away. The people were in despair, and attributed their misery and the unfruitfulness of the years to evil arts and to the witch-folk. In the officials of the time, among whom the distress now also awakened gold-greed, they found all too willing help to render this their belief pernicious to many. Through the whole diocese, all cities and villages, there now ran---as an eyewitness relates---accusers, inquisitors, judges, minions, and executioner's assistants, who seized all suspects and burned them in great numbers; for scarcely one escaped who had once been accused. \

Soon the terror spread also into the city of Trier, and soon spared not even the former blood-judges themselves; for Dietrich Flade, rector of the university and city schultheiss, who had led a great multitude of those unfortunates to the stake, was burned in 1586 according to the rules of his own judicial procedure. Him followed in death two mayors and several senators and judges. Canons of several chapters, pastors, rural deans had the same fate. In two villages at about the same time only two women remained; for the fury of the people and the madness of the judges had only ever increased; so that scarcely one remained whom suspicion had not struck. The notaries, the actuaries, and the innkeepers enriched themselves meanwhile; the executioner rode like a courtier on a high horse, clad in gold and silver; his wife vied in finery with the nobles.

The children of the condemned wandered forth, their goods were confiscated. There began to be a shortage of field hands and vinedressers; hence the unfruitfulness. Scarcely, men thought, had a worse plague ever raged in the archbishopric, or a madder foe wreaked havoc, than these trackers, who struck so many for whose innocence there was manifold likelihood. The persecution lasted several years; many of the superiors boasted of the multitude of pyres they had erected. Impoverishment was the consequence: now laws were given and enforced against the abomination, and now it died out, just as the war died out with the exhaustion of the money, so the fury of the witch-judges. In scarcely seven years, from 1587--93, 365 persons were burned from 20 villages near the city.

In all this the Antichrist was indeed present, although perhaps more in the judges than in the judged: and so men easily came to the belief that he must really and personally have been born. That introduced a new error into the matter. The exorcists, aware of their power in the obsessions brought about by magic, came upon the idea of making use of this power to compel the demon against his will to bear witness to the truth, and thus to spy out the secrets of his realm through himself.

For the first time, to our knowledge, use was made thereof in the matter of the Count of Gaftedy: Magdalena von Palnd, his betrothed, had, against his will and at the age of fourteen, entered the convent of the holy Ursula, and had placed herself under the obedience of Father Romillon, a former Calvinist. As she thereupon fell into a possession, the peace of the convent was suddenly disturbed thereby; for five of the sisters residing there soon found themselves likewise possessed. Among them was one in particular who was most affected by it, Louise Capelle, from the county of Avignon, likewise descended from heretical parents, originating in St. Remi, near that county; a simple, pious girl skilled in household tasks. Magdalena was for a long time unsuccessfully exorcised in secret, but then taken to St. Baume, and there given over to continued exorcism to Father F. Dompt, a Fleming, Doctor of Theology at Louvain and a Dominican. With her had come Louise, to manage the household, who at that time was not yet suspected of possession; which, however, soon betrayed itself through tone and glance; while Magdalena, in her attacks, was repeatedly lifted into the air to tear her from the exorcist who held her. \

On the eighth of December 1610, the spirits of Louise named themselves: first Verin the superior, and then Gressil and Sonnillon, his subordinates. On the day of the Conception of Mary, Verin began through her mouth to deliver a great eulogy of the blessed Virgin, concluding it thus: that he spoke not out of love for her, but compelled by fear of God, who is able to call forth all things from nothing. Catherine of France, an ecstatic sister, brought Magdalena there during this speech; and now Verin, upon beholding her, began to call out to the stronger demon who dwelt in the one present: "Though thou art my master, yet one greater than thou wills that I now speak in thy presence."

Then this one rose up raging in Magdalena, bellowed like a bull, and threw her shoe at the speaker's head. But Verin continued to deliver to her an eloquent exhortation to repentance and renunciation of the evil one, which closed with the exclamation: "Wonder, unheard-of wonder, that the devil himself saves souls, and serves them as physician and surgeon!" Magdalena, who might have seen collusion and deceit in this scene, remained unmoved; the bystanders prayed the Psalms for her, and this seemed to bend her hardened spirit. She burst into tears, and throwing herself down before the others, declared herself a perverse and wretched creature.

Now the ice was broken, and the work of conversion proceeded on its course. Verin pursued it with great insistent eloquence; and one of the possessed laid to heart for the other everything that could possibly be helpful to snatch her from the power she had hitherto served and lead her back to heaven. When the priest offered the Eucharist to both possessed ones with the words: "Ecce Agnus Dei, ecce qui tollit peccata mundi!", the spirit cried out from Magdalena: "Well for you a lamb, for us a roaring lion!" When the priest commanded him to adore his God, he replied: "What, should I adore this God, this God should I adore? I will not do it, I shall never do it, in defiance of thee, O Christ; in mockery of thee, O Mary, and of thee, O Magdalena, who art mine!" Verin now cried: "Ha, wretch, accursed one, like me! Thou hast no power over Magdalena, who will take the Lord as her bridegroom." "No," screamed the other, "she is my bride, and I will prove it."

So the spirits quarreled with one another; but the one belonging to the neophyte always drew the shorter end, yet avenged itself on her by from time to time calling forth the most violent paroxysms: it threw her to the ground, stirred up the most furious convulsions in her, and made known to the whole world through her mouth her most secret sins, which only her confessors knew, and at night it plagued her with incubi. Meanwhile Verrin continued his instruction in the Christian doctrine; at every section confirming the truth of what was said with a solemn oath. He held before her how she had three times renounced her God, who now might yet have mercy on her soul: O Magdalena! if the stars of the firmament could express thanks, if the leaves of the trees could understand these words, if the stones of St. Baume had a voice, they would all praise God for it; for your sins are many, like the sand on the sea. The hard heart of the sinner slowly softened; she had frequent relapses into impatience and despair; terrifying visions frightened her sorely; the demonically ecstatic girl did not cease, with great eloquence, to press upon her again and again. \

Now she confessed herself once more before all those present, who had come streaming together from far and wide, as a sinner worthy of hell; and she laid herself down before the church door, begging the passersby to trample her as the most wretched creature with their feet. She now gave the signs on her body, one of which proved visible upon examination; and during the exorcism a number of spirits went out from her, though this did not lift her obsession; just as with Louise, after the departure of the two lower ones, Verrin had remained behind. Her torments returned in between with renewed strength; she was lifted up high by the demon, she lost---especially when she wanted to go to confession---often her sight and hearing for several days; imagination and memory were often bound to her, her whole body sometimes swelled up; her eyes became like burning lamps, distortions ran over her face, and for 15 days Asmodeus defiled her every evening under the exorcism, by calling forth the most obscene movements in her, during which she always believed she saw Louis Gaufredi.

During these proceedings, Verrin had testified several times: that it was Louis Gaufredi, at the church of the Accoules in Marseille, who had seduced Magdalena; that he had made her renounce her baptism and her share in paradise; that he had given her the demon, and possessed her handwriting. He had cried out like one in despair that the living God forced him to this testimony, and he swore: that everything he had said was true, and he had laid a solemn oath upon the altar sacrament thereon. The priests, who had been witnesses to this, had remembered the church precept: to warn the sinning brother three times, and therefore had him admonished three times.

Once it had happened orally through Brother Franciscus; then in writing through a more urgent letter, which they wrote to him as eyewitnesses and earwitnesses of the oath, and in which they promised him that if he came to St. Baume and there converted himself in quiet; then his sins should remain hidden, as if he had laid them down in the confessional. In the third, they had urged the Capuchins in Marseille to send three of their own with the guardian, and to bring the final admonition in a second letter to him. But the Capuchins did not want to involve themselves in this matter without prior consultation with Father Michaelis; all the less so, since the demon from another possessed woman in Aix had said and sworn: that Gaufredi was no sorcerer, and that Magdalena was not afflicted by any malevolent spell.; which Verin immediately declared to be a cunning trick of Lucifer, and the spirit of Magdalena confirmed it.

Verin, for his part, now allowed himself to be commanded by the exorcist to go himself to Marseille for the conversion of the sinner, and Louise felt that he departed from her like a wind; she truly remained free of him in his absence, however with the feeling of pain from the maleficium. Thus he went a second, third, and fourth time, always fruitlessly, and on that account broke forth into curses against him: because he surpassed all sorcerers in wickedness, therefore he was the head of all sabbaths. Cain and Judas were innocent in comparison to him, and the demons themselves were of the opinion that hell was not sufficient to punish him. He had abjured God and all angels and saints; now God made use of that to which he alone had not abjured, namely the demon, in order to convert him. The time of the last and worst heresy had come; all of France was already infected by it. \

Meanwhile, Gaufredy had nevertheless resolved to go to St. Baume in the company of two Capuchins and Father Michaelis, and he arrived there on the evening of the 21st of December. It was decided to leave the exorcism of Louise to him, and Father Michaelis delegated his authority to him for that purpose. Verin began with a prayer in which he most urgently and heartily besought the Lord for grace for him; which moved the hearts of many, but did not please others, who believed that he should not be allowed to speak, and that he must be interrupted. But he continued and asked his exorcist Gaufredy: Is God almighty or not? The one questioned replied: This one is almighty. Then the other asked: Has the Church the power to command the demons? He answered: She has this power. Then he posed the third question: whether the demons could be compelled to tell the truth, and whether the oaths of the demons, sworn in all form and solemnity, were valid or not? He answered: They are valid, and God can compel the demon to tell the truth. Verin now said: Take good note of what he has admitted; but turning to him: Then exorcise me! It was done, and at the end Verin adjured him anew to renounce magic and to turn to God.

He then swore by the holy sacrament that all was true which he had said earlier, and Magdalena swore the same with a double oath. Then he said further that he must be guarded in St. Baume. The imprudent one had now ensnared himself; but on the following morning, dissension broke out among the clergy, which had already stirred earlier. Father Michaelis and the Capuchins excluded Father Romillon and the Dominican father Franciscus Dompt from their council, and in the course of the day the latter was told: he was proud, disobedient, ambitious, and striving after vain glory, and in all this sought only himself. Others judged again: he was all too credulous; still others judged differently.

Louise too was treated contemptuously, and Verin said that day to Father Romillon: she would follow another calling, and did not deserve this treatment. He also broke the silence imposed upon him against Father Michaelis. The Dominican father threw himself, in the presence of the other Capuchins, at the feet of Father Michaelis, and begged permission to return to his province, however not with complete humility: yet he wished to withdraw himself from the matter, because Father Michaelis would not listen to him, but rather to those who maintained: Verin must not be allowed to speak; Louise was not possessed, and the whole affair seemed more from the devil than from God. In this uncertainty they nevertheless continued; on the following evening Father Michaelis exorcised, Gaufredy renounced magic, and Verin said Amen. Later he cried: Adam, where art thou? Out of the depths call to God thy Lord, and he will hear thee!

He compared him, in the following days, when the struggle within him seemed to persist, to a man mortally ill who had lost his memory. He also said: the Antichrist had already been born, of a Jewess with an incubus; the magicians were his forerunners, and God wished to prepare His Church for the impending dangers. Meanwhile, Father Michaelis conducted tests with the two women, in order to convince himself and the councilors of the Parliament of Aix, who had taken cognizance of the matter, whether they were truly possessed. Berrin said on that occasion, when silence was imposed upon him: O Michaelis, God looses me, but you bind me. \

Gaufridy meanwhile renounced his written pacts, but the spirits cried out: it was not earnest with him, and he was only playing the Pharisee; holy on the outside, full of filth within. He sharply rebuked the exorcists for demanding signs from him; he must indeed, as they said, be the Bridegroom of the Church, but she too must obey her Bridegroom, who had resolved to give her light through him; they, however, imposed silence upon him. When he caught sight of Gaufridy, he began to bark, like a dog in the presence of a wolf nearby, and announced to him: if within eight days his sincere conversion did not take place, he would be burned to ashes. They say Louise is bound in her imagination; but the earth would have to swallow her, and you would have to deliver her to the flames, if she were not possessed, and if she had not sworn those many oaths of her own accord.

Meanwhile, he always refused to speak in a foreign tongue; God would not have it, he would give no signs; for if he sent an archangel in his invisible form, they would say: it is the devil; but if in his visible form, it would be said: it is a man. On the tenth of January, finally, some of the more prominent men of Marseille came to St. Baume, in order to lead Gaufridy back to their city. Silence was imposed upon Verin, from the Dominican Alès what he had written was violently taken away, and he himself was arrested for a few hours; everything stood against him, and wherever he turned he encountered mocking words, scorn, humiliation; and they even threatened to have everything that had happened declared null and void, as if undone, by the synod and the Bishop of Marseille! Upon closer investigation, however---which ensued because the Parliament had taken the matter into its own hands---one convinced oneself of the women's real possession, and the papers were returned.

Thus what had begun in 1610 at St. Baume continued in 1613 in the Netherlands. There, in a newly founded Brigittine convent, the three nuns Francisca Bollineșia, Catharina Fourner, and Perona Imberta had fallen into obsession; and at the request of the bishop of the diocese, the provincial of the Dominicans had appointed the same Father Dompt as their exorcist, to whom a Minorite, Father F. Michaelis, was assigned as assistant. They betook themselves to the place; at first the spirits were rebellious, but in the end they were subdued, and unanimously testified to Maria of Sains as the originator of the malefice. When questioned, she denied everything; but when the spirit of one of them revealed that she bore the marks of the demon, she confessed and herself indicated the places of these marks. At first she had to be compelled to these confessions by exorcism, but soon she did so voluntarily. Besides the three, all the others in the convent likewise suffered various afflictions, and she had been the primary originator of all these evils; despite the extraordinary reputation for holiness in which she stood, suspicion had soon fallen upon her; she had been locked up, but at that time had confessed nothing. Now she revealed that she had brought it about through a double malefice, in order thereby to destroy the young foundation. \

She confessed still countless other crimes of this sort; also how the exorcists had long since been well known to her, inasmuch as she had seen them in St. Baume, whither her demon Astaroth had carried her. We have already mentioned earlier what statements this resolute woman, who recoiled from no atrocity, had made; and how she herself had not shrunk from maltreating the Heavenly ones. While she continued unceasingly to make new confessions concerning the demons who obsessed her, she visited, according to her account, the Sabbath without interruption; and she always brought new signs with her, which the investigation conducted each time confirmed. Among other things, she also began to speak of the Antichrist, in which the three other demons assisted her. He was not begotten through man's agency, but through the demon; the earth had never produced a creature equal to him in wickedness. He travels through the air and performs signs and wonders. Maria de Sains knows him and has seen him in the synagogue, where he received baptism.

Now he is in his boyhood years; born in Babylon, raised in Capernaum in the land of Judea, he will one day rule the whole world from Jerusalem. But before his thirtieth year, he shall not be recognized in his full significance; then he shall reign a little over three years, and numerous heralds shall go before him. Beelzebub has declared him to be his son, and they call him Creator of Heaven and Earth, also Christ, King and Messiah. Gaufridy has administered baptism to him in his official capacity, Magdalena Palud and Maria de Sains were his godparents. Before his mother they kneel on the Sabbath, and say Ave etc., and she follows immediately in rank after the princes of the demons. She wallows in all prostitution, yet is called the Flower of Beauty.

On feast days he is brought to the Sabbath; there, said Marie, he kissed and embraced me and said: I was exceedingly beautiful, had beautiful smooth hair, and amiable and shining eyes; of all this he spoke like a grown man. Many will cling to him when he makes himself known, and everything that is written about him in the Apocalypse will be fulfilled. What now happens secretly among the sorcerers will then happen openly; nothing will be impossible to him, and his own will therefore believe him omnipotent. His sign will be the form of a goat; pressed upon the forehead among the more noble, upon the hand among the lowly. On the Sabbath they bring him, in celebration of his birthday, their gifts just as in the Epiphany to the Lord, and pay him homage thereby, and the prince of the magicians celebrates the day with three masses. \

A half year before his birth, however, in the year 1609, a boy was born to Magdalena; begotten by Gaufridy, according to the opinion of most, so that he might become the forerunner of the Antichrist; his name is Adocucy: and more beautiful and lovable than he himself, he will be raised with him in the Orient. When the time has run its course, this one will rise up against the Church; more will believe in him than have believed in Christ; the Jews will see in him their Messiah; he will transplant all the torments of Hell to earth, and apply them against the Christians; all heresies long since extinguished will revive, and Rome will fall. In place of the destroyed churches he will build new synagogues for himself, and they will honor his image there as they do him himself, and sacrifice Christian children to him; but he will secretly worship Lucifer, who will be loosed in this time, in which all vices will count as virtues, and will be preached as such by the magicians. He will perform signs and wonders, raise the dead, heal the sick; his images will speak like living beings, but many martyrs will lose their lives in these times. To him as guardians and watchmen and companions, however, Maria de Sains has borne two boys, and the nun Simona two others; they are strong as Samson, powerful and noble above all others.

The Simona who is here in question, like Sains, born in the city of Lille, had entered with her into the local Brigitten Convent; her accomplice in all her schemes and intrigues, she had also accused herself of the same things simultaneously with her. Since she was still a novice, they had therefore taken away her habit for that reason; but during the year in which she was kept locked up in the bishop's prison, she had confessed nothing. She was then released at the urging of her superiors and relatives, and had gone to Valenciennes; where she hired herself out as a maid, and thereby kept her whereabouts completely hidden from everyone. A man from Lille had fallen in love with her there, and offered her his hand; she consented, but since she needed the consent of her superiors for it, he went to obtain it; with the prohibition, however, on her part, to reveal her whereabouts to anyone.

But he did not keep his secret to himself, it became known through the women; Father Domptius, who was very interested in questioning her likewise about these matters, brought about her arrest. On July 29, 1613, he came, accompanied by two commissioners assigned to him and Maria de Sains, to Valenciennes; where they visited the arrested woman, who, however, denied everything. Maria, meanwhile, insisted on her accusation; if this one were not a sorceress, there would be none in the world. She was confronted with her; but since she always persisted in her denial, they decided to call upon the possessed ones to speak. Simona, however, replied: they might come, she did not fear the devils. The possessed ones were called forth, and now the same play began as in St. Baume: Tevtathan spoke through the person of Perona and Maria and sought to bring her to confession, also urging the commissioners to apply torture; but although the three possessed ones testified against her with one voice, she remained unshaken. \

Maria now indicated the locations of her marks with ink; she meanwhile kept crying out "Ah" and "Woe!" because she believed she was being examined; but when later actually probed, the indicated spots proved bloodless and insensible. When she objected: that when she herself had just examined one spot, blood had flowed, Maria, called in, said: "Last night you received a mark on your hand in the synagogue"; she indicated the spot, and it was found to be such. Great, eloquent apostrophes to the arrested woman now followed; but Simona was not moved by them. She said: she did not consider herself guilty of what they demanded of her; Maria replied, so it had been with her too, only when she had affirmed the questions had her memory returned. Simona answered: she would not say "yes" until she had true knowledge of what she was to affirm; all their speeches now appeared to her like dreams. Thereupon Maria: so it had often happened to her too; but the father had then asked her: whether her marks were likewise illusions? Maria tried many more means on her, confessing herself as the worst sinner; they brought Simona into a church and exorcised her at midnight, the hour of the Sabbath; the spirits joined in speaking, and swore vehemently; Simona remained unmoved.

On the following day Maria reported: the hour of the Sabbath had been shifted to three o'clock in the morning; both of them had been there, and Simona had brought three marks. They were found, exactly as she described, on the left arm. One of the possessed women now swore a solemn oath: that she was a sorceress, and now the same three questions were put to her as to Gaufridy. She affirmed all of them, yet maintained: the possessed one did not speak the truth regarding her, and finally said: she would no longer answer the spirits henceforth; when they had talked themselves out, they would fall silent of their own accord.

The demons now press upon the silent one, presenting to her: what God has done for her, how all the saints of heaven have interceded for her; how her hardness of heart, in thrusting away all this grace from herself, has infinitely heaped up the measure of her sins, and will finally, at the approaching downfall of the world, make her a child of perdition. This at last seemed to break her stubborn spirit, and she began to weep. All those present urged her on, she wept more violently; the Dominican placed the Sacrament upon her head, and still weeping she cried out: I will say no more, I say no more no!

The demon drew nearer to her and said: The eternal Father receives you, the Son pleads for you that he may receive you, all the saints unite their supplications. She, entirely dissolved in lamentations, said: I am a sorceress, truly I am such a one. The demon spoke through the mouth of the Perona: By this God who created the angels and cast us out, do you deny that I am Beelzebub, the prince of the demons, who has so often marked you? She replied: I know you, I say it with displeasure, God's power compels me to it. Now follow in sequence the confessions, during which the demons of the possessed assist her helpfully and refresh her memory; yet on the second day already, when asked if she persisted, she said: I dare not contradict, but if I agree, then everything seems to me like a dream; and it comes to me as if I were speaking lies. \
