For they consider it a disgrace to their art not to master even a weak woman; therefore they also plague the prisoners in every way, already outside the torture, with the filth of the dungeons, frost and heat: until at last, exhausted and broken, they consent to false confessions, which, as has been said, have previously been put into their mouths. With the clergy, one would think, the unfortunates must at least find some refuge. To be sure, the superiors should be only mild, pious folk of good judgment and proven wisdom, men truly permeated by the spirit of religion, who now also know how to test the spirit of men and to fathom the secrets of the heart. But such would fit little with the rest of the proceedings; one would have inconvenient observers in the vicinity, from whom the iniquity of the whole process could not escape.

Such, therefore, are removed as unfit by many courts; only stormy, hot-headed, inexperienced zealots are gladly seen; they, who immediately assert: the guilt admits of no doubt, therefore above all now press for a confession; direct all their efforts toward making her declare herself guilty; seek to deceive her with ambiguous promises, and in such wise join to the bodily torture only a spiritual one besides, which is often continued right up to the edge of the stake. Thus assailed from all sides, torn by pain, a confession is extorted from the unfortunate one; whereupon she herself is then lost, and in the usual course draws others after her into ruin, who are led on the same path to the same end; because she who cannot save herself spares no others either.

But if she does not die on the torture, and does not confess either, so that without new indications one dares neither to torture her further nor to burn her; then she is kept in even closer confinement, perhaps an entire year. For in their blind zeal they want victims, and consider it a disgrace to themselves if they release her all too easily; that would bring them an ill report. Inquiry is made so long until new indications are found; then, to boot, an exorcism is probably also pronounced over her, and she is taken to another place, to break the maleficium of silence; she is then tortured anew, and finally delivered over to the flames nonetheless, where her last cry by no means invalidates the testimony of the torture.

In such wise did things take shape at the courts in the savagery that preceded the Thirty Years' War, mounted ever higher in its course, and continued long after it. Thus around 1616 the Duke of Württemberg had begun the witch-burnings in the towns of Dornstätt, Sindelfingen, Löwenberg, and Baihingen, and the councilors had drawn up special articles on which the officials were to inquire only.

One had captured the Brigitta of Serresheim, whom they called the mother of all lords, on this occasion: when she had breathed into the face of a woman in childbirth, who thereupon became suddenly lame, and the husband of the sick woman had beaten the originator of the evil so long that she had to help her again. She was now arrested in Vaihingen by the deputy bailiff, and she herself requested that they should do her justice, because she had practiced witchcraft since time immemorial. She had killed so many children that it could not be told, well nigh four hundred, among them three that belonged to her own. These had been dug up again, boiled, cooked, partly eaten, used for ointment and lords' craft; but to the pipers the bone tubes had been given as pipes. To her own son she had killed a wife and two children; her two husbands she had lamed for many years and finally killed outright; her whoredom with her paramour had been endless. \

Countless and harmful storms had she summoned forth these forty years, in the Duchy of Württemberg for several miles along the Heuchelberg, on which mountain the sabbath was held five times yearly; at which there were always nigh two thousand five hundred, poor and rich, young and old, and among them also nobles, gathered together. She said also: if the lords were not there, the Württemberg subjects would drink no water, and in the seventh year would not be permitted to till the fields: moreover, their kitchen vessels would no longer be earthen, but would become silver. She gave as the cause that so many women fell prey to seduction, the mistreatment of them by their drunken husbands; she also pointed out to the judges the marks by which one might recognize them. One sees that the woman was a poison-brewer who had fallen into sorcery, who had prepared her own terrible end for herself; but she now gave occasion to the heedless zeal to rage in like manner against numerous innocents.

Thus it was that in the Bishopric of Würzburg, at the same time, four women had flown into the cellar of a day laborer---probably in a very natural manner---and had drunk out his wine. The torture soon transformed them into witches, and extorted from them also the further testimony: that in the Gerolzhofen tithe there were not sixty persons over seven years old who had remained unacquainted with witchcraft. Of these, first three were taken, then five others again, on the 4th of June thereafter ten, two men and eight women, on the 11th of June again three men and eleven women were drawn in and burned alive; thereupon twenty-six others likewise arrested, and first strangled, then consigned to the flames.

Since the statements of the earlier ones were always confirmed by the later, and thus the great number of the guilty became known, His Princely Grace ordained, and the officials were commanded: henceforth every week, on Tuesday, except when high festivals fall, to hold a burning; and each time twenty-three or twenty, or at the very least---and no fewer than fifteen at once---to stake and burn; and that Your P. Grace would continue and prosecute such through the whole bishopric. To this end all the centgraves had been summoned to Gerolzhofen, and it was announced and earnestly commanded them: to begin the burning of witches, and the list of those who in their time had become known was delivered to them. These then spoke so many wondrous things that they cannot be written down nor brought before the ears of youth. The landlady at the Swan confessed: that she had poisoned many people, and commonly had given musicians cats instead of stockfish, mice and rats instead of birds to eat. A midwife confessed: that she had killed nigh one hundred and ten children, of which twenty-two had been related to her. An old man said and confessed: if he had not been captured within three days, he would have laid waste everything within two-and-twenty miles round about and destroyed it with hail and pebbles. \

She drove them so harshly that the devil himself stepped in among them and forbade it to them; because it diminished his own realm, and the people, arrogant in good fortune, turned to God in misfortune. But since they would not cease, he had some of them beaten nearly to death, and treated them in such a way that they dared not show themselves for a considerable time; by which means many were also betrayed, and entered into the lord's register¹). One sees that storm damage and child mortality have allied themselves with the torture, some clairvoyance, and some malice, to bring so many people into misfortune. Such fires may have raged there for a considerable time, for in Hauber's library there is found a list of those who, from 1627 until February 1629, within two years and two months, in 20 such fires, 15 in number, were burned.

The greater part are old women and strangers, probably homeless folk; but children are also found among them of twelve, eleven, ten, and nine years; fourteen vicars of the main church, two boys from esteemed families, two little sons of Senator Stolzenburg, a blind girl, and Gobel Babelin, the most beautiful girl in Würzburg.---With most of them it will have been as it was with those of whom George Mackenzie tells: When I presided over a court, I went to question some women more closely who had judicially confessed their guilt. One among them, a simple creature, said to me: she had not confessed because she was guilty, but because she had to live poorly from her work; now, however, being called a witch, she would die of hunger. For no one would take her in any longer, or give her food; rather, they would beat her and set dogs upon her.

Therefore she had wished to be dead; at this she wept bitterly, and tearfully called upon God as witness of the truth of what she had spoken. So it was throughout the British realms, so throughout all of Germany; a bloody scourge had been swung over these lands, worse than the black death this land plague raged in the midst of the most terrible civil wars; and while the sword devoured the men, the flames were sent forth against the women. The enormity of the evil, exceeding all measure, finally had to bring about a reaction. The nature of the battle victims, driven to despair by torment, had already initiated such a thing itself. For a time the tortured had only named their own kind; and thus the fire, once kindled in a village or a town, had run through the whole class, and one had dragged many into perdition. But soon wrath and anger and the bitterness of pain had risen higher, and at last had seized even the judges themselves, who, precisely through the ecstatic side of this pain and of every other passion, had come into the closest rapport with them; and they were named, indeed princes themselves, simultaneously by many, as companions of the Sabbath, testimony being given. Now the right means had been found; their statement had to have validity, for the same signs spoke for them that were valid for the others; the agreement among several was easily given through the rapports; and for the torture there was no different measure and weight. Thus the judges themselves had to be put on trial, just as the accused; and the forms of this process then took care that the accused never escaped. \

So the flames then turned even more fiercely against those who had themselves sent them forth; just as, in the time of terrorism of our days, the same guillotine devoured all the successively following layers of the parties, one always at the judicial command of the other. The poor women had merely trodden the path to the pyres for their judges, on which they soon afterward wandered after them; now and then also at their side the confessors, who had felt no mercy. And one should imagine only the last moments of these second-order battle-victims, who now held in their hands the conviction that they had been wrongly judged; that they had ruined countless battle-victims without guilt, and now eternal justice had overtaken them on their paths, and they themselves, in atonement for them, had been given over to the same death.

Such proceedings must have aroused doubts, and made the judges cautious; there was need only of one man who--- what the crowd of confessors or court preachers had not been able to do, or not wanted to do, or not dared to do--- also opened the princes' eyes to the true state of affairs. Such a one arose in the Jesuit Spee, and he became a benefactor of humanity thereby, and earned not one but a tenfold civic crown for himself therewith. He lived in the midst of all those horrors, and had probably seen those Franconian fires. His heart bled at the sight of such calamity, and he wrote the *Cautio Criminalis*, which appeared in print for the first time in 1631. Already the better theologians of the time had spoken out against the procedure: and Tanner, Spee's order-brother, had expressed his grave doubts in his *Theology* and made suggestions for mildness, which drew upon him the wrath of the terrorists.

As confessor to many of the executed, Spee had the best opportunity to gain insight into the true state of affairs, and soon convinced himself: that of fifty condemned, not five, indeed perhaps scarcely two, were guilty. Then he wrote his book, without fear of men and without conscienceless timidity; from which we above communicated an excerpt of the description of the procedure, in which he uncovers the whole iniquity of this fury. Therewith he stepped before the princes, explaining to them: how the judges excused this their procedure through constant pressure from above; how that was, however, a grave matter of conscience not only for their councils and confessors, but also for themselves; and how they all would one day have to give account thereof before the higher judge.

They should consult the theologians about it, and those would give them information: that one may not trifle with human blood, and human heads one may not throw away lightly like skittles, as the lord-judges now permitted themselves to do, who hastened to the torture at the slightest rumor, and even interrogated under torture those for whom piety and a blameless life bore witness. We all must one day to the judgment-seat of eternity, he says, and if there every useless word must be accounted for, what will happen with such bloody deeds? That did not remain without impression; one lost the confidence that one was on good paths with this whole blood-justice; and when one first looked closely, one discovered the horrible thing in the matter.

Gradually now the pyres went out; the movement went forth from the Main and Rhine, and soon spread over all Germany. He, from whom it had first taken its origin, had not expected the reward of the world; but it would not let itself be deprived of discharging its debt to him. He had converted the place Peina back to the church through his zeal. \

The enemies of the Church in Hildesheim had therefore, as he was on the way to the place to hold the divine service, like the Frisians the holy Boniface, caused him to be ambushed; and he had sustained five significant wounds on the head, and two others on the back, but nonetheless held the church service to the point of collapse. Some years later, in 1635, he died in the Trier region, in the 48th year of his age. After him, however, among the Protestants, D. J. M. Meyfart, Director of the Gymnasium in Coburg, must be honorably mentioned.

In the time of Maximilian I, he wrote: *Christian Reminder to Powerful Rulers and Conscientious Preachers, How the Abominable Vice of Witchcraft Is to Be Earnestly Eradicated, but in Its Persecution on Pulpits and in Court Houses to Be Handled with Great Moderation*. It is only a paraphrase of the book by Spee; but from his youth onward he had often seen how things were done in the Protestant courts; how no sleep was allowed to the prisoners and they were awakened with sharp thorns when they closed their eyes; how they were given only food salted with herring brine, but not a drop of water was granted them. He had seen how, in his words, the executioners and tormentors held the precious body of man in such low esteem, how they shamefully distorted and shattered it; driving the limbs apart from one another, forcing the eyes from the head, tearing the feet from the shins, dislocating the joints from the tendons, lifting the shoulder blades from the scapula, causing the veins to swell; jerking the unfortunates now upward, and again hurling them to the ground, and turning the underside to the top.

He saw how quarrels, envy, anger, strife, backbiting, and talebearing usually gave the first occasion for the accusation; beginning with grumbling and muttering, and then publicly accusing this or that one of sorcery. Then he heard how the preachers were drawn in, blind zealots who spared no one, loading their sermons with fiery bolts, bursting forth in their own brain-madness and stubborn defiance, and crying out for chains and bonds, for towers and dungeons, for wood and straw, smoke and fire, powder and sulfur; now imagining that this was to follow the saying of the Lord: *Learn from me, for I am meek, and humble of heart*. \

Then he saw the witchcraft councils seize with iron hands, and in the most secret of all sins proceed without any moderation; he was a witness how the poor folk at their command were broken, whipped, screwed apart, torn asunder, crushed, ripped, devastated, corrupted, and laid waste; how the scold's cart rumbled daily through the streets, and yet the scolds hourly became more numerous; so that the Thuringian forests would not suffice to burn them all. All this he had seen, and his heart too was set aflame, and he cried out his woe over the perpetrators. *So now be instructed, ye kings, and be chastened, ye judges on earth! All ye kings, princes and rulers, ye centgraves, ye assessors, ye witchcraft clerks, executioners, tormentors! Ye must one day give account for every word that was commanded: to capture, to whip and behead and burn; for every mockery with which ye taunted the poor tormented ones; for every tear they wept out, for every drop they bled out!* So cried the worthy man in his indignation, and his words too were not spoken in vain on this side. Therefore, when at the beginning of the eighteenth century, from Thomasius downward, the Rationalists arrived, everything had long since been settled. Their merit is only that they set limits to the all-too-great credulity in this field; in exchange for which complete unbelief now broke in. On the threshing floor where these had been trampled about, no blade of grass grew anymore, neither herb nor weed; and it became now the riding school where they practiced their circling, and still practice to this hour.

### Chapter 3. The Church's Relation to the Abuses of the Heresy Process

The matters had arranged themselves in such a way that, if the heresy system itself---in its terrible earnestness, and in that which of truth had been in it---had arisen from an abominable perversion of human nature, the manner in which one sought to curb it, because it was carried out with cold blood, had been almost even more abominable, so that evil had gained the upper hand, and where the victims escaped it, had found ample compensation in judges and executioners. And it had not generally been rage and wrath and fury and cruelty that had inspired such proceedings; rather, a blind, imprudent, and immoderate zeal had originally brought it forth; and the insensibility of men, combined with laxity, indifference, and apathy, had then carried it further, and driven it to the extreme. The same imprudent zeal had also, not long before, called forth the religious movements; but the same laxity and indifference, at the pleasure of the rulers, had let religious convictions be prescribed to them, changed, and again and a third time other and ever other ones forced upon them. \


Keywords: chapter 3. the church's relation to the abuses of the heresy process

The same negligence had given up almost everything that should be valuable to man in society---fatherland, freedom, constitution, unity, old customs and memories, even the language; and had brought about that state of complete dissolution in which the peoples became the mockery of their neighbors. When a feeling of such disgrace finally awoke, one had sought to shift the blame from oneself and roll it over onto forms and institutions, making them responsible for what one had sinned oneself. That is the way of men; they know full well what religion means, they also know the Gospels, and they understand very well how to speak of the love that Christianity demands of them; but in practice they know how to keep free from such transcendences. On the theaters they amuse themselves with the tragic struggles of their heroes with fate, and let themselves, with attentive emotion, be indoctrinated with great words and principles, and their Posa's, kneeling on one knee, hold grand speeches to the tyrant about pride and freedom; however, under a silent agreement, they take their own greatest servility not amiss, and mutually forgive each other the slight impropriety. So then, the princes and their tyrannical laws alone should answer for the common guilt; but chiefly it is the religion that has caused the whole scandal.

The Popes, especially Innocent VI, have given the signal, and the Inquisition has now gone forth like a ravenous-hungry lioness, seeking whom she may devour. But it had not been the forms that did it, the laws had not brought it about; rather, the way in which they were executed had caused the evil. The laws were indeed superfluously bloody, according to the spirit of that time; they had, in this spirit, also well incorporated the torture; but they had fenced it in carefully, as a fragile and dangerous thing; men, however, under the pretense of exceptional cases, had torn down the enclosure, and had now proceeded against heretics and hereticesses in their merciless manner. Thus this form of process had not flowed from the well of justice; rather, from the proud and cowardly thing, the human heart, it had found its way. Even less had religion cooperated in it, or the Church hired the torture-masters, and now through the Popes issued their full authority to them. \


Keywords: the, and, they, of, had[Page 427]

\]

Just under the eyes of the Popes the evil raged most mildly; it had, as we have seen, already begun centuries before Innocent VI; all peoples on this side of the Alps and beyond were infected by it; but the proceedings had increased in cruelty in proportion as they withdrew from the direct influence of the Church; and had reached their utmost height precisely when those peoples had either decidedly fallen away from her, or at least inclined toward apostasy. The Popes had to take notice of so momentous a matter, in which the peoples believed, and had sent out the Inquisitors against the evil. That Bull of Innocent was intended only to protect the authority established for the regions along the Rhine, where the evil had recently spread anew, in its sphere of action against objections, and confirmed its right: to act in improving, arresting, and punishing ways; granting them permission, precisely in order to carry out the first part of this office, to expound the Word of God to the people in all the parish churches of their district as often as it might be needed, and to provide and arrange everything useful for their instruction according to their own discretion. Whatever they may have sinned in weakness, through excess or deficiency, and in error; the authorization for it lay at least not in the mandate that they had received. On the contrary, one must also bear witness here to the Popes, that they consistently proceeded in a moderating and mitigating manner, and, carefully following the spirit of the times, endeavored to incorporate the gained insight always into a better practice.

This relation of the Church to the whole abomination is best demonstrated from the Instructions for the Processes in Matters of Witches, Sorcerers, and Malefactors, which appeared in 1657 in the printing house of the Apostolic Chamber in Rome. At the beginning it states: Experience, the great teacher in all things, has clearly shown: how the gravest errors in the procedural conduct against the business of witchcraft are committed, to the detriment of justice and of the accused women; so that in the General Congregation of the holy, Roman, and universal Inquisition against heretical malfeasance, it has long been observed: how scarcely ever has a process of this kind been conducted regularly and in legal form. Therefore the necessity has often arisen to censure many judges reprovingly for the unjust vexations, inquisitions, incarcerations, and all manner of evil and inappropriate methods of procedure in conducting the processes; for unauthorized interrogation of the defendants, and the imposition of inhuman tortures; whereby it has come about that exceedingly many unjust death sentences or handovers to the secular arm have occurred. Many judges, as the same experience has shown, have proven so frivolous and credulous: that they, on the slightest grounds of suspicion, have held any woman to be a witch; and then have left nothing undone to extort from such an accused person, even by unlawful means, a confession that, improbable, changeable, and contradictory as it is, deserves little or no credence.

Therefore, so that the judges henceforth may conduct such processes more cautiously, they shall always keep the following before their eyes and consider it. The writing now sets forth at length on the subject, viewing it entirely from a sensible, equitable, and life-experienced perspective. A chief error of the judges, it says, is that they believe: one may proceed not only to inquisition, but even to arrest, indeed to torture, even if no corpus delicti of a maleficium is present. But such a maleficium must above all lie proven in a legal manner, and for that it is by no means sufficient, as many believe, that the maleficiated person has fallen ill, or even died; because illness and death do not necessarily follow from the maleficium. \

With the greatest diligence, therefore, the physicians of the sick must first be questioned as to whether they regard the illness and death as natural. They must write down the entire course in a verbal process in full detail, so that in the event of their inexperience a better physician may review their judgment. Moreover, the household members of the sick person shall be examined regarding the origin and course of the illness, so that their statements may be compared with those of the physicians, and the judge may then form a well-founded judgment from all of it. Before a judge orders the arrest, he must first have carefully weighed all the indications against the accused, and not allow himself to be led into hasty arrest by the complaints of the alleged injured party and his kin; without any probable ground being present that might have induced the accused to the misdeed. But if the arrest is indeed imposed, then let the judge, in person or through a capable deputy, take good care to see what relevant things are found in her house; but not merely considering what accuses her, but also such things as may justify her.

He shall take impartial witnesses to his aid in this, but exclude the alleged injured parties and their kin. He shall not judge rashly that oil in vessels, ointments, powders, and the like belong to witchcraft; but rather let the things found be first carefully examined by experts. If the relatives of the sick person bring things that they claim to have found in the bed, then let him not hastily regard them as the corpus delicti; it may easily be that they were merely planted there to secure a conviction. Feathers and wool can easily become so intertwined during bed-making that very natural combinations arise which are passed off as maleficia. Needles too are plentiful everywhere women are present; one must therefore not be surprised if by chance many of them are found together. Already the casting out of such needles from the possessed can serve as a warning to proceed with caution.

Many exorcists are in the habit of imprudently questioning the demon: whether he gained entry through a maleficium, and who performed it? The answer then comes from the father of lies in the affirmative and accusatory, and upon this a process is sometimes immediately founded against those named; but the holy Congregation has always sharply rebuked exorcists and judges in such cases. Many judges imagine that because someone shows signs of being possessed, he must also have been bewitched; and thereon they have built unjust processes against persons who are hostile to the possessed, or otherwise denounced. But this is utterly absurd; for who can deny that the demon, by divine permission without any maleficium, may torment the body of a human being? Let the judges therefore beware of this snare; and also of that which false, deceitful possessed lay for them. \


Keywords: to, the, and, in, of

meta.keywords: to, the, and, in, of

content:
[Page 429]

\]

Judges shall not readily lend themselves to exercising violence upon a witch or a malefactress merely on the basis of outcry; although otherwise reputation is of great importance. For amid the common hatred against this class of people, all are easily inclined to rise up against them, and to raise such an outcry on slight occasion; especially if the woman is moreover old and ugly. Therefore no reliance shall be placed upon it, and the judge shall first investigate its origin. He shall always take into consideration that the female sex is superstitious, and devoted to all manner of arts, especially in matters of love; that therefore from the fact that one has practiced such things, and spoken charms to heal maleficia or to bind the will, it by no means immediately follows that she is a formal witch; because such practices are not necessarily conjoined with apostasy. The judge shall thus not immediately assume the merely possible as actual, and hold himself justified in leaving nothing undone to extort a confession of things to which she may perhaps never have given a thought, on the basis of such truly forbidden exercises of that sort.

The judges may therefore not permit that a woman arrested on this account should have intercourse with anyone from outside, or---if there have been several of them---with these among themselves; because many are of the opinion that it is permitted to bear false witness against themselves in matters of apostasy, in the hope of being set free sooner. They shall also never allow their guardians, or whoever it may be, to advise them what they should say in the interrogation; because experience has shown that the women, deceived by such counsel, often confess what they had never before dreamed of. Outside the interrogation, the judges themselves shall never engage with them on the matter. In the interrogation, nothing may be put into their mouths, but they shall only be questioned: whether they know or suspect the reason for their examination? what enemies they have, and what cause they have given for enmity? How they have conducted their lives, how they have observed the sacraments, who has been their confessor? and the like, what allows a conclusion about their conduct.

Then they may be questioned in general: whether they know anything of sorcery? If they deny it, then what is on record in the files concerning such matters may gradually be brought in; however, with the withholding of the names of the witnesses. If they persist in denial, then after the conclusion of the informational process, one may proceed to the witnesses of the accusatory process. The fiscal must articulate certain points for this purpose; a copy thereof shall be communicated to the defendants, and a suitable advocate shall be assigned to them; ex officio, if they, out of poverty or otherwise, have accepted none. Moreover, the necessary time limit shall also be granted to them. If this part of the process has also run its course, then a copy of the whole shall be given to them, and a new period for defense shall be set. If this has also been heard, then the judges shall convene an assembly of legal experts; the entire process shall be read to them, as before with the withholding of the names of the witnesses; and if these are not unanimous in their judgment, or if it is a grave matter, either with respect to the crime or to the person, one shall not proceed to torture until the holy Congregation has been consulted, to which a faithful copy of the double process must therefore be sent. \

But if it should seem to the judges and their assembly that one could immediately proceed to torture in the face of pressing indications, they shall not be questioned on the crime in detail; but beforehand, the raised indications shall once more be laid before them, and on the rack itself they shall only be questioned on the truth in general, with respect to what has been presented. If they begin to confess, then in the further course nothing may be put into their mouths; but only the words of their testimony shall be written down, and the truth in the whole shall then be further inquired of them. The torture may not be of the rending kind (squasso), not torment with attached weights or sticks at the feet, nor constrict with ropes. The judges shall not lightly order a repetition of it, except in the gravest cases, and after obtaining approval from the holy Congregation.

The women shall not be shorn on the body, nor shall any weight be placed on alleged marks, if, for example, they shed no tears. The torture shall never be continued longer than one hour, and shall only reach this duration in the gravest cases and the most pressing indications, and the imposed duration shall also be noted in the records. In the case that women have also confessed to apostasy, and their presence at the Sabbath, the judges shall take care that the confessors, without any instigation, tell them: how they came to it in the beginning; they shall inform themselves about the time and circumstances, so that one may recognize therefrom whether their confession is probable.

In the case that they state facts pertaining to the verification, the judges shall apply all diligence to verify these truly; because, if they should be found false, the confession itself would also be invalidated, as one given perhaps through torture, a deceitful means, or through suggestion from somewhere, or through impatience over the imprisonment; whereby the judges must by no means allow themselves to be biased by what they may have read among the writers on the matter. But if such women have also confessed authentically, and named accomplices, then proceedings shall never be instituted against those named, on the basis of their testimony; because everything could have occurred through illusion, and justice does not require that one proceed against accomplices seen in the illusion.

The entire procedure of the judges shall be recorded precisely in the records; so that, upon reading them, one may always be able to judge it worthily. Many judges are accustomed to give no other cause for the trial than rumor; henceforth they shall avoid this error, and state the persons and circumstances that brought it to their ears, and record everything, omitting nothing. Children are often smothered in their beds by their caretakers; the judges should take care to see precisely whether, in order to conceal such things, it has not been stated in a given case: that the witch had killed them. In all these trials, the fees prescribed by the holy Congregation shall never be exceeded; and in the case of poverty, the judges shall guard against every unjust extortion. \

This instruction, which we have communicated not by selection but in its entire scope, does the chamber all honor; it is pure, sound human understanding, a circumspect and insightful practice, humanity, equity, and mercy in it; to the shame of the torturers who instigated and carried out that abominable mischief. It must necessarily have put an end to the barbaric naturalism of the courts, and led the procedure back into an orderly course of trial; which, though it still does not guard against all error, yet makes it rarer and more accountable before God. The practice prescribed here was the same that, more than a century and a half earlier, the worthy judges of Del Rio had already followed; in it, therefore, the view of the Church on the matter is expressed.

Even in the particulars, the clerics who acted in its spirit and according to the mildness of the doctrine arranged their procedure according to similar principles. They understood: that everywhere it depends more on the improvement and instruction of the unfortunates than on the intervention of a bloody terrorism; which only incites the wild, rending beast in man to lust, in order to tear it to pieces. This is already evident in the manner in which Father Surin treated the obsessed in the convent of Loudun.

Here he did not wield the sharpness of the sword, not even did he make frequent use of exorcism; for he understood: that above all he himself, with his person, must stand surety for those entrusted to him. He therefore first turned in persistent prayer to God and his saints, the Virgin at their head, that help might come to him from there; and he held himself, during the course of many years, unceasingly in this prayerful communion. And the spirits cried out in the possessed: that this was the way to torment them and bring them to ruin. Into the same communion he soon also drew the obsessed Johanna; and as she too learned to maintain herself persistently in it, one of her spirits was thereby alone, without exorcism, compelled to depart.

He further judged that the main reason for the connection of man with the demon lay in the sins and evil habits of the former; all the more so, the deeper these were rooted; thus that in the measure in which sin was more present in a soul, all the more the devil would take root in it and triumph. Therefore, one must above all strive to eradicate this main cause, and thereby weaken the powers of the demon. This was also acknowledged by the spirits, as they cried out again: We have no more than what the vices of men give us; if these are eradicated, then we must succumb and depart from here.

He therefore continually exercised Johanna in the struggle with these her evil inclinations of the corrupted nature; her progress therein was soon attested by the spirits, who threatened him because he was introducing a completely new method, and offered themselves to all obedience if only he would cease therewith; for it was the greatest misfortune for them on earth to possess a mortified person, whose slaves they would be, instead of ruling her in her evil inclinations. She still had four spirits, and Father Surin devised the plan to attack each in his own stronghold. The one who drove her to all pranks, and the other who drove her to all pleasures; both he subdued by instilling in her the spirit of a earnestly strict penitence. She slept therefore on the hard ground, scarcely made any fire, scourged herself three times a day most sharply, wore a cilice and a chain around her body, fasted almost always, abstained from all fruits that she loved, and also ate with it many things that seemed to burden her in her stomach weakness. \

Thereupon he also attacked the other spirits, who had taken up position in the proud-anger part, and combated them with humility and patience. When she therefore boasted under the impulse of her spirits; then he had her thrown down by beggars, trampled with muddy feet, and struck on the mouth. He sent her to the sister cook with the request: to give her a discipline, which the latter then performed quite simply. He made her publicly ashamed, for which she always thanked him afterward, and begged him to tell every man all her sins that she had confessed to him in a general confession. As she could not obtain this from him, she herself confessed before her fellow sisters her greatest and most shameful sins, and also made a vow to become a lay sister.

In the same way he combated the natural laziness in her, kept watch over all her gestures, words, and works, killed off in them everything that he noted as wrong, proceeding in each from the principle that the improvement of souls is more a work of the anointing of the Holy Spirit and of prayer than of science. The spirits let their impatience and displeasure appear in the course of the whole procedure: that they were forced to remain in a place where no nourishment and no space was left for them. But the purpose was achieved as desired; the demons departed one after another, each marking the forehead or hand with the name of a helpful saint or a cross.

The spiritual therapy of the father was, as one sees, not a palliative or symptomatic one; but a thorough one, which went to the root of the evil, and uprooted and mortified it. It was now certainly not the business of the judges to proceed in such ways; but they had to let the accused, through those called to it, first be guided on them; and if they showed themselves there unamendable and incurable, but to deny it is certainly impossible in any way, since the evil has become a great national scourge; that it would also have required a great institution extending over the infected parts of the land, in order to effectively combat the infection that had spread so widely.

The Church has always known how to set limits to such secular plagues through such institutions; and it is at first glance surprising that nothing of the sort was undertaken on a grand scale from her side. When in the preceding age Manichaeism, in the moral laxity of the century, took root in a threatening manner; then highly inspired men, Dominic and Francis of Assisi, set their orders against it: the one forming the spiritual knighthood of the Crusaders; the other sent out to instruct the misled people. The undertaking succeeded as desired; the poisonous mushroom that had grown out of the decay was eradicated; but the two orders outlived the danger against which they had been equipped. Manichaeism, gathering itself together and retreating precisely to its most poisonous principle, had shrouded itself in night and secrecy; and though it was thereby removed from the daylight side of humanity, it had for that very reason infected its night side all the more, and there laid out the entire apparatus of sorcery and witchcraft, in which it henceforth lost itself. The institutions that had combated it on its earlier exoteric side had now to follow it into this esoteric concealment, and continue the struggle begun on the outside now also in these inner realms. \

Two things were to be done in this: first, to ward off the further spread of the evil through better instruction; and then to eradicate what had spread through suitable means, of which the last appeared to be punishment distributed according to justice. The two orders had to divide the work between them: the lesser brethren, hastening to the infected regions or summoned there, had to form unceasing missions that instructed the poor, downtrodden, ignorant, misled people, and enlightened them about the goal and end of the path that many had taken merely out of ignorance of a better one. They had to win it back from the deception to the truth, and know how to occupy the misled forces that, in the absence of a worthy counterforce, had attached themselves to the unworthy.

If the evil was in this way isolated by cutting off the tributaries and driven back to definite organs; then the other order, that of the Preachers, might take over the spiritual jurisdiction of this now surveyable and controllable herd of perdition; and make the ascetic improvement, guidance, and healing of the deadly wounds its vocation. Always having such a religious-moral influenza before their eyes in the most remarkable examples, it could not be difficult for the order, with some attention, to penetrate to the innermost core of them, to see through their nature and essence, and in its tradition a mass of facts had to accumulate in this way that made these Christian priests just as insightful physicians of the spiritual evil as those of antiquity had raised themselves to knowledgeable experts in poisonous ills on a similar path. What proved itself mortally struck and incurable could then be handed over to the secular arm; but even here the acquired insights still imposed on the members of the order the obligation to appear as advisers to the judges and defenders of the accused; and where a ray of hope was still present, to hold back the utmost from the unfortunate. Without doubt that shameful blot would then not have come into the history of many peoples, and the two orders would first have fully fulfilled the purpose of their foundation. But corporations, like individual persons, like to rest on the laurels they have once won.

It was necessary that this entry into a new form of their vocation should be preceded by a new metamorphosis of their own form; for this, a new generation of men equally inspired by God was required, such as their founders had been. But the times had grown old; the forces that had formerly been at work had dried up, the enthusiasm had cooled. The men whom the Church needed did not come forward; the peoples had withdrawn from the great history, and each one arranged its domestic affairs; the great institutions, which had formerly encompassed all things, therefore gradually fell into ruin, and every people was left to its own worldly understanding.

Thus have things turned out, not as they should have, but as they could; in miserably torn Germany, in the most miserable manner; and those who had forfeited their lives on the pyre became likewise the sacrificial victims of the bad order; just as later those thousands who bled to death on the battlefields of foreigners, sold by their leaders for base Mammon. The injustice that befell them---one must cherish faith in the higher world order, that they have found their compensation there anew; here below they have at least not died entirely in vain, even if the acquisition could have been gained at a cheaper price. However clumsily and unskillfully one may have proceeded, the experience could not be wholly lost; the facts have accumulated, and it has become possible for the spirit to order and penetrate them; so that the state of affairs lies clearly before one's eyes. \

One knows better the scope of the means over which nature disposes; one has penetrated deeper into the secret workshop where her forces work wonders that no longer inspire terror and dismay. One knows better the nature of those nocturnal men who wander about dreaming by day, because the old night with all its horrors and monsters has taken up residence in the dark regions of their temperament, and there now broods something sinister, which one no longer holds to be worthy of death. One distinguishes those who have entangled themselves with evil and thereby caused harm from those who have refrained from misdeeds; already Charlemagne commanded that the former be duly punished, but the latter be handed over to the bishop so that he might convert them.

In future cases one would follow this example, and thus the return of the mischief has become impossible forever. But just as one has found occasion to recognize the bright side of human nature in the saints, so has one here also recognized the reverse side; opposite every radiant point there, one has found in it also a nodal point of the night: the one testifies for the other, as the one covers the other. Thus all phenomena have their place, and with it their guarantee; and it is no longer necessary to gaze at them with stupid, superstitious wonder, and to be excessively frightened by them; or with equal rationalistic stupidity to deny them, and for that reason senselessly to reject the testimony of incredible facts. The whole region is thus, with regard to its earthly side, taken up into the circle of our knowledge, and can henceforth neither oppress nor alarm us; because even the transcendent element in these phenomena, in this its knowable aspect, by no means withdraws itself from the laws of our spirit.

But thereby the sting is also drawn from evil for the future, that it, if it should perhaps emerge anew in masses, might become a terrible weapon of evil. It can no longer overawe or bewitch us; for even if malice should succeed in mastering it as an instrument for enforcing its claims, it could not succeed in mastering the masses with it in the long run.

But the Church, in that she would confront the enemy not only through the power entrusted to her, so now also through her knowledge and insight, and completely subdue him, would only find the opportunity to glorify herself in him.
